HEADLINE: The Nation;
Washington Steps Back, and Cities Recover

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
NATIONAL political leaders used to talk about fixing up urban America. They mostly don't now. Even pretending to have a broad vision for what the cities could be, or should be, let alone having a plan to pay for it, is no longer required or expected.
Yet even as the Federal Government has retreated, many cities, and notably New York, are seeing levels of investment and development in poor and once-blighted areas that were unimaginable not all that long ago. 
 That raises some quietly insistent questions. Was this chain of events -- big government runs away, cities improve -- a matter of cause and effect, or mere coincidence? Would the blossoming of Harlem in the 1990's as a retail destination, the flow of stock market capital into shopping centers in Newark, or the renaissance of Times Square be occurring, or happening in the same way, if the heavy tread of the Department of Housing and Urban Development bureaucracy still walked the earth? Is the absence of policy, or even debate, about the nation's cities actually a blessing?
There is little doubt that the spirit of hope and enterprise that urban experts talk about in cities did arrive at the same time that the old trappings of big government were taking the last train out of town. In a kind of baton handoff of devolution, the Federal presence gave way to a mostly local presence, which in turn gave way to the market. The sidewalks of Herald Square are clean not because of the New York City Department of Sanitation, but because corporations formed their own business improvement district to pay for street cleaning and other extra services. Urban renewal is dead. Long live urban renewal.
But proving a direct link of cause and consequence is another matter. Urban planners, investors and politicians say that to attribute everything about the improving condition of cities to the Federal Government's paying less attention to them -- essentially the logic of Congressional budget hawks -- is as incorrect as saying Government played no role at all. Even to ask is to revisit some very old ideological battlefields.
It was, after all, the free market, not government, that first told cities to drop dead, beginning in the 1960's as retailers began fleeing for suburban malls. To a generation of urban politicians, including some who lined up in New York last year to oppose the expansion of suburban-style big-box retailing in the city, the market is simply not to be trusted or depended upon when it comes to poor neighborhoods. Banks discriminate, they say. Grocers overcharge.
 
Getting Lucky
Similarly, people who think there should be a national policy on the cities are loath to credit the Federal Government with any aspect of urban improvement. The Government simply created a vacuum, those critics say. If it was filled with something positive, then everybody just got lucky, nothing more.
"I don't want to let them off the hook that easily," said Thomas O'Brien, research director at the Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions, a non-partisan research organization that favors a greater government role. Mr. O'Brien said that a nation with no society-wide goal of making its urban centers livable has little to be proud of, however much some poor city residents may now be able to buy a Mickey Mouse watch or to get a prescription filled without taking a bus.
The actual evidence cuts both ways. Some pieces of the urban resurgence appear to be almost purely market driven -- meaning they would probably be happening no matter what Government had or hadn't done. Others do seem to be caused by a changing government climate. And some, like the nationwide decline in crime, are crucial but don't fit into either category.
The story of the brownfields offers a textbook case of how all those forces combined. Brownfields are former industrial sites, many of them in poor urban areas, that are vacant and polluted, but not polluted enough to qualify for clean-up money from Washington.
Beginning in 1994, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency quietly relaxed its formulas for the brownfields. A retail use, for example, would require a less rigorous, and less expensive, clean-up than a residential use. That change created a new industry, which arose to clean up and resell the properties.
At the same time, the cataloguing of brownfield sites became a function of local government, which can respond to the needs of business faster than the Federal bureaucracy. And perhaps most crucially, investors who were looking for returns greater than the 12 percent to 15 percent typical in mainstream real estate saw urban values appreciating as the crime rate declined.
"On a brownfield site, you can make 20 percent to 30 percent, if you do the numbers right," said Christopher J. Daggett, president of Chadwick Partners, an Edison, N.J., company formed 19 months ago to get into the brownfields business. "When the market is tight, people look for other alternatives."
Retailers rediscovered cities for the same reason: higher returns than the suburbs, with too many stores, could offer. Companies like Disney went to Harlem not to do economic development, but to make money.
An explosion in the number and size of Wall Street mortgage investment pools has similarly aided the cities without particular intent. The pools, which buy and sell residential and business mortgages, have grown so large that they find they can venture into urban areas, where risks and returns are both higher than in the suburbs, without significantly raising their overall risk. And the competition for the best return creates a pressure to make those new investments.
 
Nowhere Else to Invest
Real estate investment trusts have also made a contribution -- though indirectly -- by buying up so much property outside the cities. That has nudged traditional lenders like banks toward urban markets because of a shrinking universe of properties that are available.
"There's a flood of cash chasing a limited number of deals," said Anne Habiby, research director for The Initiative for a Competitive Inner City, a Boston-based group founded in 1994 by Harvard Business School professor Michael E. Porter.
Indeed, there is some evidence that government has forgotten what little bit of urban policy it still has. A Presidential executive order, issued in the 70's and still in effect, says Federal agencies should situate new offices in urban areas whenever possible, to help boost economic activity.
But development experts say the order is ignored with impunity. The Federal Aviation Administration, for example, with more than 800 employees at Kennedy International Airport, has looked for a new home for years. New York officials said downtown Jamaica, Queens, best fit the Presidential order, but this year the F.A.A. instead designed a site selection plan that specifically ruled out Jamaica. Congress promptly approved it.

HEADLINE: The World;
Global Good Times, Meet the Global Glut

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON'S failure last week to persuade Congress to give him freedom to negotiate trade deals reflected skepticism among Americans about the benefits of a global economy -- not only free trade, but an entire system that allows money, factories and jobs to move anywhere.
Domestic politics, of course, played a big role in the President's decision to retreat when he failed to muster enough votes for passage. But the skepticism is not limited to politicians jockeying for the next election, or union officials charging that jobs are going south. The worriers are often the very business executives and international investors who built today's global economy and now fear that it might backfire. 
 There is something to worry about. The Asian financial turmoil may be the first stage of a developing worldwide crisis driven mainly by a phenomenon called overcapacity: the tendency of the unfettered global economy to produce more cars, toys, shoes, airplanes, steel, paper, appliances, film, clothing and electronic devices than people will buy at high enough prices.
"There is excess global capacity in almost every industry," Jack Welch, chairman of General Electric, said in a recent interview in The Financial Times of London.
The problem arises because the global economy sucks businesses into building too many factories. Allied Signal, for example, a multinational corporation based in Morristown, N.J., built a polyester plant in Longlaville, France, in 1993 and expanded it last year. The polyester, used in nylon carpets and tire cords, is sold in France and shipped across open borders to customers everywhere in the region.
 
The Danger of Price Wars
But a group in South Korea, an emerging industrial nation seeking to be a big player in many major industries, opened a polyester plant in Korea recently. Taking advantage of open borders, the Koreans are shipping their polyester into Europe and other countries, grabbing away customers and market share by offering lower prices. And the customers, offered more polyester than they need, have encouraged a price war.
Price wars, up to a point, are good for consumers. The inflation rate in the United States has fallen in part because of global overcapacity, and business people everywhere complain that they can't raise prices. "That is what overcapacity means," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant.
The danger is that at some point this house of cards must tumble down. In an open-border global economy nearly every car manufacturer, for example, is trying to have a presence in every market. But when all the factories crank out more cars than people can buy, down come car prices. Down go the profits of car companies. Out go the workers. And down go the number of people who can afford to buy cars. Economies can spiral downward toward recession, or worse. That is what is beginning to happen in Asia now.
East Asia has been the main source of the world's overcapacity in recent years. Since 1991, countries like Thailand, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines have accounted for half the growth in world output, primarily manufacturing, according to David Hale, chief global economist for the Zurich Insurance Group.
 
Dominoes
The financing for this new production often came from international investors moving huge sums across borders. They frequently borrowed the money at low interest rates in Japan and the United States and then invested in booming Asia in expectation of earning a high return. Money borrowed at 1 or 2 percent a year in Japan might typically pay 8 to 10 percent invested in Asia.
Chunks of this money inevitably went not into factories but into speculation. Borrowers defaulted. And as the hoped-for big returns failed to materialize, fear grew, first in Thailand, that money invested in that country's currency, the baht, would not earn enough to pay debts incurred in dollars or yen. There was a run on the baht last summer, which spread to stock prices and to other Asian financial markets.
The factories -- the new capacity -- remained intact, but the millions of Asians counted on to be customers pulled back. In their place, the energetic consumers in the world's richest country, the United States, have become the targeted buyers for much of the unsold Asian output. And as imports from the region rise (they have risen only slightly so far) there is downward pressure on prices in the United States and on the wages of workers who make products that compete with the imports. Just the threat of an Asian alternative produces this downward pressure, some economists argue.
The global economy appears, in effect, to be capable of self-destruction. That is the view of William Greider, a journalist who writes extensively on economics and whose recent book, "One World, Ready Or Not" (Simon & Schuster), has made him a principal voice among those who point to the dangers of an unregulated global economy.
"It produces more and more goods even as it suppresses wages at both ends of the world, in industrial as well as developing countries," he said. "You cannot do that forever -- producing more and cutting the wages of those who buy -- without some collapse."
That view has been attacked by several influential economists, particularly Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The American economy, he says, is still mostly self-contained; global trade has not made that much of an inroad. What's more, he says, workers will eventually share in the earnings from rising production. And finally, Mr. Krugman maintains, overcapacity is not a question of too much supply, but a faltering of demand.
The Krugman solution is to turn up the demand; central banks do this by cutting interest rates so companies and consumers can borrow money less expensively. "There is no shortage of things on which people want to spend money," Mr. Krugman said. "You would have to have a worldwide depression to shock them into not buying, into sitting on their money."
That seems unlikely, but in the end it could happen. Already central banks in Asia, instead of lowering interest rates to encourage spending, as Mr. Krugman suggests, have raised them in an effort to strengthen their currencies, among other reasons.
 
Pressure on America
 South Korea could be the next country in trouble, analysts say, hurting Japan in the process. Some of the huge sums invested in Korea were borrowed from Japanese banks. A loan default in Korea could bring down a Japanese bank already weakened by the recession in that country. And with its own consumers already balking, the fresh blow of a bank default would make Japan even more eager to export its unsold goods -- its overcapacity -- to the United States. With that in mind, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin publicly urged the Japanese Government last week to spur domestic consumption.
Mr. Rubin's concern is understandable, given that the United States is the alternative if the Japanese don't buy enough -- Americans being the world's consumers of last resort. The United States trade deficit keeps rising as imports grow, forcing American manufacturers to cut back. Just last week Eastman Kodak announced 10,000 job cuts, in part to accommodate overcapacity in film manufacturing, especially competition from Fuji of Japan.
But the American trade deficit would have to quintuple before the economy gets into trouble, said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic forecasting service.
"There is the possibility," he said, "that you can bring in so many low-priced imports that businesses in this country would have to cut back and unemployment would rise. But that sure is not happening now."

HEADLINE: Racism Is Not The Issue

BYLINE: By Orlando Patterson; Orlando Patterson, a professor of sociology at Harvard, is the author of "The Ordeal of Integration: Progress and Resentment in America's 'Racial' Crisis."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Why are we having a national argument on race? By all objective measures -- recent opinion polls, demographic data and academic studies -- race relations between blacks and whites have never been better. What is more, the majority of African-Americans are content, even optimistic, about their interactions with European-Americans, according to a close reading of a recent Gallup Poll, for example, and other surveys.
This viewpoint has also been forcefully argued by the scholars Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom in their new book, "America in Black and White." While I differ with many of their arguments, particularly with their opposition to affirmative action, their basic premise is correct -- that relations between the races are getting better, as are the conditions of most African-Americans. 
 Nonetheless, civil rights leaders insist that this belief is dangerously wrong because they think that America remains mired in racism. Social scientists like Stephen Steinberg of Queens College in New York indicts America for its retreat from policies supporting racial equality; Carl Rowan, a syndicated columnist, has just published a book called "The Coming Race War," and the journalist David K. Shipler has titled his pessimistic book about race "A Country of Strangers."
Finally, President Clinton has placed the resolution of the so-called crisis on his list of potential historical legacies.
But let's get the facts straight. According to the most recent census data, blacks have virtually closed the gap with whites not only in the percentage graduating from high school but also in the percentage graduating from junior college.
Black full-time workers have also started to close the income gap, according to census data. From 1970 to 1995, the average annual income of white men declined by 3 percent, to $34,741, while that of black men increased by 11 percent to $27,136.
Nonetheless, major problems still remain for the bottom quarter of the African-American population -- 26 percent of all black families and 41.5 percent of their children remain trapped in poverty. The situation is no longer worsening, but it is no better than conditions were a quarter century ago.
Nor have we seen the end of racism, as some conservatives like Dinesh D'Souza have absurdly announced. About 20 percent of white Americans are still at least mildly racist (meaning, among other things, that they are averse to living in neighborhoods with only a few minority families), according to my research using polls, including one in 1994 by the National Opinion Research Center. But because blacks make up only 13 percent of the population, this means that for every two blacks there are still three white racists.
We have made great progress, but there is still a long way to go. Here is what we should be asking: How does racism hurt the lives of African-Americans? For the poorest among them, is racism the real problem? Do ordinary black Americans think that race is their biggest problem?
When it comes to earnings and self-esteem, racism may be less of a problem for the poorest blacks and more of a problem for middle-class blacks who are in direct competition with whites for jobs, status and power. This is the main reason that I think we need affirmative action for another 15 years or so. Isolated from critical networks of influence and economic power, middle-class blacks badly need affirmative action to level a playing field that for 300 years favored whites.
Certainly, poor blacks are hurt by racial discrimination -- mostly in biased police behavior and draconian drug-sentencing laws that result in horrendous incarceration rates for young men. But as the sociologist William Julius Wilson emphasized more than 19 years ago, race is of secondary importance when it comes to the economic conditions of poor blacks. Poor blacks, like poor whites, are impoverished partly because they attend bad schools, come from broken families and live in broken communities. But the basic problem is that the poor, no matter how hard they work, earn too little to pull themselves out of poverty.
Indeed, in a Gallup Poll taken in June, poor blacks said that money, not racism, was their biggest problem. This poll, which measured race relations, found that three-quarters of blacks considered their own relations with whites to be good, and indeed, had a close white friend. The same poll found, however, that 53 percent of blacks were dissatisfied with their incomes. Unsurprisingly, for poorer African-Americans, the figure was much higher.
If money is the problem and not racism, why do many leaders, white and black, warn that America's racial problems are getting worse? This pessimism results from a strange collision of interests.
White liberals believe to some degree the stereotype that African-Americans are a dependent and chronically victimized group. Any problem associated with blacks is simply assumed to be racist in origin. Emphasizing failure and crisis is also an effective way to argue for more government intervention.
Black political leaders also have a vested interest in maintaining that a racial crisis exists. Their legitimacy and a good part of their livelihood depend on defending entitlement programs.
On the right, leaders and scholars exaggerate the crisis in race relations to highlight the failures of liberal programs.
The news media give all these wrong-headed beliefs their full attention. In the tabloids and on the television news, articles about urban crime and racial incidents are common. Even leading newspapers play the "racism forever" game, partly out of a misguided and patronizing liberalism. For instance, in reporting the results of the June Gallup Poll referred to earlier, most newspapers stressed the one pessimistic finding: that a majority of black respondents thought that relations between the races were generally getting worse -- an impression drawn from the press itself.
Newspapers ignored the more accurate and positive finding: the great majority of respondents reported that their own experiences with whites were good and getting better.
Martin Luther King's dream of an integrated America has not been deferred. The nation is overcoming what was once its greatest flaw, racism. Denying its persistence is naive and reactionary. But ignoring the country's extraordinary progress, while exaggerating racism's impact, is counterproductive as well. It obscures and diverts attention from what is now our greatest shame -- chronic poverty and growing income inequality -- and it plays right into the hands of those on the right and left who promote the vile dogma of racial separatism.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

TRADE
'Fast Track' Hits a Wall
President Clinton conceded that trade legislation he had called crucial to the nation's global leadership was dead for this year. He asked that the measure, which would have given him authority to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could accept or reject but not alter, be shelved. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said the legislation's chances of being passed next year, when members of Congress are seeking re-election, were even more remote. Clinton's defeat was a victory for organized labor, which saw American jobs threatened, but many business executives warned that it would prove costly to the nation's economy.
 
THE ECONOMY
Sales Off; Slowdown Ahead?
Autumn struck the economy in October, chilling it so much that some economists worried that an economic slowdown was taking hold just before the holiday shopping season. Shoppers spent a seasonally adjusted $213.7 billion last month, down 0.2 percent, the second consecutive monthly drop in retail sales, the Commerce Department reported. The Labor Department said prices paid to producers like food processing plants and factories inched 0.1 percent higher in October, meaning that the Producer Price Index has declined at a 1.2 percent annual rate during the first 10 months of the year. The productivity of American workers grew at an annual rate of 4.5 percent in the third quarter, the fastest pace in five years, easing fears that labor shortages could lead to renewed inflation.
 
MARKETS
Who's Exuberant Now?
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chief often quoted as warning against irrational exuberance in the financial markets, sounded quite a different note last week. With the markets gyrating wildly, he became soothing, saying that problems in Asia and elsewhere should not threaten prosperity in the United States or the soundness of the nation's financial system. The Fed voted on Wednesday not to raise interest rates, concerned that tightening monetary policy would further destabilize global markets and betting that the American economy might slow sufficiently to avert any inflationary threat. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 7,572.48, down 8.84 points, while the Nasdaq composite was down 18.59, to 1,581.51
 
BRITAIN, THE BRAND
Embracing All Things Modern
To compete in the modern world, Britain is being "rebranded," Tony Blair's spin doctors recommend in a study, as "one of the world's pioneers rather than one of its museums." Out are scenes of village cricket, tea and scones. In are images of pulsing telecommunications, global business transactions, bold architecture, cheeky advertising and daring fashion. Even Britain's venerable red telephone boxes are being replaced by transparent glass booths. While the Labor Party goes mod, Tories say they still prefer "Rule, Britannia" to "Cool Britannia."
 
PEOPLE
Cash for Katzenberg
The Walt Disney Company settled with Jeffrey Katzenberg, its former studio chief, who had sued for at least $250 million. He contended that Disney owed him a share of the profits from hit films like "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King." What he will receive is still to be decided. . . . Warren Flick, Kmart's president and chief operating officer, who is given much credit for reviving the retailer's sagging fortunes, will retire after only two years at the company, for health reasons. . . . Mildred Robbins Leet and Glenn Leet, a Manhattan couple, have fought an 18-year battle against poverty. Since founding the Trickle Up Program, a nonprofit organization that gives modest amounts of seed money for new businesses, they have helped 65,000 entrepreneurs, mostly women like Maria Miranda, a millener in Jackson Heights, Queens, below, to start small businesses.
 
INTERNATIONAL
A Delay in Russian Bonds
Gazprom, the Russian monopoly involved in a natural-gas project in Iran, postponed a $3 billion bond offering for which Goldman, Sachs is the lead underwriter. . . . ING Groep, the expansionist-minded Dutch financial services company, is seeking to buy Banque Bruxelles Lambert of Belgium for $4.68 billion in cash and securities.
 
LAYOFFS
Kodak to Cut 10,000 Jobs
Eastman Kodak, struggling to compete with Fuji of Japan in film sales, said it would cut 10,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force. It hopes to save $1 billion in the next two years. It was the biggest layoff announcement by any American company this year and comes on top of some 40,000 Kodak job cuts since 1983. . . . Fruit of the Loom will cut 2,900 jobs, or 17 percent of its American work force. The cuts will effectively complete the company's drive to move its sewing operations to Mexico, the Caribbean and other offshore sites with cheaper labor. . . . Waste Management, responding to pressure from dissident shareholders, announced a broad reorganization that will eliminate 20 percent of its corporate and support staff and save $100 million annually.
 
AUTOMOBILES
G.M. Taking a Hit
General Motors said it would take a charge against earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion to pay for job cuts, write-downs in the value of some factories and other changes intended to streamline the company in the long term. It did not disclose details, but the bulk of the job cuts are expected to come in Europe. And G.M. lost a bid to manufacture passenger cars at a plant in southern China. The winner, Honda, will produce a model resembling its Accord at the plant, which was vacated by the French auto maker PSA Peugeot Citroen. . . .In a rare admission of a serious engineering error, Daimler-Benz halted shipments of its Mercedes A-Class subcompact, which is to be sold in Europe, while it refits the chassis to prevent the car from flipping during high-speed turns.
 
DEALS
Dial MCI for Money
Money talks. In what would be America's biggest merger ever, MCI Communications, the nation's No. 2 long-distance telephone company, agreed to be acquired by Worldcom, an industry upstart, for $36.5 billion in cash and stock. Worldcom triumphed over GTE, which offered $28 billion, and British Telecommunications, which bid $19 billion. . . . Shareholders of ITT, the once-sprawling conglomerate that has shrunk under the leadership of Rand V. Araskog, left, into what is now primarily a hotel and casino company, endorsed a $10.2 billion cash-and-stock sale to Starwood Lodging Trust, rejecting a $9.3 billion hostile takeover offer from Hilton Hotels.

HEADLINE: Free Namibia Stumps the Naysayers

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: WINDHOEK, Namibia

 BODY:
In 1990, when Namibia became an independent country under black majority rule, there were bitter jokes that goats would soon be grazing on grass in cracks in Windhoek's streets.
Seven years later, it hasn't happened. Windhoek is still probably the cleanest, safest capital in Africa. 
 What is remarkable is how little has changed. This is perhaps not surprising in a country where German is an important language 82 years after Germany lost the colony. But compared with the rapid pace of change in next-door South Africa, it is a bit of whatever the opposite of future shock is.
South Africa gave up control in 1990 after running the country for 75 years, much of the time in defiance of the United Nations, but it still dominates the economy.
All the diamonds and most of the beef and fish Namibia exports go there, and the Namibian dollar is pegged to the South African rand, which stores still accept. And as in South Africa, the white minority still controls the bulk of the land and wealth. The average white person earns 14 times as much as the average black one, and unemployment or underemployment is estimated to be 40 percent.
Despite rapid growth, the place still feels empty. The country is twice the size of California, but has only 1.7 million people, fewer than Brooklyn does.
What is not desert is dry, and water is a pressing issue. Updates on El Nino are in the paper almost daily, for fear that the long drought that ended last year will return. The biggest political battle is over whether the Kunene River can be dammed for drinking water, a move that would chase the migratory Himba people off their ancestral land and submerge the Epupa Falls, the area's sole tourist site. A proposal to build a coastal desalting plant is being debated.
And Sam Nujoma is still President, and probably will be for a while. That bothers the largest donors: Germany, the United States and the Nordic countries. They quietly told the governing party, the South-West Africa People's Organization, that they would prefer Mr. Nujoma stuck to the original plan: two terms. But the party, at its convention in May, found a loophole: it said his 1990 election did not count, since independence was not in place, so he can run again in 1999.
"We mentioned George Washington turning down a third term," said a Western diplomat. "But it's a done deal. You can keep kicking that wall, but what for? And the U.S. didn't become less of a democracy because F.D.R. got a third term."
To the relief of the donors, the party did not amend the Constitution, though it could have, since in 1994 it increased its parliamentary majority to 74 percent, from 57 percent in 1990. "The party decided that a third term should be limited to Sam," a party member said. Mr. Nujoma, 69, has groomed no successors.
The President's credibility from 23 years as a guerrilla leader is seen as balancing competing factions. Black-white relations are peaceful, but those between the Ovambo-speaking people, who dominate his party, and the Hereros and Namas are tense.
The smaller tribes accuse the Ovambo of grabbing jobs, scholarships and contracts. The head of the opposition DTA party, Mishake Muyongo, waxes almost paranoid on the topic. He says Ovambo women, famous for their beer-brewing, deliberately get Nama men too drunk to go to work, so their Ovambo husbands can take their jobs.
Ben Amathila, the Minister of Information, scoffs at the stereotype and calls it "malicious politicking."
More voters share Mr. Muyongo's more mundane complaint that the governing party is profligate. Besides the presidential limousines and helicopter, he says, Mr. Nujoma has a $22 million Falcon jet bought in 1992. Now there is talk of buying him a $45 million jet because the Falcon cannot reach Europe nonstop.
"Planes are like toys Sam Nujoma has to play with," Mr. Muyongo said. "But we are holding out our left hands to beg while our rights are digging into our pockets to pay for his jet. That money would build a lot of clinics."
The jet issue is clearly something of an embarrassment, and Mr. Amathila paused before he said: "The President is important to the stability of this country. He's an asset that might prove expensive to maintain, but he's worth it."
More popular anger is directed at the 43 members of Parliament who are Cabinet ministers or deputy ministers. They get $55,000 a year, plus allowances for housing, furniture, electricity, telephones and drivers. They also get free television satellite dishes, cellular phones, a Mercedes for weekdays, a Land Cruiser for weekends and, when they they travel overseas, $1,500 a day "pocket money" in addition to their hotels and meals.
Recently, Cabinet ministers drafted a bill giving themselves each an extra $15,000 a year "servants allowance" and generous retirement packages. When news of that leaked, the outcry was so great that the Cabinet balked. But it then drafted a law to punish members of Parliament, or reporters, who released details of legislation still being drafted. That provoked a louder outcry from the press, and the paragraph referring to reporters was removed. That, said a Western diplomat, is a good example of how governance works in Namibia. "They go to the threshold of scrapping democracy," he said. "But then they don't cross it."
 In a recent survey of seven southern Africa countries by the Helen Suzman Foundation, a nonprofit pro-democracy group, Namibia was the only one where a majority of respondents said they felt free to criticize their government and to hold public demonstrations.
Financially, diplomats say, the Government's smartest move is that a third of the $1.2 billion national budget goes to education.
The Government's weakest point is that there are still 70,000 government employees. Strong unions and the governing party's historical Marxist bent mean that attempts to shrink the bureaucracy to 40,000 have been foiled.
In a country where change comes slowly, the most unpredictable element is probably Mr. Nujoma himself. He has lambasted journalists, the "gay and lesbian conspiracy," environmentalists who oppose the annual seal slaughter and members of the opposition who dare mention that the governing party ever mistreated prisoners.
"The reactions are predictable," a diplomat said. "The donors make veiled threats, then the Prime Minister 'clarifies' what he means, and they cover it over.
"Why does he do it? That's Sam."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After seven years of independence, Sam Nujoma, right, is still President of Namibia and is likely to remain in office for some time. To the consternation of Western donors, he has not groomed a successor. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Map of Namibia: Windhoek, Namibia, may be Africa's cleanest and safest capital.

HEADLINE: Agency Says Gas Emissions Will Be Worse Than Thought

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases from energy use will grow faster than previously expected in the United States in the next few years, the Energy Department said this week. This would make it more difficult for the United States to live up to President Clinton's proposal to cap emissions of these gases at 1990 levels over the next 10 to 15 years.
The department said national economic growth would be slightly higher than previously estimated, competition would make electricity cheaper and fuel prices would not change much. More oil will be used because there will be more cars with more horsepower, and more people traveling by plane. 
 These factors are likely to increase emissions of greenhouse gases, produced largely through the use of fossil fuels like oil and coal, the annual energy outlook by the Energy Information Administration said.
Representatives of about 150 nations will meet in Kyoto, Japan, next month to negotiate cuts in emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, threatening to alter the climate.
Jay E. Hakes, head of the Energy Information Administation, said that carbon emissions in 1990 were 1,336 million metric tons and that analysts had assumed that if no action were taken, the number would climb to 1,722 million by 2010. "The rough idea has been that we need to reduce carbon emissions by 28 or 30 percent to get back to 1990 levels." With the new estimate, though, the 2010 figure is 1,803 tons, which would require a reduction of close to 35 percent.
The new estimate is based on annual economic growth of 2.1 percent, up from 1.9 percent, Mr. Hakes said. Stronger growth means more disposable income and more demand for energy. The estimate is based on oil prices rising less than 10 percent by 2020, and coal prices declining 1.4 percent a year through 2020, faster than was expected last year. According to the new projection, electricity prices will drop 1 percent a year as a result of competition.
If the price of energy decreases, Mr. Hakes said, consumers and businesses will have less incentive to invest in improved energy efficiency. Lower electricity prices will also make it harder for renewable energy sources, like solar and wind power, to gain a foothold in the marketplace.
Mr. Hakes said that there were technologies with the potential to reduce carbon output, but that no new inventions or improvements of existing devices appeared likely to be in wide enough use by 2010 to upset the forecast much. Beyond that, he said, the prediction is less certain.
In fact, the department's track record for long predictions is poor. In the early 1980's, the Energy Information Administration predicted that crude oil prices could be nearly $300 per barrel by the turn of the century. The price of crude oil these days is around $20 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Trade Fight Was Battle of Perception Against Analysis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
In the days since Congress handed President Clinton a major defeat on trade, top White House aides have been asking themselves the same question: at a moment when the economy is booming and other nations say they are terrified by the competitive edge of American companies, why did Congress become convinced that trade was threatening the livelihoods of working Americans?
Mr. Clinton talked himself hoarse repeating the same statistical mantra: 13.5 million new jobs, many created by America's export boom over the last five years, and the lowest unemployment rate in two decades. At the same time, he repeatedly fretted in public that he had been a "complete failure" convincing Americans that their prosperity was linked to the blooming of trade. 
 In a capital where images always have a greater staying power than statistical analysis, Mr. Clinton ran headlong into headlines that members of Congress threw back at him: Kodak lays off 10,000 in Rochester, Levi Strauss shuts down 11 plants in four states, Fruit of the Loom ends its production in the United States.
Some of those layoffs were linked to foreign competition; many were not, and many no doubt would have happened whether or not the United States expands its network of trade agreements around the world.
But as many members of Congress told Mr. Clinton in the days leading up to the failure of the "fast track" trade legislation, what mattered was the continuing sense of anxiety in their districts, even in the best of boom times. After listening to Mr. Clinton's pitch, they would respond with stories about plant closings, a shrug of the shoulders, and explain that rightly or wrongly their constituents blamed Nafta, the most prominent of the more than 200 trade agreements signed in Mr. Clinton's first five years in office.
The fast track legislation would have renewed the President's authority to negotiate agreements that Congress could approve or disapprove but not amend. Traditionally, Presidents have received that authority so that other nations know that whatever deal they strike will not be reopened by Congress.
But this was not really a debate over the trade agreements themselves or whether the President should have the authority to negotiate new ones. Instead, it became a referendum on who benefits the most from trade in an era when companies clearly have fewer geographical constraints than ever.
One of Mr. Clinton's closest economic advisers, who insisted on anonymity, said this week: "This was a collision that had been building for a long time between Bill Clinton's picture of prosperity and the fears members of Congress were hearing every weekend back home. And you know what? They were both right."
Mr. Clinton has been living with this economic duality for most of his Presidency. While economists remain mired in a debate about whether trade or technology bears more responsibility for the displacement of American workers, few doubt that the overall gains to the American economy from the explosion in the last decade in foreign trade -- which has bloomed from 10 percent of the economy in 1970 to nearly a quarter today -- have been tremendous. And most agree that the gains to the gainers greatly outstrip the losses to the losers.
But that is very different from saying that a majority of workers share in those broad gains.
The losers, in fact, are often concentrated in particular industries and particular Congressional districts. They are far more likely to hold union jobs -- thus the well-organized opposition to the bill from union leaders. Workers who have not finished high school are much more vulnerable to job losses that arise from competition with lower-cost producers abroad.
In the fast track fight, for example, union leaders often cited the plight of clothing workers, who sew garments made from American or foreign fabrics. "The statistics are pretty clear: the number of these workers has declined, and their real wages have gone down, too," said Sidney Weintraub, a professor at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington and author of a recent study, "Nafta at Three: A Progress Report."
The automotive unions were also among the sharpest opponents, after watching many auto parts plants move abroad and seeing many foreign auto makers, especially the Japanese, open nonunion plants on American soil.
Whether trade agreements accelerated the loss of those types of jobs is a subject of heated debate: American companies have been moving factories to lower-wage nations for decades, and other countries have been investing heavily here since the early 1980's.
The political problem that the White House never confronted head-on was laid out soon before the vote in a study published by the Council on Foreign Relations. While trade enriches the nation, they concluded, "the living standard of the most typical income earner in the very middle of the income distribution may not rise." In addition, the study said, "global integration may not benefit middle-class citizens as a group." As a result, the study concluded, "further global integration, by itself, may not be democratically supportable."
Some of Mr. Clinton's aides are beginning to say that the White House, preoccupied by the Congressional politics of stitching together a majority coalition of Republicans and Democrats, erred by not acknowledging more explicitly that many Americans are losers from freer trade. They were they willing to acknowledge publicly, however, what many say privately: that the Administration wildly oversold the benefits of free trade to ordinary workers in 1993, during the Nafta debate.
"Members of Congress were listening to something very real in their districts," said Robert B. Reich, Mr. Clinton's Secretary of Labor in the first term. "A third to half of the work force has not benefited from this economic expansion. And as an Administration, we did not do enough to make sure the losers had a fair chance of becoming winners."
In fact, many of the programs Mr. Clinton initiated to secure the passage of Nafta in 1993 -- aid to workers who were displaced, even if Nafta itself was not clearly the culprit -- were never aggressively carried out.
In private, some of Mr. Clinton's advisers say they concur with Mr. Reich. But they insist that their bigger problem was one of perception: every plant closing seemed to amplify the bad news, washing over the more subtle evidence of job growth.
"It's enormously frustrating," Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, said. "Nobody gets told when they are hired: 'You owe your job to the fact that we're doing more business in China.' "
For the President and his advisers, the question now is whether it is too late to revive their arguments in Congress. Mr. Clinton insisted several times in recent days that "this isn't over yet," and his aides suggest that early next year he will be back with a narrower trade bill. That would give him specific authority to negotiate with more than 120 nations in the World Trade Organization on agreements that Congress could ratify or reject, but not amend.
The minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said he was open to a new bill, as long as it clearly addressed issues of worker rights and environmental conditions abroad. The labor unions say they are not automatically opposed to a fast track bill, as long as their members are well protected. But many Administration officials doubt that the unions will back any bill that emanates from the White House.

HEADLINE: Iraq Says Attack Would Not Alter Its Ban on U.S. Inspectors

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Iraq said today that its decision to expel American arms inspectors working for the United Nations could not be reversed even by military attack, and it warned of a new chapter in the "great and eternal mother of battles."
A day after President Clinton ordered a second aircraft carrier to the Persian Gulf for possible military strikes, the reaction carried in Iraq's official newspapers and state-run television was starkly defiant. 
 Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf accused the United States of seeking nothing short of toppling President Saddam Hussein. A newspaper owned by President Hussein's eldest son urged Arabs to attack American and British targets in the region to show solidarity with Iraq in its standoff with Washington and the United Nations.
The Government newspaper Al Jumhuriya declared in a front-page editorial that the use of force by the United States "will cause destruction in certain parts of Iraq but it would not be able to change the current situation or change the firm facts."
The United States has said that it prefers to peacefully resolve the crisis, which began on Oct. 29 when Iraq vowed to expel American members of the United Nations weapons inspection team and to shoot down American U-2 spy planes supporting the team.
Iraq's decision on Thursday to carry out the expulsion of the Americans, who left the country on Friday, has led the United Nations to withdraw most of the rest of its inspectors and has severely undermined a nearly seven-year effort to uncover Iraq's secret program to build weapons of mass destruction.
Mr. Clinton's decision to send a second carrier to the Persian Gulf was intended to signal American willingness to use force to compel Iraq to back down in the confrontation.
The strong language from Iraq today served as a renewed declaration that it had no intention of doing so.
"One aggression, 2 or even 10 means nothing but more sacrifices," Al Jumhuriya warned in the editorial today, reminding Iraqis that they had already withstood heavy burdens under the economic sanctions that have been imposed on Iraq since it invaded Kuwait in 1990.
At the same time, Iraqi officials said they intended to turn now to some of the United States' closest Arab friends in hopes of winning support that might check any American attack.
Mr. Sahaf announced in Baghdad this evening that Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz would begin an Arab tour with a visit to Cairo on Sunday and that he hoped to draw on the "disgruntlement and unhappiness" across the Arab world toward the American position.
Mr. Aziz tried and failed this week to win a compromise at the United Nations. But Mr. Sahaf said the Iraqi envoy would ask other Arab governments to echo Iraq's demand for a direct dialogue with the Security Council as a possible way out of the current crisis.
Officials from the United States and the United Nations have said that Iraq's decision to expel the American inspectors appeared to have been prompted by concern that they were closing in on crucial evidence about Iraq's secret biological weapons program.
But Mr. Sahaf, the Foreign Minister, today reiterated Iraq's insistence that those and all other weapons of mass destruction proscribed under United Nations resolutions had been destroyed long ago.
At a briefing for reporters in Baghdad, Mr. Sahaf said this evening that his country was not on a war footing.
But a very different impression was being given on state-run Iraqi television, which warned today that an American attack could come at any moment, and borrowed from the propaganda of the Persian Gulf war to forecast a reprise of "the mother of all battles."
Also for the first time since the gulf war, Iraqi television has begun to broadcast announcements ordering reservists from elite commando units to report to their bases.
The call for Arab attacks against American and British targets was published in the newspaper Babel, which is owned by President Hussein's son Uday. Its front-page editorial said that "American and British interests, embassies and naval ships" should be atacked in military and commando operations by "Arab political forces."
Hundreds of Iraqi families have moved into a presidential palace in central Baghdad in the apparent hope of deterring an American military strike. But accounts from diplomats in Baghdad and reports from Iraq's official press suggest that the Government now is beginning war preparations in earnest.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
In Maine, Signs of Hope For Rivers and Anglers

BYLINE: By Pete Bodo

 BODY:
Since the early 19th century, hydroelectric power brokers and entrepreneurs eager to service industry and the needs of a budding nation freely took rivers away from the fish and other creatures that inhabited them. Now it appears that fish may be getting some rivers, or at least some critical parts of them, back.
In a decision applauded by environmentalists as well as recreational angling groups, the final environmental impact statement prepared at the behest of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has recommended that the commission deny Bangor Hydro-Electric Company the license to construct the Basin Mills project on the lower Penobscot River in Maine. 
 This extensive project would have created a new dam that would have posed serious threats to the continuing effort to restore the once-copious runs of Atlantic salmon to the Penobscot. It would also have seriously jeopardized the rights of the Penobscot Indian Nation to pursue fishing for ceremonial purposes.
In a related decision a few months ago, the commission refused to re-license a dam notorious among anglers for the role it played in the last century in destroying the salmon runs on Maine's Kennebec River, the Edwards Dam near Augusta. The repercussions of these determinations may eventually roll across the continent from the piney bogs of northern Maine to the rugged palisades of the mighty Columbia River in the Northwest, where a hot debate is also raging about the value and role of dams and hydroelectric projects.
"I'm not sure you can say that these decisions by F.E.R.C. actually set a precedent," said Bill Townsend, a director of the Atlantic Salmon Federation and an activist in the Penobscot coalition, the umbrella organization that together with the Penobscot Indian Nation led the formal opposition to Basin Mills. "But they certainly signal a real willingness by F.E.R.C. to adhere in spirit of the 1986 amendments to the Federal Power Act.
"Up until those amendments were made, the official legal attitude seemed to be, 'When you need to generate power, build a dam and everything else be damned,' " Townsend said. "But among other things, the amendments mandated that resource issues, particularly those pertaining to fish and wildlife, are entitled to equal consideration with power generation needs when it comes to issuing or renewing licenses."
Another key component in the amendments was a provision for public commentary in the licensing procedure, a change that suddenly created issues of public accountability in the commission. During the public commentary period, the Kennebec coalition filed a 7,000-page document that ultimately helped convince the preparers of the final statement that the dam should be shut down.
Mona Janopaul, a spokeswoman for Trout Unlimited, said: "If there are precedents being set here, it is in the sense that previous victories for environmental or conservation groups tended to be over small projects. You know, a small group of people getting together to save lovely local waterfalls. But the Basin Mills Project is a big one, on a large river, raising significant issues."
Supporters of the Basin Mills Project, both in the public and in industry, often cited job creation as a significant benefit of license approval. However, most of the jobs created at Basin Mills would have been during the construction phase. Hydro projects do not create much in the way of long-term, sustainable employment.
The final environmental statement for Basin Mills not only quantified the negative impact the project would have on the Atlantic salmon restoration effort, but also produced numbers showing the economic benefits salmon angling brings to the Bangor area.
According to the final statement, Atlantic salmon anglers visiting the Penobscot spent $1.65 million on travel and fishing-related expenses in 1994. The consumer surplus value of Atlantic salmon angling on the Penobscot, which is the amount of money anglers spend beyond expenses directly related to fishing, was $775,000.
These figures would rise dramatically if the salmon fishery on the Penobscot were enhanced rather than threatened, or left stasis. In evaluating the options open to the commission, the final environmental statement concluded that denying the license to build and operate Basin Mills, and removing the current Veazie Dam (the most desirable scenario for environmental and conservation groups), would potentially double the Penobscot's production of wild salmon.
Quantifying the economic value and benefits of wildlife, and habitat suitable to it, is both a fashionable and risky proposition that raises the hoary issue of living and dying by the same sword. Few opponents of the Basin Mills Project, or any other hydroelectric project, are willing to make purely economic arguments for the management of wildlife resources.
By the same token, the effort to save rivers from further degradation and corruption has been greatly aided by critical changes in the way energy is created and distributed, ranging from Federal-mandated deregulation of the industry to the development of new energy technologies. These days, power companies can import cheap energy from clients, some of whom are willing and able to degrade their own environment in ways that the Government and the public no longer deem acceptable.
The environmental frontier is global, but that is no reason not to celebrate small victories in the battle to keep our precious rivers from becoming mere energy factories.

HEADLINE: Three Lenders Begin Loan Programs for Some Foreign Students at N.Y.U.

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Japanese students attending New York University got an unusual offer in the mail recently: the chance to borrow up to $50,000 to help pay for college.
For college students, loans are as much a part of the college experience as S.A.T.'s and dormitory food. But for foreign students, borrowing is not usually an option. The big Federal loan programs are open only to Americans, which limits the ability of many foreign students to study in the United States -- and the ability of colleges to attract them. 
 But N.Y.U. recently lined up three lenders willing to make loans to its foreign students: Citibank began offering loans of up to $50,000 this month to Japanese students. Last week, American Express agreed to extend college loans to N.Y.U. students from Taiwan, and Chase Manhattan Bank agreed to make loans to students from Korea and China.
The moves are significant because foreign students make up a growing portion of the student body in the United States.
About 450,000 foreign students now attend American colleges and universities, about three times as many as 20 years ago, according to the nonprofit Institute of International Education.
The four countries involved in the loan programs account for about one-third of all foreign students at American colleges and universities and more than 42 percent of N.Y.U.'s 4,000 foreign students.
Educators say the availability of loans would probably attract students from less-wealthy families. "This should allow a broader population of foreign students to attend college in the United States," said Richard M. Krasno, president of the institute.
Although foreign students must show that they can pay for college before they are granted a student visa, many underestimate the cost and run short of money, said Keith Jepsen, director of N.Y.U.'s Office of Financial Aid. It was to help those students -- and attract more -- that Mr. Jepsen began talking to lenders about offering the loans.
The terms for the Citibank loans are somewhat similar to those for American student loans, although the interest rates are lower, because rates in Japan are lower. Japanese students are allowed to borrow up to six million yen, or about $50,000, with a minimum of one million yen, or about $8,300, from Citibank in Japan. The interest rate is 3 percentage points above the Japanese prime rate (currently 1.625 percent) and will be reset annually. Borrowers pay an application fee of about $300 and an origination fee of up to 3 percent of the value of the loan. Repayment is between 2 and 10 years.
The terms for the Chase and American Express loans have not been worked out, but Mr. Jepsen expects them to be similar to those for the Citibank program. And he expects the loans to be available soon.
Japanese students at N.Y.U. said they found the loan program interesting but were not sure whether they would use it.
Yukiko Amita, a 23-year-old first-year graduate student from southern Japan, said she thought her father would find the loans appealing, because the terms were better than they were for the money he had borrowed to send her to New York.
Shin Mitsugi, a 24-year-old graduate student in public administration from Tokyo who also received an undergraduate degree from N.Y.U., said that the 4 percent interest rate was attractive but that he probably would not borrow, because he was in his final year of study.
"The new program is a good idea, but students have to be very careful," he said. "Repaying a loan is a big responsibility."

HEADLINE: Political Right's Point Man on Race

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
In many ways, Clint Bolick, a 39-year-old Washington lawyer, is the maestro of the political right on issues of race. He is increasingly setting the tone and defining the terms of the national debate, forcing civil rights groups to respond to his view, rather than enacting their own, of what Government policy on race ought to be.
As vice president of the Institute for Justice, a public interest law firm, he has been the leading voice in attacks on Government programs that give breaks to minority groups and women. Over the last few years, he has rung up a series of victories and near victories that have left conservatives enthralled and his liberal adversaries fuming. 
 He led the fight -- which few initially thought could be won -- that this week blocked Bill Lann Lee, a Los Angeles lawyer, from becoming the Justice Department's top civil rights enforcer, putting President Clinton on the defensive about what to do next. Four years earlier, Mr. Bolick orchestrated the pressure that forced the withdrawal of the nomination of Lani Guinier, a University of Pennsylvania Law School professor, for the same position.
He was a principal strategist in the nearly two-year fight that held up passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, bedeviling proponents of the measure, which opponents called a quota bill. And Mr. Bolick virtually wrote a bill before Congress that would end Federal affirmative action efforts.
He was a featured mover in the drive to force the Clinton Administration to ban the consideration of race in adoptions handled by public agencies. And he is a prime architect behind school voucher plans in Milwaukee and Cleveland.
"I would say that, in terms of Washington-based groups, he is the person who is most active in these legislative fights," said Linda Chavez, who was chairwoman of the Civil Rights Commission in the Reagan Administration and is active in the battle against affirmative action. "He has really been giving leadership on these issues."
Mr. Bolick, who makes $110,000 a year with the Institute of Justice, seems to relish befuddling civil rights groups as much as he enjoys his favorite pursuits of scuba diving and sipping vintage Chardonnay.
Along the way, he has earned praise from many conservatives and contempt from liberals who accuse him of engaging in distortions and mudslinging. Many liberals still fume over the characterization of Ms. Guinier as a "quota queen," in a Wall Street Journal opinion piece Mr. Bolick wrote. And they suspect that Mr. Bolick was at the bottom of suggestions that Mr. Lee had acted improperly in trying to work out a consent decree involving hiring women by the Los Angeles Police Department.
"I have serious problems with Clint Bolick, not because he has differing views, but because of his tactics," said Theodore M. Shaw, deputy counsel-general of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. "I think they're unprincipled and divisive."
Mr. Shaw added: "I've engaged in a lot of discourse with him. I've been on panels with him and debated him. It's only recently that I've come to the conclusion that I just don't respect him."
The life story of Mr. Bolick, a balding man with puffy cheeks and an often-used hearty laugh, places him at or near many of the major events or personalities that have been featured in the contemporary liberals vs. conservatives clashes.
He attended law school at the University of California at Davis a year after the Supreme Court ruled that it had to admit to its medical school Alan Bakke, a white man initially denied enrollment because of a racial quota program. His first job was at the Mountain States Legal Foundation, a public interest law firm founded by Joseph Coors, the conservative beer magnate, and run for years by James Watt, who later became the Reagan Administration's combative Interior Secretary. Associate Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court is the godfather of one of his children.
In tone, style and philosophy Mr. Bolick is more than the leader in the fight against affirmative action. He and his colleague, William (Chip) Mellor, 46, who is president of the Institute for Justice, epitomize a generation of white Republicans for whom the civil rights struggles of the 1960's and 70's are receding memories and who readily say their party was on the wrong side in the 1960's, but also say they feel no guilt about it.
"The younger generation of Republicans is too young to have been in the wrong place in the 1960's, and they have no baggage whatsoever to carry around," Mr. Bolick said in an interview at the institute's offices a short distance down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.
And he says he is a rarity: a conservative Republican who cares about racial issues.
For years, Mr. Bolick has waged a frustrating battle to get his party engaged on racial matters, beyond using race as a wedge issue to appeal to white swing voters. He has contended that the party had to have a strategy to help minority groups advance. Otherwise, he argued, the field is conceded to liberal approaches.
"Sometimes a bad idea will win out over a good idea," Mr. Bolick once said in a speech. "But a bad idea will always beat no idea."
The son of a welder who died when Mr. Bolick was 12, he attended Drew University in Madison, N.J., then the University of California at Davis Law School in 1979. At the time, Davis was still reeling from the 1978 Bakke decision, which said that places could not be set aside for minority students but that race and ethnicity could be factors in admissions. It was, Mr. Bolick says, a debate dominated by liberals who brooked no challenge to their dogma.
"It was very, very hostile," Mr. Bolick said. "You either believed in the dominant ideology or people hurled names at you."
After law school he signed on as a lawyer at Mountain States Legal Foundation in Denver, a libertarian public interest law firm that aggressively fought Government regulations, especially in the area of the environment. He took to it readily.
"It was so exhilarating," he said. "I couldn't wait to come to work every day."
During his time there, a friendship developed between Mr. Bolick and Mr. Mellor, who was running the foundation. Mr. Mellor was a former campus anti-Vietnam War protester whose disillusionment with both the left and with the Government flowered after the Kent State shootings in 1970.
He and Mr. Bolick play complementary roles in the institute. Mr. Bolick acts as the front man, giving speeches, writing articles for newspaper opinion pages and doing the bulk of the interviews. Mr. Mellor does more of the litigating and handles the fund-raising.
The two started the organization in 1991 with seed money from trusts controlled by Charles G. and David H. Koch of Wichita, Kan., brothers and oil and gas executives whom Forbes magazine once described as two of the richest men in America.
Though their battle against programs that extend advantages to women and minority groups brings them the most attention, Mr. Bolick and Mr. Mellor say their main purpose is to promote a sense of economic freedom and empowerment.
As such, they have litigated on behalf of a black operator of a shoe- shine stand in Washington fighting Government regulations. They have also gone to court to fight requirements in several states that operators of African-American hair braiding salons take expensive cosmetology courses that teach beauticians how to use hair-straightening chemicals.
"I like this guy," said Ali Rasheed, owner of The Braidery in San Diego, whom Mr. Bolick has represented. "I like him as a human being. I like what he does. He was straight up and down and honest with me. He told me he doesn't believe in affirmative action and all that."
Mr. Bolick is also a strong advocate for vouchers to let poor children attend schools of their choice, public or private. He contends that competition among schools would improve education for minority students, allowing them to succeed without the need for any preferential treatment.
But Mr. Bolick's efforts these days may be only a harbinger of the torments to come for civil rights organizations. Among the programs at the Institute for Justice is an effort to train scores of young, libertarian lawyers to work all over the country to roll back Government regulations and to challenge preference programs.
If they succeed -- and even if they do not -- Mr. Bolick may have achieved what he once told an interviewer he hoped would be his last words: "I helped changed the world and had fun doing it."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Soccer in the City: Coach Yells, Player Translates, Team Wins

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
At halftime, chilled and dispirited after playing poorly and leading by only one goal, the defending city soccer champions of Martin Luther King Jr. High School sprawled in the locker room at Riverbank State Park in Harlem. Their coach was ranting.
"I am not happy. This is not my team. You are playing without heart. Don't you realize you are this far away from being eliminated? There is no tomorrow." Coach Martin Jacobson smiled. He liked that phrase. "There is no tomorrow. There is no tomorrow. Got that?" 
 But some players just stared at him. They didn't get it. He suddenly remembered they didn't speak English. He turned to his midfield star, a year out of Senegal. "Say it in French, Mansour."
Mansour Ndiaye's two-minute translation of four words on Wednesday may or may not have inspired the team's three unanswered goals in the second half and its 35th straight victory. Tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Riverbank, it meets Midwood in a quarterfinal match of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament. But if American soccer fulfills its awakening promise as a major 21st century sport, you might add "Say it in French, Mansour," to the slogans on the nation's locker room wall.
"This wave of immigrants in the inner city are going to make the game happen here," says Jacobson, who learned his soccer forty-odd years ago on Long Island from a Holocaust refugee. "These are kids who come here at 15, 16, already accomplished as players. They'll become role models for younger, American-born kids. The future is already happening; I've had calls from both Nike and Adidas."
Jacobson's scenario may be wishful thinking, but other coaches, and officials of Major League Soccer, which signed up last year's King star, Barry Swift, see the cities as potential pools of talent. But for that talent to be successful, says Hugo Salcedo, a member of the 1972 United States Olympic team who works in development for M.L.S., there must be an integration of the inner-city immigrant player's "flair and technique" with the American-born suburban player's "strength and determination." It is not unlike basketball's complex dynamic of textbook and schoolyard styles.
At King, which with more than 3,200 students is the largest high school in Manhattan, the soccer players are almost a cult within a subculture, coming from among the 250 English as a Second Language students. The school has had its problems lately, but it also has a reputation for excellent business and law courses and is open to students from all boroughs; it became a recruiting magnet once Jacobson, who is deeply enmeshed in the metropolitan area's soccer-playing network, took over the team three years ago and turned it into a winner.
Two of the three senior captains, forward Randy Guerra and defender Kevon Isa, are Trinidadians living in Brooklyn. The third, Ndiaye, came here a year ago from Dakar, where his parents are optometrists, to live with an uncle in Harlem. He arrived speaking a Senegalese language, Wolof, French and a little German. He is ranked third in his class, and the spectrum of serious interest in him ranges from the professional soccer league to Harvard. The substance of his locker room speech in French helps explain that interest.
"I told them it was important that they understand there will be tough times," he translated for his non-Francophone listeners after scoring two goals in the eventual 5-1 victory over Franklin K. Lane. "I told them that this is the playoffs, all the teams are good, so you must be prepared for tough times. We won't always be winning, 10-0. So we have to keep going, never flag, not lose heart, play our game until the very last minutes, be organized and disciplined."
It was a speech he should have repeated the following afternoon when his old teammate, the star of last year's championship squad, unexpectedly appeared at school. Barry Swift was wearing a red MetroStars cap and a warmup jacket from Sunderland, a First Division English team. When he saw the King principal, Stephanie D'Amore, in the hall outside the coach's office, he threw his arms around her in a bear hug.
She stepped back puzzled. "What are you doing here? Why aren't you in England?"
Swift looked a little sheepish. He said he had just flown in to fill out some immigration papers. Then he added: "If I stayed there the whole three months, and then went to MetroStars spring training, I wouldn't see my family. And there's nothing to do in Sunderland. You practice, you eat, that's it. Not even movies. There was no balance in my life."
D'Amore, once a high school volleyball coach, said: "There won't always be balance in your life. Sometimes you have to sacrifice for a goal. You ever hear about delayed gratification?"
She exchanged freighted glances with Jacobson, and he said, "We still need to work on some life skills, Barry."
Officials at M.L.S., which had placed Swift in a development program that paid him $2,000 a month plus $7,500 a year toward college tuition, were not entirely surprised by his abrupt leave-taking. They admit that they need to do a better job of counseling young inner-city players before sending them off to train with foreign teams.
Social and economic problems take up more of Jacobson's time than coaching does; immigration paperwork is a constant.
Most players are undocumented, and the registration known as the green card has become a prerequisite for either a Division I scholarship or domestic player status in M.L.S. And many of the players have late-night jobs that interfere with games and practices, much less sleep and homework.
Mamadou Diap, for example, a junior defender from Senegal, won't quit his job in a quick-chicken joint in Harlem despite Jacobson's nagging. Diap has been robbed at gunpoint, and his mother keeps reminding him that they came to America so he could have a better education, not better clothes. But the heavy gold pendant on his chest makes him feel good, he says.
"Can't have Mama do everything for me," he said, flashing his sweet little smile. It widened when he was asked how many hours he worked to get the necklace. "Two weeks."
"I don't want to see that gold anymore," snapped Jacobson. "You are getting too materialistic, Mamadou, too American. Next you'll be wearing baggy pants, then you'll lose your culture and I'll throw you off the team."
This was sidewalk counseling on the way last week to practice at what the team calls Jurassic Park, a patch of land under the West Side Highway and the rising towers of Donald Trump's Riverside South. King has no outdoor sports facilities. The team shares the field with Martin Soto's sculptures of endangered animals. The 6-foot-4-inch Isa wove around a polar bear to practice a corner kick at Ronnie Lowe, the goalkeeper, who was defending an elephant.
The stink of fish rose from the Hudson River, just feet away on the other side of a chain-link fence. Jacobson bought three Nike balls at $25 each for this week of practice and playoff games. He screamed at his players to keep their passes and shots low on the ground. Already this season, nine balls have cleared the fence and gone to sleep with the fishes.
Jacobson thinks Nike should have bought the team balls, especially after it announced it was giving $120 million to the United States Soccer Federation, some of it presumably for youth development. Unlike basketball, in which high schools and colleges are the main conduits of talent, soccer is dominated by clubs. Jacobson was introduced last season to Lincoln Parker, a Nike regional marketing representative who replaced the team's eight-year-old uniforms and promised a shipment of bags, shoes and outerwear.
The players were excited at the prospect; two weeks ago, they beat the New Jersey state champion, Kearny, but couldn't forget that once the rains began, their opponents slipped on Umbro ponchos while they tore head holes in plastic garbage bags.
"We're not in the business of trying to take over high school soccer," said Parker, dismissing the notion that he was trying to brand Jacobson with the swoosh before Adidas came through with shoes and apparel. "I sent him stuff before I knew how good they were. I did it because I heard they had to sell cookies to pay for road trips."
The promised sweat suits didn't come in time for Wednesday's second-round game, which might have accounted for the team's chilled first-half play and the need for Mansour's pep talk. The clothes didn't arrive on Thursday either, but black socks, gym bags and $130 shoes did.
The players tried not to eye the boxes during the coach's blackboard diagramming of attacks and defenses punctuated by instructions for individuals to "get back" or "pull up" or "mark your man." Jacobson began pointing at the newest team member, Mansour Seck, three weeks out of Senegal and known as Baby Mansour to distinguish him from Ndiaye.
"You've got to mark your man, Baby Mansour, get on him right away," said the coach, rapping chalk on blackboard. "Got that?"
The 16-year-old Seck just stared at him. Jacobson sighed as he understood.
"Say it in French, Mansour."
