LENGTH: 952 words

HEADLINE: Albright to Consult Arab Countries on Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERN, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will make a rapid tour of Arab countries on Sunday to consult with them on how to deal with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, American officials said this evening.
Ms. Albright, who met here in Switzerland with Yasir Arafat today for talks on the peace effort with Israel that officials said produced only modest progress, will go to Bahrain, Kuwait and then Saudi Arabia, the officials said, presumably to stiffen their resolve against Iraq and its challenge to the United Nations. 
 "The reason for these stops is that those are the countries that are the front-line states, that face the greatest risk of Saddam Hussein continuing to threaten his neighbors," said the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin.
"At a time like this it's very important for the United States to consult with its friends in the gulf," he said.
 President Clinton was also active on the diplomatic front. A senior Administration official in Washington said President Clinton spoke by telephone with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on how to maintain Security Council unity in the search for a diplomatic solution in Iraq.
Ms. Albright will start the day with a brief stop in the morning at the American-sponsored Middle Eastern Economic Summit meeting in Qatar, which most Arab countries are boycotting,
Arab governments have already said they do not want military means used against Iraq in the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections, while American officials from President Clinton on down insist that all options are available, if necessary, including military force.
American officials say that the issue of Saudi permission for American troops to use Saudi bases in case of military action or to position American equipment there is always a sensitive one, but declined to provide details.
Since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, when the Saudis provided full basing permission, American, French and British pilots are allowed to use an air base in the center of Saudi Arabia to maintain a no-flight zone in southern Iraq.
American officials said that there was also a major American naval station in Bahrain, an air base in Qatar and about a battalion of American troops in Kuwait, with equipment there for a brigade-sized force.
After her talks here with Mr. Arafat today, and talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in London on Friday, Ms. Albright said that she saw some new openings in the stalled Middle East peace talks and urged both parties "to use December in a positive way."
"There have been some gaps, but we can also see some openings," she said. "And what I'd like to see in the next few weeks is a process of closing the gaps and increasing the openings."
She said that both leaders "are cognizant of the fact that it is essential to get the process moving."
"There is an understanding that 1997 has not been the best year for the peace process," she said. "But it's only November, and perhaps we can use December in a positive way."
Mr. Arafat looked very pale today, his eyes watered, and his lower lip trembled steadily. There have been rumors that he is ill. When asked about his health, he said: "I didn't have a good night's sleep. I had to work all night and I had to leave early in the morning, approximately 5 o'clock."
American officials said that Mr. Arafat was coherent in the meetings and spoke Arabic more fluently than his halting English. They acknowledged the rumors about Mr. Arafat's health, especially in the Arab world, but said he did not seem "very much different" than in the past.
But Mr. Arafat, when he saw Ms. Albright in September, did not have the involuntary tremor he displayed today, and he seemed thinner and more frail.
Mr. Arafat said he remained committed to the peace effort and was grateful for the United States attempt "to push the peace process forward and to protect it."
He said the Palestinians were willing to enter negotiations with the Israelis on a complete settlement of all the issues between them, "but it's equally important to have a full and precise implementation of the agreements already reached," he said.
He put special emphasis on an Israeli pullout from the West Bank, which was due in September but Mr. Netanyahu has delayed, citing Palestinian failures to cooperate fully with Israel on security and against terrorism.
On Sunday, the visits to Bahrain, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia will also allow Ms. Albright to cut the Qatar stop even shorter than planned. The meeting, which includes Israel, is being boycotted by nearly all of America's Arab friends, including the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Bahrain and Morocco.
The Palestinians are also boycotting. And even the Israelis are not sending their Foreign Minister, David Levy, but their Trade and Industry Minister, Natan Sharansky, instead.
American officials say that many businessmen from the region will come to the annual conference, now in its fourth year, and that a prime goal is to promote economic ties.
While in Bern, Ms. Albright also spoke to Swiss Government officials and legislators, praising their efforts now to get to the bottom of the Nazi gold issue, and urging them to continue efforts to discover why the bank deposits of Jews and others who died in the Holocaust were not returned to their heirs.
It was the first visit by a Secretary of State to the Swiss capital since 1961, and Ms. Albright, who studied in Switzerland as a young girl and learned her French here, praised the Swiss for their internationalism and efforts for peace.
"But if we are not to repeat the mistakes of the past," she said, "we cannot shrink from any aspect of the truth of the past."

HEADLINE: Deferring to 'Great Yellow Father';
Kodak Workers Say Layoffs May Be Necessary Medicine

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Bill States, a supervisor at an Eastman Kodak plant here, is searching the want ads and polishing his resume -- tasks that, at age 55, he thought were behind him. But like thousands of his colleagues, he is suddenly worried that he will be among the 10,000 people the company plans to lay off.
So it is surprising to hear Mr. States say that he does not begrudge the company even though he had figured it would employ him until his retirement in five years. 
 "Sure, I'm scared about losing my job," he said after his shift the other day, over drinks at Bathtub Billy's, a sports bar across the street from the company's five-mile-long industrial park. "But I want to see Kodak survive one way or the other, with or without me. Kodak is essential to the future of this community."
Unlike other Northeastern cities, like Buffalo and Utica, Rochester has been able to weather the decline of the region's manufacturing economy in recent decades, and the sturdiness of Kodak was in large part responsible.
But now Kodak itself is in trouble, leaving many people in this city and its booming suburbs wondering if they, too, are vulnerable to a new global economy in which brand loyalty is undercut by stiff price wars. In the case of Kodak, the battle is being waged primarily by Fuji, the Japanese film manufacturer.
The announcement of the impending layoffs has stirred a wave of conflicting emotions: even as many people express the predictable shock and fear spurred by corporate downsizing, they also grudgingly accept that the cutbacks may be the only chance for the city's major employer to manage in a cutthroat global marketplace.
Indeed, the relationship between Kodak and this city runs so deep that people here say that having a smaller Kodak is preferable to having no Kodak at all. What, they ask, would become of Rochester if it lost the "Great Yellow Father," as Kodak was once known because of its paternalistic employment practices and trademark yellow boxes of film.
For Kodak is not only Rochester's largest employer, putting about 34,000 people to work in a city of about 232,000, but it is also the largest buyer of goods and services in the city, sustaining scores of small businesses, from caterers and toolmakers to advertising agencies and printing shops. There are few other large American cities as dependent on a single company as Rochester, a conservative town on Lake Ontario in western New York.
"Kodak is the strength of the fabric of this community," said Art Aspengren, the president of the Rochester Industrial Management Council, an association of 370 companies. "It is in everything. If there is such a thing as a company town, this is a company town."
Ever since George Eastman, the company's founder, set up shop here at the turn of the century on the third floor of a building on State Street, Kodak has been regarded as an important and model corporate citizen.
The city's major institutions have long been supported by donations from the company and the Eastman family, from the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra and the Eastman School of Music to the University of Rochester Medical School and its Strong Memorial Hospital.
Beyond that, people have grown up for generations in Rochester with the belief that a job at Kodak is a job for life.
But Kodak started going through profound changes beginning in the early 1980's, as a bottom-line approach supplanted the company's old paternal ways. It closed down several divisions and has reduced its work force in Rochester to 34,400, from a high of 60,406 in 1982. It is not clear how the latest work-force reduction by Kodak, announced Tuesday, will affect Rochester, because the company has not said which of its plants around the world will bear the brunt of the layoffs, though Rochester is sure to take a significant hit, given its headquarter status.
The biggest blow to date in Rochester came in 1986, when the company shed a little over 9,000 jobs here. Suddenly, the informal covenant of job security no longer seemed certain. In a sign of the times, the company tried to provide for some of them by creating a Career Resource Center, where dismissed employees could go to have resumes typed, study job listings and scan trade journals and catalogues for technical schools. Kodak also announced that year that it would make cuts in its charitable contributions.
"I think a lot of people were bitter at the beginning," said Karl King, a glass maker who was laid off in the early 1980's but was later rehired as a security guard. "But now people are more accepting of the situation and what's taking place now. The economic picture is changing, and the company is trying to survive just like the people inside the company are trying to survive."
Rochester's economy, up to now, has been able to absorb the blow. Its metropolitan region has been among the most economically robust in the state. It boasts an average unemployment rate of 4 percent, compared with 6.1 percent statewide and 4.7 percent nationwide, according to the New York State Department of Labor.
The relative prosperity in Rochester, experts agree, can be traced largely to one factor: The region has been able to retain and even create manufacturing jobs, even as the state has continued to lose them at a staggering rate. In the metropolitan area, 24 percent of the nonagricultural jobs are in manufacturing, compared with 14 percent statewide, according to the State Labor Department.
But Rochester's prosperity relies heavily on a single source: Kodak. For not only does the company provide more than a quarter of the region's manufacturing jobs; many of the remaining manufacturing jobs are provided by companies in the region that rely on business with Kodak to remain afloat.
To the degree that people here are expressing anger over the latest round of layoffs, it is directed not so much at Kodak, but rather at its executives. They complain that many of the company's current leaders did not, among other things, react quickly enough to the challenges mounted by Fuji and instead fell back on Kodak's name recognition.
Not only that, employees complain, the executives needlessly heightened anxiety among workers by announcing the layoffs, but then refusing to say who would be affected for at least the next few weeks.
Kurt, a data collector for Kodak who refused to give his surname for fear of reprisal from his bosses, said he could not imagine that George Eastman would have approved, especially around the holiday season.
"Kodak will always be Kodak, a great place to work," he said. "But we don't agree with many of the decisions that management has made. It just seems that every time they slip up, they take it out on the working men and women."
But in the end, people have come to accept the latest round of layoffs with more resignation than rancor because, they say, the future of Kodak, and thus of Rochester, is at stake. As Mayor Bill Johnson put it in a recent interview, "One of our fervent hopes is that this short-term pain will produce a long-term gain."
Mike Devries, 47, a manager in the company's maintenance department and a Kodak employee for 28 years, could not agree more. While he said he realizes that he may be out of a job come December and that he is worried about how he will pay his mortgage and provide for his family, he said he is willing to accept the layoffs if they will help Kodak become more efficient and successful.
"I would feel some remorse if I wound up being laid off," he said. "But you have to take the cards as they come." He added, "The important thing is that Rochester remains viable and Kodak stays here for the good of everyone."

HEADLINE: On California Trip, Clinton Blends Politics and Fund-Raising

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Mixing a little retail politics with his wholesale fund-raising, President Clinton came here today to show that he shares Californians' environmental concerns and to support the local Democratic Congressman, Vic Fazio, by dedicating a wet and grassy refuge for birds on their wearying migrations.
Then the President moved on to his own familiar circuit, stopping in at a $5,000-a-plate lunch with California businessmen, his third fund-raiser for the debt-stricken Democratic Party in less than 24 hours. 
 In dedicating the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, the largest wetlands restoration project in the West, Mr. Clinton praised the partnership of Federal and local governments, duck hunters, environmentalists, farmers and others that produced it.
"You're doing the right thing and you're doing it in the right way," said Mr. Clinton, wearing a red cap and green windbreaker. "We can do anything if we roll up our sleeves and get down to work and honestly listen to people who have different experiences, different perspectives, and different genuine interests."
As Mr. Clinton spoke, a chilling drizzle and a cutting wind transformed what White House aides had hoped would be a striking photograph into a melancholy scene of black mud, brown reeds, and rippled gray water reflecting a gray sky.
Less than 100 years ago, the Yolo Basin contained almost 70,000 acres of freshwater wetlands and forest. At a cost of $12 million to the Federal Government and $5 million to California, officials prepared this wildlife area of 3,700 table-flat acres. Private, nonprofit groups contributed volunteer labor and advice.
In addition to providing a habitat for numerous species, the area is intended to serve as a stopping point for birds migrating along the route known as the Pacific Flyway. A few minutes before Mr. Clinton spoke, flocks of hundreds of ducks streamed past, far overhead.
When Air Force One arrived today at McClellan Air Force Base, which the Defense Department is closing down, Mr. Clinton delivered another message intended for the local audience. He announced that he would sign the $257 billion defense authorization bill even though members of Congress seeking to protect bases in their own districts inserted some language that could interfere with efforts to create businesses at the base. But Mr. Clinton went on to promise a series of modest initiatives to help retrain workers, support new uses of the base, and sustain the local economy.
An aide to Mr. Clinton said that that message and Mr. Clinton's trip to the wetlands were intended to provide support to Mr. Fazio, a frequent White House ally re-elected in the past with thin margins. In the wetlands, Mr. Clinton called Mr. Fazio "one of the most outstanding members of the United States Congress in either party."
For his national audience today, Mr. Clinton promoted his decision on Friday to temporarily suspend imports of modified assault weapons. In his weekly radio address, he ridiculed the notion that such firearms could be used for anything but making mayhem.
"You don't need an Uzi to go deer hunting," Mr. Clinton said, "and everyone knows it." "Assault weapons in the hands of civilians exist for no reason but to inspire fear and wreak deadly havoc on our streets."
On Friday, Mr. Clinton halted for 120 days imports of such firearms, blocking permits issued to dealers for 600,000 guns and freezing applications to import a million more. During the suspension, the Treasury Department will consider whether it can ban the guns permanently. The agency has the authority under the 1968 Gun Control Act to ban imports of such firearms if they are not used for "sporting purposes."
The National Rifle Association today attacked Mr. Clinton's announcement, and released a statement saying that the President is attempting to apply the 1994 gun ban to a whole new class of weapons.
"Everything the N.R.A. has ever said about the Clinton 1994 gun ban is coming true," the organization said.
In remarks on Friday night, Mr. Clinton boasted of the 1994 assault weapons ban, which applied to the domestic manufacture, sale and possession of 19 types of assault weapons, and also banned the domestic manufacture and sale of semiautomatic weapons with certain military characteristics. Imported weapons were already subjected to the broader "sporting purposes" test.
After lunch, Mr. Clinton flew to Los Angeles, where he planned to stay tonight at the home of the Hollywood producer Jeffrey Katzenberg.

HEADLINE: A Mature, Wealthy Israel Gives Its American Cousins a Jolt: 'Jews Are Not News'

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 15

 BODY:
American visitors to Israel these days might be forgiven for suspecting that they never left home, what with the proliferation of McDonald's arches, Blockbuster videos, football games on cable, shopping malls, epic traffic jams and the air of prosperity.
Yet for all the apparent Americanization, Jewish visitors from the United States are also often surprised to learn that the big Jewish news stories back home -- the recovery of Jewish-owned gold from Swiss banks, the revelation of Madeleine K. Albright's Jewish roots or, more recently, the fury among Reform and Conservative Jews over conversions in Israel -- are minor news in Israel. 
 The fact is, according to Israelis who follow relations with diaspora Jews, that interest in American Jewry has waned with the passage of generations, the growth of prosperity and the evolution of a national identity in Israel. "There's so many other problems here," said Matti Golan, an Israeli journalist. "I think most Israelis don't devote too much time and attention to relations with American Jews." He wrote a book critical of American Jews, "With Friends Like You: What Israelis Really Think About American Jews."
As one Israeli journalist put it when his editors played down a story he had written about American Jews, "Jews are not news."
That might startle those American Jews who believe that their financial and political support is vital to the survival of what they often still perceive as a vulnerable, struggling Jewish state. Israelis would retort that fewer than 20 percent of American Jews have visited Israel, and that American Jewish donations amount to less than 1 percent of the Israeli gross national product.
Underlying all such debates is the hard fact that American and Israeli Jews have moved far apart in the past half-century. At the founding of Israel, most new arrivals were likely to have a close relative in the United States and a common Yiddish language with American Jews.
"Once it was brothers in Israel and America," said Avraham Avi-Hai, an official of various fund-raising organizations and author of a study of relations between Israel and the Jewish diaspora. "Now it's distant cousins."
But even in the early days of the Israeli state the relationship with the United States was ambivalent.
"Basically," said Stuart Schoffman, a journalist who immigrated nine years ago from the United States, "there was a long-term pattern of mutual condescension, in which Israel was an impoverished country cousin and you sent blankets to keep them warm in winter, and America was a place of sludge-pot assimilation and stunted Judaism, for which Israel provided heroism and inspiration."
"All that is changing," he said, adding that Israel is "like the kid who was always asking Dad for the keys to the car. Now he has his own car. On the flip side, virtually every American Jew has reason to be disappointed in Israel at this moment."
A major frustration for Israelis has been with what they perceive as American Jews' efforts to push policies for which Israelis have to pay the price in blood and hardship.
The resentment is shared by right and left. Some on the right, like the legislator Benny Elon, have urged an end to Israel's dependence on $3 billion annually in American aid, believing the money gives Washington leverage to press policies that many Israelis consider deadly. And Israelis on the left erupted in fury recently when an American millionaire, Irving Moscowitz, fomented a confrontation with the Palestinians by moving Jewish settlers into a house he had bought in East Jerusalem. These decisions, Israelis argue, are for those who vote and bear arms.
"We distinguish between issues which are universal issues of Judaism, whether conversion, immigration or the moral precepts of society," said Simcha Dinitz, a former Ambassador to the United States and head of the Jewish Agency. "But on the line between us and the Palestinians, or us and Jordan, we're ready to hear opinion, but the decision has to be made, for better or for worse, by people duly elected as the Government of Israel. We'll decide whether to divide Jerusalem -- you divide New Jersey, if you want."
Such resentment is often expressed in Israeli reminders of how few American Jews immigrate to Israel. The number, about 3,200 a year, is considerably smaller than the number of Israelis who leave Israel for the United States.
Beyond the mutual pique lies the simple fact that Israeli Jews have had their own nation for nearly 50 years now. They do not share the problems of identity with Jews who still live as minorities in their own countries, no longer persecuted but still threatened with assimilation.
"The differences come from an objective situation," Mr. Golan said. "Israeli Jews are born and raised in a majority, while American Jews are born and raised as a minority. It makes a big difference in mentality. In that respect, Israelis in a way feel more at ease with majorities in other countries than with diaspora Jews."
That difference occasionally becomes evident in disputes with other countries. Thus, while American Jews pursued gold held by Swiss banks as descendants of the Jews from whom it had been stolen, some Israelis, for whom the issue had another, international-relations dimension, were uncomfortable with it.
The distinction between acceptable and unacceptable diaspora input into Israeli affairs has led some Israelis to suspect that American Jews' anger about conversion was really a channeling of rage about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's hard-line policies and his strained relations with President Clinton. "I can't help but suspect that the issue here is one of political sublimation," said Rabbi David Rosen, head of the Anti-Defamation League in Israel. "Were the diaspora Jews to be a bit more happy about where Israel is headed politically, they might be a bit more tolerant."
That bewilderment at the fury of the American Jews belonging to the Reform and Conservative movements was widespread among Israeli Jews, in part because few among them are familiar with these movements, which have only token membership in Israel, and in part because the dispute with Orthodox Jews is really nothing new.
The current argument centers on lawsuits brought by Reform and Conservative Jews to compel the Israeli Government to recognize non-Orthodox rabbis' right to perform conversions. Orthodox Jews, who hold a traditional monopoly on religious affairs in Israel, then moved to enshrine their control in legislation. Although this authority would only apply to Israel, many American Jews have taken the proposal as an affront and charged that they are being regarded as second-class Jews.
Some Israelis recognize that the conversion issue is critical to American Jews, because the Reform and Conservative movements, with their less stringent rules for religious behavior, are the main defense against assimilation into American civic culture. The more relaxed approach to conversion, for example, makes it easier for the spouse of a Jew to become Jewish.
But Israelis note that this problem does not exist in Israel. The dispute here between secular and religious Jews is over civil versus religious rights in issues like driving on the Sabbath -- not over identity.
To Orthodox Jews, the issue of conversion in Israel is part of an internal struggle with secular Jews, and many find it hard to understand why American Jews are so upset.
Rabbi Avraham Ravitz, a legislator from the United Torah Judaism, described the Orthodox opposition to the Reform and Conservative demands in terms similar to those of secular Israelis who resent American interference in security issues. "We feel very upset about them to come here and not live here and just to interfere and give orders to us how to behave and what laws we should pass," he said.
But to Rabbi Rosen, the dispute, however unpleasant now, could prove a long-term boon if it served to lower the level of mutual ignorance. "It got the Israeli Government to recognize its responsibility to seek a compromise," he said. "It led diaspora Jews to target contributions to those associations that promote its own values, and the greatest success is that more Israelis know about forms of Jewish life in diaspora than ever before."

HEADLINE: LEADING DISSIDENT IS FREED BY CHINA TO AN EXILE IN U.S.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sunday, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Chinese Government this morning released from prison its best-known democracy advocate, Wei Jingsheng, on medical grounds and put him on a plane to the United States, according to members of Mr. Wei's family.
His exile comes just a few weeks after the visit to the United States of China's President, Jiang Zemin, which included a summit meeting with President Clinton. During the visit, disputes over human rights clouded otherwise amiable meetings. American officials had expressed disappointment that no prominent dissidents, like Mr. Wei or Wang Dan, a leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations, had been released before the visit. 
 State Department and White House officials said they could not confirm the account. Late this morning, the American Embassy here said it had no comment.
"I can tell you only that during times like this, the less said the better and we're not saying anything," said a White House aide who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 Mr. Wei's brother, Wei Xiaotao, said that the dissident was on his way to Detroit for medical treatment and that he planned to return to China one day, Reuters reported.
Mr. Wei, 47, who had spent all but six months of the last 18 years in jail, had become a symbol of China's continuing suppression of any public call to end Communist dictatorship. A former Red Guard who had worked as an electrician at the Beijing Zoo, he vaulted into prominence in 1978 with a single, piercing thought, written on a wall poster: that China could never become an advanced country without real democracy.
In the years since then, in letters smuggled out of prison and during his brief moments of freedom, he has been an unrelenting, often sassy critic of the Government, openly taunting the late Deng Xiaoping, who first had him arrested in 1979. But he suffered severe health problems and reportedly was subjected to beatings and other mistreatment in prison, and family members had made desperate pleas for his release.
Mr. Wei's release now, soon after the China-United States summit meeting, may help clear the way for President Clinton's planned return visit next year. Chinese political observers, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that for Mr. Jiang to have released Mr. Wei before the recent trip would have been interpreted at home as a sign of weakness, while the release now can be portrayed as a statesman-like act.
For Mr. Jiang, exiling Mr. Wei also removes from the scene a major irritant. In prison, he was an international cause celebre, even seen as a potential Nobel Peace Prize winner. Abroad, his impact may be muted, since the Chinese Government keeps such close control over the import of information.
President Jiang, during his American trip, insisted that dissidents like Mr. Wei were criminal, not political, prisoners and said their fates were up to the judicial system. He left open, however, the release of ailing dissidents on medical grounds.
In the introduction to a book of Mr. Wei's writings published earlier this year, Andrew Nathan, a political science professor at Columbia University, wrote of Mr. Wei, "The prisoner says things that cannot be allowed to be said, but has the cheek in doing so to break no laws, to cite the Communist classics, to take the government's boasts about human rights at face value."
In 1978 and 1979, a period known as the Democracy Wall movement, Mr. Wei dared to criticize the national leader, Deng Xiaoping, openly. In an essay titled "Do We Want Democracy or New Autocracy?" Mr. Wei charged that Mr. Deng, although lauded for loosening the economy, was only strengthening the Communist Party's political control. His most famous essay was his first, written in large characters on the Democracy Wall and titled "The Fifth Modernization: Democracy." This was a play on the official campaign for "four modernizations" in agriculture, industry, science and technology, and defense. Put on trial in 1979 for "counter-revolutionary propaganda and incitement," he was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
In a letter he wrote to Mr. Deng from prison after the June 1989 crackdown -- no one knows if it was delivered -- Mr. Wei wrote with characteristic directness: "So, now that you've successfully carried out a military coup to deal with a group of unarmed and politically inexperienced students and citizens, how do you feel?"
In 1993 Mr. Wei, well known abroad and a hero among the cadre of democracy activists at home, was freed on parole. His release coincided with China's ultimately unsuccessful application to become host of the 2000 Olympics.
Out of jail, Mr Wei continued to speak out. In early 1994, after he had dinner with the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights who was accompanying Secretary of State Warren Christopher to Beijing, Mr. Wei was rearrested and sentenced to an additional 14 years. The American Government was humiliated.
But now, China seems bent on forging positive relations with the United States, whose trade and investment it badly needs if it is to continue with the dramatic economic progress that is transforming the country and, many political experts say, preventing more widespread political dissent.
Discussing the possibility of Mr. Wei's release recently, a Chinese person who quietly nurses pro-democracy views said that of course he and others would be gratified to see Mr. Wei's terrible suffering end. But he noted that a few thousand other dissidents languish in jail and that in any case, such high-profile releases are simply gestures that the Government can offer and rescind at will. The Government, he said, despite recent efforts to improve judicial procedures, can still on political grounds arrest anyone it wants to at any time.
Wei Shanshan, Mr. Wei's youngest sister and a resident of Germany, had lobbied American officials to continue pushing Mr. Jiang to grant a medical parole for Mr. Wei, who had been jailed for all but six months of the last 18 years.
Otherwise, she said on the basis of a recent visit to him by other family members, he might die. "I do believe this visit of Jiang offers us the very last opportunity," Ms. Wei said in an interview on Oct. 24. "If we miss it, it may be the last." She met with the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, Stanley O. Roth, and John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary for Human Rights, as well as with National Security Council officials.
In 1993, Mr. Wei was diagnosed as suffering from coronary heart disease, high blood pressure and arrhythmia, an irregularity in the heartbeat. His family has also said that he suffers from arthritis and spine and neck problems.

HEADLINE: Hold Me! Squeeze Me! Buy a 6-Pack!

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
ON a blustery evening in August, six Manhattan women gathered in the air-conditioned studios of Focus Suites, a market-research company on Lexington Avenue where hand-picked groups meet to critique consumer products like soap or perfume or cereal.
The women sat on sofas and ate miniature quiches from paper napkins while Hazel Kahan, a market-research consultant, asked them questions about a bachelor friend of theirs. He had hired Ms. Kahan to convene the focus group of single women -- all of whom had shot down his efforts to begin a relationship -- and to answer questions like "How could he make himself more appealing?" and "Should he change his wardrobe, his hair, his laugh?" 
 While the women, who ranged from their mid-20's to their mid-30's, giggled and offered mostly genial advice ("Bolster your confidence" "Change your wardrobe"), they knew that the man in question sat behind a one-way mirror, watching their reactions. He was applying the principles that any company trying to sell toothpaste or CD players uses to shape a product for the marketplace. But in his case, the marketplace was a more personal one: the brutal dating world of Manhattan.
After the session, Ms. Kahan debriefed her client, a 30-ish author, who refused to allow his name to be used, to protect his privacy. "I said, 'This is what it means, and these are the implications for your future,' " Ms. Kahan said.
Influenced by the tidal wave of marketing and advertising tossed at them each day, Americans seem to be undergoing a curious transformation: personal identities are being swapped for the attributes of consumer products, as individuals come to see themselves increasingly as brands.
Taking a cue from Michael Jordan and Martha Stewart, celebrities who have spun off many-tentacled business empires based on their identities, and armed with magazine articles and books about the power of "the personal brand," individuals are using the rules of brand management to help shape their resumes, their personal images and even their social and marital lives.
Richard Kurtz, a 59-year-old market-research consultant in Manhattan, uses brand marketing to distinguish his work from other freelance consultants in his field. "Branding is the neon in your name," he said. "You go to the store, and there are all these different brands of mustard. Tell me, Am I French's, or am I Grey Poupon? How can I make people see me differently? How can I add value to me?"
In Seattle, Will Powers employed the principles used to shape corporate identities to improve his marriage. On a sheet of paper, under the heading "The product I'm selling to my wife," Mr. Powers wrote a list of attributes like "commitment" and "shared dreams" that he hoped would impress his customer.
"I asked her to write down what she wants from the product, which would be me," said Mr. Powers, 28. "And she generated her own attribute list for the brand, which included things like 'honest,' 'funny,' 'sympathetic.' "
What is going on here? To a certain extent, average Americans are trying to jump on the bandwagon that first got rolling about the time Calvin Klein placed his name on the rumps of millions of jeans wearers and that has since zoomed onward with a Martha Stewart magazine, television show and line of towels and linens.
Jane Pratt, the former editor of Sassy magazine, who went on to have two television talk shows ("Jane" and "The Jane Pratt Show") and to found a new magazine (also named Jane), recalled that a friend once advised against naming her first television show after herself. "He said, 'You're turning yourself into a product,' " Ms. Pratt recalled.
But today, no one she knows thinks it odd that her magazine is named after her or that the spine of the November-December issue is imprinted with the tag line "Take a Dip in Lake Me."
"That's the weirdest thing of all," Ms. Pratt said. "None of my friends think there's anything strange about it at all. We sort of expect that everybody will have something named after them at a certain point."
Celebrities and civilians alike seem to have borrowed one of the business world's buzzwords of the 90's -- "branding" -- to define their most personal selves.
"What marketing and brands have taught people to do is look at things and sum them up in an instant," said Nick Shore, a partner in the NickandTom Brand Agency, a firm that creates brand identities for products like Surge, Coca-Cola's teen-oriented soft drink. "For example, you can look at a person, see chinos, a baseball cap turned backward, T-shirt, and think, 'O.K., I got it.' It is one of the most fundamental plate-tectonic shifts going on in American culture right now."
Some experts are not so sanguine. Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University, said the current interest in personal brands is the latest example of a 20th-century trend that began in 1937 with Dale Carnegie's motivational book "How to Win Friends and Influence People," which applied the techniques of the then-nascent advertising industry to personal relations.
"It has become increasingly necessary to navigate huge market bureaucracies and to market yourself within them and among them by seeming personable," Professor Miller said. It is profoundly cynical, he added, but reflects the huge power of commercials in American lives. "You are offering yourself as a commodity, as a thing," he said. "You're not a winning personality; you're a salable item. It represents a new level of self-dehumanization."
Last summer, Fast Company, a business magazine, published a special issue devoted to "The Brand Called You," and in it, Tom Peters, the business guru and best-selling author, wrote an article outlining the steps anyone can take to make himself or herself into a brand-name product. Hundreds of readers flooded the magazine's Web site with responses, anxious to learn more.
This month, Mr. Peters's latest book, "The Circle of Innovation" (Knopf), is out with a chapter called "Tommy Hilfiger Knows" that is devoted to the personal brand. (As for Mr. Hilfiger, this month he hired the William Morris Agency to develop a talk show called "Tommy TV.")
New York City, with its Empire State Building-size egos, is the birthplace of the personal brand. Last week, the gossip columnist Cindy Adams branded herself by introducing a perfume, Gossip by Cindy Adams. Donna Karan has extended her brand to a line of Timothy's coffee, despite the fact that she herself does not drink coffee.
Meanwhile, HarperCollins recently hired its first brand manager, Carl Raymond, whose job includes refashioning the images of formerly tweedy authors. When you see an author's name, the soft-spoken Mr. Raymond wants you to have an immediate, visceral reaction. If you catch a glimpse of a book by John Gray, the author of "Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus," Mr. Raymond wants you to think of one word: hope.
"John Gray owns that word," he said. "And everyone needs" -- he paused, then pushed his voice a note or two higher -- "hope." Mr. Raymond is busy developing slogans for authors: "There is hope" for Mr. Gray and "Take it personally" for Dr. Laura Schlessinger, a radio personality and marriage and family therapist. His job is to make sure the phrases appear on every piece of literature, every book jacket and every T-shirt.
"What draws consumers to brands is that there is something tangible that comes to their minds when they see Gravy Train or Crest -- or John Gray," Mr. Raymond said. "Although our aim is not to treat John Gray as if he were dog food."
Back on Earth, mere teen-agers are also conceiving of themselves as brands. Jesse Daggett, a 17-year-old college freshman who lives in Salem, Ore., started to think of himself as a brand after he read Mr. Peters's article in Fast Company. At the time, Mr. Daggett was not looking to become a corporate executive or to market a line of athletic footwear; he was a clerk in a Dairy Queen.
"I realized that the best thing to do was to establish myself as a brand," Mr. Daggett said. "Everyone in the shop was a couple of years older than me, and I had to prove myself. To establish myself as an identity, who I am."
And Mr. Daggett, true to the marketing mindset, can nail down his personal brand in a few words: "I like to think of the brand Jesse this way," he said. "Hard worker. Putting yourself in charge. If something needs to be done, Jesse can do it and get it done and be the leader of the team. That's the Jesse brand."
Part of the reason that people no longer hesitate to think of themselves as products with labels is that advertisers have persuaded consumers over the last decade that brands, and products, have human qualities. Think of the Neon, a car that rolls onto your television screen and says, "Hi," or the Apple computer, whose smiley-face computer icon tells you when your laptop is warming up or shutting down.
"The most powerful brands have human qualities," said Scott Bedbury, a senior vice president of Starbucks. "And this is why there is a buzz these days about people being seen as brands."
Mr. Bedbury signed a six-figure contract this month with Little, Brown to write a book about the power of branding. "People like Martha Stewart and Michael Jordan are great examples of people transcending flesh and becoming brand concepts," he said. Mr. Bedbury's editor has encouraged him to devote ample space in his book to the creation and maintenance of the personal brand.
Although the rhetoric in the field is often high-flown, Mr. Kurtz, the freelance market-research consultant, remains humble: "If I wake up at 4 in the morning and say to myself, 'Hey, why am I not having a great month?' I think to myself, 'I've got to contact people, I've got to get moving, I've got to think about my brand.' Because my brand is me. If people buy my brand, if they hire me, that means they like me. They love me. They accept me. And everybody wants to be on life's short list. Everybody wants to be loved."
Mr. Kurtz's feelings disturb some marketing professionals, including Ms. Kahan, who conducted the focus group for the frustrated bachelor.
"I think it's really alarming that we let a market economy dictate our human relationships," Ms. Kahan said. "I think it's much more healthy for the human model to dictate to the business world than for the business model to inform human life."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
In Refinancing, Homeowners Find a Source for Saving

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A MINI-BOOM of mortgage refinancings has occurred in recent weeks, in large part because of the recent turmoil in the stock market.
The percentage of total mortgage dollars that were devoted to refinancings rose to 43.2 percent for the week ended Nov. 6, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. In the summer, that percentage was in the teens. 
 "Whenever you see lower interest rates, there is a spurt of refinancings," said David A. Lereah, chief economist at the mortgage bankers' group.
Mortgage rates have had their most stable year in a decade, fluctuating only about one percentage point, though they have moved down about a quarter point in recent weeks. The mortgage bankers' group says the current average rate for a 30-year fixed-rate conventional mortgage is 7.28 percent.
Mr. Lereah said the recent drop was small but noted that 7.25 percent was an important threshold; rates dipped below that mark earlier this fall. "Psychologically, that's an important point with people, especially if they are sitting on the fence," he said.
The recent decline in rates resulted from the stock market's fall late last month, which prompted many investors to seek shelter in bonds. That drove bond prices up and yields down; mortgage rates often track the rate on the 10-year Treasury note.
Moreover, the decline in stocks also makes it less likely that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to stem inflation. Indeed, the Fed's policy-making committee decided last week to leave rates unchanged.
Experts are divided on the future direction of interest rates. Some say rates will keep falling as long as inflation is dormant; others believe interest rates could rise, in part because refinancings could help spark consumer spending, eventually putting upward pressure on inflation.
"Interest rates probably don't have much more space to fall in a growing economy and are likely to rise as the Fed takes hold of the economic reins sometime next year," said Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president at HSH Associates, a mortgage analyst. "But that little bit of an increase probably won't take us past 8 percent."
Refinancings can save borrowers significant sums. At 7.25 percent, the monthly principal and interest payment is $682.17 on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage of $100,000. For a similar loan at 7.50 percent the payment is $699.21. That $17 monthly savings may not sound like much, but it adds up to more than $6,100 over 30 years.
Most refinancings have been into 30-year fixed-rate loans, Mr. Gumbinger said, especially because rates on one-year adjustable-rate mortgages now rise from their low first-year teaser rates, often in the 5.65 percent range, to more than 8 percent the second year because they are linked to the one-year Treasury bill rate, about 5.41 percent now, plus a 2.75 percent premium.
The spread between long-term and short-term rates is narrow these days, Mr. Gumbinger explained. He said short-term rates, like that of the one-year Treasury, were being propped up by the Fed as an anti-inflation measure. And long-term rates, like that of the 10-year Treasury note, are low because investors are confident that inflation will remain in check.
Indeed, Mr. Gumbinger said many people who are refinancing had adjustable-rate mortgages with rates now higher than those on fixed-rate loans. "One-year A.R.M.'s are not the product right now," he said.
Some borrowers, though, are also taking out "5-1" and "7-1" loans, which stay fixed at rates lower than those for 30-year fixed-rate loans for five or seven years and then adjust annually. For example, at Homerica Mortgage, a mortgage banker in Harrison, N.Y., the rate is 6.6 percent on a "5-1" loan and 6.95 percent on a "7-1" loan.
Interest rates for home-equity loans and lines of credit have not declined as much as for mortgages, largely because they are linked to the short-term prime rate plus a premium. According to the Bank Rate Monitor, which follows interest rates, the national average interest rate on a home-equity line of credit is 8.40 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 23, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a recent increase in the refinancing of home mortgages referred incorrectly to a formula for figuring interest rates for adjustable-rate mortgages. After a low, teaser rate in the first year, the rate often rises to the sum of two figures: the one-year Treasury bill rate plus a premium of 2.75 percentage points, not 2.75 percent.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
401(k) Fees Nibble Now, With the Bite Felt Later

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
OVER try to find out how much of your 401(k) savings is being shaved off in fees?
High expenses can, over time, seriously reduce the magic of compound interest and leave you with a smaller nest egg for your old age. And the practice of making workers pay a growing portion of fees brought the Labor Department to hold hearings on the issue last week. 
 Workers typically do not know what fees they pay because Federal law does not require disclosure on the periodic statements they receive.
The range is wide. It is not common to find a 401(k) plan that has an annual cost of 5 cents for each $100 invested for administrative fees, though they do exist. But it is easy to find a plan that charges $2 a year for each $100 invested -- a difference that amounts to hundreds of thousands of dollars over time.
Most Americans have about $1 per $100 taken annually from their 401(k) account in fees, according to Olena Berg, the Assistant Labor Secretary for Pensions. Testimony at last week's hearings showed that more than 90 percent of those fees are for investment management, with the rest going to cover the costs of keeping records, issuing statements and complying with Federal regulations.
Critics of fund managers say they are taking advantage of the ignorance of the company official who sets up a plan, lining their pockets with extraordinarily high fees. The fund managers themselves say their fees are highly competitive.
Workers who invest in mutual funds can roughly calculate their investment fees from annual disclosure statements required by the Securities and Exchange Commission, but banks and insurance companies are exempt from this rule. And no plan has to disclose fees paid by each worker for record-keeping, preparing statements, legal costs and other administrative expenses.
This lack of disclosure is a key reason that the divide between the highest-cost plans and the least expensive is widening.
The biggest, smartest companies are using their economic sophistication and the clout of their huge funds to negotiate low-cost deals, while smaller and less aggressive employers often unwittingly agree to high fees, which are paid out of their workers' 401(k) savings.
Leaders of the mutual fund industry and several large professional and trade organizations, as well as consultants who advise small companies on retirement plans, all urged the Labor Department to require disclosure of total fees, saying it would help hold fees down.
The 28,000 401(k) savers at the Exxon Corporation pay about a nickel a year on each $100 in their 401(k) accounts, said James E. Bayne, the company's retirement funds manager and the chairman of the pension committee of the Financial Executives Institute.
Some workers at other companies, testimony showed, pay $2 per $100.
In dollars and cents, the difference between paying a nickel and paying $2 out of every $100 may seem small, but over time those differences become enormous. After 30 years, the worker who saves $5,000 annually, invests in stocks and pays the nickel fee will have more than $1 million, assuming a 10.9 percent rate of return. That is 53 percent more than someone in the same situation who pays fees at the $2 rate.
Michael P. Barry, a managing director of Bankers Trust, which manages the seventh-largest pool of 401(k) funds in the nation, said "the large corporate sponsors and providers are reinventing this market" by forcing down fees and emphasizing low-cost index funds.
Exxon, which Mr. Barry and others said was a leader in the drive to lower costs, tells workers about its super-low fees in its corporate newsletter. It charges no fees for two of its four investment options and it absorbs all administrative costs.
While tiny, Exxon's fees are not the lowest. Workers at Eastman Kodak pay just two pennies per $100 for its Standard & Poor's 500 index fund, one-tenth what Vanguard, the mutual fund company known for its low costs, charges retail customers of its S.& P. 500 index fund.
Myra R. Drucker, the Xerox Corporation's chief investment officer, said that her company had pushed down total 401(k) fees to as little as 17 cents per $100. She said that even Xerox's most expensive investment option, an international stock fund, costs only 79 cents per $100. That is less than half the cost to a retail customer, who is more expensive to service, typically has a smaller account and is more likely to move the money elsewhere.
LOW fees are not limited to corporate giants. Gencorp, the Ohio automotive and aerospace manufacturer, is less than a tenth the size of Xerox, but its fees are about 13 cents per $100, and the company charges workers for only half of that, said David K. McNiff, Gencorp's director of investment management.
The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, operates four mutual funds, charging its own 401(k) savers about 33 cents per $100, roughly one-third what it charges retail customers of its mutual funds.
Ms. Drucker, of Xerox, said that while many big companies "are focused on costs, in the small-plan market it is not as clear that the employers have the bargaining power or the understanding that they need to have" to get the best prices.
John Bohan, the Pillsbury Company's vice president for pension investments, said that "the small- to medium-size plans are the ones where the owner has neither the background nor the time to get the information to really understand pricing, and so when somebody comes in offering to serve him and his needs he often does not get the best deal, which is unfortunate for the employees."
Stephen J. Butler, president of the Pension Dynamics Corporation in Lafayette, Calif., who advises small employers on how to reduce costs, said high fees "are a form of misappropriation of plan assets."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 23, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the effects of annual fees on the value of workers' 401(k) plans referred incorrectly to the Exxon Corporation's plan. The company, not the employee, pays nearly all of the 5 cents in costs per $100 in each employee's account.

HEADLINE: The Two Hollywoods;
What Does The Audience Want?

BYLINE: By Geoffrey O'Brien

 BODY:
Movie makers who assume they know what the audience is looking for learn, more often than not, that they have misunderstood yet again. It could hardly be otherwise, when the spectators themselves scarcely know. We scan the abbreviated titles on the marquee of the 12-screen multiplex (Edge Game Kiss Girls Ice Storm Tibet) as if a secret message were encoded there, or roam disconsolately among the aisles of a video store crammed with movies we aren't quite in the mood for. The 20th century draws to a close amid a glut of product and a pervasive loss of surprise.
 We have seen all the old images -- from the parting of the Red Sea to the arrival of intelligent extraterrestrials -- and are still waiting for film makers to show what the new ones will look like. In the short term, we know all too well what to expect: more exploding helicopters, more meet-cute romances, more gross-out sight gags, more serial killers tracked down by more odd-couple buddies, more jaded yet photogenic teen-agers committing antisocial acts, more well-appointed, mildly spiced-up adaptations of Victorian and Edwardian novels. After 100 years of movie watching, it is perhaps hardly surprising to feel that the most obvious possibilities have been played out. The century of spectatorship that arrived with the dawn of movies and crested with the triumph of television rolls toward the exit in a world so full of screens and formats that the problem of what to show on them has become almost secondary. 
 Film makers, no doubt, had it easier in the beginning. Nothing had been used up yet: there was a whole world to plunder for surfaces and anecdotes, a civilization of stories and legends to adapt. Almost anything was beguiling, especially to an audience that might have been happy just to get out of the cold and into the cozy darkness of a nickelodeon. All was novelty: waves dashing against rocks, a weight lifter flexing his muscles, a child playing a practical joke on his grandmother. A basic vocabulary of movie possibilities -- the chase, the fight, the kiss, the dance -- was pretty much in place by 1905. So was the basic cinematic thrill: the transference that lets the spectator conquer space and time, sail across dizzying expanses of ocean and desert or linger to catch (in close-up) the whispered confidences of lovers.
 For most of the century, the movies never stopped changing, adding sound and color, new faces, new subjects. By now we yearn for leaps in narrative complexity and sensual elaboration of those earlier decades. It took only 30 years to go from Griffith's two-reel melodrama "The Lonedale Operator" to "Citizen Kane." Shouldn't the 56 years since Kane have taken us further into the future than we seem to have got, or is this as futuristic as it will ever get? The collisions are more lifelike, the aliens and dinosaurs blend more seamlessly with their surroundings, but it's all in the service of the same old stories. At times things seem to have gone in reverse as we watch movies -- "Speed" or "Air Force One" -- that resemble nothing so much as state-of-the-art elaborations of the formulas of "The Lonedale Operator."
 The spectator is always torn between the desire to move forward into the unknown and the desire to go back to the comfort of home; the movies often oblige by doing both at the same time. The "Star Wars" trilogy served up the future by infusing the form of 1930's Flash Gordon serials with a more complex, and moreinsidious, understanding of "the dark side." (And now, mildly revamped with a few fresh special effects, it serves it up for another generation.)
 "L. A. Confidential" marches boldly into the past, remaking the 50's in the image of 90's retro-noir, as if the Next Big Thing were the uncanny resurrection of Lana Turner and Chet Baker. The film's labyrinthine plot makes its nostalgic trappings new by juxtaposing them with horrific images (prisoners beaten by cops at a Christmas party, rats scampering from a rotted corpse) that would never have made it to the screen in the 50's. "Boogie Nights" carves out fresh cinematic territory by circling back to the world of 70's porno chic, a forbidden world now far enough in the past to be explored not only without anxiety but in a mood of comic detachment.
 What we want to see can only be defined in terms of what we have seen; it's hard to order what isn't on the menu yet. (Hence the 'Die Hard' on a bus variety of Hollywood shorthand.) Any discussion of what audiences want tends to become, by default, a discussion of what they already have -- the century's accumulation of dance numbers and jewel heists and dream sequences. Yet there's no way to measure how far even the most successful films may have fallen short of what spectators yearned for. Quantitative analysis of box-office results only confuses the issue. Take 1949: in a year remembered for such noirish classics as "Criss Cross," "The Set-Up," "White Heat" and "They Live by Night," the biggest draw was Larry Parks in the nostalgic musical "Jolson Sings Again." In 1969, slices of the Zeitgeist like "Monterey Pop," "Easy Rider" and "The Wild Bunch" trailed behind a Disney comedy about a self-motivated Volkswagen, "The Love Bug." By the same token, you might well ask if the deepest desires of 1996 can really be measured by its greatest hits, "Independence Day," "Twister" and "Mission: Impossible."
 But when it comes to deep desires, the spectators are as much in the dark as anyone. That's the way they like it: hoping for astonishment and knowing as little as possible about the details of what's coming up. Coming attractions! The promise in that once-magic phrase persists despite all disappointments. Maybe "The Fifth Element" will actually provide a persuasive glimpse (just as the director promised in his interviews) of life in the 23d century; maybe "Austin Powers" will restore the Carnaby Street of 1967 in all its mod splendor. We end up settling for whatever minor pleasures we can get -- in one case a comical drag queen in the middle of a space-age shoot-out; in the other an unheralded turn by Burt Bacharach -- while continuing to hope for the miraculous, an alternative world we haven't yet imagined. Such a miracle doesn't have to be expensive; it can be as ordinary as a bunch of laid-off steel workers in "The Full Monty," learning to take their clothes off without embarrassment as they turn themselves into male strippers.
 "The Full Monty," compared with large Hollywood machines like "The Game" or "The Peacemaker," is positively Luddite in its poverty of means. Its premise -- a group of otherwise hapless individuals who by banding together triumph over their difficulties -- evokes a long line of British movies of various genres. "The Full Monty" makes the formula new by adapting it to the abandoned factories, the unemployment offices and the rundown houses of England's depressed industrial North -- everything associated with the kitchen sink naturalism that displaced those earlier, more heroic British films. Initiated into a scene of unrelieved drabness and despair, we watch as male striptease becomes the healing ritual that restores a lost community, and we are seduced into accepting a resolution that could happen only in the movies.
 We are seduced because we want to be, having come to need the imaginary space on the other side of the screen in the same way that apartment dwellers need mirrors to make their interiors less cramped. Our secret dream is to walk through the mirror and find that the space on the other side is just as real and that we can live there. An ever-vaster entertainment industry does everything it can to make that dream feel real, as it goes about constructing bubble domes within which we can sit for the next thousand years watching variations on all the old favorites. If the variations begin to seem increasingly homogenized, it's only because a globalized industry inevitably favors movies with simplified plots and stripped of local references that impede penetration of foreign markets.
 It won't happen quite so neatly, of course; history is never that cooperative. For a slight sense of where the new plots and the new images might be coming from, you can look (if you can find them) at some of the films that rarely, if ever, make it to the multiplex: films like "Destiny," by the Egyptian director Youssef Chahine, in which the theological disputes of 12th-century Andalusia prove uncomfortably, and violently, contemporary; "Underground," Emir Kusturica's boisterous and confetti-strewn waking dream of Yugoslavia's bloody unraveling, or Abbas Kiarostami's "Taste of Cherry," with its vision of the desolate Iranian spaces (so desolate they beckon to suicide) where urban outskirts merge with wasteland.
 What these films have in common is their acceptance of sudden, drastic change as a permanent possibility; the dangers they contemplate are not generated in special-effects labs. The moment it seems there are no new stories to tell might turn out to be precisely the moment when the world is once again preparing the unimaginable, whether the audience wants it or not.

HEADLINE: Brave New World of Competition

BYLINE: By CHRISTIAN BAUMGAERTEL 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
In the display window of a little corner bookstore hangs an oversized question mark, a poster that Erika Tapp, one of the managers, put up several years ago to attract customers. But recently, this symbol has assumed a significance that Mrs. Tapp did not anticipate: She is beginning to fear for her store's survival.
Mrs. Tapp and her colleague, Irmgard Irle, run the Autorenbuchhandlung, or Authors' Bookstore, a small but well-stocked cooperative in the residential West End of Frankfurt. Their vocation is serving customers with rarified tastes -- readers of experimental poetry and prose by authors like the avant-garde poet Kurt Mautz or the novelist Peter O. Chotjewitz, whose 1968 novel "Island" put him among the pioneers of new literary forms. 
 In much of Europe, booksellers like Mrs. Tapp and Mrs. Irle are convinced that no one can stay in business selling arcane works at full price if some nearby rival offers discounted best sellers. Until now that has not happened. But Mrs. Tapp and Mrs. Irle are concerned that such competition may arise as top officials of the European Commission, under the banner of promoting free trade, take aim at one of the most venerable practices in German publishing: price fixing.
At issue is an age-old industry practice known as Buchspreisbindung, under which booksellers and publishers mutually agree not to mark book prices below the publisher's suggested retail price. The practice, which includes books sold in Austria and Switzerland as well, has been in place for 110 years, but has run afoul of free-trade advocates since the entry of Austria into the European Union in 1996.
While there are similar systems in place in most European countries, the German agreement is the only voluntary price-fixing mechanism that applies across national boundaries, which puts it within the authority of the commission, the executive arm of the European Union. European competition rules generally prohibit price-fixing across borders within the European Union, but the only analogous case so far, the Net Book Agreement in Britain and Ireland, was abandoned in 1995 before the commission could rule.
In this case, though, the industry seems set on defending its current practice as necessary to protect Germany's literary variety. "Books are not just commodities," said Eugen Emmerling, a spokesman for the German association of booksellers and publishers, in an interview. "They are also carriers of information and opinions. This is also about freedom of speech."
The agreement has helped create a large network of small and medium-sized bookstores across the country. There are 2,500 publishers listed in the agreement and more than 9,000 independent retailers.
Whereas production of new titles in the United States has remained stagnant at around 45,000 to 50,000 a year since the book market was liberalized in the 1970's, Germany has tripled its output to well over 70,000, putting it in third place behind China and Britain. And while the retailing sector as a whole suffered a downturn in the last few years, book sales actually expanded to more than 17 billion marks, or about $10 billion, in 1996, up from less than 15 billion marks in 1992.
But even with the price agreement long in place, small stores have been under pressure. Chains like Thalia in Hamburg, modeled after American giants like Barnes & Noble, are increasingly displacing small booksellers in the big cities, while on-line and mail order book businesses are augmenting their market share.
Regensburg-based ABC Bucherdienst, Germany's leading on-line bookstore, doubled its revenue to 6 million marks, or $3.5 million, last year, while Amazon.com, the American Internet bookseller, announced plans for a distribution center in Germany. And in a display of the trend toward larger bookstores, Hugendubel, a Munich-based bookstore chain, recently opened a 40,000-square-foot megastore in Berlin.
An end to the price-fixing, booksellers say, would expose them to a price war in which only big chains could survive.
Mrs. Tapp and her colleague are both shareholders in the Authors' Bookstore, a cooperative owned collectively by booksellers and writers. Founded in 1972 to counter fears of a growing trend toward mass production, the idea of this joint venture is to showcase books that have little or no advertising budget and would probably not make it into the bigger stores.
"The market for demanding literature is always very limited," said Klaus Schoffling, managing director of Schoffling & Company, a small Frankfurt publisher. "If the price-fixing falls, we would lose about one-third of our customers."
Publishers like Mr. Schoffling fear that a concentration in the book market would leave them at the mercy of a few major players who could dictate conditions.
So far, even retailers that stand to profit from a liberalization have refrained from attacking the price agreement. "In purely economic terms, we would be better off without the price-fixing," said Heinrich Hugendubel, owner and managing director of the Hugendubel chain. "But the variety of the book market would certainly suffer. It is a question of our cultural responsibility."
Privately, however, not everybody in the business is as high-minded. "Many of my colleagues are for a removal of the price agreement," said Benjamin Taschen, founder of the Cologne-based publisher Taschen-Verlag. "But if you say that in public, you are a persona non grata. The price-fixing is a sacred cow."
Andre Rettberg, managing director of Librodisk, an Austrian retailing chain that sells books, compact disks, videos and home office supplies, has vowed to bring the issue before the European courts if the commission fails to end the agreement. In the long run, Mr. Rettberg argues, the book market will benefit from competition.
The European Commission has declined to comment on the case until a final ruling is made by the end of the year. But whatever decision is made by Brussels, Mrs. Tapp has made up her mind. "I would not want to work in one of those big chains, where I have no relation to the books I am selling," she said. "For them, books are just sheets of paper."
