HEADLINE: Anna's World;
In Industry of Glamour, Editor of Vogue Turns a Lot of Heads

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
It was fashion week, and there was Vogue's editor, Anna Wintour, at the Marc Jacobs show in her usual front- row seat, wearing her signature sunglasses and a Marc Jacobs gray waffle-knit cashmere sweater.
When Ms. Wintour went backstage after the show earlier this month to congratulate the designer, there was Marc Jacobs, air-kissing well-wishers in the same gray waffle-knit cashmere sweater. 
 On the cover of November's issue of Vogue, there is Stella Tennant, the model, smiling in rum raisin lipstick -- and Marc Jacobs's gray waffle-knit cashmere sweater.
This is the glamorous, cozy world of Ms. Wintour. Perhaps no other magazine editor wields as much influence over the industry the magazine covers. Perhaps no other magazine editor is as personally involved in the publication's subject matter. Indeed, it is sometimes difficult to tell where Vogue ends and Ms. Wintour begins. But between them, the editor and her magazine leave no part of the $161 billion fashion industry untouched.
Now in her 10th year as Vogue's editor in chief, Ms. Wintour has been both deified and demonized. But however people in the industry feel about Ms. Wintour personally, just about all agree she has taken Vogue to a whole new blockbuster level as the bible of fashion -- and that she has become an icon in the process.
"She has the star quality; she is a star," said the designer Oscar de la Renta. "There has never been a Vogue as important as Vogue is now."
So far this year, advertisers have spent $124 million in Vogue, according to Competitive Media Reporting, an ad research firm in New York. And Vogue's publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, said he expected to end the year with close to 2,800 ad pages, making 1997 the best financial year in Vogue's 105-year history.
When Ms. Wintour took over the magazine in July 1988 -- after an undistinguished tenure as editor of House & Garden that followed a stint as editor of British Vogue -- American Vogue had lost its edge.
"Vogue needed fixing," said S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Conde Nast and its parent Advance Publications, who said moving Ms. Wintour had to do with needing her at Vogue, not removing her from what was then titled HG.
Competition in the field has intensified since Ms. Wintour joined Vogue. Elle magazine -- which had threatened to unseat Vogue just before Ms. Wintour took over -- beat out Harper's Bazaar for the No. 2 spot in 1994 and now has 34.6 percent of the market (Vogue has 41.9 percent; Harper's Bazaar 23.5 percent), according to Competitive Media Reporting.
In addition, magazines like Marie Claire and Mirabella have been nipping at Vogue's heels. And television entertainment news shows have come to treat the world of fashion as the new Hollywood.
But with a circulation of 1.1 million, Vogue for the moment seems secure in its position as the industry heavyweight. A strong economy and Vogue's aggressive ad sales have helped the magazine, but some say Ms. Wintour's visibility and mystique are integral to its success.
"She is a major player," said Fern Mallis, the executive director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. "Her influence is terribly important to our industry. Everybody in our business wants to have Anna on their side and to do something that pleases her."
 
Vogue: Powerhouse In Fashion Industry
Ms. Wintour's power stems in large part from her power base. As the Conde Nast flagship, Vogue is able to pay top dollar for location shoots, photographers, models, even the paper it is printed on. But because the wafer-thin, neatly groomed, meticulously appointed Ms. Wintour has become such a public figure, the industry has become as enthralled with her personal style as it is with her magazine.
"She's more than just the editor in chief of Vogue," said Arie Kopelman, the president and chief operating officer of Chanel. "She has become a persona."
Gossip columns and television entertainment news shows seem to chronicle her every public appearance. Photographers at the fashion shows flash their bulbs in Ms. Wintour's face as often as they do Madonna's. Designers look to her for ideas about materials, models and photographers. Retail executives look to her for advice on how to stock their stores. And people in the fashion business just plain look at her.
"The Red Sea parts when she walks through the room," said Andre Leon Talley, a contributing editor at Vogue who has worked with Ms. Wintour for 14 years.
Her look has been copied the world over: page-boy haircut, big Chanel dark glasses, slim-legged pants, short skirts, stiletto heels with bare legs, tight sweaters.
"The haircut and the sunglasses we use in a lot of our ads and on our models," said Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director for Bloomingdale's. "We have done windows that purposely emulate her look. The fashion office looks to Anna to see what kind of accessories she's wearing. She's a taste maker."
 
Advertiser Needs, Editorial Decisions
People notice what she is wearing, how she wears a Calvin Klein outfit to the Calvin Klein show at 11 A.M. and arrives at the Donna Karan show the same day at 5 P.M. decked out in Donna Karan.
Ms. Wintour describes this as a routine gesture of respect. But when she wears a designer's clothes, it registers as considerably more than just a courtesy. "For her to have my sweater on, when she could be wearing anything in the world -- it's pretty great," Mr. Jacobs said in a telephone interview from Paris.
Seeing Ms. Wintour wear certain designers (Mr. Jacobs, Chanel, Calvin Klein) and invite them to her home for parties, some may cry favoritism. And the fashion press has long been suspected of a quid pro quo when it comes to designer's advertisements: I'll give you this many pages of ads if you feature my clothes in the magazine. But Ms. Wintour insists that none of this influences her editorial decisions.
"Most of our major advertisers are people we put in the magazine anyway," said Ms. Wintour, wearing a loden green suit with fur collar and spiked leather boots in a recent interview at her Madison Avenue office. "It's a balancing act; you can't only think about your advertisers."
That said, all other things being equal -- if, she is deciding between two beaded evening dresses of comparable quality -- Ms. Wintour said she would go with the advertiser's. "If I don't, I'll hear about it," she said.
Among fashion magazines, this seems to have become the conventional wisdom. "This is a business, and we are obligated in our business to be conscious of the people who support us," Mr. Galotti said. "If we have the same two dresses, I would hope in every instance we would choose our customer's -- and do."
Nevertheless, there are designers, like Mr. Jacobs, who do not advertise in the magazine, and have still received a generous share of coverage. "We don't have the money; our fashion show is our advertising," Mr. Jacobs said. "It does not govern what Anna shows or what she pushes."
Indeed, Vogue under Ms. Wintour has become known for championing struggling newcomers and helping them along the way, like John Galliano, who -- despite hard times -- rose to become the designer at Givenchy and, recently, Christian Dior.
"We kept putting his clothes in the magazine," Ms. Wintour said.
People in the fashion business say this apparent blurring of lines goes with the territory. Vogue cannot pretend to be an observer, they say. It has a vested interest in the health of the industry, the success of designers, the strength of retail sales.
"Just the way the staff of Variety, I suppose, live and socialize with movie people, we're involved with retailers, designers, fashionable people," Mr. Newhouse said. "Does it bother me? No. I don't think issues of great ideological substance are involved."
And Ms. Wintour makes no bones about where her loyalties lie. "Designers have become really good friends of mine," she said. "I don't apologize for who my friends are."
 
Beauty and Style Are Supreme Values
Because of Ms. Wintour's close relationship with the fashion side of her magazine, some say Vogue's features department has become something of a poor stepchild. And there has been considerable turnover among editors over the last several years. Several former editors interviewed, all of whom insisted on anonymity, said that Ms. Wintour's criteria for articles required that profile subjects be famous, rich or beautiful.
"You can't mention the middle class," one former editor said.
If an article is proposed on someone less than attractive, one former editor recalled, Ms. Wintour has been known to say, "Have you seen her? She's hideous.' "
Editors say Ms. Wintour has killed articles because the accompanying photographs showed unattractive people. They also say that she hires people based on looks. "People who work there have to look a certain way," a former editor said. "If somebody hasn't changed their appearance within six months of getting there, something isn't going right."
While Ms. Wintour said that appearance did not play a role in features content, she said it could be a consideration in hiring. "If we're talking about fashion editors, on the whole it is important to me that they have a sense of style," she said. "And on the editorial side, after a few months they will end up looking like Vogue. It just rubs off that way."
Over the years, people in the industry have become fixated on Ms. Wintour's personal life as well as on her personal fashion style. Much has been made of her potential rivalry with Elizabeth Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar; of her frostiness, which inspired the phrases Nuclear Wintour and Wintour of Our Discontent; of the sunglasses that render her inscrutable, inaccessible.
 
Brusque or Shy? Well, Intimidating.
To some extent, it seems Ms. Wintour's reputation for brusqueness is grounded in reality. "She's basically warmhearted and kind, but she can be the ice maiden," Mr. Ruttenstein said. "If one wants to get friendly with her, you have to wait for her to come to you."
Her colleagues and associates describe her as direct, demanding and involved in every detail. "You know what she wants; she makes it very clear," said Katherine Betts, Vogue's fashion news director. "She's very tough. She can be intimidating, if you don't understand where she's coming from."
And some say that she inspires fear, that people at the magazine and in the industry have been known to quiver in her presence. "People are always afraid of icons, and Anna has become an icon," said Patrick McCarthy, the chairman and editorial director of Fairchild Publications, which publishes Women's Wear Daily. "But I don't think she uses her power unwisely."
Much of the criticism leveled at Ms. Wintour seems to stem simply from a need to knock her off her pedestal and evades the question whether she behaves as a male executive would.
"People say that about anybody who works hard and does well," Ms. Mallis said. "Those characterizations are meaningless. People are incessantly curious about the people they can't get close to."
Moreover, while it may be difficult to imagine a woman of such coiffed control waking up with flyaway hair, talking with food in her teeth, or breaking down in tears, the London-born Ms. Wintour, 48, is allegedly human. She takes her children to school, helps them with homework (she has a daughter, 10, and a son, 11) and says she enjoys a loving relationship with her husband, David Shaffer, the chief of child psychiatry at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
Nevertheless, there is a public image to keep up. Ms. Wintour gets her hair done every morning at home. Conde Nast gives her a clothing allowance that Ms. Wintour would describe only as "generous." She shops by checking off choices in designer's "look books," which catalogue their collections. If designers refuse to accept payment for their clothes, Ms. Wintour said she made a contribution to their favorite charities. She also borrows outfits for various events and gives them back.
And while Ms. Wintour seems a bit weary of Wintour lore, it does not seem to dampen her passion for the job. From the time she dropped out of high school -- presumably a difficult thing to do as the daughter of Charles Vere Wintour, a prominent British newspaper editor, and Eleanor Trego Baker Wintour, the daughter of a Harvard law professor -- Ms. Wintour has been devoted to fashion. Even a promising career as a sprinter failed to grab her.
Part of this may have had to do with the fact that her siblings were academic stars who used to rib her with messages like, "Are you at the hairdresser or the dry cleaner?"
"I didn't feel I could compete," Ms. Wintour said. "So I went the other way."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

Barclays Said to Discuss A Merger With NatWest
Barclays and National Westminster, two of Britain's largest financial institutions, are discussing a merger that would be worth more than $20 billion and would vault the merged concern to the top of the British banking industry, bank advisers say. 
 But several factors make it likely that a deal will not be completed soon, if at all. The advisers say that National Westminster has not welcomed the proposal and that British regulators may balk at the enormous size of the merged bank, which would have assets of 371 billion, or $627 billion. Page D2.
 
Films Find Haven on Small Screen
The market for theatrical release of movies like "Oliver Twist," at left, that are aimed at children has turned more forbidding. As a result, the makers of growing numbers of such films have found themselves pushed into the embrace of television showcases like ABC's "The Wonderful World of Disney." Entertainment. D10.
 
Supercomputer Rebound in U.S.
In a remarkable shift, the United States has recaptured from Japan the No. 1 spot in the competition to build the world's fastest supercomputer. In fact, American companies now manufacture 16 of the 20 fastest machines. D4.
 
Telephone Alternative Gaining
Economy-minded telecommunications consumers are expected to spend about $30 million next year making voice and fax calls over the Internet. But forecasters say the market for Internet telephony will balloon as glitches in the technology are ironed out. An emerging crop of companies is already jockeying for position. D5.
 
Interactive Strategy at Microsoft
Six months after Microsoft bought WebTV Networks, which sells Internet access delivered via television sets, it has become clear that the Silicon Valley start-up is central to the software giant's drive into the global market for interactive digital media. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. D5.
 
Lucent Readies Digital TV Chips
Lucent Technologies has begun shipping a prototype of a new chip designed to serve as a signal receiver in digital television sets, computers and cable boxes. Motorola, meanwhile, said it joined a group that will develop a competing chip. D10.
 
Free Trade Worries Booksellers
Small booksellers in Germany, long protected by stringent price-fixing rules, fear that the end may be in sight for them as European officials promoting free trade take aim at the century-old tradition. D11.
 
Notoriety Helps Video Game's Sales

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: America's Energy Independence

 BODY:
The worldwide scramble to develop new and existing energy sources has become a driving force in contemporary foreign policy. The Clinton Administration, building on America's dual role as the world's largest energy producer and largest energy consumer, has made itself a main player in this new world energy game, promoting increased production at home and abroad. Its sensible goal is to lessen the country's vulnerability to pressures from energy exporters and protect Washington's freedom to make foreign policy based on larger American and global interests.
Global energy supplies are not tight now, but demand is rising quickly, especially in areas of robust economic growth, like the United States, China and Southeast Asia. Last year, the world consumed just over 70 million barrels of oil every day. That is projected to rise to nearly 105 million barrels by 2015. Proven worldwide reserves are now about one trillion barrels, a figure that tends to rise over time with new exploration, cheaper extraction methods and changes in price. 
 America's daily oil consumption was just over 18 million barrels last year, up nearly 10 percent from 1991. Without significant new gains in conservation and efficiency, the United States can be expected to consume more than 22 million barrels by 2015. Imports have been rising even more sharply, and now account for just over half the oil the country uses.
The Administration is right to emphasize developing new low-cost foreign sources. The United States learned the perils of overdependence on Persian Gulf supplies during the 1970's Arab oil embargo.
But there is no strategic justification for the favors, like reduced royalty payments, that the Administration and Congress have been lavishing on domestic producers. The United States can retain its energy independence while relying on foreign sources of supply, leaving much of its own untapped wealth in the ground as a strategic reserve. The Administration has also failed to focus on more efficient use of existing energy supplies and on stronger conservation efforts, whether through taxes, regulation or market-based incentives.
Diversification is not the only motive behind the race for new supplies. There is worry that prices will rise if global consumption grows as rapidly as predicted. Meanwhile, the investment climate has been transformed by political changes in oil regions, like the collapse of Communism in Russia and the Caspian Basin and Latin America's more welcoming attitude toward foreign investment.
The Administration's policies have produced good results in Venezuela, from which the United States now imports more oil than it does from Saudi Arabia. Since 1995, American companies have helped Venezuela sharply increase its production capacity. Washington has promoted business partnerships with Russia's oil and gas industry, in the hope that American technology will help Russia pump more energy at lower cost from aging wells.
Washington has also been wooing the newly independent governments of the Caspian Basin, like Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan, all of which sit astride rich energy deposits or vital pipeline routes. Rightly, it has pressed the case of American companies seeking a share of Caspian energy rights, encouraged the removal of regulatory obstacles and sought consistent standards for cross-border pipeline routes.
But except for Georgia, Caspian area governments have shown scant tolerance for democracy and human rights and have tried to use their leverage with Washington to deflect American pressures on these issues. The Administration should be cautious about the tradeoffs it makes to smooth access to oil. One aim of energy independence is to gain more freedom to pursue larger national goals. Washington should not subordinate these goals to a mindless rush for new energy suppliers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Trying to Use the Saw But Spare the Forests;
80 Years Later, Logging Rebounds

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: FISHKILL, N.Y., Nov. 12

 BODY:
A half-ton log of white oak cut from a Hudson Valley tree thumped from a sorting rack into the mud. "That one's going to Spain," said Brian Arico as he pulled a lever that sent another log rolling in front of him.
Next in line on the rack were several logs of red oak, twice as thick as telephone poles, cut north of Danbury, Conn. "All this red oak's going to Japan and Indonesia," said Mr. Arico, 32, a former logger who has built a thriving company here 50 miles north of New York City, where he exports the hidden bounty of the region's rebounding forests to buyers around the world. 
 Eight decades after the last wave of clear-cutting for farmland and charcoal sheared the forests of New York and Connecticut, oak, maple, cherry, tulip poplar and other trees have matured into lofty stands that are prized on the growing world market for logs and lumber.
As a result, almost invisibly, a substantial logging industry has returned to the wooded areas ringing New York City, with chainsaw-wielding crews offering landowners thousands of dollars to extract valuable trees in areas as close to the city as Westchester and Fairfield County, Conn.
The re-emergence of logging has been driven in part by growing demand for maple and oak, partly because of changing tastes in places like Japan, where the blond wood is now favored over darker, tropical wood varieties, according to several forestry economists. New York and Connecticut have also seen a sharp rise in the harvest of softwood trees like pine, because of sharply reduced cutting on Federal lands in the Pacific Northwest.
The trade means that wooded lots in the region -- if properly managed -- can represent a bonanza for property owners, providing steady income for decades. But it has also spurred some owners to do "liquidation cuts," in which all the valuable trees are taken at once, with no thought to the ecology of the forest.
State environmental officials in New York and Connecticut have created programs to encourage logging methods that keep the forests healthy. Nonetheless, unscrupulous logging crews occasionally cruise neighborhoods to dangle offers of big money, and leave ragged, muddy messes behind. In some cases, timber theft occurs when a cutting crew strays across a property line, lured by a prime specimen of cherry or oak.
Many communities, concerned about the impact of such cutting, have enacted ordinances that limit, or even prohibit, logging. The moves to limit logging have also been driven by the widespread perception among suburbanites that all logging is akin to the destructive practices highlighted in films about the deforestation of the Amazon region or the Pacific Northwest, state environmental officials say.
But state officials and many loggers say that predatory practices are the exception, and that local laws are stifling what could be a profitable and environmentally sound business.
Unlike the clear-cutting in the rain forest, in most cases in the New York region only mature trees are taken, allowing smaller trees to soak up the sunlight flowing through the new gaps in the leafy canopy, and potentially providing another crop of wood 10 or 15 years down the line.
"People think logging is a lot of greed and mess, but if you do it right it helps the animals and the woods," said Michael Shultis, a logger who scours the Catskills for prime stands.
He and other people in the industry say that logging a standing forest is far better than having it sold off to developers, who are increasingly subdividing the land.
"That is a one-way street, and then we've lost a resource forever," said Jeffrey Wiegert, a senior forester for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. Mr. Wiegert helps run a program that offers landowners tax breaks for long-term commitments to forest harvesting.
Recently, Mr. Wiegert hiked into the woods to oversee a crew completing a three-week cutting job at Camp Surprise Lake, a 638-acre summer camp near the Putnam County village of Cold Spring. Michael Ferrucci, a forester from Madison, Conn., had drawn up a decadeslong management plan for the site, leaving a mix of mature and younger trees that would provide harvests well into the next century.
"They're going to smooth the ruts, lay down mulch and seed," Mr. Ferrucci said of the cutting crew's work. "In a couple of years, you won't know they were here."
Squatting on a pile of freshly cut logs that was headed for a sawmill upstate, Mr. Ferrucci carefully counted rings, finding that almost every tree had lived 88 years. "That was probably the last clear-cut for charcoal for the foundries in Cold Spring," Mr. Ferrucci said.
Since that time, forests across New York State have rebounded. In all, the state's forest cover has more than tripled in this century, from 20 percent 100 years ago to 62 percent today.
Mr. Ferrucci said that the history of the forests -- reclaiming what had been open fields -- also helped shape the stands into the valuable resource they have become. Red oak, now prized overseas, has become a dominant species here because it is one of the first type of tree to colonize abandoned fields, he said.
Outside of areas like the Adirondacks, where trees are grown for paper pulp, just about the only clearcutting these days occurs when a forested tract is bought by a developer. Because of this kind of cutting, Westchester, Rockland and other counties near New York City are seeing a net loss of woodlands for the first time in this century, according to state forestry statistics.
Despite the demand for local lumber, the potential for a suburban homeowner to profit by cutting trees is somewhat limited. Some loggers eschew heavily populated areas to avoid hidden hazards that sometimes lurk inside tree trunks. Robert Dermer, who owns a small sawmill, Board Silly, in Ridgefield, Conn., said that suburban trees frequently held nails, screws and other metal objects that could shatter saw blades. "It can be a hook for a hammock or a swing," he said. "Last week one of those porcelain insulators tore us up for a day."
And most logging companies, averse to taking costly trucks and other large equipment into suburban areas, will not approach a landowner with a lot smaller than 10 acres or so. But some do. In eastern Connecticut, David Trowbridge, who works for a large logging company during the week, spends weekends hauling logs from small lots using a team of oxen, to limit the environmental damage from running big machines in the forest.
The bustling export business in hardwood is still largely hidden, and thus continues to take many residents of the suburbs near New York City by surprise.
A few years ago, Michael Morris, a freelance writer, prepared to build a house on his forested two-and-a-half-acre lot in the Westchester town of Ossining. A grove of old tulip poplar trees, some nearly a yard across at the base, stood on the house site, he said, so he invited two sawmills to bid on the timber.
The trees were cut and hauled away. Later, Mr. Morris said, he thought it might be nice to buy some of the milled lumber back to use in the house he was building. "I called the mill," he recalled, "but they said 'You're too late.' They'd already sold all the logs and shipped them to Japan."
Thomas Birch, who works for the United States Forest Service, said it was the Japanese who fueled the last big export boom for hard maple -- which is New York's state tree and is also called sugar maple -- in the 1960's and early 70's. "That's when the Japanese discovered bowling," he said. The wood went into bowling-alley floors and bowling pins.
While in some cases the finished product of the state's harvested wood -- furniture, flooring and the like -- comes back to consumers in the United States, much of it ends up in homes in Japan, in furniture stores in Milan or in vineyards in France.
The white oak being exported by Mr. Arico in Fishkill was slated to be cut into staves in Spain, bound into casks and shipped to a French vineyard to age wine. "They love the taste of our trees," Mr. Arico said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Tame the Beast

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
It is becoming an intolerable threat to American interests and world stability. President Clinton is going to have to deal with it unilaterally, before its reckless, irresponsible, dictatorial leadership destroys us all. Things can't be allowed to continue like this, with all talk and no action. Whatever powers the President needs to meet this threat are fine with me. Whatever it takes, baby, whatever it takes. Because this out-of-control beast has got to be stopped.
I'm talking about the U.S. Congress. 
 If you just took the first 435 names in the phone book, surely, surely you could come up with a more intelligent, worldly body than the 435 narrow-minded, shortsighted, weak-kneed, navel-gazing characters now representing the American people in the House of Representatives. Thank goodness this Congress adjourned Friday for vacation. Who knows what it would have done with another week.
As it was, the Congress spent its last week barring the President from signing any more free-trade agreements, barring the President from paying America's overdue U.N. dues -- at a time when the U.S. is trying to rally the U.N. to deal with Iraq so the U.S. won't have to act unilaterally -- and barring the President from adding $3.5 billion to the International Monetary Fund so that the I.M.F. can better deal with global financial meltdowns before they hit America's shores. Both the I.M.F. and U.N. payments are being held hostage by Newt Gingrich until Mr. Clinton gives in to demands of Republican anti-abortion fanatics.
Let's look at the least understood of these issues: the money to the I.M.F. What Congress does not understand is that, geopolitically speaking, we are in a somewhat new world today. During the cold war, it was regional military conflicts -- from El Salvador to Angola to Vietnam -- that tended to get globalized and regional economic crises, such as in Brazil or the Philippines, that got ghettoized. This was because in the cold war the two superpowers took sides in every regional conflict, making each one a potential global crisis.
Today, it's just the opposite. Because of the absence of any global U.S.-Soviet competition, regional conflicts -- Albania, Algeria, Bosnia -- tend to get ghettoized. Now it is the regional economic crises that get globalized, because of the increasing interconnectedness of markets and information. The domino theory belongs to economics today, not politics.
The shakiest, most important domino out there now is South Korea. You almost wonder today whether South Korea will collapse before North Korea. South Korea is suffering through a string of large corporate bankruptcies and bank defaults. Its corporations, notorious for dubious bookkeeping practices, owe at least $150 billion to foreign banks, many of them Japanese. South Korean investment banks are also big holders of speculative Russian and Asian stocks and bonds, which have recently soured. If South Korea totters, it will hit Japan's banks. And if Japan's banks weaken, they will have to sell some of their U.S. stocks, bonds and T-bills. And if the Japanese yen weakens, it will balloon the U.S. trade deficit, and set off another bunch of dominoes. Indonesia, which owes $100 billion to foreigners, is the other shaky domino.
It would be nice to just say to the South Koreans or Indonesians: "You made your mess; you clean it up." But if they topple, it won't just hit them or Billionaire Bob on Wall Street. It will also hit Joe Sixpack on Main Street. Because Billionaire Bob's trust fund and Joe Sixpack's pension fund are in the same mutual funds.
The problems of Indonesia, Thailand and Korea are largely problems of bad governance, corruption, insider dealings and under-regulated banking systems. They are problems that can only be solved by getting into the internal wiring of these countries and repairing both their software and hardware. The U.S. can't do that -- not without triggering a real backlash. That requires an impartial international institution: one that has both the know-how to fix bad software and the financial clout to tell these countries that unless they make painful internal reforms, they will suffer badly, but that if they do the right thing, the I.M.F. will help cushion the pain.
But if the I.M.F. is disempowered or underfunded, the U.S. will have to deal with the situation itself or just let the dominoes slam into us -- and slam they will. But don't fret, the Congress will take care of us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: IRAQ SENDS SIGNAL IT DOES NOT WANT TO FIGHT WITH U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16

 BODY:
In signs that both Iraq and the United States would like to step back from another conflict in the Persian Gulf, Iraq sent signals today that it did not want a military confrontation, and the United States persuaded Russia, once Iraq's strongest ally, to press Saddam Hussein to back down in the dispute over weapons inspections.
In Baghdad, the official Iraqi News Agency reported that at a Cabinet meeting President Hussein "stressed that Iraq was not seeking a confrontation with the American administration." 
 And Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, in an interview with Le Figaro in Paris, said Iraq would readmit American arms inspectors if the United Nations agreed to change the makeup of the inspection teams, with equal representation given to each permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. That offer was rejected by American and United Nations officials, who said that Iraq should not dictate who is on the teams.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking in Kuwait before flying here for meetings with Saudi officials, explained the American request to Russia by saying, "In our effort to build diplomatic pressure, we look to Russia and France, because of their unique ability to communicate with Saddam Hussein, to convince him that the only way out is to change course."
France, like Russia, has long ties of sympathy and commerce to Iraq, and American officials said that French leaders are also considering a separate approach to Mr. Hussein. But the French commitment to do so was "less clear" than Moscow's, a senior American official said.
"The Russians in particular and the French to some extent have had influence over Saddam Hussein in the past," said the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin. "The idea is that they would be in the best position to convey to him the steeliness of the will of the international community to resolve this problem."
The Russian intervention is another indication of American reluctance to get into a military confrontation with Mr. Hussein that could break international solidarity.
"When we feel we've exhausted all diplomatic options, you'll know it," a senior American official said. "But we're taking a deliberate, diplomatic approach. We want to see a diplomatic solution. It is the strength and unity of the international community that has the best chance of succeeding."
The latest crisis with Iraq began on Oct. 29 when Iraq vowed to expel American weapons inspectors working for the United Nations and to shoot down American U-2 spy planes. The inspectors were part of teams monitoring Iraq's compliance with United Nations resolutions demanding that it destroy all its weapons of mass destruction. The American inspectors were thrown out of the country on Friday, and the United Nations pulled out most of the other inspectors as well.
The Russian commitment today came in a series of telephone calls between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin and their foreign ministers, Ms. Albright and Yevgeny M. Primakov.
The Russians have come out most strongly against the use of force against Iraq, and many American officials still blame Mr. Primakov, then working for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for trying to forestall the allied attack to drive Iraq out of Kuwait six years ago. But American officials said the Russian effort may be the best chance remaining to persuade Mr. Hussein to let weapons inspectors return without warfare.
Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright have also spoken with President Jacques Chirac of France, and his Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine. Mr. Chirac condemned Iraq today and said France was "in solidarity with the U.N. and the United States in this crisis."
The announcement of an imminent diplomatic approach to Mr. Hussein seemed in part intended to reassure nervous Arab countries that the West was not interested in rushing to war. Arab newspapers have been contrasting the American willingness to pressure Iraq with its reluctance to pressure Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to come to better, faster terms with the Palestinians.
But the announcement also provided welcome distraction from Ms. Albright's brief and embarrassing visit to Doha, Qatar, to an American-sponsored economic conference boycotted by nearly every Arab country despite intense American diplomatic pressure on them to show up.
In fact, Ms. Albright's daylong shuttling from Qatar to Bahrain, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia was made necessary because their foreign ministers refused to attend the Doha conference, which Israel did attend.
Because senior Arab officials were not there, she had to go to them, to discuss the confrontation with Iraq and what moderate Arabs might be prepared to do about it.
This linkage between Arab unhappiness with Mr. Netanyahu and reluctance to support American military pressure against Mr. Hussein is acknowledged privately by American officials, who in public try to keep the issues separate.
In her speech to the business and trade officials in Doha -- their numbers limited by the boycott from countries like Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and even Morocco -- Ms. Albright urged Israeli and Palestinian leaders to find the courage to make peace.
"Unfortunately, time is not on our side," she said. "Every week that goes by without a renewal of serious momentum towards peace creates new opportunities for the enemies of peace, and adds to the discouragement of those on all sides who urgently desire peace."
In Kuwait, Ms. Albright met Defense Minister Salaam al-Sabah, who said that Kuwait wanted a peaceful resolution to the crisis, but understood that "Iraqi intransigence opens the door to all options that might not be in the interests of Iraq."
In Bahrain, Ms. Albright met with members of the United Nations Special Commission, who were pulled out of Iraq when Mr. Hussein ordered its American members expelled. Ms. Albright received a detailed briefing, closed to the press, from commission leaders about what they had been discovering about Iraq's continuing efforts to develop weapons of mass destruction.
She then spoke to a group of inspectors and nurses, to thank them "for your sacrifice for world peace." She praised them for facing "personal risk without flinching, without complaining, and, I might add, without surrounding yourselves for protection with women and children." Mr. Hussein has gathered Iraqis, including children, around palaces and other likely targets of any missile or air strikes.
"You are not the instrument of one nation or region," she said, "but instead you are the means for the enforcement of international law."
But some of the inspectors were quietly uncomfortable with the attention Ms. Albright lavished on them, cameras rolling, because it seemed to ally them more closely with Washington than with the United Nations generally, the very accusation Iraq levels against the commission.

HEADLINE: Israel's Controversy Over Religion Affects Donations by Jews in U.S.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
While American Jews are contributing record sums to Jewish causes at home and abroad, thousands of them are withholding or diverting up to $20 million in donations this year, partly to protest the religious and peace policies of Israel's conservative Government, leaders of Jewish organizations say.
Bernard C. Moscovitz, the chief operating officer of the United Jewish Appeal, the primary fund-raising vehicle for Jewish social welfare in Israel and the United States, said that Jewish giving was still 2 percent higher this year than last year but that giving had been running 8.5 percent ahead of last year's pace until some leaders urged that donations be withheld or diverted. 
 Others warned that the withholding or redirecting of contributions could turn into a major philanthropic rebellion if Orthodox Jews succeeded in cementing their control over religious life in Israel. They also said a shortfall of $15 million to $20 million in projected donations in a year of huge Wall Street profits was significant.
"Twenty million dollars is not chopped liver," said Jonathan Levine, the American Jewish Committee's regional director for the Midwest.
The dispute over Orthodox control, or "who is a Jew," as the religious pluralism controversy is known, points to deeper changes under way in Jewish philanthropy.
Experts on American Jewish giving say several factors are responsible for a growing percentage each year of Jewish giving to non-mainstream Jewish and non-Jewish institutions and causes.
These factors include an aging Jewish population and a generational shift in giving patterns, a high rate of religious intermarriage and social integration among Jews, a changing relationship to Israel and a fraying of what has been the most successful fund-raising system in history -- the United Jewish Appeal and the 189 local Federations in Jewish communities throughout North America that raise and allocate money for social welfare at home and abroad.
"We're experiencing a sea change in Jewish life which has extraordinary implications for Jewish giving," said Gary N. Tobin, the director of Brandeis University's Cohen Center for Modern Jewish Studies.
The change is partly obscured by the fact that it comes during a time of record giving.
American Jews, who constitute close to 2.5 percent of the United States population, raised as much as $4.4 billion in 1995, said Jack Wertheimer, the provost of the Jewish Theological Seminary and author of an article on philanthropy in the 1997 American Jewish Year Book.
The annual Federation-United Jewish Appeal campaign, the fund-raising centerpiece of local Jewish communities, will raise about $737 million this year, as opposed to $721 million last year. Including donations to its $4 billion endowment and other gifts, the Federation will raise a total of $1.6 billion.
Contributions to religious institutions, though they are not added up nationally, probably total as much as $1.4 billion a year, not including gifts to synagogue capital campaigns, Mr. Wertheimer said.
In addition, other Jewish charities will probably raise a minimum of $700 million, not including charity for Jewish education, an ever-growing $1 billion economic sector.
Altogether, Mr. Wertheimer estimates Jewish giving to Jewish causes at more than $4.5 billion this year.
But while overall Jewish giving is growing, until this year annual donations to Federation-United Jewish Appeal campaigns, when adjusted for inflation, were on the decline since 1989, along with the number of contributors to these campaigns and the percentage of their charity that is directed to Jewish causes.
Moreover, two-thirds of Jewish "megagifts" -- that is, gifts from Jews of more than $10 million -- that a generation ago went to Jewish causes now go to museums, colleges, libraries and other nonsectarian institutions, said Jeffrey R. Solomon, president of the Andrea and Charles Bronfman Philanthropies.
"It's a difficult time in Jewish philanthropy," concedes Richard Wexler, a Chicago real estate lawyer who is national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal.
 
The Gifts Shift To Foundations
Mr. Moscovitz argues that the annual campaign's relatively lackluster performance was caused partly by the fact that the same donors gave the Federation system an additional $1 billion from 1990 to 1995 for "Operation Exodus," the emergency campaign to help Jews leave the former Soviet Union and resettle in Israel. Still, even he agrees that there is some cause for concern.
Most Jewish giving now goes through independent family foundations or takes the form of gifts to endowments, often with strings attached. That limits the Federation system's ability to direct the donations as it once did and the collective power wielded by such communal giving.
"This weakens the ability of the Jewish community to plan, coordinate and allocate its resources," Mr. Wertheimer said.
As a result, organized Jewish giving to education and the poor in America and what Professor Tobin calls "philanthropic Zionism," that is, expressions of support for Israel through giving to the traditional vehicles of the secular Jewish community, are also under pressure.
Analysts say some of the changes reflect a deep confusion and frustration within the American Jewish community over Jewish identity at home and discontent with Israel's policies abroad. But no issue has polarized giving to Israel as much as the religious pluralism legislation now pending there, action on which has been deferred until January.
The legislation would bar non-Orthodox Jews from the country's 150 religious councils, which distribute some $70 million a year in Government funds, and would bar anyone but Orthodox rabbis from converting people to Judaism in Israel.
In the eyes of many American Jews, 85 percent of whom are unaffiliated or belong to the Reform and Conservative streams, this would effectively disenfranchise them.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who last night addressed the Council of Jewish Federations, says he understands the threat the issue poses to American Jewish-Israeli solidarity. But he also knows that political parties representing Orthodox Jews control 23 of the 66 seats in his coalition in the Israeli Parliament and thus, if not appeased, could topple his Government.
Mr. Moscovitz said Federation-United Jewish Appeal donations had been up 8.5 percent this year until an effort to forge a compromise on the religious legislation collapsed this summer.
In response, prominent American rabbis, lay leaders and Jewish commentators urged American Jews to redirect contributions to Israel from the Federation system, which works closely with the Israeli Government, to alternative charities like the New Israel Fund, the Abraham Fund, the Israel Policy Forum and others whose programs were primarily aimed at promoting tolerance, democracy and pluralism in Israel.
 
Federation Agrees To Aid Diversity
Such appeals have infuriated Federation officials, who accuse their proponents of fostering disunity among Jews and putting sectarian and political concerns ahead of the needs of disadvantaged Jews. Sixty percent of United Jewish Appeal money, they emphasized, goes to American Jewish causes.
But the Federation system has responded by agreeing to increase the $15 million it now spends on programs in Israel that promote religious diversity, tolerance and democracy to $20 million next year.
And following an agreement last month with representatives of the Reform and Conservative communities, it has also pledged to encourage Jews who favor those goals to make a supplemental contribution to the Federation campaign specifically for such programs.
Still, few think that would prevent a plunge in giving to the Federation system should the legislation in Israel be approved. Professor Tobin said his research showed that no other single issue "cuts as much to the philanthropic core," for two reasons.
First, he said, American Jews, given their high rate of intermarriage -- 52 percent in 1991 -- "don't want anyone telling them that their children are not really Jews."
Second, "Americans Jews, like all Americans, don't like extremists, and they don't like theocracy," he said. "So the notion that one branch of Judaism controls the political scene and disenfranchises them is totally at odds with their democratic, pluralistic American identity and values."
Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, the spiritual leader of Temple Beth-el, a reform congregation in Great Neck, N.Y., said he would continue calling for a retargeting of Jewish contributions until the Orthodox Jewish hold on Israeli politics was broken.
"The Non-Orthodox American Jewish community is fed up with supporting -- through Federation and religious yeshivas -- the very groups that attack us with rocks and excrement while we pray at the Wall," he said, referring to an incident that occurred in August at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.
Mr. Moscovitz asserted that appeals for retargeting had led not to rechanneled aid, but to a modest reduction in contributions. "Some people have just used this as an excuse not to give," he said.
But interviews with spokesmen for several alternative Jewish charities report that their fund-raising is up sharply.
For example, Gil Kulick, the communications director of the New Israel Fund, which was started in 1979 with a grant of $100,000 from 10 San Francisco families, raised a record $13.5 million last year and has seen a 25 percent increase in contributions this year.
"We're up by about 50 percent in the last two years," he said, attributing the increase to Jewish fury over pluralism.
 
Impact of Youth And Cold War's End
But the changing relationship between American and Israeli Jews may eventually have an even more drastic effect on giving.
"Apart from the religious pluralism problem, the perception that Israel's economy is booming and that external threats appear to be disappearing in the wake of the cold war make these the most challenging years we've ever faced," Mr. Wexler said.
Moreover, younger Jews, comfortably integrated into American life and most of them born after the Holocaust and the creation of Israel, simply have a different relationship to the Jewish state.
"For my kids the Holocaust is ancient history, and they have no emotional relationship to Israel," said Michael Steinhardt, a leading New York philanthropist. "No wonder the proportion of dollars going Jewishly is diminishing."
Younger Jews, in fact, are far less likely to give to and through the Federation. Studies show that only a quarter of Jews age 32 to 50 give, and that only 12 percent of intermarried households, as opposed to 59 percent of all-Jewish households, give to the United Jewish Appeal.
Still another factor is growing donor demand that Jewish charity begin at home. In response, the proportion of Federation dollars going to Israel has been declining for a decade -- from an average of 60 percent to 40 percent. But donors are also demanding greater control over how their donations are spent.
That has triggered an explosion of giving through some 11,000 family foundations or funds, 3,500 of which are not under the Federation umbrella. And there are a growing number of endowments, three-quarters of which make gifts that are directed or restricted. All told, Mr. Wertheimer said, gifts to campaigns, endowments and foundations totaled more than $8 billion from 1990 to 1995, only half of which were under Federation control.
Direct gifts to Israeli and American Jewish institutions through, for example, "friends of" groups, have also soared in the last decade and now equal twice the amount of money that goes to Israel through Federation channels. Such groups and family foundations increasingly form what Mr. Wertheimer calls a "parallel philanthropic universe" to that of the Federation, drawing away resources and talent.
Mr. Moscovitz denies that this independent giving reflects, to some extent, dissatisfaction with the Federation system, which some donors call arrogant and overly bureaucratic.
The United Jewish Appeal, he said, is trying to expand its donor base of 800,000, whose average gift is $900, through new mailings four times a year, as well as through more personal contact with and greater flexibility for givers. He also points to the United Jewish Appeal's program that allows donors to specify where they want some of their money spent.
But increasingly, he said, the Federation system will evolve as an agent that marshals funds and provides choices for independent and Federation donors. He and others in the field also see philanthropic "partnerships" between federated and independent givers, as well as Jewish and non-Jewish groups, as the wave of the future.

HEADLINE: Collapse of Japan's 10th Largest Bank Sets Off Large Market Rally

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 17

 BODY:
A major Japanese bank collapsed this morning in a new reminder of the weakness in Asia's financial system, just as American and Japanese officials were discussing new ways of responding to financial emergencies in the region.
The bank that collapsed, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd., is not one of the handful of leading Japanese financial institutions known around the world. But it is the nation's 10th largest bank and the first of Japan's 10 major "city" -- or commercial -- banks to require a bailout. 
 Its failure, and the intervention by the Bank of Japan, spurred a tremendous rally in stocks here, as traders apparently sensed that the Government would be getting more involved in bailing out the country's ailing financial sector.
Alarmed by the weakness of Asian countries generally and the risk that the economic crisis in Asia will spread, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka of Japan today expressed concern about the fall in the value of the yen.
The Japanese Government immediately intervened after the bank failure. It extended emergency central bank loans and arranged for another bank, North Pacific Bank, a regional institution based in the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido, to take over the failed bank's deposits and outstanding loans.
"Since all deposits will be protected, I strongly urge depositors not to worry and to take sensible actions," Mr. Mitsuzuka said at a news conference this morning. Mr. Mitsuzuka was clearly concerned about the possibility of bank runs that would add to the instability of Japan's banks.
Japan's action on the bank came after of week of intensive exchanges with the United States, which has expressed growing alarm at Japan's descent into another economic slowdown and at the precarious state of the nation's banks. Mr. Summers hailed the intervention on the failed bank and said that "the market's response appears to confirm the importance of decisive action."
Indeed, stocks soared on the news of the bank's failure. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up a dizzying 1,200.80 points, or 7.96 percent, to 16,283.32, led by banking stocks.
Mr. Summers and Mr. Mitsuzuka also issued separate statements, clearly coordinated, warning against further depreciation of the yen.
The United States has been concerned that bank collapses and economic weakness in Asia, and especially in Japan, could ripple across the Pacific and damage the American financial system. One risk is the loans that American banks have made to Asian borrowers, and another is that Asia will buy less from the United States and export more, thus raising America's trade deficit and eroding economic growth.
The dollar traded lower on the show of support, though it later rebounded. In late afternoon trading, the dollar was quoted at 125.26 yen, down 0.14 yen.
Mr. Summers flew to Tokyo via Europe, where he had discussions with economic officials, and from Tokyo he will travel to Manila, the Philippines, for consultations with Government officials from around the region. One reason for the trip appears to be to coordinate policies that would be necessary in the event of a financial emergency in South Korea or elsewhere in the region.
Though he was vague about precisely what he talked about, Mr. Summers said he had agreed with Mr. Mitsuzuka to work for "new arrangements to promote regional cooperation and enhance prevention" of crises. Mr. Summers said the two countries had also agreed on "new initiatives to strengthen the capacity of the International Monetary Fund to respond effectively in event of financial emergencies."
One problem for American and Japanese officials alike is that they want to prepare for financial crises without undermining confidence and increasing the likelihood that there will be crises to address. South Korea, in particular, is insisting that it is in fine shape, and so it is diplomatically awkward for Western countries to make plans in case it is not.
Last week, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin wrote a letter to Mr. Mitsuzuka, expressing concern that Japan was not acting quickly enough and effectively enough to address the problems in the banking sector. Mr. Summers added to that message by expressing "concern about the outlook for the Japanese economy" and calling for "effective action to restore domestic demand growth."
The last point reflects concern Japan will try to export its way out of its financial difficulties, at the expense of the United States economy.
Earlier this year, Japan increased its national sales tax, curbing domestic demand just as it was mired in a slowdown.

HEADLINE: Netanyahu Calls for Unity In U.S. Talk

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel issued a call for unity tonight to some 3,500 leaders of American Jewish groups gathered here as word spread of diplomatic activity aimed at getting the battered Middle East peace process off its knees.
Mr. Netanyahu, who arrived from London, where he had met with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, was said by aides to be working on a possible return there on Monday night, perhaps for a meeting with King Hussein of Jordan or with the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. 
 Israeli television reported that Mr. Netanyahu was cutting short his American trip to meet with Mr. Arafat in London. Palestinian leaders denied that a meeting was in the offing, but Israeli officials here declined to rule it out.
Mr. Netanyahu told the American Jews that his Government was the only one "capable of uniting the people of Israel behind a permanent peace settlement with the Palestinians and a peace treaty with Syria."
He repeated that while Israel would not compromise on security, it wanted to offer Palestinians "unfettered self-rule." Addressing the Palestinians directly, he said: "Our hand is extended in peace. Accept it and you will bring untold benefits to both our peoples, who pray and yearn for the completion of the longed-for peace between us."
Mr. Arafat met with Ms. Albright in Switzerland on Saturday. The Secretary said after that meeting -- as she had after conferring with Mr. Netanyahu on Friday -- that more decisive action was required from each if the four-year-old Israeli-Palestinian peace plan was to move ahead.
Mr. Arafat reiterated his commitment to peace but insisted, as had Mr. Netanyahu before him, that the fault for the delay lay with the other side.
Mr. Netanyahu was to go tonight to Los Angeles, where he was scheduled to address the World Affairs Council on Monday and take part in a fund-raising dinner for an Orthodox Jewish religious school movement, Aish Hatorah. The dinner is to honor the actor Kirk Douglas, who has discovered his Jewish roots and faith in recent years.
Mr. Netanyahu's original schedule had him staying in Los Angeles until midday Tuesday to urge local industrialists to invest in Israel, whose economy has grown more oriented toward high technology.
But the last portion of his trip seems open to question if one or more of the meetings being negotiated in London materializes.
A summit meeting between Mr. Netanyahu and King Hussein is not likely to produce dramatic results. Jordan remains the best friend Israel has in the Arab world, but an attempt in September by the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad to kill a member of the militant Palestinian group Hamas in broad daylight on a street in the Jordanian capital heightened tensions between the Governments.
The United States would doubtless like to shore up relations between them at a time of potential military action against Jordan's eastern neighbor, Iraq. Should the Clinton Administration choose to go ahead in efforts to force the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, to allow American weapons inspectors back into his country, it would have an easier time if its allies in the area were on good terms with one another.
Tonight, Mr. Netanyahu urged all Jews to stand behind President Clinton "when he is facing down Saddam Hussein."
Across a broad range of relationships, these are not easy times for the Israeli Prime Minister.
His reception by the American Jewish community leaders here was correct but not very warm, because of widespread opposition among American Jews to a proposed bill in Israel that would write into law Orthodox rabbis' control of conversions to Judaism there. The talk in the hallways of the Indianapolis Convention Center, where the annual General Assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations is being held, was one of defiance to perceived Israeli Orthodox control over liturgy and Jewish identity.
Mr. Netanyahu needs the support of the Orthodox political parties in Israel to remain in power and has therefore not been willing to cross them on this issue. But he did make clear to those assembled here that affiliates of the Conservative and Reform movements need not fear that they were second-class Jews, by his lights.
"No power on earth can rob any Jew of his or her identity," he said. "Every Jew is a legitimate Jew." He also assured them that he would insist that conversions performed by non-Orthodox rabbis outside Israel continue to be recognized by the state.

HEADLINE: Grim Reckoning in Japan -- and Beyond

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow is the author of "The House of Morgan," "The Death of the Banker" and a forthcoming biography of John D. Rockefeller Sr.

 BODY:
The financial whirlwind sweeping through Southeast Asia has now struck the Japanese stock market with the swirling fury of a tsunami. On Friday, the Nikkei 225 average tumbled to 15,082, its lowest close in two years. Despite sharp gains in early trading today, this downward trend portends problems of a magnitude dwarfing those emanating from the smaller East Asian countries. So long as financial instability seemed confined to Hong Kong, Thailand et al., one could blandly argue that the problem was somehow small and containable. Now that the contagion has infected Japan, the global ramifications could be profound.
The East Asian crisis can be traced to the demise of Japan's "bubble economy" in the early 1990's. After years of wildly inflated prices, Tokyo stock and property markets plunged, hobbling local banks with hundreds of billions of dollars in bad loans. At the time, regulators should have goaded banks into writing off bad debt, packaging it as securities, or selling the collateral behind property loans. Instead the Government opted for a myopic policy of mystery and evasion, protecting a banking system that had become dangerously overextended. Through lower interest rates, it hoped the banks would muddle through without painful surgery on the fundamental structure of Japan Inc. 
 Flush with spare capital in a stagnant economy, the banks embarked on a manic lending spree in Southeast Asian nations rife with speculation, corruption and politically biased investment. Before long, the lending had assumed proportions that beggared description. From a mere $40 billion in early 1994, Japan's Asian lending ballooned to $265 billion, with $87 billion stored up in Hong Kong alone.
At first, the Japanese were attracted to Asia by rich loan spreads of a sort unavailable in more mature industrial economies. By last spring, however, the lending binge had taken on a feverish, desperate air. American and European bankers watched aghast as Japanese banks "dumped" loans in the region -- that is, extended credit at ridiculously thin profit margins to grab market share. By massively exporting capital to Southeast Asia, the Japanese banks re-created the bubble economy that had been punctured at home and that had sent them abroad in the first place. At the same time, Japan targeted Southeast Asia as its main arena for export growth and industrial expansion. Small wonder that stock investors have pounced on Japan as a leading casualty of the region's tribulations.
Last week's nervous selling dragged the Nikkei average down into a murky zone that threatens the very moorings of Japanese finance. Unlike American banks, Japanese banks can count as capital a portion of the paper profits held on their huge stock portfolios. Under Japan's distinctive system of cross-shareholdings, banks own big blocks of shares in their major borrowers, and vice versa. These reciprocal arrangements mean that nearly half the shares in Tokyo never really trade but are frozen in cartel-like ties that define Japan Inc., binding bankers and client companies in economic clusters known as keiretsu.
Since banks and brokers can employ unrealized stock gains as capital, the financial system has an eerily elastic quality. When the stock market soars, bank capital -- and hence lending -- expand in a self-sustaining process; conversely, when the stock market sinks, capital and lending contract. So long as banks had hidden assets from stock market gains, they had extra capital to cushion emergencies and cash hoards to shore up sagging profits.
For several years, economists have worried that the fateful intertwining of the stock market and banking system would create what the British financial analyst Andrew Smithers has termed a "doomsday machine." Such pessimists conjured up this nightmare scenario: the Tokyo market sinks to a point at which it wipes out hidden assets on banks' stock portfolios, sharply eroding their capital. This then provokes a steep recession, causing stock prices to plummet further in a downward spiral. Some analysts think that we are approaching just such a threshold, or even that we breached it last week.
The critical question is the level at which the doomsday machinery is triggered. Jesper Koll, an economist at J. P. Morgan in Tokyo, estimates that Japan's three long-term credit banks shed all their stock gains when the Nikkei sank below 16,000. The country's 10 large commercial banks, he contends, would cross the line at 15,100, a level penetrated last week. And the seven leading trust banks would exhaust their hidden gains at 14,900. As for Japanese life insurers, Neil Rogers of UBS Securities reckons that their stock profits vanished at the 16,900 level.
The Japanese banks thus face an extraordinary situation of triple jeopardy. They must grapple with hundreds of billions of dollars in loans to a troubled region -- loans mostly denominated in dollars that have become much more expensive after the currency devaluations in Southeast Asia. The banks must weather this crisis while working off at least $250 billion in home-grown problem loans. And they must accomplish this miracle amid a self-reinforcing contraction of their stock portfolios and capital. Already international creditors are demanding a special risk premium on loans to Japanese banks.
The repercussions of this swelling crisis could be grave. For seven years, the Japanese have tried to rejuvenate their sluggish economy. After glimmers of hope, the gross domestic product experienced a startling 2.9 percent drop in this year's second quarter. Since Japanese companies rely heavily on cheap bank credit, they would expire in record numbers if the falling stock market shrank the banking sector. This would tip Japan into recession, depreciate the yen, and stimulate a fresh export offensive that would worsen already tense trade relations with the United States.
In the 1980's, it seemed that Japan had evolved a humane, efficient variant of capitalism. The Government sheltered banks and brokers from failures, while banks bailed out client companies and ailing competitors. Profitability was invariably subordinated to growth and stability. By suspending the cleansing action of the marketplace, the Japanese aimed to soften the rough edges of capitalism. That strategy has now been exposed as a destructive pipe dream. By propping up failing banks or merging them with healthy banks, the Japanese simply bottled up problem loans and tempted bankers into risky credit practices.
Paradoxically, the Japanese Government recently began to allow the winnowing of bankrupt financial institutions. When Hanwa Bank perished last year, it was the first Japanese bank allowed to fail in the postwar era. Nissan Mutual Life was declared insolvent in May while Sanyo Securities collapsed this month under $3 billion of debt. Hokkaido Bank has now become the first casualty of the latest phase of the crisis. And the Liberal Democratic Party is reportedly considering a plan to buy preferred stocks from the banks, causing the Nikkei to rally sharply this morning.
In the long run, the Tokyo stock market crisis will likely dissolve the bonds uniting banks with bureaucrats and corporate clients. As the Government regulates banks instead of cosseting them, bankers will balk at serving as docile instruments of industrial policy. As credit is priced more realistically, companies will desert traditional bankers for the capital markets and jettison their bank stocks. The banks, in turn, will liquidate stock portfolios that simply obligate them to succor sick borrowers. Most important, the new owners of the liberated stock will demand profitable performance from corporate managers.
Next year, the "big bang" will initiate a period of financial deregulation in Japan. Bankers, brokers and insurers will finally compete on common turf, ending the clubby insularity of Japan Inc. Meanwhile, global investors will have to deal with the grim aftermath of the ancien regime.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Steven Salerno)

HEADLINE: Working Moms Take the Blame;
Try Flexible Scheduling

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"When Waaa Turns to Why" (Business Day, Nov. 11) addresses some of the difficulties of working parents, but from an all-too-traditional perspective. You present the issue as an artificial dichotomy, suggesting that a parent must choose between career and family. 
 Work-at-home arrangements, compressed workweeks, flexible work scheduling and on-site child care all allow parents to see more of their children during regular working hours without sacrificing time at the job.
More and more companies offer these options as part of an overall family-friendly program -- among them Unicom, Colgate-Palmolive and Hewlett-Packard. The corporate culture in these companies helps to insure that parents who take advantage of such programs are not relegated to the "mommy track" with its reduced opportunities for career advancement.
 
JONATHAN HICKMAN
Research Associate
Council on Economic Priorities
New York, Nov. 13, 1997

HEADLINE: Dropping Barriers Can Rescue Third World Poor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is curious that you refer to the defeat of "fast track" authority as "disturbing testimony" to the power of union campaign money (editorial, Nov. 13), ignoring not only the campaigning of environmental, religious, consumer and farm organizations but also the effort that corporations have expended to sway policy makers on this and other trade issues. 
 Furthermore, while you are right that the North American Free Trade Agreement did not create the devastating economic crisis in Mexico, it is integral to the adjustment strategy that was imposed 15 years ago by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and that has impoverished millions of Mexicans and gutted national and local production.
According to the Mexican Action Network on Free Trade, since Nafta's inception, average real wages in Mexico's manufacturing sector have dropped 31 percent while productivity has risen by 32 percent. Until workers can freely organize to defend their interests, there is no reason to expect that this trend will not continue.
 
KAREN HANSEN-KUHN
Washington, Nov. 13, 1997
 
The writer is Latin America program coordinator, Development Group for Alternative Policies.

HEADLINE: OUT OF CHINA: ANALYSIS;
China Loses, China Wins

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 16

 BODY:
By releasing Wei Jingsheng, China's leading dissident, and sending him into exile in the United States, Chinese leaders have made a major concession to international pressure. They have also rid themselves of China's most potent political martyr.
Mr. Wei, whose eloquent writings on democracy landed him in jail 18 years ago, and whose refusal to bend kept him there, was taken from a labor camp on Saturday night and brought to Beijing to see his family before departing this morning on a flight to Detroit. 
 Mr. Wei's brother described him as buoyant, carrying the same upbeat spirit that seemed to keep him alive through years of suffering in China's gulag.
After so many years of worrying about Mr. Wei's survival, his family and supporters seemed understandably thrilled that freedom had finally come.
And yet Mr. Wei, 47, is not fully free. He is not free to live in China. In exile, his influence on Chinese affairs may dissipate, and it is unlikely that he will be allowed to return to China any time soon.
One of the biggest unanswered questions on Mr. Wei's first day of freedom was why he dropped his long-standing refusal to leave China.
Perhaps, as family members said, Mr. Wei's health has deteriorated so much that he needs medical treatment. It has been hard to gauge the seriousness of his heart disease or other ailments since he has been in custody, but it may also be that Mr. Wei was given no choice.
The timing of Mr. Wei's release is clearly entwined with United States-China relations and, specifically, with President Jiang Zemin's trip to the United States two weeks ago.
American diplomats deny that they made any concrete deal with China to exchange Mr. Wei's freedom for greater trading rights. But that swap is now one of the net results of the visit, and it is hard to imagine that the long negotiations preceding the summit meeting in Washington did not involve careful discussion about what each side wanted most.
Mr. Jiang, in addition to his craving for the international recognition of a full state visit in Washington, wanted the United States to drop restrictions on China's ability to buy nuclear technology and military helicopters. Done.
Now, with Mr. Wei's release, Beijing has reciprocated by giving the Clinton Administration what was at the top of its wish list: a human rights triumph to point to as a tangible yield from "engaging" Beijing.
Releasing a political prisoner may seem like a simple act without cost. Yet China's leadership is still so sensitive about internal critics that it generally fears that letting one go might be interpreted as a sign of political weakness.
That one man can so threaten the system, as Nelson Mandela did when he was in a South African prison, is a sign of how fragile the system remains.
For the moment, however, releasing Mr. Wei makes China's leadership look relatively confident and secure. This has been Mr. Jiang's year, emerging from the shadow of Deng Xiaoping, the political patriarch who died in February, to assert himself as China's foremost leader, presiding over the return of Hong Kong in July and dominating a Communist Party Congress in September.
Whether Mr. Wei's release is a solitary gesture, or a signal of a broader political relaxation by Mr. Jiang, remains unclear for now.
Political experts here feasted on the possibilities raised by Mr. Jiang's ambiguous remarks at Harvard University, when he used the word "mistakes" in answer to a question about the Government's relations with the people and the use of military force to suppress the 1989 Tiananmen demonstrations. Whether those comments were intended only for a foreign audience, or for a domestic one as well, is still under debate.
International human rights advocates, while welcoming today's news, argued that Mr. Wei's release did not alter the basic state of human rights in China.
"What we need to see is a structural legal change that will lead to the freeing of other dissidents in China," said Robin Munro of Human Rights Watch in Hong Kong.
The official reason given for Mr. Wei's release was medical, since the authorities needed to justify their previous refusal to let him go.
"Wei Jingsheng has been released on parole for medical treatment because of his illness," the New China News Agency reported in a short dispatch. "Wei has gone abroad for medical treatment."
Mr. Wei's release was not reported on tonight's main evening news broadcast, which instead reported on a trip to Japan by Prime Minister Li Peng and on a conference on maternal care in Beijing.
But Wei Jingsheng is not a household name in China. Although he became the hero of the Democracy Wall movement in 1979, Mr. Wei had no role in the defining political event of the current generation -- the massacre around Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989 -- and is not as well known as the student leaders of that year.
Yet his case has attracted great interest by those who follow the progress, and lack of it, in China's efforts to develop a rule of law. Within the leadership, Mr. Wei's piercing analysis and cogent arguments for greater democracy seem to have provoked considerable concern, and Mr. Wei's letters to top leaders are said to circulate widely.
In a culture that strongly discourages individuality, and that demands submission to authority, Mr. Wei is an extremely unusual figure.
Stubborn, patient and humorous, Mr. Wei has been unyielding in his insistence that true prosperity will come to China only with true democracy. He has rejected the counterargument that China's booming development of recent years is a sign that economic advancement can come without a political complement.
Since 1979, when Mr. Wei was first sent to prison, he has been free for only six months. He served many years in solitary confinement and has said he was subjected to repeated beatings, as well as constant psychological pressure.
Mr. Wei was released in 1993, six months before his 15-year sentence was complete, and just one week before the International Olympic Committee was to award the 2000 Olympics that Beijing was competing for. Sydney won in a close vote.
At the time, Mr. Wei ignored warnings from the authorities to keep quiet. Under China's unusual legal system, his "political rights" were still revoked, meaning, among other things, that he was not supposed to speak out publicly on political issues.
Mr. Wei argued that it was his right to speak freely, and he continued to write and publicize his political views. A meeting with John Shattuck, the American Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, in Beijing seemed to infuriate the authorities, who soon took Mr. Wei into custody again.
"There's no question that he was arrested the second time because of the meeting with Shattuck," said Tong Yi, Mr. Wei's assistant at the time, who was later jailed for 18 months before being allowed to go to the United States, where she is now a political-science student at Columbia University.
In violation of Chinese legal regulations, Mr. Wei was in custody for 18 months before he was charged with a crime. In court, in a session his family was barred from attending, he was convicted of plotting to overthrow the Government, and was sentenced to 14 more years in prison.
Having said that he had no regrets about sticking to the views that put him in prison for the first 14 1/2 years, Mr. Wei seemed destined to serve 14 more.
Conditions were extremely harsh at times. Mr. Wei's family, allowed to visit him irregularly, complained that other prisoners had been encouraged to beat him, and that he was being kept in a brightly lighted cell with a glass wall so that prison guards could observe him 24 hours a day.
Mr. Wei's brother, Wei Xiaotao, said that Mr. Wei now suffers from heart problems and high blood pressure.
