INTERNATIONAL A3-17
 
U.S. and Iraq Show Signs Of Easing Confrontation
Iraq and the United States showed signs of stepping back from a conflict over United Nations arms inspections. Iraq reportedly offered to readmit Americans as long as other Security Council members were equally represented on inspection teams. American and United Nations officials rejected the offer, but Washington persuaded Russia, once Iraq's strongest ally, to try to persuade Iraq to back down. A1
 
Albright to Visit Pakistan
Secretary of State Madeline K. Albright is to arrive in Pakistan today for meetings that are expected to focus on fighting drug trafficking. A1 

Chinese Dissident in U.S.
Wei Jingsheng, China's most famous dissident, arrived in Detroit after Chinese leaders released him from prison for medical reasons and sent him into exile. He was immediately admitted to a hospital. A1
 
Scandal Shakes Chubais
Anatoly Chubais, Russia's free-market crusader, is reeling from a scandal over a questiondable book deal in which three of his closest aides and allies were purged last week. The dismantling of his team and the damage to his reputation will almost certainly hobble his bold plans for Russia's economic reform. A3
 
Jews Withhold Israel Donations
While American Jews are contributing record sums to Jewish causes, thousands are withholding or diverting up to $20 million in donations this year, partly to protest the religious and peace policies of Israel's conservative Government, leaders of Jewish organizations say. A1
 
Aides to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who addressed American Jewish leaders in Indianapolis, said he might travel on to London, perhaps to meet King Hussein of Jordan. A11
 
Protests erupted in the West Bank after the funeral of an 8-year-old Palestinian boy, Ali Jawarish, who was shot by an Israeli soldier. A8
 
Bank Fails, Japan Rallies
Japan's 10th largest bank collapsed, offering a new reminder of the weakness in Asia's financial system. The failure, and intervention by the Bank of Japan, spurred a tremendous rally in stocks as traders apparently sensed that the Government would get more involved in helping the financial sector. A14
 
Hungary Says Yes to NATO
Hungarian voters overwhelmingly approved joining the NATO alliance in a referendum that barely attracted enough voters to make it valid. The referendum was being closely watched in Washington, where the Clinton Administration has made the eastward expansion of NATO the centerpiece of its foreign policy in Europe. A6
 
NATIONAL A18-21
 
Chicago Tries to Protect Children in the Crossfire
Officials in Chicago are studying ways to protect children at Jenner Elementary School in the Cabrini-Green housing project, where frequent violence forces the children to be kept inside during school hours. One plan would move the children to another school, taking them out of the path of gang gunfire. Another would create a kind of security zone, in which parents would be paid, given white arm bands and trained to stand on dangerous corners; "safe havens" would be set up at churches, marked with white flags, so that children could duck inside to safety. A1
 
Sweeping Adoption Changes
President Clinton is preparing to sign into law the most sweeping changes to the nation's adoption and foster-care system in nearly two decades. The changes, approved by Congress last week, are intended to make it easier to remove children from abusive families and speed up their adoption. A20
 
Indian Suspicions Grow
Leaders of impoverished American Indian tribes say they believe the Government will help Indians -- but only those Indians who have helped the Democratic Party, preferably in the form of six-figure campaign contributions. "If you have money, you get a meeting and you get what you want," said George Newago, the chairman of the Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians of Wisconsin, whose proposal for a casino was rejected by the Interior Department in 1995. A20
 
A Deadly Quest for Money
The police in LaPlace, La., said a gambling habit and lust for a piece of the American dream drove a mechanic to kill six elderly residents within a 20-mile radius of his family home. Most of the dead were elderly; most were found in their homes with their pockets turned inside out. A18
 
Protest at Army Base
Nearly 600 protesters who had tried to deliver petitions calling for the closing of the Army's School of the Americas were arrested at Fort Benning, Ga., after defying police orders not to enter the base. Most of the 597 people who were arrested were charged with trespassing and released. Critics of the school say it has been a training ground for dictators and their henchmen, while its supporters say the school provides training in democratic principles and human rights. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Logging Quietly Returns To the Woods of Suburbia
A substantial logging industry has returned, almost invisibly, to the wooded areas ringing New York City, driven in part by a demand for maple and oak in Japan and elsewhere on the world market. State environmental officials in New York and Connecticut have created programs to encourage logging methods that keep the forests healthy. Nonetheless, unscrupulous logging crews occasionally cruise neighborhoods as close to the city as Westchester and Fairfield County, Conn., to dangle offers of big money to property owners, often leaving behind ragged, muddy messes. B1

Antonio Fernandez, the leader of the Latin Kings gang who is known as King Tone, was arrested on a residential street in Brooklyn Saturday night along with 31 other members of his gang after the police received reports of disorderly conduct by armed men, the authorities said. No weapons were recovered and after a full day in custody, 24 gang members, some of them teen-agers, were to be charged only with unlawful assembly and disorderly conduct, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney said. HEADLINE: Once Upon a Time, And for Years After

BYLINE: By EDEN ROSS LIPSON 

 BODY:
At noon on a dress-down Friday a few weeks ago, the bright white offices of Simon & Schuster Children's Books were empty. The corridors, lined with colorful books and posters, were deserted. The large conference room, however, was jammed, warm and smelled of sandwiches. The entire staff, about 75 people, from editors and assistants to receptionist, casually attired, had gathered for a brown-bag lunch, to hear Margaret K. McElderry answer questions about a publishing career that spans more than half a century.
Ms. McElderry, who was not dressed down but elegant, as usual, may have found the questions familiar. But as usual, she was modest and inclusive. 
 "I was an English major, like so many of you," she recalled, "and an economics minor, though you'd never know it. It was the Depression, and when I graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1933, I told the career adviser I wanted to live in New York City and work with books."
" 'You have absolutely nothing to offer publishing,' " Ms. McElderry remembered being told. The line has drawn a big laugh for decades, along with the adviser's follow-up: "Why don't you consider library work?"
The woman who spoke so lightly is living history. At 85, she is the last of her class of editors who brought American children's books into the postwar world, the direct link between what latest estimates put as the $1.79 billion children's book industry and the handful of remarkable editors, mostly women, who created it.
This week as schools, libraries and bookstores celebrate National Children's Book Week, Ms. McElderry is celebrating a milestone of her own, the 25th anniversary of her publishing imprint, now one of six lines of children's books at Simon & Schuster.
She began her career by following the adviser's suggestion. After a year at the Carnegie Library School in her hometown, Pittsburgh, Ms. McElderry came directly to the New York Public Library. In retrospect, the library was perfect training for editing children's books, the ones that endure and are read by succeeding generations: "The Borrowers" or "Ginger Pye" or "The Dark Is Rising" or "The Changeover," all of which Ms. McElderry published.
She worked for Anne Carroll Moore, the library's first Superintendent of Children's Work, initially as the junior assistant (salary $1,320 a year), dusting the office, answering the pedestal telephone that stood on Miss Moore's desk and cataloguing and reading each book the library bought.
She spent part of the summer of 1934 in the Children's Room of the Central Harlem Branch, and after a stint in Mott Haven in the Bronx, she returned to 42d Street for nine years as Miss Moore's first assistant. She studied the special collections of picture books, the books in foreign languages and others designed to serve the wide variety of children in New York's multiracial, multinational population.
In those years, everyone in the world of children's books came to call on her boss, Miss Moore, that steely New Englander whose conviction that children deserved the best inspired and supported trade publishing of children's books.
The New York Public Library's annual list of best books, which Miss Moore initiated in the 1930's and Ms. McElderry carefully typed each year, continues to carry weight. (The 1997 list will be distributed on Thursday at the Donnell Branch in Manhattan, where the central children's collection is housed. The 31st Anne Carroll Moore lecture will be open to the public and delivered by Katherine Paterson, the distinguished Newbery-medal winner.) The list, like the other key library awards, has a measurable impact in a field where the librarian's sticker seals of approval translate into bookstore sales.
During World War II, Ms. McElderry left the library to work in the office of war intelligence in London. On her return to New York, she took over the children's department at Harcourt Brace. The children's book editors of the day -- Ms. McElderry, Ursula Nordstrom at Harper & Row, Elizabeth Reilly at Thomas Y. Crowell, Mae Massie at Viking and others -- worked with great independence. They nurtured artists and writers, building up the backlists of titles that demonstrate the development of talent over decades and continue to bring in revenues.
Editors had "their writers," but great courtesy prevailed among the publishing houses. A 1952 letter from Nordstrom to Natalie Savage Carlson, included in the forthcoming collection of Nordstrom's letters, "Dear Genius," gently turns down a manuscript and suggests that Carlson send it "to Miss McElderry," because "she does lovely books."
 
An Editorial Mind Open to the World
 At Harcourt Brace Ms. McElderry's career was marked with firsts. Alone in that generation of editors, she saw a world beyond the United States and found and published picture books as well as novels from abroad. She was the first to publish German and Japanese postwar novels for children. And she introduced young American readers to Europeans, including Lucy Boston ("The Children of Green Knowe") and Helme Heine ("Friends"), Australians like Patricia Wrightson and South Africans including Niki Daly.
By the time the Children's International Book Fair at Bologna, Italy, began in 1966, Ms. McElderry already knew the agents and publishers who traded there. She was, and still is, shown new work of many European artists and writers before any other American publisher.
She was the first editor whose books won both the Newbery and the Caldecott Medals in the same year, 1952, a feat unequaled until 1994. In 1996, with many other honors in between, two novels she edited, "Yolonda's Genius" by Carol Fenner, and "The Moorchild" by Eloise McGraw, were Newbery Honor Books.
Susan Hirschman, the editor of Greenwillow Books, clearly remembers meeting Ms. McElderry for the first time, in 1955, in circumstances somewhat similar to the recent brown-bag lunch at Simon & Schuster. Mrs. Hirschman was then an entry-level secretary at Alfred A. Knopf and a member of an informal networking group called Young Publishers. In the crowded bedroom of an apartment on the West Side, she listened, inspired, as Ms. McElderry described her work.
Years later, when Mrs. Hirschman took over the children's department at Macmillan and attended the important librarian meetings and conventions, she modeled herself on Ms. McElderry. "She stood like a figurehead next to her booth," Mrs. Hirschman said, "eager, ready, upright, bristling with energy, and people flocked to talk to her."
There was one important interruption in the story Ms. McElderry tells of her career in publishing. She had been at Harcourt Brace for 25 steadily profitable years and, like her woman colleagues at other houses, she had consciously shunned publishing adult books or entering the boardroom frays, though her list supported many adult literary whims.
 
Coping With Change In Style and Life
 At noon on the Friday before the Fourth of July weekend in 1972, she was called to a meeting by two of William Jovanovich's associates and was told to dismiss her entire staff save one and take early retirement at the end of the month.
"I asked, 'Why are you doing this? What have I done?' " she says, still baffled by the experience. "And he said, 'You've been fine, but the wave of the future has passed you by.' "
On the contrary, the wave carried her to Atheneum where she set up shop that fall with her own imprint. Neal Porter, now the publisher of DK Ink., was a marketing associate in 1982 and remembers Pat Knopf, the publisher of Atheneum, calling him in to discuss the succession when Ms. McElderry retired.
Margaret K. McElderry Books, the first children's imprint to carry the name of the editor, survives while a dozen or more eponymous imprints have appeared and disappeared in the last quarter-century. It continues, although Atheneum was bought by Macmillan and Macmillan by Robert Maxwell and the imprint is now part of Simon & Schuster which in turn is part of Viacom.
Surrounded by bureaucratic procedures and paperwork, she still publishes about 25 books a year, many of them from abroad.
Stephen Roxburgh, the publisher of Front Street Books, remembers attending his first board meeting of the Children's Book Council, the trade association, nearly 20 years ago when he was at Farrar, Straus & Giroux. "I looked around the room at the photographs of the past presidents and happened to notice that Margaret's term was the year I was born. When I mentioned it to her later she laughed merrily and then asked so politely, 'When was that?' " (It was 1950.)
"Much is for the better," she tells the junior assistants and editors. "Books for children have come to be seen in their rightful place and an important part of the development of children."
"Of course," she adds, "in the old days we used to sit and read. Now I don't read at all in the office; I do it at home on Wednesdays and on the weekends."
As for the marketing departments that have supplanted library and editorial training as the key background for editors, she says, "They get the books out, but with the emphasis on the bottom line. I doubt that anyone talks about quality anymore."
"The people upstairs," she says of the executives who run the publishing conglomerates, "don't have a clue about who we are or what we are doing."
Meanwhile Ms. McElderry, with a substantial number of successful surgical repairs behind her continues at a pace that leaves other editors breathless. Her calendar at Simon & Schuster shows one long trip to Europe in the spring, with stops in England and at the Bologna Children's Fair, at all the major children's book conferences, sales conferences and with a few speaking engagements.
Whenever possible, she accompanies her authors to their speaking engagements, a mannerly relic of protocols past. In the 1950's, for example, she regularly accompanied her authors on special Children's Book Week tours of the elaborate book fairs that were sponsored by The New York Times, The Chicago Tribune, The Cleveland Plain Dealer and The Detroit Free Press.
On Wednesdays she reads at home in the parlor that faces the toddler playground on Washington Square in Greenwich Village, and in August she reads in her unmodern cottage on Nantucket, which is just as her parents left it. She has no plans for retirement and a full list of titles to publish next year.

An article on Nov. 17 about the children's book editor Margaret K. The article also misstated the number of this year's Anne Carroll Moore Lecture, delivered at the Donnell Branch of the New York Public Library for National Children's Book Week. It was the 41st in the series, not the 31st.

HEADLINE: From Under the Sea, Signs of Climate Jolts

SERIES: THE WARMING WORLD: Confronting climate change.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
AS scientists seek to improve their imperfect understanding of how and why the world's climate is changing, evidence continues to mount that most of the last 10,000 years -- long thought to be a benign era whose stability was crucial to the rise of civilization -- has in fact been typified by episodes of warmth, cold, drought and flooding more extreme than anything experienced in the 20th century.
About a thousand years ago, for instance, Europe basked in warmth that nurtured vineyards in Britain and allowed the Norse to colonize Greenland. At roughly the same time, what is now California was baking in centuries-long droughts, dwarfing the mere seven-year droughts of today. Early South American civilizations literally dried up and blew away. But only a few centuries later, in what is called the Little Ice Age, severe cold gripped much of the world, sending glaciers coursing down mountainsides, freezing European harvests and starving much of the populace. 
 Natural variations like these raise important questions in the scientific debate that underlies efforts by the nations of the world, at a conference beginning Dec. 1 in Kyoto, Japan, to cope with the prospect of climate change. How much of the global warming observed in the last century is natural, and how much has been caused by waste industrial gases that trap heat in the atmosphere? And how might natural climatic fluctuations modify and interact with whatever climate changes caused by people are in store for the future?
Now an important new element has been added to the emerging picture of pervasive, natural climatic change in the Holocene, the period since the vestiges of the last ice age vanished 10,000 years ago. Centuries-long cold spells much like that of the Little Ice Age have occurred more or less regularly, roughly every 1,400 to 1,500 years, report researchers, led by Dr. Gerard Bond at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, in the current issue of the journal Science. They discovered the oscillations by analyzing climatic signals in ancient ocean sediments in the North Atlantic.
The quasi-periodic swings were found to persist over the last 32,000 years, which is as far back as it was possible to date the sediments by the radiocarbon method. This means that the 1,500-year cycle also operated in the last ice age.But during that period, the cyclical cold spells were much more severe than in the Holocene. In the ice age spells, Dr. Bond said, the surface temperature of the North Atlantic where the sediment samples were taken dropped by about 9 to 14 degrees Fahrenheit. In the Holocene spells, the drop was about 2 to 3.5 degrees.
How that translated into changes in the air temperature is unclear. Scientists believe, on the basis of other evidence, that air temperature dropped by 1 to 3 degrees in the Little Ice Age.
In the late 19th and 20th centuries, the global temperature has bounced back from the Little Ice Age cold, rising by about 1 degree and suggesting that the world may now be in the early stages of a centuries-long cycle of natural warmth. "We could be coming out of the colder phase into the warmer phase of the cycle right now," Dr. Bond said. On the other hand, he said, the warming of the 20th century could be a relatively temporary warming blip, and the cold of the Little Ice Age might resume. He and his colleagues discovered many such temporary interruptions of previous cold phases.
The dominant view among climate scientists is that the warming of the 20th century has been caused at least in part by emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, which are produced by the burning of coal, oil and natural gas. The prevailing view also says that further warming is in store as a result of the emissions and that such warming could seriously disrupt the earth's climate system in the next century. Representatives from some 150 countries are to convene in Kyoto to negotiate cuts in emissions.
But no one knows how much of the observed warming is attributable to the heat-trapping gases and how much is caused by natural fluctuations in climate. In an attempt to sort things out, scientists have been focusing more on past climates, searching for patterns that might shed light on the present and future.
While the impact of natural variations on present-day climate cannot yet be pinned down with precision, Dr. Bond said, "it's probably fair to say that we're seeing a component of natural variability" in the last century's warming.
Other recent studies have suggested that the world is in the early stages of a natural warming phase and that, if so, any warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions would come on top of the natural temperature increase, delivering something of a one-two punch.
That has been suggested most recently by other new research reported in the current issue of Science. Investigators headed by Dr. Jonathan Overpeck of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Geophysical Data Center in Boulder, Colo., examined climatic indicators in lake and ocean sediments, tree rings and glacier ice in the Arctic. They found that from 1840 to the mid-20th century, Arctic temperatures warmed to their highest levels in 400 years, ending the Little Ice Age in those latitudes. The researchers attributed the early part of this bounce-back warming to natural causes but said that greenhouse gas emissions had probably contributed after about 1920.
All the recent findings say only so much about where the present-day climate fits into the long-term pattern of natural variations. The 1,500-year oscillations discovered by Dr. Bond and his colleagues, said Dr. Delia Oppo, a paleooceanographer at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute at Woods Hole, Mass., "are not perfectly periodic so we don't really know where we are in detail -- it's not that cut and dried." But "if we can nail the timing more clearly," she said, "it really helps us when we're looking at global warming." Dr. Oppo wrote a commentary on the Bond team's study in Science.
The Overpeck team, writing in Science and referring to its study of the Arctic, cautioned against efforts "to simply extrapolate past patterns of change into the future." That will "ultimately fail to anticipate future Arctic climate change and its impacts," the scientists wrote. Reliable predictions, they said, will require computerized climate-system models that simulate the long-ago changes now being reconstructed.
While precision eludes scientists who are researching ancient climates, a raft of studies in recent years has made it clear that the conventional view of the Holocene as an even, tranquil interval in climatic history is in error.
Compared with big climatic swings of the past, like the ice ages and the super-warming of the Cretaceous period, which melted almost all the world's ice before ending some 65 million years ago, the Holocene variations are small. But compared with the experience of everyone alive today, they seem large indeed.
The catalogue of Holocene climatic variability is large and growing. Several times in the Holocene, for instance, great stretches of the American West have been converted by drought into expanses of windblown sand like the Sahara. Starting about 3,300 years ago, the upper Mississippi Valley experienced a series of what would today be called 500-year floods.
Archeological and climatological evidence suggest that a number of pre-Inca cultures rose and fell in tune with big droughts. Starting about 1,100 years ago, California experienced droughts lasting 220 years and 140 years, both more intense than present-day droughts lasting less than a decade. The 20th century, scientists say, has actually been part of a California wet period. The droughts a millennium ago coincided with a similar drought that caused the collapse of South America's most advanced pre-Inca empire, a nation-state called Tiwanaku. That was roughly the same period when the Norse colonized Greenland and Britons tended vineyards.
Drought has also been implicated in the collapse of the classic Maya civilization in Yucatan, and a 300-year drought is believed to have brought the Middle East's earliest known empire, that of the Akkadians, to its knees some 4,200 years ago.
And now, thanks to the Lamont-Doherty team's study, there is the evidence of semiperiodic cold spells of millennial length. The team analyzed corings taken from ocean sediments off Ireland and southeastern Greenland.
The corings contained two kinds of evidence. One was grains of sand deposited on the sea floor when cold water north of Iceland periodically moved southward. The water carried ice, and sand was released from the ice when it melted in the more southerly latitudes. More sand at a particular time, the scientists reasoned, signified more sea ice and thus a movement of cold water southward. That, they inferred, cooled the climate.
The second kind of evidence involved tiny animals called foraminifera that live in oceanic surface waters. Their calcified shells also fall to the sea floor when they die. Certain kinds of these animals thrive in colder waters, some in warmer ones. The researchers found cold-water foraminifera in the same seabed strata as bigger concentrations of sand grains.
Together, this evidence indicated the existence of the 1,500-year cycle (1,470 years with a margin of error of plus or minus 500 years) of alternating cold and warm spells. The cycle is independent of, and superimposed on, the longer cycle in which ice ages come and go every 100,000 years or so, the researchers concluded.
The team's coring record stopped just short of the Little Ice Age, but Dr. Bond said that event appeared to have been the latest in the series of 1,500-year cold cycles. Other studies of ocean sediments have previously demonstrated that the Little Ice Age reached its coldest point about 300 years ago, that an even colder cycle occurred about 8,200 years ago and that there were instances of pronounced rises in temperature, to somewhat higher levels than today's, 1,000 and 2,500 years ago.
The cause of the 1,500-year oscillations is unclear. It could have to do with changes in the sun's output, some scientists say, but the Bond team favors some sort of mechanism within the climate system involving interactions between the atmosphere and ocean currents.
Deep ocean currents transport heat around the globe and are particularly important in delivering it to the North Atlantic region. Many scientists believe that interruptions or weakenings of the currents are involved in large-scale climatic changes. In the current issue of the journal Nature, a study headed by Dr. Jess F. Adkins of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology links the beginning and end of the last interglacial period around 120,000 years ago to abrupt changes in these deep currents.
That interglacial period was similar to the Holocene in that it marked a warm interval between ice ages. Because of the apparently major role of the ocean currents, many scientists express nervousness about the possible effects of greenhouse warming on the currents.
For example, computerized climate models indicate that global warming would cause more water to evaporate from tropical oceans and be carried northward, where it would condense and fall as rain or snow, said Dr. Scott Lehman, a paleoclimatologist at the University of Colorado in Boulder who wrote a commentary on the Adkins study in Nature. The extra influx of fresh water, he said, could dilute the salt content of the heat-transporting current, and the density conferred by salinity affects the capacity to carry heat.
Less salinity "tends to weaken the conveyor" of heat, he said. That could cool the North Atlantic region substantially, but the overall warming exerted by greenhouse gases would probably keep the rest of the world warmer.
In any event, he said, "the stability of interglacial climate is delicately poised with respect to the ocean circulation." To the extent that climate is governed by natural oscillations, Dr. Lehman said, "we may excite that process by fossil fuel burning."
 
Warming World
 This article is one of a series that has appeared since Aug. 12 on the science, politics and economics of climate change with the approach of an international meeting in Kyoto, Japan, beginning Dec. 1 to discuss limits on greenhouse gases.

SECTION: Section D; Page 12; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Information Technology Field Is Rated Largest U.S. Industry

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Sales by the computing and telecommunications industries have grown by 57 percent during the 1990's, to $866 billion, making those businesses an increasingly important force in the nation's economy, according to a study to be released today.
Indeed, the field of information technology -- often defined as both computing and telecommunications -- is the nation's largest industry, ahead of construction, food products and automotive manufacturing, the study concluded. 
 The study, sponsored by the American Electronics Association and the Nasdaq stock market, which lists the shares of a large number of high-technology companies, represents perhaps the most comprehensive statistical portrait to date of what is called "the new economy" -- populated by high-technology companies that generate new wealth, new work practices and new challenges in public policy.
The study, based on Commerce Department data, is titled "Cybernation: The Importance of the High-Technology Industry to the American Economy." A large part of the report's intended audience is in Washington, where a growing number of high-technology policy issues are being debated. Those issues include whether to establish national educational standards, whether to relax export curbs on data-scrambling software, whether to impose special taxes on Internet commerce and whether to raise immigration quotas to allow more skilled workers into the United States.
The report also provides Silicon Valley with some useful intellectual ammunition as its entrepreneurial leaders increasingly yet uncertainly try to gain influence in Washington.
"Whether we like it or not, high-technology issues are going to be front and center in Washington and in state capitals during the next few years," said William Archey, president of the American Electronics Association, a trade group.
"At the state and national level, policy makers have a lot of positive impressions about the high-technology industry, but often very little knowledge of it," Mr. Archey said. "The biggest public policy threat to the high-technology field is the ignorance of technology and of how these industries work."
The electronics group is being joined by a number of new high-technology lobbying efforts. These range from the strengthened Washington presence of companies like the Microsoft Corporation to the formation last summer of the Technology Network, a Silicon Valley group headed by John Doerr, general partner of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, and James L. Barksdale, the president of the Netscape Communications Corporation.
So far, the younger computer companies have generally tried to promote their positions with small offices in Washington and without being big contributors to political campaigns. That approach is very different from the one favored by the other side of information technology, telecommunications, an industry that deploys corps of lobbyists and makes sizable political contributions.
For purposes of the new study, telecommunications was grouped with computer hardware and software as a single field mainly because the technologies are so closely linked -- and becoming more so, as the nation's communications system makes the transition to the digital technology of computing.
The high-technology sector, the study reports, generated 6.2 percent of the nation's output of goods and services in 1996 and employed nearly 4.3 million people. Workers in the field earn wages 73 percent higher than the average wage in the overall private sector, the report shows.
Productivity -- or output per worker -- in the high-technology field is also growing sharply. From 1990 to 1996, as high-technology revenues increased 57 percent, to $866 billion, the report said, employment rose 7.2 percent, to 4.26 million.
The revenue and employment figures in the study were assembled from the Government's statistics, grouped by type of business, a system called the standard industrial classification, or S.I.C., codes. The study included sales and jobs data reported by companies in 45 of these industrial groups.
Using Government statistics to define a field as broad as high technology is tricky. But some analysts say that the study's methodology was fairly conservative. For example, the report excluded semiconductor manufacturing machines and electronic games because those two businesses fit into much broader S.I.C. groupings; if they had been included, they would have bloated the overall information technology numbers.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Rise on Benign Industrial Production Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Rebounding from early weakness, Treasury securities prices moved higher yesterday, after a benign industrial production report for October alleviated some fears of inflation among investors.
The 30-year bond gained 14/32, to a price of 100 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.06 percent, from 6.10 percent on Friday. Volume was somewhat lighter than it had been as investors awaited today's consumer price report; on average, analysts expect a gain of two-tenths of a percent over all in the October Consumer Price Index, with a one-tenth of a percent gain excluding the volatile food and energy categories. 
 While industrial production in October rose by a healthy five-tenths of a percent, that was less than analysts expected. And Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said, "Slower gains are in store due to both negative upcoming trade effects from Asia and also the recent softening in U.S. retail sales of durable goods."
The market reacted favorably to the report, as investors concluded that it added to the recent signs of a slowing economy, which would reduce the need for an interest-rate increase to head off inflation. But for the interest-rate-sensitive bond market, Mr. Harris added, next month's industrial production report could be more significant; it will be issued on Dec. 15, a day before the next meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy.
Bond prices were also helped yesterday by a drop in oil prices as it appeared less likely that the standoff between the United States and Iraq would result in military action.
Initially, the market was down after a strong rally in overseas stock markets. The big gains, particularly in Tokyo stocks raised concerns among Treasury investors that the recent strength in the bond market, fueled by a so-called flight to quality because of concern over volatility in global stock markets, might now reverse itself.
William McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a speech to a group of German mortgage bankers, indicated that he was growing more confident that the Asian financial crisis was close to ending. "Still that doesn't mean there won't be additional swings in prices," he said. "We shouldn't assume that the markets are already fully stabilized."
Analysts said yesterday's weekly auction of new Treasury bills saw moderate demand, in line with expectations. The average rate at auction was 5.165 percent for both the three-month and six-month issue. Even though the slowing of the flight to quality from overseas generally pressured the bill market yesterday, the auction was helped by tightened supply. The Treasury sold only $14.5 billion of bills, down from $15 billion as recently as early October.

HEADLINE: Crude Oil Prices Take Big Drop Amid Talk of Iraq Compromise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil posted its biggest drop in a month yesterday as Iraq and the United States sought to resolve a dispute over weapons inspections without a military confrontation that could disrupt world oil supplies.
In other markets, orange juice reached a six-month high on a Florida cold snap and coffee rose. 
 December crude oil fell 74 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $20.26 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a seven-week low, dragging down heating oil and gasoline prices.
Iraq is the source of about 1 percent of the world's oil supply under a United Nations agreement that allows Iraq to export $2.14 billion of oil every six months to buy food and medicine. The agreement, an exemption from broader United Nations economic sanctions, comes up for renewal Dec. 5.
Iraq expelled American inspectors last week and Washington dispatched a second aircraft carrier to the Persian Gulf, moves that helped send crude oil prices 2.5 percent higher late in the week. The Middle East accounts for a third of global oil supplies.
After Iraq offered a compromise, a State Department spokesman said the United States was considering a proposal to allow Iraq to sell more oil as one of several options to encourage Iraq to comply with weapons inspections.
The drop in crude oil helped send December heating oil down 1.69 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 57.85 cents a gallon, and December gasoline down 1.55 cents, or 2.5 percent, to 59.44 cents a gallon.
Orange juice jumped on speculation that a cold snap in Florida over the weekend could signal a crop-damaging frost ahead.
"There's a freeze scare in Florida today," said James Cordier, an analyst at Allendale Inc. in St. Petersburg, Fla. "That scares people into buying futures contracts."
Orange juice for January delivery rose 2.25 cents, or 3 percent, to 84.70 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange, the highest price for a most-active contract since May 19.
Coffee rose on anticipation that an industry report from the Green Coffee Association would show that stockpiles plunged last month.
Coffee for March delivery rose 1.3 cents, or eight-tenths of a percent, to $1.5275 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
After markets closed, the association said inventories declined 283,000 bags during October, to 2.011 million.

HEADLINE: Approving the Rail Link to Kennedy

 BODY:
Of the 10 busiest world airports, New York City's John F. Kennedy International has a dubious distinction. Although 42 percent of its arrivals are headed for Manhattan's central business district, it does not have a decent rail link to the city. Today the Federal Aviation Administration can help the region's economy, and all users of the airport, by approving the Port Authority's request to help finance a $1.5 billion rail link with revenue from a passenger surcharge.
The 8.4-mile rail link that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would build in Queens from Jamaica to J.F.K. is by no means the best mass-transit option that travelers deserve, namely a seamless, one-seat ride all the way from the airport to Manhattan. But after decades of dithering, this critical link, which would connect the airport to the Long Island Rail Road and three subway lines, is a move in the right direction. The Port Authority's promise to make the transfer at Jamaica simple and to design this line so that it can be easily transformed someday into a one-seat ride makes this option palatable. 
 The Air Transport Association, the airlines' industry group, opposes the plan and wants the revenue invested instead in projects that would expand aviation capacity and improve the airport itself. But there is ample precedent for investing in rail. The Port Authority has already used the surcharge for a 1.1-mile rail link that ties Newark Airport to New Jersey Transit and Amtrak.
Approval of the Port Authority's request by the F.A.A. would help cut highway congestion and spur Kennedy's expansion. Equally important, travelers would no longer feel as though getting to and from Kennedy was an Outward Bound experience.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Zurich Group to Buy a Big Piece of a Hong Kong Investment Bank

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Zurich Group has agreed to pay $200 million to become the biggest shareholder in Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., a fast-growing Asian investment bank that has been hurt by the plunge in regional stock and bond prices.
The agreement, announced on Sunday, gives Peregrine the backing of a global powerhouse with $85.5 billion in investments. For the Zurich Group, a rapidly expanding Swiss insurance company that is one of the world's biggest money managers, the purchase of the 24.1 percent stake provides it with a ready-made avenue for growth in Asia. 
 Peregrine, one of Asia's biggest investment banks outside Japan, said last month that it had incurred losses of $37 million from equities and derivatives trading between July and October as Asian securities markets and currencies tumbled. But it denied that it had lost as much as $1 billion during the year as a whole and said a sale of the firm was not in the works.
On Nov. 1, the Japanese Bond Research Institute, Japan's largest credit-rating company, placed Peregrine's credit rating on review with "negative implications" and said the firm faced "pressure on its financial strength" because of the turmoil in Asia.
Peregrine's chairman, Philip Tose, said of the agreement with the Zurich Group, "We have gained a very large and prestigious independent minority shareholder that can bring us credibility and give some comfort to our bankers. They have clearly undertaken very exacting due diligence of our group, underlining that we do not have any of the problems that have been the subject of the rumors that forced our share price down."
The transaction values Peregrine at $830 million, about three-quarters of its book value at the end of 1996. That is less than the amounts of two or three times book value that some American securities firms have recently fetched.
The Zurich Group paid a per-share price for its stake that was 9.8 percent above Peregrine's closing stock price on Friday of $6.80 (Hong Kong), or 87 cents (United States). Peregrine's stock jumped 15 percent today, to $7.85 (Hong Kong).
Zurich Centre Investments Ltd., the group's private-equity arm, will receive convertible preference shares with full voting rights, as well as three seats on an enlarged nine-member board. The convertible stock may be exchanged for common shares between Jan. 1, 2001, and Dec. 31, 2004, for $8 (Hong Kong) a share.
Peregrine will pay a fixed rate of 7.5 percent on the convertible shares. Peregrine convertible bonds outstanding are trading at nearly twice that yield. At a time when it is very difficult for many Asian corporations to get credit, and when the Hong Kong prime lending rate is 9.5 percent, the rate to be paid is "not a bad deal" for Peregrine, said Anne Gardini, head of Hong Kong research at ABN-AMRO Hoare Govett Asia Ltd.
The Zurich Group's investment will reduce Peregrine International Holdings Ltd.'s stake in the investment bank to 20.3 percent from 26.6 percent, making it the second-largest shareholder. Peregrine International is a private company whose owners include Mr. Tose and the investment bank's managing director, Francis Leung.
The investment is the latest expansion step by the Zurich Group, which reached agreements this year and last to buy the financial-services unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. for shares and $2.1 billion, the New York money-management firm Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc. for $1.7 billion, and the Kemper Corporation, an American insurance and asset-management company, for $2 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Crusader Takes On the Postal Piggy Bank

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
He is called Japan's Don Quixote, and indeed, it does seem that Junichiro Koizumi is tilting at windmills.
Or, rather, tilting at post offices -- 24,667 of them, to be exact. Mr. Koizumi, Minister of Health and Welfare, wants to privatize them, contending that no less than Japan's future role as a world financial leader hangs in the balance. 
 Yes, financial. For the Japanese post office is far more than a mere mail carrier. As guardian of an astounding $2 trillion in savings and $800 billion in life insurance policies squirreled away by people like "Mrs. Watanabe," the ubiquitous housewife who controls the family purse strings, it is also a financial monolith that dwarfs titans like Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank, Citibank and Deutsche Bank.
But to Mr. Koizumi, it is a juggernaut threatening to strangle Japan's private financial institutions. "We can achieve nothing without tackling this problem," he said recently.
Problem? Most Japanese consider the post office a cultural icon, a national treasure. Postmasters here think nothing of picking up an old man's passbook on their way to work and dropping off his withdrawal on their way home at night. They run errands for elderly widows, find jobs for customers' children and organize local festivals and events.
No wonder, then, that the man calling the post office a troublesome anachronism is meeting with fierce resistance. In a recent poll by the newspaper Asahi Shimbun, more than half of those surveyed were adamantly opposed to privatizing the post office, and his office has received a flood of -- what else? -- letters pleading with him to stop.
But with Japan's economy struggling again, weighed down by a mountain of bad debts held by banks and other financial institutions, such opposition has not fazed Mr. Koizumi. Indeed, so passionate is he about privatization that he has threatened to resign if his boss, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, fails to back him.
Tokyo is scheduled to announce its decision as early as Wednesday. In many ways, privatizing the postal system is being seen as a litmus test of Mr. Hashimoto's resolve to reduce Government influence and unleash market forces on Japan's economy. Without at least a modest step in that direction, some say, Tokyo will never rival London and New York as a global financial capital.
"Politically, privatization is difficult, but it is important that the Hashimoto administration make it clear that the Japanese Government will privatize the postal savings system in the long run, if not right away," said Heizo Takenaka, a professor of economics at Keio University.
Mr. Koizumi contends that allowing a public financial institution -- one that is protected by and, indeed, part of, the Government -- to compete with private banks that do not enjoy such favored status is not at all the free and unfettered competition Mr. Hashimoto has promised. "Japan is being drawn into global competition," he said. "I doubt whether one can truly carry out meaningful reform if we leave intact a national bank that operates outside the market economy."
The system began in 1875 as a way of harnessing private savings for use in building the country's infrastructure, and much of the savings and life insurance money it takes in is passed on to the Ministry of Finance, which has used it for everything from rebuilding Tokyo after World War II to providing low-interest loans to small businesses and homeowners.
"The postal system is a symbol of Japanese history and society," said Shumpei Tsukahara, a member of the "postal tribe," lawmakers who fiercely defend the institution in Parliament. It is vital, he said, that it "continue as a national institution."
Interestingly, if anyone has reason to feel warm and fuzzy about the postal system, it is Mr. Koizumi himself. In the 1930's, his grandfather, Matajiro, was head of what is now the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, the post office's overseer. And he himself served as postal minister for a brief stint in 1992 and 1993.
But Mr. Koizumi, 52, is a hard-hearted realist. "Times are different," he said. "Japan was poor back then, and the economy was still weak. Private financial institutions were still undeveloped, and so the post office had a role to play."
Its role is still extensive. Postal savings represented about 45 percent of all deposits at the end of last year and have probably climbed even higher, as bank customers and investors move money out of scandal-ridden securities firms and banks laden with bad loans.
And local postmasters, whose jobs are hereditary, have cultivated unrivaled grass-roots support through community service. They lend that support to the Liberal Democratic Party, long the ruling party here. In some districts, postmasters round up more than 4,000 new party members a year, by some estimates, although as Government employees they are barred from official political activity.
Their influence was apparent at their national convention in October, which was attended by several ranking ruling-party officials, who denounced privatization and its supporters. "We will never forget your support and kindness," vowed Koichi Kato, the party's secretary general, using a Japanese word, "go-on," that implies a deep sense of obligation.
Katsuji Shimizu, head of Zentoku, the postmasters' organization, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications declined to comment, saying the timing was not right since the Government was expected to make a final decision on the matter as early as this week.
While the postal tribe is not saying much publicly these days, the extent of its influence can be measured by how quickly the Government rejected the recommendations of the group it appointed to come up with ways to overhaul the Japanese bureaucracy.
In September, the Administrative Reform Council suggested privatizing first postal insurance and then postal savings, but this idea was given a quick heave-ho by Mr. Hashimoto and his Cabinet.
It was then that Mr. Koizumi made his threat to resign, setting off a "will he or won't he" debate that has been running ever since.
Japanese Cabinet ministers resign over scandals, not policy. But Mr. Koizumi is not your average Cabinet minister. "Koizumi-san is a very strange person, isn't he?" said Mr. Tsukahara, a member of Mr. Koizumi's faction of the party.
And by Japanese standards, Mr. Koizumi is indeed a strange bird.
His latest outrageous act was to refuse the roughly $2,400 monthly stipend given to those who have served in Parliament for 25 years, saying he could not accept such a payment when the national deficit is so high. He also refused to have his portrait painted, saving the Ministry of Finance nearly $8,000.
Last summer, he raised eyebrows as one of six Cabinet ministers to visit a shrine to war dead that some regard as a symbol of Japanese aggression in World War II.
He is divorced, which is almost unheard of in Japanese political circles, and has raised his two sons, now 16 and 19, by himself.
And, unlike most Japanese politicians, he speaks good enough English to have served as an interpreter for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on one of her visits to Japan.
"I don't think I am odd," Mr. Koizumi said. "The politics here are what is odd."
That may be, but he is certainly the odd man out in the postal savings discussion. Even Washington, which has been pushing hard for changes in the Japanese financial system, is treading lightly on postal privatization.
Change could come unaided, though. Some economists say deregulating private-sector financial services will make them so attractive that Mrs. Watanabe will take her money out of the post office without privatization. "By the year 2010, the postal savings system will be privatized, either by law or simply by circumstance," said Jesper Koll, head of research at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd.
But Japanese bankers are not at all sure. The post office enjoys so many hidden subsidies, they say, that even with deregulation, they will be unable to compete with it if it retains Government sponsorship. "All we want is a level playing field," one Japanese banker said. "They're playing the game under a different set of rules."
The postal financial services, for instance, pay no taxes or deposit insurance and are not required to hold reserves against potential losses. A Government advisory panel estimated that those exemptions save the system some 950 billion yen a year, or about $7.5 billion. But that means it also costs taxpayers that amount in lost revenue.
"So far, the inefficiency of public finance is not so clear to the Japanese people," Professor Takenaka said. "My mother-in-law, who lives in the country, asked me just the other day why I wanted to put her post office out of business."
While rates on the postal system's time deposits are no higher than those of private banks, the deposits are more liquid. The most popular postal savings account, called a teigaku, yields compound annual interest semiannually but can be withdrawn without penalty after six months. In the private sector, a depositor would forgo a few tenths of a percent in interest for such a privilege; a teigaku holder does not.
An internal report by the International Monetary Fund suggests a step-by-step privatization of postal financial services, perhaps by region, along with lowering rates on teigaku and making the system's subsidies more visible.
Changes like those would put postal savings "on a more equal footing with the private banking sector," the report concludes, adding, "Such a development would represent a significant step toward establishing a more dynamic and competitive financial system in Japan."
With the economy on the verge of another recession, though, the Government seems unwilling to take on so popular an institution right now.
And Mr. Koizumi is still going to work every morning, leading many to conclude that his threat to resign was a bluff.
Not so, he says. "I believe the Prime Minister's passion for reform has not waned," Mr. Koizumi said. "I trust that he will contain the opposition within the party and implement a reform that cuts deeply into the issue, thereby avoiding a situation where I would have to resign."
By staying on now, Mr. Koizumi poses perhaps a bigger threat to Mr. Hashimoto's already wobbly Government. Because the postal system plan comes from the governing party, not out of the Parliament, it will require the approval of all Cabinet ministers, regardless of their portfolio and responsibilities. If the recommendations do not go far enough to please Mr. Koizumi, then Mr. Hashimoto would have to sack him to get the measures passed, an embarrassment that would send a negative message about the depth of his commitment to change.
"One person alone does not make politics," Mr. Koizumi said, "but I think it's worth testing to see what a single person can do."

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Rose in October For 15th Consecutive Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
United States industrial output advanced in October for the 15th straight month, though at a subdued rate, indicating that inflation does not greatly threaten the economy, analysts said.
Federal Reserve figures showed today that production at factories, mines and utilities rose five-tenths of 1 percent, a smaller-than-expected rate, led by increased output of consumer goods and computers. The advance matched September's revised gain of five-tenths of 1 percent, which had initially been estimated at seven-tenths of 1 percent. 
 "The overall industrial picture is still solid," said Jonathan Basile, an economist at HSBC Securities in New York.
The Fed report showed that the plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, rose to 84.3 percent in October -- its highest level since March 1995 -- from a revised 84.2 percent in September. Previously, the September plant-use rate was estimated as 84.4 percent and before the report, analysts expected an October reading of 84.7 percent.
While central bankers consider a rising plant-use rate as a sign that inflation could accelerate, a variety of inflation gauges suggest no imminent threat of rising prices. On Friday, for instance, the Labor Department said that producer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in October.
Moreover, manufacturers continue to hold down production costs and improve the efficiency of their plants and employees. Manufacturing productivity -- the average amount produced in an hour of work -- rose at an annual rate of 9.8 percent in the third quarter, the biggest gain in 15 years, Government figures showed last week.
In today's industrial production report, the broad category of manufacturing output rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month. Within that, business equipment production, including computers, rose 2.5 percent; auto and truck production rose three-tenths of 1 percent, and household appliance production rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
Construction supplies production fell two-tenths of 1 percent as mining output fell 1.1 percent and output at utilities rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
Analysts expect that several factors, including the economic crisis in Asia and a traffic backup on the Union Pacific Railroad could cause the economy to slow in the fourth quarter from its 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Growth Predicted in Computer-Based Jobs

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Strong growth is expected to continue through the first years of the next century in computer-related employment in the New York City metropolitan region, in fields from telecommunications to Wall Street to the small start-up companies in the Internet industry, state officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say.
Now comes the tough part. What skills will be required for New York-area residents to land those jobs? Given the pace of technological change, can the region's schools, students and training organizations even prepare for those jobs? Will the jobs look so different as to be unrecognizable? 
 "For the kids in kindergarten, we don't know what jobs will be there when they complete their schooling -- we're not sure what the labor market will be," said Jan L. Hennessy, project director for the New York Association of Training and Employment Professionals, and a participant at a daylong conference in Newark last week on job skills and education standards sponsored by the Federal Department of Labor.
One major message of the conference was that gazing into the future of the regional job market is like analyzing a complicated football play in which every player is in motion. Experts in such fields as manufacturing and retailing said that the levels of education and skills required for many jobs in their industries would continue to rise, putting new pressures on schools to prepare graduates who can communicate well and work in teams: skills necessary for entry-level clerks and highly paid technicians alike.
The conference, part of a series of meetings being held around the country to discuss emerging job skills, focused on a particular answer to the jobs-in-flux phenomenon: skills standards. Establishing education and skills standards for any job, conference speakers said, sets up a system of measurement, which is valuable even if the yardsticks need to be adjusted as jobs evolve.
"In the past, if you were a manufacturing worker, you went in, put your head down, did your work and went home -- that's not the case today," said C. J. Shroll, vice president for work-force development at the National Coalition for Advanced Manufacturing. "We need to communicate that to schools."
The skills standards process also has other benefits, experts like Mr. Shroll said. It injects a certain practicality into education, because students, in learning what specific skills must be mastered for a job, realize that some subjects -- surprise! -- actually have value.
"If you link the Pythagorean theorem, say, to measuring the size of a room, suddenly you realize that there's a reason to know geometry, that it's not an abstract subject," said John F. Kershaw, manager of the General Motors Training Center in Moorestown, N.J. "The key word is 'meaning.' You put meaning in education, and motivation develops as a result of that."
But making projections about specific jobs is risky. Last year, for example, Connecticut issued a 10-year projection of the fastest-growing occupations in the state, a list led by jobs in the casino industry, which was then in the middle of a hiring spurt. In the new preliminary projections to be released later this year, the casino jobs are shown leveling off. The new numbers will show electronic pagination system workers -- people who lay out text and art on computer screens for print or electronic publishing -- topping the list of fastest-growing occupations, followed by computer engineers and computer support specialists.
In New Jersey, systems analysts will be in vogue for the coming decade, followed by computer engineers and home health care aides, according to Labor Department projections. In the New York City region as a whole, computer engineers top the list of fastest growing occupations, according to projections from the New York State Department of Labor. The engineers are followed by electronic pagination system operators, systems analysts and computer support specialists.
Officials at the New York Labor Department said that the next updating of projections of occupational growth will take into account an increase in New York City retailing, which was creating more jobs than economists had expected when the last round of numbers was prepared last year. Projected growth in health care employment, on the other hand, is likely to inch downward as hospital consolidations and labor-saving technology advance into the industry more quickly than expected.
A recent study by the Community Service Society of New York, a private nonprofit antipoverty organization, said that people making the transition from welfare to work over the coming decade would create yet another demand for work-related education.
The study said that while New York was producing many entry-level jobs with low education requirements in industries like retailing, the overall job mix was "continuing to evolve toward jobs that require higher skills and pay higher wages."

HEADLINE: U.S. Stocks Surge After Strong Rally in Japan

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A strong rally in Japan spurred a surge in United States stocks yesterday as American investors apparently were encouraged by the handling of a bank failure by the Japanese government.
Large multinationals and technology, banking and financial services companies -- whose stock prices have suffered recently as investors weighed the fallout from weaker Asian economies -- led the way. 
 In addition to Coca-Cola and General Electric, stocks posting strong gains included I.B.M., Compaq, Dell, Intel, J. P. Morgan, Travelers and Chase Manhattan.
After the Japanese Government intervened to assist with the closing of a regional bank, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd., Japan's Nikkei 225 soared 7.96 percent in its largest one-day surge in seven years.
Stocks were slightly higher at midday today in Tokyo. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 19.78 points, or 0.12 percent, at 16,303.10.
The Japanese market gains also spilled over into other world markets, including Hong Kong, Brazil, Britain, Germany, Sweden and Israel. But some Southeast Asian markets ignored the increases. Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea and Thailand finished lower, with South Korea's composite index, falling the most, just over 4 percent.
Gaining strength from Japan's rise, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 125.74 points, to 7,698.22. Despite the sizable gain, the Dow moved off its highs late in the day and again failed to finish above 7,715.41, the level it had reached on Oct. 24, the Friday before its record 554-point drop on Oct. 27. Still, during the last three trading days, the Dow has gained more than 296 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index gained 17.85 points, to 946.20. That put the index above its Oct. 24 level of 941.64 for the second time.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 30.60 points, closing at 1,614.11, up 1.93 percent.
But the Nasdaq 100, a listing of the 100 largest stocks on the over-the-counter market, gained 21.85 points, or 2.13 percent, to 1,049.70, indicating investors' preference to place their technology bets on larger company names.
But analysts say the rally does not mean stocks will just go up from here.
"I think the market is being led by a pretty overnight picture in the world markets," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal Lyon & Ross.
Several investment strategists cautioned that even with the Japanese rally, Asia was not out of the woods yet because of lingering problems throughout the region.
"I think it's premature to get overexcited at this point," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Smith Barney.
"You can get some good news in one spot and some bad news in another," added Mr. Acuff, who just returned from a one-week visit with institutional investors in Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore.
"It was clear from my trip that expectations for growth are continuing to be revised downward" and that the impact will last for more than six months.
And the full impact of slower growth in Asia and other regions like Latin America cannot yet be gauged, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
"Our view is that this is not the start of a very big uptick in the market," Mr. Cripps said of yesterday's gains.
He said that earnings of United States companies should slow in 1998, in part because of the negative impact of the slowdown in Asia.
But that view has not yet been reflected in compilations of earnings estimates from analysts.
As of the end of last week, analysts had not significantly lowered their 1997 or 1998 earnings estimates for the stocks in the S.& P. 500, said Charles L. Hill, director of research at First Call, a Boston-based company that tracks earnings estimates. Analysts are forecasting 12 percent growth in 1997 and 14 percent growth in 1998, he said.
"Given the pressures that are emerging out there, that would seem unrealistic," Mr. Cripps cautioned.
Indications of slower company growth could come as early as fourth-quarter pre-earnings announcements, said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan.
Jeffrey Bahrenburg, a global strategist and Japan specialist at Merrill Lynch, said that yesterday's move by the Japanese Government to deal with the weakness of its banking system was only "a step in the right direction." The markets could continue to be volatile, he cautioned, while the Government develops a plan to deal with the banking crisis.
American depository receipts of several Japanese companies were among the stocks posting the strongest gains yesterday.
Ito-Yokado, a supermarket chain in eastern Japan, rose 12 1/2, to 190. Canon gained 8, to 118 1/4, and Mitsui, a trading company, rose 6 1/8, to 147. Matsushita Electric gained 6, to 160.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1884 words

HEADLINE: For the South, G.O.P. Secures Defense Bounty

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: PASCAGOULA, Miss.

 BODY:
In the decades that the Democrats controlled Congress, influential members from the South proudly brought home military-procurement contracts like eight-point bucks strapped to the hoods of their trucks.
For generations, Southerners like Senators Richard Russell of Georgia, John C. Stennis of Mississippi and Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representatives L. Mendel Rivers of South Carolina and Carl Vinson of Georgia used their powerful positions on the Armed Services Committees to bring jobs and dollars to their states and to help insure their own political longevity. 
 These days Congress is ruled by a different breed of Southerner: tight-fisted, fiscally conservative Republicans, bound and determined to rein in Federal spending.
But the tradition still holds. The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi; House Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia and the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, each succeeded this year in adding large sums to the military budget to give lucrative construction contracts to hometown companies.
None of the projects had been requested by the Clinton Administration. But the President, apparently not inclined to provoke a war with the Congressional leadership, chose not to excise the projects with his line item veto.
Here in Pascagoula, Mr. Lott's hometown, officials at Ingalls Shipbuilding are celebrating a $720 million appropriation added to this year's military budget to speed the construction of a DDG-51 Aegis-class destroyer.
In Marietta, Ga., just a block outside Mr. Gingrich's district, workers at Lockheed Martin are about to begin building eight C-130J transport planes, worth a total of $503 million, despite the Air Force's contention that it does not need or want them.
And near New Orleans, just outside Mr. Livingston's district, the Avondale Industries shipyard has received $100 million as a down-payment on construction of an LPD-17 amphibious ship that was not supposed to be financed until next year.
"The Southern Republicans are just continuing a tradition that was well established by the Southern Democrats," said Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University and an authority on Southern politics. "They balance the budget elsewhere."
 
On a Question of Need, 2 Different Answers
The Federal budget is, and always has been, a deeply political document. On Capitol Hill, money follows power and seniority, which helps explain why West Virginia, home of the veteran Democratic Senator Robert C. Byrd, or central Pennsylvania, home of Representative Bud Shuster, the Republican who leads the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure are so endowed with Federal largesse.
But the South, which for much of this century was grindingly poor, has long depended on Federal spending, particularly for military projects, to shore up its economy, and has long rewarded the lawmakers who provided it.
Regarding this year's appropriations, Mr. Lott, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Livingston argue that they are simply supporting a strong defense and that there is a military justification for each project. In the case of the two shipbuilding programs, they say they will save the Pentagon money by speeding construction and avoiding inflationary price increases. Regarding the Lockheed Martin contract, Mr. Gingrich said in an interview that it had become the obligation of the Republican Congress to buy planes that "a liberal Democrat Administration" will not.
Although the Republican leaders are responsible for setting national priorities, none apologize for fighting for their home states and districts. "It's one of the most important shipyards in the country," Mr. Lott said of Ingalls Shipbuilding, "and if I were not supportive of my hometown, that shipyard and the workers in that shipyard, I wouldn't deserve to be in Congress, now would I?"
But opponents of the extra military spending question whether the purchases of ships and planes are truly needed, especially this year. Furthermore, they contend that this year's contracts illustrate the primary weakness of pork-barrel spending: even when it is not overtly wasteful, it substitutes political priorities for sound policy judgments.
"In all fairness, much of what they've added is in the Pentagon's five-year plan," said Lawrence J. Korb, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the first term of the Reagan Administration. "So the question is whether they more need planes or tanks or ships. If Livingston was from Detroit, would we be buying more tanks? And if Lott was from California, would we be buying more planes?"
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, who has chafed many of his colleagues with regular critiques of pork-barrel spending, said he was disturbed that his party had continued the Democratic practice of adding politically influenced dollars to the military budget, particularly given other Pentagon needs.
"It's troublesome that Republicans are doing this because, in 1994, I thought one of the commitments we made to the American people was that we would eliminate wasteful and unnecessary spending," said Mr. McCain, who sits on the Armed Services Committee.
"The money should be going to where it's needed," he said. "There are 12,000 military families on food stamps. We're seeing a hemorrhage of Air Force pilots from the military because they're stretched way too thin. We're failing to modernize our forces. Our readiness is deteriorating. Our backlog of maintenance in our depots is at an all-time high."
 
Helping a Company, Even in Good Times
Here in Pascagoula, of course, there is no such hand-wringing. Ingalls Shipbuilding, which employs 10,000 people at its 800-acre shipyard, is not only the largest private employer on the Mississippi Gulf Coast, but also in the state. With union wages that average $28,000 a year, it has provided a decent living for generations of workers in one of the poorest states in the country.
One of those workers was Mr. Lott's father, Chester, a sharecropper whose life improved significantly when he moved his family to Pascagoula and took a job as a pipe-fitter at Ingalls. Mr. Lott played tuba in a high school band that performed for battleship launchings.
But the end of the cold war, and the subsequent shrinkage of the military procurement budget -- to $38.9 billion in 1997 from $108 billion in 1987 (in 1997 dollars) -- has posed hardships for Ingalls. Twenty years ago, the shipyard finished seven warships a year. Now it produces three.
At Ingalls, employment has dropped 60 percent, from a high of 25,000 in 1977. Although Ingalls, a division of Litton Industries, has tried to diversify, 90 percent of its business still comes from the Navy.
Without enough work to keep the country's six private-sector naval shipyards operating at anywhere near capacity, military analysts are questioning whether the industry should consolidate. Because the Mississippi Gulf Coast economy could not absorb thousands of unemployed shipbuilders, the pressure is intense on Mr. Lott and other members of Congress from Mississippi to make sure that Ingalls remains viable.
Last December, Ingalls suffered a bruising blow when it lost out on a Navy contract to build the first 3 of a class of 12 new amphibious assault ships, the LPD-17, worth about $750 million each. The deal was awarded to a consortium of the Bath Iron Works Corporation in Maine and Avondale Industries in Louisiana, a decision that outraged Mr. Lott.
Mr. Lott and Ingalls then turned their attention to an existing contract to build 12 DDG-51 destroyers from 1998 to 2001, with the ships split evenly between Ingalls and Bath, a subsidiary of the General Dynamics Corporation. First, they tried and failed to get the Navy to shift 2 of the 6 Bath ships to Ingalls. Then they succeeded in persuading the Navy, and Congress, to speed up the construction of two additional destroyers, which would not have been contracted until after 2001, and to have them both built at Ingalls, one in 1998 and one in 2001.
"The question for the Navy was how do you keep Ingalls happy so Lott doesn't get angry," a Congressional staff member said on the condition of anonymity. "And the answer was to build two extra ships. Are they there because of Congressional intervention? Absolutely."
Mr. Lott said the rationale for building the two additional destroyers earlier than planned was that it would be cheaper to do so, a point acknowledged by all sides. He added that if Ingalls had been forced to reduce its work force much further its ability to compete effectively for future Navy contracts would have been hurt.
"We need to keep them viable," Mr. Lott said. "We should have learned from past experience that if you drop your guard, if you lose your manufacturing capability when everything is nice and peaceful, then when you need it in times of buildup or war it's very difficult. You don't retrain a nuclear welder in a week's time."
 
'Egregious Waste' Or Games People Play?
In Mr. Gingrich's case, the Pentagon says it does not even want the eight C-130J transport planes that were added to this year's budget. The White House had requested one such plane, but Congress appropriated money to build nine.
"We didn't request them," said Gloria J. Calef, an Air Force spokeswoman. "They just gave them to us."
Mr. Gingrich scoffed at that notion. "It's a game the Air Force plays every year," he said. "The Air Force always under-requests C-130's and they always know they'll be added by Congress."
But one high-ranking Air Force official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the Air Force actually had more transport planes than were called for in the Pentagon's strategic plans.
Furthermore, the official said, the transport planes being replaced by the C-130J's "still have some life on them." And financing for construction of the new planes was not accompanied by financing for spare parts, maintenance equipment and other logistical support, making them something of a burden.
"The fact of the matter is that Lockheed needs to sell C-130J's more than the Air Force needs to buy them today," the official said.
Both Senator McCain and Mr. Korb, the former Assistant Defense Secretary, agreed. Mr. McCain, in a letter to President Clinton urging a line item veto of the planes, called them "a particularly egregious waste of taxpayer money."
Mr. Livingston, meanwhile, secured $100 million as a down payment to Avondale for construction of one of the $750 million amphibious assault ships that was not scheduled for construction until 1999.
"I don't apologize at all," Mr. Livingston said. "The Navy wants the LPD. It's been high on their five-year plan. It's going to be built. It's got to be funded. This is some advance funding that enabled Avondale to begin planning for a ship that they had already won."
But a Congressional staff member countered that there was no military need to advance Avondale the money. "Why make the down payment?" asked the staff member, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "They just took $100 million and devoted it to this year's budget, for no purpose at all. You get nothing. Nothing for national defense. Nothing for the taxpayer."
