HEADLINE: Too Many Trees Are Falling

BYLINE: By James A. Leach; James A. Leach, a Republican, is a United States Representative from Iowa.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The only trouble with the movement for the preservation of our forests," Theodore Roosevelt noted in 1908, "is that it has not gone nearly far enough." That is still the problem today.
In the waning hours of the just-concluded session, Congress passed a bill intended to set up a pilot "fuel break" project in certain national forests in California. But is the bill landmark legislation because it places modest limits on logging, or will its allowance of cutting on more than 40,000 acres only continue the 300-year hemorrhaging of one of our most precious resources? 
 Like the bison herds that sustained the Plains Indians, the sea of trees that covered the eastern half and far west of America seemed to early settlers to be an inexhaustible resource.
In 1891, with the effect of two centuries of profligate tree cutting becoming apparent, Congress established the national forest system. But a short six years later it created the Federal timber sales program, and logging in our new national forests began.
Today, with 95 percent of the country's original forests already logged, most of the remaining 5 percent are subject to being cut, with logs hauled from public land on access roads constructed at public expense.
Less than 4 percent of the country's wood products come from public lands, yet Federal subsidies for this logging are inexcusably large; last year alone, the subsidy was $791 million. And the Government not only subsidizes roads for logging companies, it also pays communities to support schools and other services for the families of loggers.
But the program's real cost extends beyond this corporate welfare. Continued logging in national forests worsens soil erosion, lake and stream sedimentation, and air and water quality. Some jobs may be created, but whether their number exceeds those in the fishing, recreation and tourism industries that are jeopardized when machines intrude on nature's habitat is open to question.
Indeed, according to the Forest Service, logging jobs represent less than 3 percent of all jobs in our national forests.
If we are to be good stewards of public lands, we must protect what remains of our national forests. One way to do this is to create programs to insure maximum use of recyclable materials.
In 1992 almost half of all American hardwood lumber production was used to make pallets for shipping. And according to the industry, more than half of these pallets are used just once and then discarded, ending up in landfills. Subsidized wood products promote this type of waste.
Ending the logging subsidy makes good environmental and economic sense and should be a high priority for a free-market economy. That is why Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, a Georgia Democrat, and I have introduced legislation to end logging on public lands.
Our bill would provide for the retraining of displaced timber workers, economic development assistance to affected lumbering communities, and research into recycling and ecological restoration.
At first blush, some might think ending logging on Federal land is environmental extremism, but in fact, it is common sense.
Insuring the environmental future requires a global effort, and we should do our part. The United States is quick to scold third world countries that destroy tropical forests, decrying the impact on global warming and biodiversity.
If we are going to exhort other countries to preserve their forests, we ought to act to save our own. Forest preservation is neither a regional nor a partisan issue. The national forests belong to all Americans, and their proper management is everybody's business.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Cathay Pacific is offering a big discount on round-trip fares from the U.S. to Hong Kong.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
HOPING to revive Hong Kong's slumping tourist industry, as well as increase passenger loads, Cathay Pacific is offering an economy-class round-trip fare for two from New York or Los Angeles for $999, plus taxes. Travel, which includes five nights at one of the approximately 60 participating hotels, must be booked no later than Dec. 3 and completed by Feb. 15, 1998. Seats are limited.
The hugely discounted fare amounts to a formal recognition that Hong Kong's once vibrant tourist industry has been in a deep slump since last May, two months before it reverted from British to Chinese rule. Tourism fell 35.2 percent this July, compared with the previous July; it plunged 24.4 percent in August and 22.4 percent in September. 
 Those falling numbers have hurt -- if not imperiled -- Hong Kong hotels, restaurants, boutiques, the tourism work force, and, of course, Cathay Pacific. Other airlines are also feeling the pinch; traffic on Northwest Airline's Tokyo-Hong Kong route is down about 15 percent so far this month.
Its 2-for-1 offer, Cathay Pacific said, is designed to revitalize Hong Kong's inbound tourism. The carrier added that it hoped to attract 20,000 visitors who, according to the Hong Kong Tourist Association, could "inject more than $18 million (United States) into the area's economy."
Malaysia is also experiencing a drop in tourism, largely because of haze from the forest fires in Indonesia that covered much of Southeast Asia last month, causing airports to shut down and the United States and some European governments to warn their citizens against visiting the involved areas. As a result, tourism is down throughout most of the region, from Singapore to the Philippines.
But Malaysia, which has plans to double its number of tourists to 20 million by 2000, is especially worried by the drop in tourism and hotel cancellations -- so much so that some hotels are offering discounts up to 50 percent
Ahmad Zaki, the head of the Malaysian Tourist Office in New York, acknowledged yesterday that tourism had fallen off throughout the region. But he added that while some air pollution from the fires remained, it was no longer a big problem.
 
Hotel for 'Sale'
Times Square has long been synonymous with New Year's Eve, so it probably is not surprising that the Millennium Broadway hotel is planning a special event to welcome in the year 2000: It has offered to "sell" the 627-room hotel for three days to a single customer for $3 million. And it claims to have a bona fide potential customer.
"It's an international company," said Michael Littler, the manager of the 52-story hotel just off Broadway on 44th Street. "But we still have to work out some details."
Whoever it is, the "buyer" will have exclusive control of the hotel and its staff from Dec. 30, 1999, until checkout Jan. 2, 2000. In addition to all meals, snacks and beverages for up to 1,200 guests, the price tag will include the hotel's attached Hudson Theater, which seats 700 theater-style or 300 for a sit-down dinner. And it will include the right to entirely wrap the top of the building with a corporate logo or "any legal or acceptable promotion."
"We'll know by the end of this year whether we have a signed contract," Mr. Littler said, and if that falls through, the hotel will keep the bid open until next September. After that it will take the offer off the table, because, he added, "We already have enough inquiries to fill the place with individual visitors."
 
Read Before You Go
Business travelers going abroad will be able to bone up on the culture and commerce of the countries they are visiting with a series of books recently introduced by the American Geographical Society. Reintroduced, and updated, to be exact, since the series, "Around the World," was a big seller years ago but has not been published for 25 years.
The six volumes published so far are on Japan, Switzerland, Australia, Fiji, Madagascar and Malta, with Brazil, Scotland, Brunei and Oman to follow. Only 60 pages each, the books are not intended as travel books but as introductory overviews, and all are written by geographers; the volume on Japan, for example, is written by Roman Cybriwsky of Temple University, the author of a previous book about Tokyo.
 
Plug In the Car
Hilton Hotels said yesterday that it was equipping its hotels and corporate office in Southern California with charging stations for electrical vehicles.

HEADLINE: On Using the Subway Surplus

 BODY:
Despite their reluctance to admit it in public, the executives who run New York City's mass transit are accumulating a 1997 surplus that would make some on Wall Street salivate. At $126.8 million and rising, the surplus could wind up close to $150 million. But whatever it totals come Dec. 31, every penny ought to finance vastly improved bus and subway service -- plus discounts and marketing efforts that will persuade more people that you can get around faster underground than above.
Transit executives should have their spending plans to relieve overcrowding and improve the environment for riders locked in long before year's end. As riders and officials know, those who hesitate run the very grave risk that history will repeat itself. In recent years Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have made deep, unwarranted cuts in state and city aid to the operating and capital sides of mass transit, contending they were only forcing the system to tighten its belt. The Governor's recent remarks, which tilt toward returning the windfall to the system's customers, are encouraging. The Giuliani administration has expressed interest in using the surplus for reducing debt, improving subway and bus service and more experimentation with fare discounts. 
Around the city, there is a spirited debate over the size of the surplus. Transit officials, acting conservatively, put the number on the low side -- at $37.7 million, which they attribute to increased ridership. They are reluctant to toss in all of the $48.1 million expected from dedicated tax streams and the like because it is unclear that they will receive all of it from Albany. Other longtime students of the system see a pot that just might hit $150 million.
Whatever its final size, the recurring share that results from increased rider revenue and dedicated tax funds will give transit officials the wherewithal to add trains and enhance the cleanliness and physical conditions of stations, subways and buses.
With ridership and confidence in the service rising, the Mayor and Governor need to remember that a healthy transit system is good for the economy and the city and state tax base. The system deserves investment, not disinvestment.

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index: Again No Surprises

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Despite the nation's economic strength, consumer prices rose only modestly again in October and helped push inflation during the last 12 months to the lowest level since oil prices collapsed a decade ago.
The benign inflation data for October, reported today by the Labor Department, marked the fourth consecutive month that overall consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 When volatile energy and food components are deleted from the Consumer Price Index data, consumer inflation during the last 12 months is at its weakest rate in more than 31 years.
"The Consumer Price Index remains a picture-perfect portrait of stability," said Jarry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Economists continued to marvel at how inflation has remained in check even with a fast-growing economy that has helped drive the unemployment rate down to the lowest level since the Nixon Administration.
Over the last year, consumer inflation shrank to 2.1 percent from 3 percent even as the jobless rate was falling to 4.7 percent from 5.2 percent, challenging traditional assumptions that inflation and unemployment go in opposite directions.
The 2.1 percent rate is the lowest since the 1.1 percent rate in 1986, when an extraordinary drop in oil prices sharply reduced inflation. The so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes food and energy and is a more accurate barometer of long-term price trends, was 2.3 percent over the last year, lowest since 1966.
"Current price performance is unprecedented," Cheryl R. Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, told clients today. "Inflation has never been so low so far into an expansion."
Joseph Liro and Anita Ash, economists at CIBC Oppenheimer, called the latest price figures, which were in line with expectations, "boring but very satisfying."
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said retail inventories jumped a hefty 1.1 percent in September, suggesting optimism about the holiday shopping season and pointing to an upward revision in national output for the third quarter that was initially estimated at a 3.5 percent annual pace.
Analysts said it appeared the inventory buildup was intentional, rather than caused by sluggish customers, because the $320.2 billion worth of stockpiled merchandise was enough to last just 1.5 months, a bit more than in August but less than in September 1996.
The price report showed consumers paid just one-tenth of 1 percent more for energy last month than in September, after two months in which prices spurted a total of 2 percent. This moderation was partly offset by sizable but presumably temporary gains in the cost of home maintenance, dairy products, hotel rooms, tobacco and airline fares.
Medical care inflation continued to slow, edging up one-tenth of 1 percent last month to bring the 12-month advance to 2.5 percent, barely more than the 2.3 percent advance for all items other than food and energy.
What inflation there was last month was in services, which account for 57 percent of the Consumer Price Index and rose three-tenths of 1 percent. The price of commodities, which account for 43 percent of the index, was unchanged.
While services are up 3 percent over the last 12 months, compared with 1 percent for commodities that are subject to greater international competition, some analysts said they found little reason for concern.
Suzanne Rizzo, an economist at Maria Fiorino Ramirez, a New York investment advisory firm, noted that service inflation had decelerated for much of 1997, to a 2.7 percent rate for the three months through October.
"Rather than goods catching up with services," as many had once projected, she said, "services have been slowing down."
Medical care services, for example, rose at a 2.2 percent annual rate during the latest six months, sharply below the 3.1 percent rate for the six months through April.
For the New York metropolitan area, prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month to bring the 12-month inflation rate to 2.4 percent, compared with 2.1 percent nationwide. Prices rose 2.3 percent in Chicago and 1.4 percent in Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: Quixotic Quest to Invent A Different Car Engine Fails

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
After four years and $24 million, the brothers Ben and Harold Rosen -- one a successful venture capitalist and the other a celebrated rocket scientist -- are abandoning a quixotic quest to remake the automobile industry.
The brothers said yesterday that they were closing down Rosen Motors, a venture they founded in 1993 to create a car that would run on conventional gasoline but would have virtually none of the pollutants and twice the fuel economy of today's automobiles. 
 Rosen Motors successfully road-tested its first vehicle last January and had since refined its design. But the Rosens decided to call it quits because they were unable to attract a major auto maker that would provide the cash needed to transform the prototype into a commercial vehicle.
"We always said that the marketing challenge would be the most difficult," Ben Rosen said yesterday. "That was our Achilles' heel."
Mr. Rosen said that a few of the 10 car makers he approached were interested in an alliance, but that none was willing to invest in Rosen Motors and commit to using its technology in future cars. "We weren't interested in doing a deal with a company where this would be in research and development forever," he explained.
One reason there was so little interest is that the world's car makers are already spending considerable time and money developing alternatives to today's internal-combustion engine.
Last month, six new such vehicles were announced at the Tokyo automobile show, including a hybrid gasoline and electric car from Toyota that gets 66 miles to the gallon and will go on sale in Japan next month, making it the first mass-produced hybrid-electric vehicle. Ford, General Motors, Chrysler and others are working on designs that use fuel cells, batteries, or simply refine a conventional engine so that it is cleaner and more fuel efficient.
"Is this a big setback for the industry?" said Sheila A. Lynch, the executive director of the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium, a government-supported nonprofit group that promotes the use of clean vehicles. "To be quite blunt, no."
But Rosen Motors, which is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., was certainly one of the most celebrated and daring attempts to dethrone the internal-combustion engine. The idea was born in the early 1990's, when Harold Rosen, 71, who is credited with inventing the geosynchronous communications satellite, retired from the Hughes Aircraft Company and decided to take a stab at reinventing the automobile. He convinced his younger brother, Ben, 64 -- who has helped found several successful technology companies, including Compaq Computer, where he remains chairman -- to bankroll the effort.
The Rosen design uses a small gas turbine engine, much like a miniature jet engine, to create electricity that drives motors attached to the axle of a car. A flywheel that spins as fast as 60,000 revolutions a minute recovers energy as the car brakes, which can then be used to increase the car's acceleration.
Rosen Motors recently fitted the powertrain into a navy blue Mercedes E320 sedan. The goal was to improve the performance until the car could go from zero to 60 miles an hour in six seconds, faster than the acceleration of a Mercedes with an eight-cylinder internal-combustion engine.
The company said it was on track, but Ben Rosen, who has spent $24 million of his own money, decided that it would cost too much to continue development alone. The 70 employees of Rosen Motors will be laid off, though some will be hired by the Capstone Turbine Corporation. The company, based in Tarzana, Calif., makes the gas turbines, which can be used as stationary power generators, and is partly financed by the Rosens.
"We are proud of the fact that we had this dream and we pursued it with our money," Ben Rosen said. "We didn't succeed. That is what is so great about our system: you either succeed or fail on the merits."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Japan Fears Push Bonds Slightly Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices for Treasury securities slipped slightly yesterday, hurt by talk in the market of Japanese selling but buoyed by a Government report showing that consumer prices rose only mildly last month.
The 30-year bond fell 1/32, to a price of 100 26/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.07 percent, from 6.06 percent on Monday. 
 Some investors continued to worry that Japanese Government agencies might decide to sell American Treasury securities to finance a plan to bolster banks, after the Government shut down a major commercial bank this week. Others, though, said such selling was unlikely because Japanese agencies hold more lower-yield Japanese Government bonds than they do Treasuries, making a sale of the Japanese securities more likely.
Also weighing on Treasury prices were reports of a billion-dollar sale of five-year notes and a $500 million sale of long bonds by large investors.
But the news that consumer price increases have again stayed in check helped limit the declines.
"Inflation continues to be very subdued, benign and nonthreatening, and thus remains one of the few constants in the economic picture," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management.
In October, the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent, as economists had expected. On a year-to-year basis, the increase in the index stands at a low 2.1 percent.
Mr. Fine said that confidence about continued low inflation had played a key role in pushing bond yields to near-21-month lows. Contributing to the feeling that prices will stay in check has been an expectation that American economic growth will slow, in part because of the recent turmoil in Asian markets.
"However," Mr. Fine said, "what matters going forward is the extent and the timing of the anticipated slowdown, because to say the economy will slacken from its current 4 percent pace is not a particularly heroic assumption."
During the last several quarters, gross domestic product has grown at surprising strong annual rates: 3.5 percent in the third quarter, after 4.2 percent in the second.
Kenneth J. McCarthy of the Economic Intelligence Company, a consulting and forecasting firm, said that low inflation and slower growth would normally be a prescription for higher bond prices. The problem now, he added, is that bond prices have risen so much in recent weeks that it is hard to see how they can go much higher.
"In this environment, current interest rate levels are already too low," he said. "While they may go lower temporarily, we remain convinced that at current levels, interest rates are in a bottom zone and the next major trend will be upward."
Bond yields could also run into some resistance because of looming new supply in the next week or so. Today, the Treasury is to announce the size of next week's auctions of new two-year and five-year notes, while investors brace for this week's supply of corporate debt. Analysts expect about $10 billion of corporate and asset-backed debt to be priced.

HEADLINE: Profit Taking Sends Dow Down to 7,650.82

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday for the first time in four sessions as investors took profits.
Lingering concerns that slowing Asian economies would hurt profits of United States companies also weighed on stocks. Shares of Avon Products Inc. tumbled 8 percent yesterday after the company warned of lower overseas earnings. 
 "No matter how you slice the baloney here, the events that we saw in Asia are on balance negative for earnings," said Rick White, who manages $2.4 billion for Salomon Brothers Asset Management Inc. in New York. "It's hard to make a case for the market rocketing north."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 47.40 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,650.82, after rising 4 percent in the last three sessions. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.97 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 938.23. The Nasdaq composite index lost 13.67 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,600.44, after rising 1.9 percent on Monday.
Avon fell 5, to 57 1/2, after the direct marketer of cosmetics said fourth-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates because of lower-than-expected sales in Brazil, China and Japan. The company cited tighter regulatory controls in China and concern among Brazilian consumers about the nation's economy.
Colgate-Palmolive, which also does a lot of business in Brazil, fell 2 5/16, to 63 15/16.
Still, many analysts said any slowdown in Asia and Latin America would not have such dire effects on most American companies. And investors still like the fundamental backdrop in the United States: an expanding economy with falling interest rates and growing profits.
Schlumberger Ltd. and other oilfield service and equipment stocks, some of this year's best-performing issues, tumbled the most yesterday. Schlumberger fell 4 9/16, to 83 5/8; Smith International slid 4 11/16, to 67 7/16, and Cooper Cameron fell 4 1/2, to 65. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange Oil Service Sector Index, up 50 percent this year, declined 5.4 percent.
Analysts offered several explanations for the drop, including concern about increased supplies of oil from the Middle East, which would curtail drilling elsewhere.
AT&T, one of the 30 Dow components, rose 3 7/8, to 52 1/2, after Blake Bath, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, reiterated a "buy" rating on the stock, with a 12-month price target of 72 a share.
Mr. Bath said that after meeting with company executives, he was convinced AT&T would make an effort to cut expenses and make a key acquisition.
Hewlett-Packard, another Dow component, fell 5/8, to 61 5/8.
The company said it might close some plants after missing Wall Street's earnings estimates because of higher-than-expected expenses. The computer and printer maker fell short of expectations for a third quarter in a row.

HEADLINE: A Chorus of Silence From China's Few Dissenters

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Inside an ash-gray apartment block, up a stairway made narrow by stacks of winter cabbage, a gray-haired veteran of China's dissident movement held a finger to his lips as he opened the front door, silencing a visitor until the door was safely closed, the shades drawn and tea served.
Seated in a cramped living room, the dissident was eager to discuss the politics of the day, and he traded opinions and gossip with the fervor of a tabloid columnist. But he lamented the way Beijing's tightly constricted political atmosphere made it impossible for him to speak publicly, lest he be sent back to jail. 
 The release of Wei Jingsheng, China's leading dissident, who flew to the United States on Sunday, leaves behind a small band of political partisans who are essentially powerless to voice their concerns, much less organize any significant advocacy. Other dissidents languish in prison, similarly silent.
The gray-haired dissident said that Mr. Wei's departure, while bringing cheer to many sympathizers who are happy to see him free, has not otherwise altered the monotonous political landscape for dissidents here. The Communist Party tolerates no open questioning of its authority these days.
"There is a time to speak out and a time for silence," the dissident said. "Now is still a time for silence."
There is virtually no public debate of real political issues in China today. Political reform, religious freedom, even China's ambitious dam projects: almost every topic of political substance has been banned from serious discussion in public meetings or in the state-run media.
One measure of how tight the political atmosphere is in Beijing can be seen in the fact that there simply aren't many dissidents to check on. Two who openly criticized Government policies in the past said today that it was "not convenient" to meet or discuss the political situation.
It may seem remarkable that a nation as enormous and complex and fast-changing as China would be able to allow so little open discussion of political issues.
Yet a central paradox of China today is that such strict political limitations coincide with a tremendous expansion of personal freedom in recent years. Economic growth has brought an ever-wider array of choices when it comes to a job, a place of residence or a spouse -- all areas where Communist Party authorities once wielded near-absolute control.
"Ordinary people pay less attention to politics today than a few years ago," said the gray-haired dissident. "That's good. It means they can spend their time on other things."
When a change in the political atmosphere may come, he added, is as hard to predict as week-to-week developments in any country. President Jiang Zemin's recent trip to the United States, he said, laid the groundwork for Mr. Wei's release more than for any political relaxation.
Merle Goldman, a professor of Chinese history at Boston University, who has written extensively on Chinese dissidents, said Mr. Wei's release could encourage other dissidents to speak out.
"I see this as a -- I can't say a green light -- but as a way for people who have been silent to come forward now," said Ms. Goldman. "It'll be hard for Jiang to crack down now because he wants better relations with the U.S."
Mr. Wei was the best known of China's dissidents because of his eloquent writing and his unwillingness to bend to pressure from the authorities during his long incarceration, which spanned more than 18 years with only a brief respite.
The ranks of Chinese dissidents overseas are splintered and largely unheard in China. Some are refugees from the student-led movement in 1989, like Shen Tong and Chai Ling, who experienced only a few months of political activity within China followed by escape and then years of exile in the United States.
Yet Mr. Wei's case more closely resembles that of Wang Juntao, a longtime political activist who was jailed in China from 1989 until 1994, when he was released shortly before Congress voted on whether to renew most-favored-nation trading status for China. The official reason Mr. Wang was sent to the United States was also medical treatment.
A dilemma faced by Mr. Wang and Mr. Wei is that going overseas robs them of the moral stature that inevitably comes with bearing the hardship of being a political critic within China, whether in jail or not.
It is the same choice that could face Wang Dan, a 28-year-old former student leader who is the best known among China's remaining political prisoners. Mr. Wang said in the past that he would resist going overseas, though his mother has said more recently that he would consider it if it were necessary for medical reasons.
Asked today whether Wang Dan might also be released on medical parole, Shen Guofang, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, answered elliptically, "There have been such cases in the past, and there will continue to be such cases in the future."
Human rights activists in the United States, while welcoming Mr. Wei's release, have insisted that it does not really affect the overall human rights situation within China.
"Sending one more dissident into exile does not represent an improvement in China's human rights situation," said Xiao Qiang, executive director of Human Rights in China. "It is a disgrace that the Chinese Government holds its own citizens hostage to international politics."
A better measure, Mr. Xiao said, can be seen in the countless cases of ordinary people who face irrational or unfair handling by China's security and judicial branches.
One recent case involved a former prosecutor in Anhui Province in central China, who was detained without charge for 46 days after he wrote several open letters to Government leaders asking for the release of other dissidents. The man, Shen Liangqing, 35, has said he planned to sue the local government after it held him from Sept. 1 to Oct. 17 without charging him.

HEADLINE: BANKING'S CONSOLIDATION: THE BIG INVESTOR;
A Rattler of Status Quo With Status in His Veins

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
It seems incongruous that George Strawbridge Jr., a member of an old Main Line family, a historian and the biggest individual shareholder in the Corestates Financial Corporation, has played an instrumental role in the takeover of Philadelphia's last independent banking franchise, ending a tradition that stretches back to colonial days.
Mr. Strawbridge, who is 59, owns more than 5.1 million shares of Core states, a stake worth more than $400 million. If the sale of Corestates to the First Union Corporation goes through as now structured, the value of his holdings will be worth at least an additional $25 million. 
 Mr. Strawbridge, who was closeted in the Corestates board meeting yesterday and could not be reached for comment, has been a force at Core states since the fall of 1995, when Corestates agreed to buy the Meridian Bancorp of Reading, Pa., for $3.2 billion. Mr. Strawbridge, who was a big holder of Meridian shares, was named to the Corestates board shortly after the merger was completed.
But people close to the negotiations say Mr. Strawbridge has increased his influence even more in the last few months and has been pressuring Terrence A. Larsen, Corestates' chairman and chief executive, to sell the bank.
The pressure intensified after negotiations with the Mellon Banking Corporation broke down. Mr. Larsen balked at what would have been an $18 billion deal, in part because it would not have given him a substantive role in the new, combined company.
According to people close to the transaction, after the Mellon deal collapsed, the pressure on Mr. Larsen to sell came from board members like Mr. Strawbridge who were dissatisfied with the approach Mr. Larsen was taking in negotiations to sell Corestates.
Mr. Strawbridge has experience in dealing with recalcitrant bank chairmen, and his relationship with Mr. Larsen has a familial connection.
Mr. Strawbridge was one of a group of board members at Meridian who forced the company's sale to Corestates. Samuel A. McCullough, who at the time was chairman of Meridian, initially objected to the sale, insisting that the bank remain independent.
Mr. Strawbridge, who took two members of Meridian's board with him to Corestates, is a distant cousin of Peter S. Strawbridge, heir to the Strawbridge & Clothier retail chain, which was sold in July 1996 to the May Department Stores Company. Peter Strawbridge is also on the Corestates board.
But a much closer relative, G. Morris Dorrance, was the chairman of Corestates before Mr. Larsen succeeded him in 1988. Indeed, Mr. Dorrance was instrumental in elevating Mr. Larsen, a former economist, to the top job. Mr. Dorrance retired long before George Strawbridge became a big owner of Corestates stock or a director.
Mr. Strawbridge's connection to the Dorrance family, heirs to the Campbell Soup fortune, comes from his mother, the late Margaret Dorrance Strawbridge.
His father, George Strawbridge Sr., was long a force in Philadelphia financial circles: until he died on April 3, 1990, at the age of 80, the elder Mr. Strawbridge was a senior vice president and director at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., the Philadelphia-based stockbrokerage firm.
Initially, George Strawbridge Jr. used his Campbell's inheritance to buy big tracts of Brandywine Valley horse country and develop a racing stable, Augustin Stables. An avid steeplechase rider, he is a former president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.
What's more, Mr. Strawbridge is an academician. After receiving his bachelor's degree at Trinity College in Hartford, he earned M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Pennsylvania, where he specialized in Latin American history and politics. Currently, he is an adjunct professor at Widener University in Chester, Pa.
Mr. Strawbridge began investing in banks in the Philadelphia area in the 1970's, when he bought out the William duPont family's stake in the Delaware Trust Company, a sleepy bank in Wilmington, for an estimated $10 million. The value of his holdings has risen substantially since, as Delaware Trust was first sold to Meridian and Meridian was sold to Corestates and as Corestates is now being sold to First Union.
As of late yesterday, it was not known for certain whether Mr. Strawbridge would be named to the board of First Union. It is also not clear what relationship, if any, he has with First Union's chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Crutchfield Jr. But if the past is any guide, investors might find it instructive see how their relationship develops.

HEADLINE: Retailers' Earnings Near Expectations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Several big retailers -- Home Depot Inc., the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation and Limited Inc. -- reported fiscal third-quarter operating earnings yesterday that were in line with or above analysts' expectations.
Analysts said the results showed that consumers were in the mood to spend as the holiday shopping season approached, amid low unemployment and rising incomes. 
 As consumer incomes and confidence have risen, so have the number of people willing to invest in buy or remodel a house, analysts said, benefiting retailers like Home Depot.
Home Depot's operating profits rose to $299 million, or 40 cents a share, above the 39-cents-a-share estimate of 24 analysts surveyed by First Call. Without the special charge, Home Depot, the nation's largest home improvement retailer, earned $236 million, or 32 cents a share, up from $221 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier.
At Dayton Hudson, higher sales at the Target discount chain lifted operating profits above analysts' estimates. Net income at the Minneapolis-based retailer rose to $160 million, or 71 cents a share, compared with $107 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.
Ann Taylor said that net income fell to $2.2 million, or 8 cents a share, from $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. But it still managed to drum up enough sales to better Wall Street estimates of per-share earnings of 6 cents, based on 13 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International.
Limited's earnings -- $42 million, or 15 cents a share -- matched the average estimate of 22 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S.

HEADLINE: THE TEAMSTERS: LOOKING FORWARD;
Delay of Election Is Sought To Allow for Hoffa Inquiry

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A day after a court official barred the teamsters' president, Ron Carey, from running for re-election next March, another court-appointed monitor said yesterday that she would seek a postponement of the election to allow more time to investigate the campaign finances of Mr. Carey's rival, James P. Hoffa.
Mr. Carey's supporters applauded the move because it raised the possibility that Mr. Hoffa might also be disqualified. A postponement would also give the Carey forces more time to settle on a candidate strong enough to replace Mr. Carey. 
 "We are asking for as full an investigation of Hoffa as they did of Carey," said Kenneth Paff, national organizer of Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a Carey faction. "We believe that a full investigation might uncover that employer money or mob money had been funneled into the Hoffa election campaign."
But none in the Carey camp suggested that their leader would somehow be reinstated, although Mr. Carey, who is 61, has announced that he will appeal Monday's ruling by the court official, Kenneth Conboy. Instead, they suggested that a new leader would probably emerge from among various Carey allies, without speculating on who that might be.
The election overseer, Benetta M. Mansfield, was appointed by the Federal courts to supervise the teamsters election. She reports to Judge David Edelstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who has overall supervision of the teamsters and must ultimately decide whether to delay the election, and for how long.
Ms. Mansfield said she sought the delay because Mr. Conboy, in barring Mr. Carey from re-election, had also said there was enough evidence to justify an investigation of Mr. Hoffa.
Ms. Mansfield and Mr. Conboy serve as court-appointed officials under a 1989 consent decree the union accepted to settle a Federal racketeering suit.
The stakes in the election are enormous, not only for the teamsters but also for the American labor movement. Mr. Carey, as teamsters president, played a big role in installing John J. Sweeney in 1995 as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and his downfall could hurt Mr. Sweeney. Under Mr. Sweeney's leadership, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has channeled tens of millions of dollars into expanding union membership and supporting pro-labor political issues and political candidates.
Mr. Hoffa's aides criticized the request for an election delay. "We think it's an effort where they won't hold an election unless they can fix it," Richard Leebove, a spokesman for Mr. Hoffa, said of the Carey camp. "What they are going to do is go after us."
Some Federal officials said the coming battle over leadership of the teamsters' union could hurt the union movement just as it was regaining some public support. In particular, they cited the union's success in rallying support during a strike last summer of 180,000 teamsters against the United Parcel Service. The union had called for less part-time work and higher pay for part-timers.
"After the U.P.S. strike, the teamsters certainly were identified as a symbol of the union movement's ability to represent an important new class of workers: part-time workers," said Edward Montgomery, chief economist at the Labor Department. "The concern now is that all of the scandal associated with the election financing will erode public support."
The teamsters, with 1.4 million members, have expanded far beyond truck drivers, their original constituents. They represent Northwest's flight attendants, for example, salt-mine workers near Cleveland, 25,000 New York City public employees, performers at Disney World and thousands of office and health care workers.
Until a new president is chosen, Mr. Carey will continue to lead the union. And his effectiveness -- or the effectiveness of the union itself -- will get its first test in negotiations just getting under way for a new contract for 100,000 long-haul truck drivers. One issue -- whether drivers should continue a current practice of being called in to drive although they might not have gotten sufficient rest -- is the sort of safety issue that Mr. Carey would have used in a public relations campaign to get public support for the teamsters, said Michael Belzer, a transportation expert at the University of Michigan.
Mr. Carey, who became president of the teamsters in 1991 on a platform of rooting out corruption, narrowly won re-election last December against Mr. Hoffa, the son and namesake of the powerful teamsters president who disappeared in 1975.
But a court-appointed official threw out the results in August, and on Monday, Mr. Conboy ruled that Mr. Carey had illegally diverted $700,000 in union funds to his election campaign, and for that reason could not be a candidate in the new balloting, scheduled for February and March of next year.
That seemed to leave the field open to Mr. Hoffa, who is far better known among the teamsters members than the two or three others considered potential candidates. But Mr. Conboy also said on Monday that the Hoffa camp might have "systematically misreported" its campaign contributions. He called for a further investigation. And in anticipation, Ms. Mansfield said yesterday that she would petition the court for a suspension of the balloting.
Ms. Mansfield also postponed the mailing of the December issue of the union magazine The Teamster. She said it would be misleading to distribute the "notice of election included in the magazine."

HEADLINE: At Ancient Site Along the Nile, Modern Horror

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: LUXOR, Egypt, Nov. 18

 BODY:
In the Middle Court of the Temple of Hatsepshut today, piles of newly strewn sand could not disguise the plain fact that a structure dating from before 1400 B.C. had become a late 20th century slaughterhouse.
Blood spattered the ancient colonnades, and sandstone pillars were marked by bullet holes and bits of flesh. These traces of evidence, together with accounts by survivors, began to provide a gruesome picture of the Monday-morning massacre in which Islamic militants fell upon two groups of tourists admiring the magnificent pillars and carved reliefs memorializing a queen who wore a false beard to rule as a Pharaoh. 
 Firing automatic weapons in a prolonged fusillade, the attackers left 58 foreign tourists dead.
"They shot everyone in the arms and legs," a surviving Swiss tourist, Rosemarie Dousse, told the Swiss national radio. "Then they killed everyone who was still alive with a shot to the head."
"They took all the young women, the girls, and disappeared with them," Ms. Dousse said. "I don't know where they went with the women but they hurt them. We could hear screams of pain." There was no official confirmation that young women had been singled out in this way, however.
The militants were also said to have been armed with knives, and there were reports by credible witnesses that they had seen bodies of several foreigners in which an ear or a nose was missing. These accounts, too, were not officially confirmed.
Today, as some tourists began to leave Egypt in fear, others ventured to the temple here despite the chilling accounts. Those interviews and other details that have emerged in the last two days indicate that the slaughter was more vicious than was previously known, and that the militants seemed intent on making even more tourists their victims.
The Egyptian authorities said today that the final death toll was 58 foreigners, rather than 60 as reported on Monday, in addition to four Egyptians and six attackers. According to their governments, the dead included at least 35 Swiss, 9 Japanese, 6 Britons, including a child, and 4 Germans. Others killed in the attack included a Bulgarian, a Colombian and a French citizen, the Egyptian authorities said.
By many of the accounts that emerged today, the attackers took advantage of a modest police presence and killed their victims in two clusters inside the grounds of the ancient temple.
A statement issued in the name of Egypt's most prominent Islamic militant group said the massacre had begun as an effort to take hostages in order to secure the release of a leader imprisoned in New York for his role in the World Trade Center bombing. But the accounts by survivors gave no hint of any attempts to take tourists alive.
In an apparent acknowledgement of shortcomings, the Egyptian official responsible for internal security, Interior Minister Hassan al-Alfi, was reported this evening to have resigned. President Hosni Mubarak, who visited the scene of the attack, told reporters that Egypt would now "take much more tougher measures" to protect foreign visitors.
But within 24 hours of the attack, some tour operators had suspended vacation tours in Egypt. Seven charter aircraft left London today for Luxor to fly tourists home, in some cases weeks ahead of schedule.
In the face of that reaction, the Egyptian Government hurried to reopen the temple to the public. This morning, guides were pointing out to visitors famous images including a relief in the Punt Colonnade that celebrates a trading expedition to Punt, on the Somali coast, that brought back to Egypt valuable wares, including incense and myrrh.
The tourists had arrived at Hatshepsut's Temple on Monday morning to climb a steep ramp leading to the Middle Court and a pair of colonnaded terraces at the rear that were the temple's archeological gems.
It was there, witnesses said, that as many as 50 of the victims died, because the cramped terraces offered no route of escape in the face of the assault by six men armed with knives and automatic weapons.
The attack began just before 8:45 A.M., when six men dressed in plain black clothing and carrying vinyl bags entered the temple through its main gate, ignoring guards' request to produce their tickets. "This is the ticket," the last of the men finally replied as he produced an automatic weapon and opened fire, killing a police guard.
Ahmed Ghassam, 40, another guard, described the exchange. He too was shot, but in an interview from his hospital bed, he said he had survived because the body of the other guard had fallen on top of his.
A 45-minute rampage inside the temple followed. People who had access to the site before the dead were removed said that the main concentrations of bodies had been near the Birth Colonnade and the Punt Colonnade, and that between 20 and 25 people, most if not all of them foreigners, had been killed at each site.
Today, bullet holes had been patched and some blood stains scrubbed away, but debris including a piece from broken eyeglasses and a stray earring near a patch of blood remained. And deep inside the colonnades, the amount of blood and tissue sprayed high upon some walls appeared at least in part to substantiate the accounts of witnesses who say that some of the victims were hunted down and slain.
While the assailants relied mostly on automatic weapons, some accounts said they also used knives to kill and to mutilate several bodies.
Mr. Ghassam was among several witnesses who said he had seen the raiders slit the throats of some victims. Ahmed Youssef Aly, a Luxor-based journalist, said that during a visit to a morgue on Monday night he had seen several mutilated bodies, including that of a Japanese woman missing an ear and a Swiss man whose nose was missing.
Even as they fled the scene at about 9:30 A.M., the assailants may have intended to renew their attack elsewhere.
After running from the temple grounds, the attackers hijacked an Isis Tours bus and its driver, Hagag al-Nahas, 36. They fled again on foot after a gun battle near a police checkpoint left one militant dead. The remaining five were killed near the Valley of the Queens some time after 11 A.M. in the last of many firefights that raged as policemen and civilians pursued them into the rugged hills.
Mr. Nahas, who was badly beaten with a rifle butt during the hijacking, said, "They were trying to go to another place to shoot more people, and I refused."
The Islamic Group, Egypt's largest Islamic militant organization, took responsibility for the attack, saying that it had intended to take hostage as many foreign tourists as possible, and that it had hoped to force the release of its spiritual leader, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, from an American jail.
But Egyptian officials and other experts said the methodical nature of the killings did not appear to be consistent with an attempt to take hostages. In attacking tourists, the militants have made plain that their goal is to undermine a sector vital to the Egyptian economy, and the experts said they may be trying to frighten foreign governments, tour operators and potential tourists.
The dead included four Japanese couples on honeymoon, and George Wigham, 68, and his wife Ivy, 71, a retired couple from Kent, England.
"They just liked the idea of going down the Nile," their son Paul said today in a telephone interview. "It was their dream. I tried to persuade them not to go, but my father said he could get killed just as easily at home. It was the trip of a lifetime for them."
Many tourists remained in Luxor today, however, and most of those who were interviewed said they saw no reason to change their plans. Several hundred, including many Americans, even visited the Temple of Hatshepsut.
"Lightning never strikes twice in the same place," Mike Grubbs, 33, of Lamont, Colo., explained.
For others, however, a heavy pall had been cast by notices posted by tour operators in several hotel lobbies this morning. They included an announcement from the British-based Thomson Tours that the company was suspending its tours in Egypt "in accordance with advice received" from several authorities, including the British Foreign Office.
At one hotel, tourists who had been given less than two hours notice of their departure were boarding buses for the Luxor airport and a flight home to Manchester, England. "I think it's the right thing to do," said Sasha Ainbow, who until Monday night had expected to stay on in Egypt for another week.
"It's like the I.R.A., isn't it?" Mrs. Ainbow said, referring to the Irish Republican Army. "An explosion goes off and you never know if there will be just one or many, many more."

GRAPHIC: Photo: American tourists visited the ancient Temple of Hatshepsut in Luxor, Egypt, yesterday, undaunted by the massacre of 58 foreign tourists and 4 Egyptians by Islamic militants at the temple the day before. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A12)
 
Diagram/Chart: "Pharaoh's Temple: Scene of Horror"
A reconstruction of the killings at the Temple of Hatshepsut, near Luxor, Egypt, on Monday, from official and eyewitness accounts.
 
THE ATTACK
 
1. 8:45 A.M. -- Six armed men storm a ticket booth at the 3,400-year-old temple, killing an Egyptian guard.
 
2. 8:45-9:30 -- Gunmen go up a ramp to the temple's middle courtyard, where hundreds of people are milling about, and begin shooting at tourists in and around the ancient colonnades. More than 50 are killed and about 25 are wounded.
 
THE SHOOTOUT
 
3. 9:30 -- Gunmen flee past the ticket booth and hijack a tourist bus and its driver.
 
4. 9:45 A.M. -- Bus stops near a police checkpoint by the road to the Valley of the Queens. Shooting erupts, and one gunman is killed.
 
5. About 10 A.M. -- Gunmen flee on foot into the hills north and west. By about 11:30, five more have been killed. (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Illegal Iraqi Oil Shipments Increase, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Senior officials of the United States Navy and State Department told a Security Council sanctions committee today that Iraq's illegal exports of oil through the coastal waters of the Persian Gulf have jumped 500 percent in the last year.
These exports, primarily of diesel fuel, are carried in ships that stay within the territorial waters of Iraq and Iran, out of the reach of an international naval force patrolling the gulf to enforce a United Nations embargo on Iraq. 
 The international force, comprising ships from Australia, Belgium, Britain, Canada, the Netherlands, New Zealand and the United States, is coordinated by Vice Adm. Thomas B. Fargo, commander of the United States Fifth Fleet.
American officials said that the briefing occurred coincidentally during the crisis over weapons inspections in Iraq. But some diplomats expressed concern at the timing of the charges of increased smuggling.
The United States has used the sanctions committee in the past to maximize pressure on Baghdad at critical moments. The committee meets behind closed doors.
The American officials, who declined to be identified, said that the Iraqis, apparently working in close cooperation with Iranian officials, had developed an efficient export-import operation in the sea corridor hugging the coast of Iran to the border with Pakistan and beyond. Diesel fuel is shipped out in a steady stream of vessels, the officials said. Iraqis earn cash from the sales or buy imports prohibited by sanctions.
There has been illegal trade in the Persian Gulf since sanctions were first applied to Iraq after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. But that trade, always small in scale, has suddenly mushroomed, American officials said. They estimate that Iraq sold about $10 million in diesel fuel in 1996 and $75 million this year.
Some of the fuel has been traced to Bombay, where the Iraqis would be able to purchase any number of useful but prohibited items, including electronic equipment and chemicals. India and Iraq were trading partners before the 1991 war in the gulf.
Since the border trade is out of the reach of interception ships, whose activities are limited to international waters, officials do not know much about Iraqi imports beyond the cargoes that have been seized when ships strayed onto the high seas.

HEADLINE: In Afghan Refugee Camp, Albright Hammers Taliban

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: NASIR BAGH, Pakistan, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Speaking to Afghan refugees here, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today issued her harshest criticism of the Taliban movement that rules most of Afghanistan, calling its treatment of women and children "despicable."
At the desolate mud-brick camp for 80,000 Afghan refugees, 25 miles from the Afghan border, Ms. Albright spoke proudly of her own experience as a wartime refugee who rose to become the first woman to serve as Secretary of State. She urged the young Afghan women and students, listening attentively in their flowing head scarves and long trousers, to take charge of their lives, demand education for themselves and seek equality in their society. 
 "It is impossible to modernize a nation if half or more of the population is left behind," Ms. Albright said at the Bibi Mariam school for girls at the camp, which is helped by American aid provided through the International Rescue Committee. "If a society is to move forward, women and girls must have access to schools, be able to participate in the economy and be protected from physical exploitation and abuse."
The Taliban, which began as a movement of fundamentalist Islamic religious students in Afghanistan's villages, took over Kabul, the Afghan capital, in September 1996, but has been unable to seize the northern part of the country. Although American officials welcomed the initial stability in Kabul, they were appalled by the abuses of human rights by the Taliban, and the State Department's tone has grown increasingly condemnatory.
Pakistan has recognized the Taliban, and the country's security services provide important help to the movement. Asked by a Pakistani journalist in Islamabad this morning why Washington would not recognize the Taliban, Ms. Albright said bluntly: "It's very clear why we're opposed to Taliban. We're opposed to their approach to human rights, to their despicable treatment of women and children and their lack of respect for human dignity, in a way more reminiscent of the past than the future."
Asked if Ms. Albright's comments embarrassed Pakistan, a senior minister, emphasizing that he was speaking unofficially, said that "it is no great problem in Pakistan, but what we don't know is what the reaction will be over there," pointing to the mountains beyond which Afghanistan lies.
But both Pakistan and the United States support a United Nations mediation effort to try to form a coalition government that might last and bring the Afghan civil war to an end. Of the three million Afghan refugees who entered Pakistan from 1979 onward, about half returned after the fall of the Communist Government, American officials said.
But 100,000 more refugees have come since the fall of Kabul to the Taliban, and the bulk of the women Ms. Albright spoke to today had fled Kabul. Some expressed resentment that the United States did not back those opposed to the Taliban before their victory.
At the camp, Ms. Albright and two of her top aides, both of them women, met privately with a group of women to ask them about their lives. Given cultural and religious restrictions, only female reporters were allowed into the room to listen, but they provided a description and tape of the meeting to their male colleagues.
"We've had a hard time getting our jobs," Ms. Albright said to the 25 or so women and girls in a small mud-brick classroom, "but not as hard a time as you."
Ms. Albright said that "American women have been very concerned about Afghan women."
"We have read about you," she said. "And I especially wanted to come to meet with you and hear your stories."
"I find that women have the same stories," Ms. Albright continued. "It is very hard for me to sit here and compare myself to you, and I have been very lucky, as have my friends. But I know we are all the same, and we have the same feelings -- we all suffer when we hurt and we all suffer for each other."
"I have found that when women are given a chance to work and raise children, they can be so brilliant," she said. "Yet so many women are destined to suffer, and we should do all we can to help them."
Dressed conservatively in a long brown jacket and trousers, Ms. Albright concluded by telling the women: "I hope I can come visit you again -- but come to a Afghanistan where you can live as full equals. We really are all sisters."
The last working visit of a Secretary of State to Pakistan was by George P. Shultz in 1983, although Mr. Shultz also went in 1988 to the funeral of Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq.
In conversations with Pakistani officials, Ms. Albright discussed nuclear and missile proliferation and other security questions, Afghanistan and Kashmir, which Ms. Albright said she hoped would be settled in her lifetime.
She also discussed the 38 F-16's that Pakistan bought from the United States but never received, an issue Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khana called "a matter of critical importance to our people."
The Pakistanis paid for the planes, which were built. But before delivery, President Bush told Congress he could not certify that Pakistan did not possess a nuclear weapon. Under the so-called Pressler Amendment, intended to discourage nuclear proliferation, the planes could not be delivered. But the United States has been unable to sell them elsewhere and return the proceeds to Pakistan. A deal to sell them to Indonesia was blocked late last year by Congress, which criticized that cpountry's human-rights record.
Ms. Albright also urged the Pakistanis to find those responsible for the killing of four American oil workers and their Pakistani driver last week in Karachi. The murders made her insistent on going ahead with her visit to Pakistan despite other pressing business surrounding Iraq, her aides said.
But her long-planned visit here was shortened by her diplomatic shuttling around to deal with the Iraq crisis, and her trip to India will be shortened as well. A visit to Bangladesh was canceled altogether. From India, she may fly back to Western Europe to meet on Iraq with other foreign ministers, but officials said that no firm plans had been made.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Untouchable Huang

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Has John Huang, the Lippo banker and Clinton fund-raiser at the vortex of the campaign finance scandal, been notified that he is a target of a Federal investigation?
No. How about "subject of an investigation"? No. Has Huang been called as a witness? No. 
 In 12 months has the F.B.I., or anybody at Main Justice, interrogated John Huang? No. Grand jury? Forget it. Huang is not in hiding; has anybody at Justice even tried to ask him anything? Again, no.
How can this be? You might think that Huang has asserted his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself, as he did to duck Congress. But he has not taken the Fifth with Justice. His testimony has not even been sought.
Because he is under no pressure from Justice to talk, Huang has not sought immunity from prosecution by proffering evidence about higher-ups. As Janet Reno's Public Integrity section dawdles, Huang lets the statutes of limitation run.
Reno's excuse for not seeking independent counsel -- that no "hard money" was being raised in Clinton-Gore White House phone calls -- was shattered by The Washington Post, which ran evidence of diversion unknown to Justice's legion of lazy lawyers. She put on a charade of "shaking up" her inept staff.
Some shake-up. Reno soon gave her fall guy, Laura Ingersoll, a special departmental commendation for "focusing the investigation on potential campaign financing violations of high officials." Ingersoll and her boss (Mark Richard, feted last week for 30 years of bureaucratic service) earned the plaudits of Reno Justice by doing about John Huang what the White House wanted done: nothing.
Did the latest patsy prosecutor, Charles La Bella, zero in on John Huang? White House videotapes long withheld from Congress, and never even sought by Reno Justice, showed Huang in action with Bill Clinton. On one clip, the Indonesian gardener solicited by Huang to channel an illegal $450,000 to the Clinton campaign popped out with the connection to Huang's old employer: "James Riady sent me." Justice shrugged.
Because The Post's Bob Woodward and NBC's Tim Russert enticed Reno into asking publicly for an interview with Clinton, La Bella had a chance to ask him about the Sept. 13, 1995, Oval Office meeting in which the President and Riady switched Huang from Commerce favor-doer to Democratic fund-raiser.
Was the President asked about this Huang meeting, or about Lippo-Riady-Huang connections to China? Clinton permitted no oath or transcript. I hear the investigators choked, confining their questions to narrow issues, not abuses of power.
Last week, with Senate hearings safely closed down, our conflicted Attorney General was humiliated by her own inept troops again, forced to reveal to the senators a long-lost F.B.I. file reporting that Huang, while working with a top-secret clearance at Commerce, gave a classified document to Chinese officials.
Leaks from Justice pooh-pooh the possibility of economic espionage. But some officials allow as how Maria Hsia, the Huang colleague who set up the unlawful Buddhist temple fund-raiser, is cited in F.B.I. files as being too tight with Beijing.
Is Justice following the lead generated at the Senate hearings about Huang's use of the faxes and phones at the Stephens Inc. "drop" across the street from his Commerce office? Huang's friends say it was for his philanthropic activities. Reno Justice wants to believe that.
About the only investigation showing an interest in Huang is Larry Klayman's Judicial Watch, a private group that started a Freedom of Information suit to find out who sold slots on Commerce's trade missions to Asia. Huang cannot plead the Fifth to this civil suit; his sole public appearance since the scandal broke was the videotape of his deposition.
Klayman (who is also suing to discover the culprits in Filegate, long sleeping in Ken Starr's arms) deposed Janice Stewart, Huang's secretary during the stint Riady arranged for him at Commerce. She swore that Huang often ordered her to shred overseas cables. Freeh's Bungling Institute shows no interest because it has trouble accessing what is already in its files.
Who will get the man at the center to sing? Not this crowd; to Reno Justice, Huang is untouchable.

Russia Says Iraq Is Ready To Resolve U.N. Impasse
Russia and Iraq have drafted a proposal to end the standoff between the United States and Saddam Hussein, said Russia's Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov. He said the plan would allow the United Nations to carry out weapons inspections, presumably with the participation of Americans, but that the open-ended search should be brought to a speedy end. A1 

A Day After Egypt's Massacre
Egypt's Interior Minister was reported to have resigned after 58 foreign tourists were killed at the Temple of Hatshepsut in Luxor, which was reopened to the public. A1
 
Albright Meets Afghan Women
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke out against the treatment of women and children by the Islamic Taliban movement currently ruling Afghanistan. She was speaking at a camp for 80,000 Afghan refugees in Pakistan, and she called the young Afghan women there her "sisters," urging them to take charge of their lives, demand education for themselves and seek equality in their society. A14
 
Mutiny May Lurk for Netanyahu
While Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was being snubbed by President Clinton in America and assailed by Arabs at a conference in Qatar, senior politicians in his party, Likud, were reported to be considering ways to oust or isolate him. The behind-the-scenes maneuvering was reported to an Israeli newspaper by Roni Milo, the mayor of Tel Aviv and a critic of Mr. Netanyahu. A6
 
Swiss Send Holocaust Check
A woman in Riga, Latvia, became the first person to receive a check from Switzerland for her suffering during the Holocaust. Reva Shefer, 75, was given a $400 check from a fund, currently amounting to $200 million, established by a consortium of Swiss banks and businesses to pay each of the 27,000 eligible Holocaust survivors in Eastern Europe. A4
 
Bombing Trial Begins in Berlin
The trial of five people charged with the 1986 bombing of a Berlin night club, in which two American soldiers and a Turk were killed, began in Berlin. Sixteen scarred and maimed victims of the bombing sat in the courtroom with the five alleged perpetrators of the attack. German prosecutors said the two Palestinians, a Libyan and two Germans on trial had acted on orders from Libyan intelligence. A5
 
Dissident Was Too Ill to Stay
Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known political prisoner until his release three days ago, had to make a painful decision to leave China but he had little choice, his sister said. She said he had shingles and other health problems that made the option of remaining in China as a martyr all but impossible. Mr. Wei, who spent nearly 18 years in Chinese prisons after publicly advocating democracy, is now in a hospital in Detroit. A3
 
NATIONAL A18-28
 
Federal Monitor Urges Delay in Union Election
A day after a union monitor barred teamsters' president Ron Carey from running for re-election, another election monitor proposed postponing the election so she would have more time to investigate the campaign finances of Mr. Carey's rival, James P. Hoffa. A28
 
Court Vetoes Abortion Law
Ohio's effort to ban a late-term method of abortion was declared unconstitutional by a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati. It was the latest Federal court ruling to block state versions of the legislation that has twice been passed by Congress and twice vetoed by President Clinton. A24
 
Sanctions Possible in Suicides
The Drug Enforcement Administration, acting on a request of two Republican members of Congress who oppose an Oregon law legalizing assisted suicide, has warned that doctors who prescribe drugs to help terminally ill patients kill themselves could face severe sanctions. A18
 
Atlanta Bombing Data Released
Still stymied in their investigation of three Atlanta bombings in the last 16 months, law-enforcement officials released details about the bombs' components, hoping to shake the memory of a sales clerk or someone who knows the bomber. A18
 
Gun 'Education' Criticized
The National Rifle Association, faced with a slump in gun sales and negative publicity, is trying to cultivate a new generation of gun owners by using the same strategies to hook children on guns that the tobacco industry has used to hook them on cigarettes, according to a study by an anti-gun group. The N.R.A. disputed the findings, saying its educational programs promote safety. A24
 
U.S. to Claim Tobacco Money
The Clinton Administration has told states that the Federal Government will take at least half of any money they recover through lawsuits against tobacco companies for the costs of providing health care to smokers under Medicaid. Administration officials reason that the Federal Government contributes at least half of every Medicaid dollar spent by the states, so it should get at least half of every dollar recovered from the tobacco companies for the costs of treating tobacco-related illnesses of Medicaid recipients. A24
 
U.S. Plotted Castro Sabotage
The Pentagon offered President Kennedy an extraordinary variety of dirty tricks designed to sabotage Fidel Castro, newly declassified documents show. These plans included sophomoric pranks, such as faking a picture of a fat and debauched Castro to destroy his image, and murderous plots. A25
 
Airbag Rules Are Amended
The Federal Government announced a new rule that would let millions of car owners obtain toggle switches to shut off airbags, but officials said the change could cost more lives than it saves. A20

HEADLINE: IRAQ AND RUSSIANS DRAFT A PROPOSAL TO END GULF CRISIS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Russia and Iraq have drafted a proposal to end the standoff between the United States and Saddam Hussein, Russia's Foreign Minister said this evening.
Yevgeny M. Primakov, the Foreign Minister, said the plan would allow the United Nations to carry out weapons inspections, presumably with Americans taking part. But he said the inspectors' open-ended search for chemical, nuclear and biological weapons should be brought to a speedy conclusion. 
 Mr. Primakov did not spell out details, but he outlined how Iraq might achieve its long-sought goal of ending the crippling economic sanctions imposed after it invaded Kuwait in 1990.
The discussions opened with the blessing of the United States, which hoped Mr. Primakov could find a face-saving way for President Hussein to back down. But the Russian proposal raised serious questions even in its bare outlines, as it seemed to call for a softening of American policy on Iraq.
Clinton Administration officials in Washington said tonight that they did not know enough about the proposal to react to it, although Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke by telephone with Mr. Primakov today.
The United States proceeded with a slow military buildup in the Persian Gulf area, including the dispatch of six F-117A "stealth" fighters and six B-52 bombers to beef up American striking power. President Clinton has also authorized the deployment of about 30 additional fighters and bombers if American military commanders conclude that they are needed.
The Pentagon said an American U-2 reconnaissance plane flew over Iraq today without incident. But the Pentagon's spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said Iraq was moving around its air defenses in the southern part of the country in a way that could be threatening.
"We think he is interested in much more than diplomacy," Mr. Bacon said of President Hussein.
Pentagon officials said the Iraqi military appeared to be setting up its surface-to-air missile batteries to "trap" allied aircraft patrolling the no-flight zones in the country's north and south, a tactic the Iraqis have used before.
For six years, the United States has insisted that the terms under which President George Bush stopped the Persian Gulf war in 1991 are not negotiable. It has never been willing to set deadlines for completing the inspections or to put any restrictions on the demands made by the United Nations.
The United Nations has insisted that the sanctions remain in effect until the inspectors certify that Iraq has destroyed its missiles and its chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs. Mr. Hussein must also meet other demands including returning of Kuwaiti prisoners of war and paying reparations to Kuwait for the 1990 invasion.
The weapons inspectors have attributed the slow pace of their work to an elaborate effort by Baghdad to conceal its armaments and destroy weapons. The head of the United Nations team said Baghdad had stepped up those efforts in the days since the inspectors were expelled.
Mr. Primakov made his televised announcement after President Boris N. Yeltsin met with Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq. Mr. Primakov boasted that he had found the diplomatic solution that had eluded the United States, France, Britain and the United Nations.
He made a similar assertion shortly before the start of the gulf war, but the allies against Iraq swiftly rejected his ideas.
Tonight, Mr. Primakov said, "As a result of these talks, a specific program has been worked out which, we believe, allows us to avoid military confrontation and the use of military methods, and to move toward resolving the crisis."
Mr. Primakov engaged in intensive diplomacy before the gulf war, as Moscow sought to dissuade Washington from its offensive to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait. As a special envoy, he shuttled from Moscow to Washington to Baghdad. Mr. Primakov even traveled to the Iraqi capital in a camouflaged car during American bombing raids.
The Bush Administration viewed Mr. Primakov's diplomacy as a transparent effort to help the Mr. Hussein's Government preserve its military might and hold on to power.
But this time the situation is different. The Clinton Administration is not eager to use force, nor are its allies in Western Europe and the Middle East. The goal is not to evict an occupying Iraqi Army from Kuwait, but to persuade Baghdad to allow United Nations weapons inspectors to work unfettered.
Nor does Iraq seem determined to fight. Its goal now is not to annex a neighboring country, but to bring a quick end to the inspections, create divisions between the United States and its allies and force an end to economic sanctions.
American officials remain suspicious of Russian intentions, but this time they appear willing to let Moscow play the role of mediator if it can deliver Iraqi concessions.
Mr. Primakov said he wanted to meet in Geneva on Wednesday with Ms. Albright, Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain and Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France to go over the details.
Secretary Albright dropped plans for a side trip in India but has no immediate plans to fly to Geneva, a spokesman said. Not only would the logistics be difficult, but American officials seem wary of putting themselves in a position in which pressure would be put on them to go along with a plan that remains somewhat vague.
A senior Administration official said the proposal appeared not to be in final form. He said it was possible that Russia was attempting a last-minute intervention that could interfere with American policy. "Is there a possibility of that?" the official said. "Absolutely. But I'm not too concerned about it, because the answer will just be no."
Another official said the fact that the Russians might not have finished their negotiations with the Iraqis could explain why they had not disclosed any details.
Mr. Primakov has talked of accelerating the work of the United Nations Special Commission established to insure that Iraq has ended its programs to develop weapons of mass destruction and has destroyed existing weapons.
That might be something the United States could discuss if the United Nations inspectors were allowed to resume their work unconditionally. But if Iraq insists that the United Nations agree to expedite its work before the inspectors are allowed back in the country, Washington will almost certainly reject the plan.
There are other potential sticking points. The United States does not want to guarantee an immediate end to the sanctions, even if the Special Commission determines that Iraq's programs to develop weapons of mass destruction have been ended.
American officials say they need to see a pattern of compliance in other areas as well before agreeing to any lifting of the sanctions.
Russia, in contrast, is eager to see the sanctions removed as quickly as possible, as is France.
Economics is a big reason. Iraq owes Moscow billions of dollars. The debts were accumulated during Iraq's war with Iran during the 1980's, when the Soviet Union was a major arms supplier. Iraq can only afford to repay these debts if sanctions are lifted and it begins exporting more of its oil.
Further, Russian oil companies are anxious to pursue lucrative deals to develop new Iraqi oil fields after the sanctions are removed. And Russian weapons manufacturers would like to conclude new arms deals.
Politically, the burst of diplomacy provides Russia with an opportunity to assume a central role on the world stage and maintain influence in the Middle East. That is important for a country that is still uneasy about its loss of superpower status.
