HEADLINE: Seoul Will Ask U.S. and Japan For Assistance

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
South Korea said today that it would ask the United States and Japan to help rescue the country from potentially the most damaging outbreak yet in a financial crisis that has erupted across Asia. But American officials, while encouraging South Korea to seek assistance, made clear that the International Monetary Fund, not Washington, would have to take the lead in any bailout of South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy.
The urgent need of the country for billions of dollars to meet its commitments to overseas lenders and to end a selloff of its currency prompted a hurried series of back-channel consultations by American, European and Japanese officials hoping to prevent South Korea's problems from infecting other markets. 
 Their immediate concern was how to persuade South Korea's leaders that the country could no longer forestall a bailout by the I.M.F. until after presidential elections next month. In the midst of a turbulent campaign in which the ruling party may lose power, Korean politicians are trying hard to avoid the embarrassment of surrendering economic policy for the country to an outside authority. This afternoon, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin issued a statement urging Korea to "move forward quickly to address the present challenges, in particular with forceful and effective action to strengthen the financial system."
To underscore the need for quick action, two senior United States officials were dispatched to Seoul today to meet with the country's new Finance Minister, Lim Chang Yuel, who took office today after his predecessor was dismissed by President Kim Young Sam. Within hours of his appointment, Mr. Lim said he would seek help from the central banks of the United States, the main military ally of South Korea, and, more remarkably, from Japan, its onetime colonial master and its current economic rival. The two American officials are Timothy F. Geithner, the assistant secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, and Edwin Truman, who runs the international finance division of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Lim did not specify what he had in mind, and no formal request has yet been made. Presumably, what South Korea would ask for is a complex transaction between central banks, known as swaps, in which dollars or yen would be temporarily exchanged for South Korean won. Mr. Lim also reversed the Government's previous insistence that it would not accept rescue plans the way Thailand and Indonesia did earlier this year, saying he would "consider an I.M.F. bailout if necessary."
Both outside economists and American officials say that the underlying industrial capability of South Korea remains strong; it is a big manufacturer of steel, automobiles and semiconductors. But the country's growth can no longer provide the cash to cover the debts of a banking system that is now in shambles after lending money to wildly overinflated real estate projects, pork-barrel construction and well-connected businesses that in return paid the ruling party handsomely.
Bad loans now total more than $20 billion, Korean officials say, and many economists believe that the real figure is much higher.
No one seems to know how big a bailout fund may be required. Internal estimates within the Treasury Department indicate that a $30 billion I.M.F. program might be sufficient. But private economists have given much higher numbers.
"The fact of the matter," one Administration official said today, "is that we still don't have all the facts."
What is clear is that any I.M.F. package would require South Korea to agree to far-reaching economic change. In such bailouts, the reforms generally include wide-ranging disclosure of critical financial data -- something the South Korean Government has so far resisted -- and permitting foreigners to invest in the country without restrictions.
Mr. Lim moved in that direction today, and said that he was ending a Government requirement that had prevented the national currency, the won, from falling more than 2.25 percent a day. Early on Thursday in Seoul, the won, which had already fallen 20 percent against the dollar since the beginning of this year, fell by the newly raised limit, 10 percent, and stocks were trading lower.
America's interest in helping South Korea goes far beyond the country's role as a trading partner. After Japan, it is America's most important military ally in Asia, and more than 30,000 American troops are based near the demilitarized zone that divides the country.
Moreover, Washington is concerned that South Korea not appear weak at a critical moment in negotiations with the North. On Friday, representatives of North and South Korea, the United States and China, meeting in New York, are expected to agree on talks in Geneva next month that could lead to a formal end to the Korean War, which ended in an armistice but no peace treaty.
Some American officials are also worried about the stability of the South Korean Government. The leading candidate for president is a longtime opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, who was kidnapped, imprisoned and nearly killed during his long career as an opposition leader against a series of repressive military governments. But Mr. Kim's political base is weak, and he is openly disliked by the country's leading businesses -- the huge conglomerates known as the chaebol -- and by the financial community.
"We could be in a position in which Kim Dae Jung takes office in the midst of a financial emergency that is going to require a lot of pain and downsizing by South Korean businesses," one American diplomat said earlier this week.
That is why the United States is trying to convince all the political factions in Korea that the I.M.F. must be called in. Once the country is committed to following the fund's requirements, the thinking goes, politicians can blame the I.M.F. for the pain of layoffs and slower growth rather. Over time, that could restore the confidence of outside investors who have abandoned Korea.
"The problem now is that there is no one in the Government to deal with," said Lawrence B. Krause, a professor at the University of California at San Diego and director of its Korea Pacific Program. "Everyone knows the Government is responsible for much of the problem," he said, and politicians on all sides of the election are steering clear of endorsing an austerity plan that will be deeply unpopular in a country known for volatile politics and sometimes violent demonstrations.
If South Korea fails to restore the confidence of foreign investors, the country's problems seem bound to worsen. South Korea has $67 billion to $77 billion in short-term debt to financial institutions outside the country that must be paid within the next year. Making those payments has become increasingly difficult, in part because of the string of bankruptcies, and in part because the quick devaluation of the local currency has made it nearly impossible for many companies to pay back a debt that is denominated in dollars.
It is a measure of the country's desperation for short-term aid that the Government was also appealing to Tokyo, not just to Washington, for aid. Korea's enmity toward Japan is longstanding; the entire Korean peninsula was a Japanese colony for most of the first half of this century, and bitterness over the treatment of Koreans still runs deep. Statues in Seoul celebrate a Korean admiral who fought off Japanese invaders more than 400 years ago.
But Japanese officials say they, like the United States, are not in a position to lend the kind of cash South Korea needs.
Japan's deepening problems, in fact, have forced the country to back away from a proposal it made in September to create an Asian bailout fund that would operate separately from the I.M.F. At a meeting in Manila that ended today, the United States persuaded a group of Southeast Asian nations that any bailout fund should be centered on the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: Albright Says Iraq Agrees to Let U.S. Inspectors Back

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Thursday, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Iraq has told Russia that it will allow the unconditional return of all United Nations weapons inspectors, including Americans, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said this morning after an extraordinary 2 A.M. meeting here of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.
Iraqi officials told the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, that Baghdad will make an announcement of its reversal later today, she said. 
 But Ms. Albright immediately tempered her optimism by saying, "I will believe it when I see it."
In a briefing with reporters after the two-hour meeting, she added, "The announcement is to be made later this morning, and then we'll have to see whether it's carried out." Either the inspectors are allowed to return unconditionally and in their previous composition or they are not, she said, adding, "I'll be watching and waiting just as you are."
An American official at the meeting said Mr. Primakov seemed "reasonably confident" that Iraq would follow through. "It was definitely his strong expectation," the official said. "And he said if Iraq did not follow through, we could all meet again."
If Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein does back down without warfare, it will represent an important victory for American and Russian diplomacy. But the price, now and for the future, is unclear.
Mr. Primakov held out to Mr. Hussein the hope of speedier work by the inspectors, to give Iraq a sense that inspections will not go on forever. Iraq also wants a change in the composition of the team, and a end of all the sanctions imposed in 1991 after the Persian Gulf war.
Ms. Albright made it clear that the United States had not agreed to changes in inspections or sanctions.
In their statement at the end of the meeting, read by the British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, the five announced a meeting on Friday in New York of the United Nations Special Commission, or Unscom, which carries out the inspections, "to discuss and advise, among other important issues, ways to make Unscom's work more effective."
Those recommendations will be subject to approval by the Security Council. But Ms. Albright also suggested that more efficient inspections might mean more personnel, which could dilute the percentage of Americans slightly. Americans currently account for about 10 percent of the inspectors. Such a change, which is not assured, could be presented as face-saving alterations to a sanctions regime that President Clinton has said could last as long as Mr. Hussein rules Iraq.
Ms. Albright said lifting sanctions "will probably be discussed at some time, but the United States has not agreed to anything."
The statement read by Mr. Cook urged Mr. Hussein to make an "unconditional decision" to comply fully with United Nations resolutions and allow weapons inspectors, "in their previous composition," back into the country.
These were the bottom-line demands of the United States and Ms. Albright, who rushed here from India to discuss a Russian plan to get Iraq to reverse course and avoid a military confrontation.
The statement said that the attendees -- Ms. Albright, Mr. Primakov, Mr. Cook, French Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine and China's Ambassador for disarmament, Sha Zukang -- "appreciated the diplomatic initiative undertaken by Russia," which "the participants in the meeting hope will lead to the unconditional decision by the leadership of Iraq to accept the return of the personnel of the Special Commission of the U.N. Security Council, that is, Unscom, in its previous composition for its work."
But the statement did not suggest, as Ms. Albright said explicitly, that Iraq had told Mr. Primakov it would do exactly that.
Crucially for the Americans, the statement also "underscored the importance of the efforts in solidarity." American officials came to this meeting unclear about the details of what Mr. Primakov was negotiating and concerned that he might be getting ahead of the Council.
There is also some lingering American mistrust of Mr. Primakov, an expert on Arab affairs and former Russian intelligence chief who, as a Soviet diplomat, tried to head off military action against Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in 1990.
The White House has been sensitive about appearing to engage in any negotiation with Mr. Hussein or offer any inducements to him, no matter how small or obvious, to persuade him to back down.
Even a sudden American and British offer to allow Iraq to sell more of its oil to buy food, medicine and other supplies for civilians if it comes back into compliance with United Nations weapons inspection requirements was described by White House officials as a humanitarian gesture with no particular connection to the diplomatic effort to resolve the crisis.
In Washington, hours before the meeting, the President reiterated that he wanted to solve the Iraq problem without military intervention, but he did not rule it out.
"Iraq must comply with the unanimous will of the international community and let the weapons inspectors resume their work to prevent Iraq from developing an arsenal of nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons," he said.
"The inspectors must be able to do so without interference. That's our top line. That's our bottom line. I want to achieve it diplomatically, but we're taking every step to make sure we are prepared to pursue whatever options are necessary."
In defiance of United Nations sanctions, Mr. Hussein expelled American weapons inspectors from Iraq last week, and the entire international team departed.
The battle over the weapons inspectors led to a military buildup by the United States in the Persian Gulf, while diplomatic efforts to bring Iraq into compliance continued.
The United States is sending 2 aircraft carriers, about 300 military planes and more than 20 warships as well as 6 stealth fighter planes, to be based in Kuwait, and 6 B-52 bombers, to be based in Diego Garcia.
Iraq's positions have shifted, following Mr. Hussein's pattern.
First Iraq demanded that all American weapons inspectors with the United Nations Special Commission leave Iraq, and then demanded that the percentage of Americans on inspection teams be reduced.
British officials suggest that problem might be dealt with by simply expanding the commission's personnel, rather than dropping any particular nationality.
But Iraq now seems to want, more than anything, to have some form of schedule or assurance that United Nations weapons inspections within its borders will end soon. And American officials -- as Ms. Albright repeated this morning -- are likely to oppose concessions on this matter, especially if they appear to have been won by Mr. Hussein's tactics.
Until inspectors certify that Iraq is free of all weapons of mass destruction, the United Nations will not lift crippling economic sanctions imposed after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990, which led to the Persian Gulf war.
But American officials have said that certification by the commission would not be enough to lift sanctions entirely, and that Mr. Hussein will have to show a sustained pattern of good behavior first, Mr. Rubin has said.
That is an assertion that other countries do not necessarily accept.
Despite President Clinton's statement about the link between the sanctions and Mr. Hussein's role, American officials deny that Washington intends to keep sanctions on Iraq as long as Mr. Hussein remains in power, as the French and Russians say they believe. But the officials also say they have "serious doubts" that Mr. Hussein, who has consistently challenged the United Nations and consistently pursued weapons of mass destruction, can ever satisfy the requirements of sustained good behavior the Americans want.

Hussein Briefs Ministers
 BAGHDAD, Nov. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Saddam Hussein briefed his ministers today on Russian diplomacy intended to calm the dispute over United Nations weapons inspections, the state media reported.
A special parliamentary session was set for Thursday.
Mr. Hussein chaired a Cabinet meeting today to brief ministers on "discussions with Russia and developments in the crisis provoked by the United States," the official Iraqi news agency said. Baghdad said it would not back away from the standoff after offering to allow the return of weapons inspectors if the Commission was restructured to ensure a balance of nationalities.
Meanwhile, Iraq has accused the American representatives on the United Nations sanctions committee of blocking four contracts under the oil-for-food accord. The contracts cover equipment for power stations and desalination plants and batteries, an official spokesman quoted by news agency said.
The United States "is seeking to aggravate the suffering of the Iraqi people while at the same time falsely speaking of its concern about their suffering," he added.
Under the oil-for-food accord first introduced in December, Iraq is allowed to sell $2 billion dollars of oil every six months to buy food and medicines and other supplies.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Boat Builder Closes, Eliminating 130 Jobs

DATELINE: EGG HARBOR

 BODY:
After 50 years, the Egg Harbor Yacht Company closed its doors Monday, putting 130 people out of work. The boat-building company was one of the largest employers in Egg Harbor, which has a population of 4,500. 
 The company shut down once before, in 1993, but was able to reopen later that year after obtaining a $3.5 million Federal loan. The company owes $3 million on the Federal loan and may have as much as $7 million in additional debt, said Rose Smith, a spokeswoman for the State Economic Development Authority.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.S. Agency Says AIDS Will Orphan Millions

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The United States Agency for International Development said today that 40 million children in developing countries would be without one or both parents by 2010.
With a population explosion of young people, especially in poor countries, "it is a crisis of staggering proportion," Dr. Nils Daulaire, senior adviser on children and women's health issues, said at a news conference. 
 According to the report, AIDS, already prevalent in Africa south of the Sahara, will become widespread in the next decade in Asia and Latin America.
"That is going to affect not only the future of these countries, it is going to affect the entire global network of trade, diplomacy and development," Mr. Daulaire said.
"What we are talking about here is something that has never been seen before, which is countries with one-sixth to one-quarter of all children without one or both parents."

HEADLINE: THE 'DRAWER PEOPLE' -- A special report.;
Newest Challenge for Welfare: Helping the Hard-Core Jobless

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: OREGON CITY, Ore.

 BODY:
After 14 years on and off the welfare rolls, Kimberly Malcom still had a few problems to work out before settling into a job.
She was fleeing a husband who had broken three of her fingers. 
 She was living in her car.
She was recovering from thyroid cancer.
And she was smoking crack cocaine.
"I probably wasn't in the welfare office for five minutes before I burst into tears," said Ms. Malcom, who soon added a suicide attempt, an alcoholic boyfriend and a runaway daughter to her list of afflictions. "I was just so hurt."
With the most employable recipients fleeing the rolls, Ms. Malcom personifies the nation's next major welfare challenge: working with the increasingly difficult cases that remain. As caseloads plunge under strict new laws, rising proportions of those left behind face the limiting conditions -- from illiteracy and homelessness to mental illness and addiction -- that analysts euphemistically call "barriers to employment."
After one of the nation's sharpest caseload declines, 50 percent in just three years, Oregon stands on the edge of this policy frontier. It is one of the first states to confront a welfare population dominated by the most troubled cases and is making unusual efforts to find them jobs. But the costs and difficulties of the work involved offer a host of cautionary lessons.
While states with far less experience are boasting of early success, the first recipients to leave the rolls are often the easiest to employ. A tougher test of last year's welfare overhaul will be posed by those who remain, especially over the next few years, as time limits threaten to chase them from the rolls. The Oregon experience offers a warning: the hardest work has yet to begin.
Officials estimate that 75 percent of those left on the rolls in Oregon suffer from mental health problems that could interfere with a job. Half acknowledge drug or alcohol abuse, and half say they have been beaten or sexually abused. Forty-two percent lack a high school education. Thirty percent have criminal histories.
And since much of this data is self-reported, sensitive problems like drug use or family violence may be even more prevalent than they seem.
"It's not just a matter of telling people, 'You ought to work,' " Sandie Hoback, the state welfare director, said. "Many of these families have real significant problems."
In this blue-collar suburb just south of Portland, caseworkers have a term for such clients with multiple, soul-wrenching problems. They call them drawer people, since that is where their files used to reside while caseworkers focused on more promising prospects.
With the files now coming out of the drawers, officials say they feel newly encouraged about the people they once wrote off. The percentage of clients placed in jobs has grown each year, even as the cases have grown more difficult. The average starting wage has risen too, climbing 6 percent last year to $6.57 an hour.
"I'm surprised at the progress we continue to make," Ms. Hoback said. "I fully expected by now we'd see some leveling off."
But Oregon has an advantage over many other states. It enjoys a generously financed program and a history of civic commitment. Other states trying to replicate these achievements will find they have been hard won. With clients needing more expensive services, from drug treatment to wage subsidies, costs per case have risen 28 percent in the last year alone. The time the average client spends on the rolls has risen 10 percent, to 29 months.
And progress now rides to an unprecedented degree on the skills of the state's caseworkers, who are being thrust into unfamiliar and sometimes uncomfortable new roles. Trained for the bookkeeper's task of calculating eligibility, they now find themselves asking clients what drugs they are taking, what mental disorders they are experiencing and what violent relationships they may be escaping.
"I think Oregon's approach is encouraging," said LaDonna Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute in Washington, D.C., and an authority on long-term recipients. "But it remains an open question about who you can help, how much you can help and how much it will cost."
Last year's law limits recipients to five years of Federal aid, while allowing extensions for 20 percent of the caseload. Ms. Pavetti doubts that percentage is large enough to cover all who will need the long-term help. And she fears that states will not grant extensions to those whose maladies are difficult to define.
"States will cover recipients with concrete disabilities," she said. "But many people fall in a gray zone. Sometimes they function and sometimes they don't."
Operating under a Federal waiver granted before last year's welfare law, Oregon essentially has no time limits. It plans to continue aid, using state money if necessary, to all who cooperate with the program by seeking jobs or services. But critics say the state remains too eager to push fragile clients into stressful, low-wage jobs, rather than train them for better-paying work. At best this promises a life of continued need, they say, and at worst the pressure can trigger a drug relapse or a resumed relationship with a violent man.
And with caseworkers exercising vast new discretion, critics also say some troubled clients simply get turned away before they can get on the rolls. Ms. Hoback, a former Legal Services advocate, contends that such instances are rare. But she is also trying to retrain the state's 750 caseworkers, who start at salaries of $25,400 and mostly lack college degrees.
"Some workers still don't get it," she said.
Ms. Malcom's odyssey shows the problems that can arise when even the most thoughtful casework collides with lives rooted in distress. As a child she was beaten so badly by her mother that her teachers summoned an investigator. She left school in 10th grade and was married as a teen-ager. Her husband threw her down the stairs while she was pregnant and left choke marks on her throat.
Though Ms. Malcom says "we're good friends now," she and her husband split up, and she drifted from bartending to welfare and from cancer to crack. By the time she returned to the welfare rolls in 1995, she had resumed living with her ex-husband and he had beaten her again. Her thyroid disease had raised her weight to 250 pounds, and she had resumed smoking cocaine.
Alarmed, her caseworker sent Ms. Malcom to a mental health clinic, but she swallowed an overdose of anti-depressants, trying to kill herself. For the next year, welfare officials deferred a job search while Ms. Malcom attended drug treatment and counseling programs. "They asked me not to do anything else -- that basically I needed to work on my mental health," she said.
As she did, Ms. Malcom began to emerge as a capable, insightful woman. Impressed by her progress, her caseworker arranged a volunteer job at the welfare office, where she did such a good job that she was hired as a clerk at more than $1,300 a month.
"She was better than the other support staff we had," said Carolyn Ross, the office head.
But Ms. Malcom met a man who moved in and drank heavily. Her daughter ran away, her depression returned, and she once more turned to crack. When she was dismissed, two months after she was hired, Ms. Malcom cried, begged and threatened to kill herself, then fled to the mental health clinic.
Though that failure is not the story's end -- Ms. Malcom found another clerical job and left welfare again -- she and Ms. Ross were each fighting off tears at a recent lunch where they discussed what went wrong.
"She showed such incredible potential," said Ms. Ross, who hopes to rehire her.
Ms. Malcom said, "To be honest, I think the success scared me."
 
The Oregon Model
Inclined to Lead, Willing to Spend
The Oregon program has developed along strikingly apolitical lines. While many governors elsewhere have cultivated tough welfare images, Oregon's politicians have mostly deferred to the state's Department of Human Resources. And with whites accounting for 79 percent of the caseload, the issue has generated virtually no racial conflict. But while welfare has scarcely figured in elections, the state has long shown an interest in innovation and a willingness to spend money.
In the first half of the decade, the average state spent just 60 percent of its potential Federal welfare-to-work money. But Oregon put up enough matching money to gain access to its full Federal grant -- then added 20 percent. And since Federal subsidies are now tied to past spending, Oregon receives about $6,600 a year per family, a figure 60 percent above the national average and second only to Wisconsin's.
As it evolved over the last 10 years, the Oregon program, called Jobs, underwent two significant shifts. The first dropped an emphasis on long-term training in favor of quick job placements. While the program still offers a rich array of services, most applicants must first spend a month looking for work before getting help. The rule evolved after officials found that even the most troubled clients sometimes find jobs.
The second shift essentially eliminated the exemptions that used to abound in welfare-to-work programs. Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, the new Federal welfare program, requires states to enroll 50 percent of their recipients in a job-related activity by 2002. By last year, Oregon's participation rate had already risen to 89 percent. The activities vary greatly, but virtually everyone has to do something.
There are two-week classes to build self-esteem, and three-month classes in marketable skills. There are unpaid "workfare" jobs to build resumes, and subsidized, wage-paying jobs for those who remain unemployed. Caseworkers have tremendous discretion in making assignments. But as long as a client complies, there is effectively no time limit on aid.
As caseworkers shifted from processing checks to offering services, they made a discovery: their clients were even more troubled than they knew. While reliable data are scarce, researchers have typically talked of a "bottom third" with sharply limited prospects. Oregon's experience suggests that the bottom third is every bit as big as -- and perhaps even more troubled than -- the researchers knew.
"We really weren't getting the story," said Jane Moore, a caseworker who specializes in teen-age mothers. "These are not cheerleaders who accidentally got pregnant on prom night. I've had Grandma, Mom and teen all come in stoned out of their gourd. I had one girl whose mother gave her to a mechanic to pay for a repair on her car."
Still, the rolls have fallen 51 percent from their peak of nearly 44,000 in March 1994. And the pace of decline has accelerated even as the state digs deeper into the caseload -- the rolls fell 10 percent in the first half of 1996 and 13 percent in the first half of 1997. Here, as elsewhere, the question remains: Where are recipients going?
Critics worry that the requirements, especially the up-front job search, simply drive some clients away. They point toward people like Elizabeth Stevens, who applied last month after her boyfriend drank the rent money, threatened to kill her and left town. Her landlord threatened to evict Ms. Stevens and her two children within 72 hours. And she was scheduled for surgery to remove kidney stones the next week. But when she applied for benefits, a caseworker turned her down.
"She said they have a waiting period of 30 days," said Ms. Stevens, who was already calling homeless shelters when a lawyer for a welfare-rights program got the decision reversed.
Even admirers of the Oregon approach, like Ms. Pavetti, worry that "some clients are too fragile to make their way into the system." But Ms. Hoback argued that caseloads were falling mostly because clients were finding jobs. The number of clients placed in jobs each month has risen to more than 1,800 last year from about 500 in the early 1990's. (The effort has been aided by falling unemployment rates, which for the last three years have averaged about 5 percent.)
While costs have also grown -- to $632 a month per client in the first half of 1997, from $493 in the first half of 1996 -- the spending has been more than offset by the savings from caseload declines. Ms. Hoback estimated that the declines had saved $114 million over the last two years.
"It's still cost effective," she said. "With the right amount of support, everyone can move ahead."
 
The Substance Abuser
For Addicts, Help First, Jobs Second
The wooded hills of Clackamas County stretch 50 miles east from Oregon City to the slopes of Mount Hood. The isolation makes the area a magnet for methamphetamine labs, hideaway trailers where the low-cost drug is mixed in marathon malodorous sessions. The drug is so prevalent that caseworkers are trained to flee the giveaway smell, which is reminiscent of cat urine.
By the time she was 20, Lori Furlow had consumed so much of it that she had already had a heart attack. That did not slow her. Facing criminal as well as cardiac arrest, Ms. Furlow passed her urinalyses on probation by chugging bottles of vinegar.
"I weighed 86 pounds," she said. "Spandex would fall off me. You could smell meth coming out of my pores."
With problems like this, Oregon caseworkers increasingly act as brokers of more specialized care. They can refer addicts to treatment or depressed women to mental health clinics. They can refer abused women to shelters or immigrants to employment counselors fluent in Russian, Spanish and Vietnamese.
But there are no clear rules about who gets what service or for how long.
"While a really good worker will figure it out, not everyone's a really good worker," Ms. Pavetti said. Recipients who do not comply face escalating penalties, beginning at $50 a month and ending in the denial of the whole cash grant.
Oddly enough, substance abuse -- for all the devastation it wreaks -- is one of the less complicated problems that caseworkers confront. The diagnosis is relatively straightforward. And addiction can often be conquered more quickly than chronic mental health problems, like depression or severe anxiety. (Many clients, however, have both.)
While previous studies have estimated that anywhere from 7 percent to 37 percent of welfare recipients have substance abuse problems, a recent Oregon survey produced a much higher figure: 50 percent.
Unlike most states, Oregon has been expanding its efforts for addicts. In 1992, it became the first state to require them to attend treatment as a condition of receiving welfare. And the Oregon Health Plan, the state's Medicaid equivalent, now provides up to 14 hours a week in outpatient care. In addition, about a third of the substance abuse clients end up in residential treatment, which is paid for by separate mechanisms, including a state tax on beer and wine.
An evaluation of the program recently found that clients who completed the Oregon treatments earned 65 percent more than clients in a comparison group. They were 45 percent less likely to be arrested, and half as likely to be investigated for child abuse or neglect. The evaluator, Michael Finigan, concluded that for every dollar Oregon spent, it saved at least $5.60 on other social services.
But a recent survey by the Legal Action Center, a New York advocacy group, found that 20 states retained an optional feature in last year's law that simply bans recent drug felons from receiving aid. And 21 other states retained a modified ban.
The restrictions come from an understandable anger at seeing benefits used to buy drugs. But Oregon officials say outright bans can make addicts unwilling to seek help. Christa Sprinkle, a drug and mental health specialist in Portland, urges a carrot-and-stick approach of services tied to penalties for those who do not comply. But Ms. Sprinkle said some caseworkers, fearing confrontation, were too slow to impose sanctions.
Indeed, it was a penalty that helped capture Ms. Furlow's attention. While ducking her probation officer and manufacturing more drugs, Ms. Furlow began receiving notices from the welfare office, insisting she report for a job-preparation class. She ignored them, her check was reduced -- and that, she insists, is what unsettled her.
"That was part of the reason I went into treatment -- you rely so much on that welfare check," said Ms. Furlow, who spent a year in a residential program.
After leaving she spent another year doing volunteer workfare assignments before landing a clerical job with the state in 1996. She now earns $18,000 a year.
"It all finally culminated -- the burnout, the guilt, the fear," she said. "I think the sanction's a real wake-up call."
 
The Hidden Factor
Physical, Sexual And Mental Abuse
As caseloads dwindle, Oregon may be uncovering a second epidemic, one less obvious and less recognized than drugs. That is the sheer level of violence that many if not most of the women have endured. While 50 percent report histories of physical or sexual assault, the real incidence may run much higher. Like women addicted to drugs, women trapped in violent relationships can be slow to concede the problem, to caseworkers or even themselves.
The injuries extend beyond the obvious, physical ones. Women fleeing violent men are often too afraid to seek work, especially if it means entrusting young children to the care of strangers. And many women find that jealous men, threatened by their move toward independence, will do all they can to keep them from classes or jobs.
"People don't always tell you they're in an abusive situation," said Wendell St. John, a caseworker specializing in domestic violence. "They just always have an excuse about why they don't follow through."
While the violence is prevalent, most states are still groping for a response. Twenty-eight states have adopted an option in last year's law that simply exempts abused women from work requirements.
Oregon has put its energy in caseworker training, rather than blanket exemptions. Many offices now have a specialist, like Ms. St. John, who works closely with local shelters. Caseworkers can waive the 30-day job search for women in dangerous situations. They can spend up to $1,200 on rent and deposits for safe housing.
But in Oregon and across the country, there is no policy for, and only the haziest understanding of, a second kind of violence: the sexual abuse many recipients have suffered as children. Yet it often surfaces in conversations ostensibly about other topics, like drugs, anxiety or self-esteem. Of the 16 recipients with noteworthy "barriers" interviewed for this article, 11 alluded to childhood incidents of rape or molestation.
One said she was raped by a baby sitter when she was 6. A second said that her mother's boyfriend had molested her when she was 12, and that her mother had evicted her when she complained. A third, a teen-age mother molested by an older cousin, said, "I don't call it anything special because it seems like it happens to everybody."
Among those it happened to was Rita Davis, whose earnest, thwarted search for work shows the unlikely impediments that recipients can face. Ms. Davis, 35, was one of 13 siblings schooled at home by an abusive father. After her husband left two years ago, she began looking for more profitable work than the paper route supporting her and her 2-year-old son. But she reads at the seventh-grade level. And she weighs 325 pounds.
An unremittingly sincere woman, Ms. Davis recounted her experience between deep, steadying breaths.
"I went to 10 or 15 temporary agencies," she said. "I'd call up on the phone and they'd say, 'Oh, you sound like the perfect person.' Then they take one look at me and they blow it off."
After months of rejection, Ms. Davis solicited the help of Gene Hanson, a job-placement counselor she had met in past training programs. Knowing she had an interest in numbers, Mr. Hanson went to unusual lengths to create a subsidized job for her as receptionist at an accounting agency. The agency hired her after the state agreed to pay most of her salary for the first six months.
Then a new problem arose: body odor. Her boss called Mr. Hanson and complained that it was driving customers away.
"I don't know what it is," said Ms. Davis, whose problem has stumped her doctor as well. "I take a shower every day."
Mr. Hanson arrived the next day with two sacks of deodorant and shampoo from a state donation bin. Ms. Davis experimented, the products worked, and she was permanently hired.
"She's even better than some professionals I've had," said her boss, Douglas Capps, who is so impressed he has promoted her to bookkeeping.
Ms. Davis was an hour into her story before she mentioned another element of her struggle: years of sexual abuse by her father.
Ms. Davis said that she waited years before having a child of her own, "because they say you pass it on." And she even wonders whether she subconsciously decided to keep gaining weight as a way to protect herself.
"Sometimes I think this is like a shield: a lot of men don't like heavy women," she said.
Ms. Davis said she chose to tell her story because it helped her to talk, and because it might help those with similar problems. "I want people to know it didn't destroy me," she said.
Now earning $6.75 an hour, she remains $3,000 in debt -- to her divorce lawyer, her doctor and a student loan agency. She has lost her health insurance, and she gets headaches from her outdated prescription lenses. But, she says, "I love this job."
"Somebody is able to look past my size and see me," she said. "I've wondered why it took so long."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
BROIDY, GERALD

 BODY:
BROIDY-Gerald. Beloved husband of Sue Broidy of Santa Barbara, died on November 19 of cancer after a long illness. He is survived by his daughter Ellen and her life partner Joan Ariel of Irvine, CA, his stepchildren Christian Greenfield and his wife Laura of Santa Barbara and Sophie Greenfield of London, UK, his brother Alfred of West Haven, CT. and cousin Joan Fallert and her husband Jerome of Santa Barbara. Jerry was born in Pittsburgh, PA on May 4, 1919 and grew up in NY where he graduated from CCNY in 1942. He served in the US Army Counter Intelligence Service in Germany during the war. His long career with Time, Inc. began in NY in 1949 where he worked in marketing, promotion and telphone sales culminating in a move to London in 1976 with Time Life Books. Following his retirement in 1984 he worked as a fundraiser for Cancer Relief in London before moving to Santa Barbara in 1993. Jerry served on the board of The Arts Fund of Santa Barbara and the advisory board of Women's Economic Ventures. He was a passionate advocate of social justice and equality for women and minorities and worked for many years for the National Urban League and the Democratic Party. He loved New York and London, music and the theater and above all the company of his numerous friends all over the world. Donations in his memory may be made to The Arts Fund, PO Box 91926, Santa Barbara, CA or The Leigh Block Hospice House, 900 Calle de Los Amigos, Santa Barbara, CA. 93105.

HEADLINE: An All-Bach Program That, the Fact Is, Isn't Quite

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
On any scale of scandal and mayhem, it doesn't even register, but truth in advertising perhaps requires full and immediate disclosure. Of the 25 Bach cantatas that Canticum Novum, a New York chorus, is performing this season to celebrate its 25th anniversary, two, or at least one and a half, are not by Bach: No. 53, "Schlage Doch, Gewunschte Stunde," which was written by Georg Melchior Hoffmann, and No. 118, "O Jesu Christ, Meins Lebens Licht," which was either conceived or arranged by an unknown second hand.
"I knew they were spurious and decided to do them anyway, for interest's sake," Harold Rosenbaum, the chorus's founder and director, said last week. "It will get people thinking: 'There must have been a reason people thought they were by Bach. They must be good. Were there other people who were almost as good?' 
 "They're actually charming pieces. And part of the reason I'm doing them is that they fit in in terms of length. They are not long."
Practicality, to be sure, is no small consideration when you are trying to cram 25 substantial works into four programs. The series, at Merkin Concert Hall, opens tomorrow evening with seven cantatas, all certifiably Bach's, and continues on March 22. It closes on May 17 with afternoon and evening concerts, 11 cantatas in all.
Why celebrate with Bach? "We've done more Bach over the years than any other composer," said Mr. Rosenbaum, who learned his own Bach first through the Swingle Singers, in the 1960's, and started Canticum Novum in 1973, when he was fresh from his studies at Queens College. Still, the group has performed only a dozen or so of the cantatas along with several larger works.
So why the cantatas now? "They are the most important body of church music ever written," Mr. Rosenbaum said, "and most of them are not very well known."
Some 200 of Bach's sacred cantatas survive. They are typically multimovement affairs, alternating choruses and instrumental numbers with recitatives and arias, and ranging in length from 5 to 50 minutes. There are also works for solo vocalist, two of which will be heard tomorrow. The cantatas were performed at the principal services on Sundays or feast days, and during some stretches, Bach ground out one a week, while also preparing the performances and carrying out other duties.
Mr. Rosenbaum carefully examined all the cantatas over three months, "the most pleasurable three months I've had in a long time," he said. Length, though only one consideration, was a major one. In this context, the great one-movement No. 50, "Nun Ist das Heil und die Kraft," despite its being merely a remnant of a larger work either lost or incomplete, comes as a blessing.
The conductor also had to take instrumentation into account so he could hire players economically. Among the more remarkable findings in his studies was that Bach, ever inventive, used no fewer than 145 different instrumentations in the 200-odd works. The program tomorrow will use only a handful of players, mostly from the Orchestra of St. Luke's, on period instruments. The program in March will roll out the big guns: trumpets and drums.
Two other of Mr. Rosenbaum's goals worked slightly at cross-purposes: to present the finest cantatas but also to bring as many unknown works to light as possible. "I found in going through them that the well-known ones are the best ones," Mr. Rosenbaum said, "or certainly among the best ones." The mix he arrived at is judicious.
Still, might not all of this be too much of a great thing? "It will be interesting to see," said George Stauffer, a professor of music at Hunter College and the president of the American Bach Society, who will give a preconcert lecture tomorrow. He suspects not, if only because of the great variety.
The first program offers four works from Bach's time in Muhlhausen (1708), two from Weimar (1708-17) and one from Leipzig (1723-50). "You can hear Bach evolving before your very ears," Mr. Stauffer said.
Yet the project remains a challenge, to say the least. "It's the craziest thing I've ever done," Mr. Rosenbaum said. Even he is already worried about that Sunday in May with two programs.
"I figure I'll have about two and a half hours in between," he said. "Should I lie down? What should I eat? Should I sit on a stool during the concert? Should I go to my church job that morning?"
Mr. Rosenbaum is the organist at South Salem Presbyterian Church in Westchester County, where he lives. He directs nine choruses, including the New York Virtuoso Singers, a professional organization, and Canticum Novum, an elite group of 26 nonprofessionals.
Canticum Novum has a busy schedule in addition to these concerts, including Christmas programs throughout December, and Mr. Rosenbaum says he encountered resistance to the Bach project among his board and, even more, his singers. "They love Bach but thought it was too much singing," he said.
The trepidation was evidently not universal among the wide variety of people who make up the chorus.
"For me it was the incentive to stay with the group," said Charles Eubanks, the assistant director of the music division at the Library of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center, who sang with Canticum Novum in its early years and recently returned. "This repertory is a lot of fun to sing."
Stephen Gomersall, another member of the chorus, confirms that it took a while for the singers to become convinced of the project's wisdom, but he now finds it exciting. He also finds it therapeutic in relation to his job, as deputy representative to the United Kingdom Mission to the United Nations, which has placed him in the news recently in relation to the tensions in Iraq.
"I've bent pretty well every rule to get to rehearsals," Mr. Gomersall said. Still, Mr. Rosenbaum reads the newspapers with trepidation, fearing that Mr. Gomersall's participation may yet fall victim to world politics.
Mr. Rosenbaum doesn't need more to worry about. "Bach is so monumental," he said. "It's very scary to do Bach."
 
The Programs
 
Canticum Novum will perform 25 cantatas, most of them by Bach, in four programs for its 25th anniversary season. The first is at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, tomorrow at 8 P.M. The cantatas on the program are Nos. 106, 54, 61, 196, 82, 131 and 4. Tickets are $20. Information: (914) 763-3453. The others are on March 22 at 8 P.M. and May 17 at 3 and 8 P.M. at Merkin Hall.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting;
Beetlemania: Snug Bugs and Other Specimens

BYLINE: By KEITH MARTIN 

 BODY:
ALL it Bug II: Early in 1998, some 65 years after the Volkswagen Beetle was conceived -- as the brainchild of Adolf Hitler -- a new Beetle will make its debut, updated for the 21st century.
This time, the car will have its engine up front; a cooling system that uses water, not air, and a price that Bug drivers of the 60's would have considered a real bummer. But even if the new $18,000 to $22,000 VW turns out to be wonderful, it's a sure bet that purists will still prefer the original to the sequel. For old-style Beetles are not just cars; they are automotive and cultural icons. 
 Decked out with peace symbols, they were the original flower power vehicle of the 60's. One named Herbie starred in a 1969 Walt Disney movie, "The Love Bug," that brought more people into theaters than "Easy Rider." In the 1973 future spoof "Sleeper," Woody Allen comes across a Beetle that had been stored for two centuries. It starts on the first try, of course.
More than 20 million Beetles have been produced, making it the best-selling car ever with a fundamentally unchanged body. (The best-selling auto nameplate, the Toyota Corolla, has been produced in many styles and variations.)
The first Beetles left the assembly line in Germany in 1939, and they are still built in Mexico at the rate of 100 a day. There are hundreds of VW-based clubs in the United States, along with numerous foreign clubs, several magazines and a host of Internet sites. The Beetle led the invasion of European imports in the 50's and 60's, which in turn gave way to the wave of Japanese economy cars that arrived in the 70's and 80's.
Hitler provided the impetus for the Beetle in 1933 by calling for a "people's car" that could travel at 100 kilometers an hour, or 62 m.p.h.; go 33 miles on a gallon of gasoline, require minimal repairs, offer enough space for four or five occupants, and have an easily maintained air-cooled engine. In 1934, Ferdinand Porsche, who later built the famous sports cars, received the contract to develop the people's car. His design featured a rear-mounted engine, eliminating the need for a long drive shaft; aluminum engine castings to keep the rear end from being too heavy, and a simple suspension of a front torsion bar and rear swing axle.
The first Beetles were sold in 1939 as the KdF-Wagen (for Kraft durch Freude, or "Strength through joy," a Nazi slogan). The cars were offered through an unusual stamp-book approach. A worker could buy a few stamps each week, and when his book was full -- with a value of 990 Reichmarks, or about 800 hours' pay for a skilled worker -- he could exchange it for a KdF-Wagen. The outbreak of World War II put a halt to the program, with few if any cars delivered.
But more than 200,000 German workers had been saving the stamps. In 1961, VW bowed to popular pressure and allowed savers to exchange their old stamps for credit toward new Beetles.
In World War II, the Volkswagen chassis was used under many types of military vehicles, the most familiar being the Kubelwagen, the German command car similar to the American jeep. One unusual variation was the Schwimmwagen, an amphibious adaptation with a retractable propeller. More than 30 years later, VW sold a variant of the K-wagen in the United States with the minimalist name of "the Thing."
After the war, the VW plant at Wolfsburg was quick to resume production despite heavy damage from Allied bombing. The first two Beetles arrived in the United States in 1949, but few dealers were interested in the odd little car with the unusual air-cooled engine at the wrong end.
Once a beachhead was established, millions of Volkswagens rolled ashore, tapping a vein of discontent with Detroit's styling excesses, conspicuous consumption and slipshod quality. American sales of all types of VW's peaked in 1970 at 582,573.
The original 1946-52 Beetles -- easily identified by their small two-piece rear windows -- are known as the "split rear window" model. (Irreverent collectors call the distinctively curved and scalloped rear deck of these cars the "pope's nose" design.)
In 1953, the two-piece rear window was replaced by a single piece of oval glass. "The oval-window Bug is the ultimate for many Beetle lovers," said Troy Heitzenrater, publisher of Voice of the Enthusiast, a newsletter published six times a year by the German Air Sucker Society, or GASS, a club for classic Volkswagen enthusiasts in Salem, Ohio. "It has the 36-horsepower engine, which is nearly impossible to break, and hydraulic brakes, which were much better than the mechanical ones on earlier Bugs."
Mr. Heitzenrater has seen both types of early Beetles, in perfect, restored condition, sell for $15,000. More ordinary cars change hands for $7,000 to $8,000.
Mr. Heitzenrater says Beetle owners are a breed apart in their ability to be "flexible people -- to take the good along with the bad." He said this may be because, amid the bustle of modern society, "the Beetle just pokes along in its own simple way, never in too much of a hurry to get anywhere."
In 1957, the front and rear windows were enlarged, giving the car the look that everyone is familiar with. During the next 40 years, engines were enlarged, transmission ratios altered, bumpers refined and electrical systems upgraded. But the basic body shell remained unchanged. (The Super Beetle, a slightly larger, upgraded version, was sold in 1971-74. Its redesigned front end made it look squashed in comparison with the standard Bug, and there is little collector demand for it.)
Among baby boomers, at least, who has not owned, driven or rode in a Bug at one time or another?
An off-white 1964 Beetle made a fine 40th birthday present this month for Betsy Killorin of Middlebury, Vt. "She's always wanted one, and now she's very happy," said her husband, Eric H. Killorin, the publisher of Mobilia, a monthly magazine for collectors of automotive paraphernalia. "It was an affordable way to satisfy a fantasy."
When he presented the car to his wife, their three children popped out of the sunroof exclaiming "Happy birthday!" Even better, when the car was later shown at a dinner party, "all the guests had a VW Bug story to share," Mr. Killorin said.
Beetle convertibles are especially prized today. They went into production in 1949, and were the last new Beetles sold in the United States in 1979. Examples in average condition are worth $8,000 to $12,000; nearly perfect soft tops bring as much as $15,000.
There is also a growing interest in Microbuses and Things, which shared the same air-cooled, rear-engine layout. The first generation of Microbuses, recognizable by their two-piece windshields, was produced from 1950 to 1967. When adapted for commercial use they were called Transporters and were available in a bewildering array of styles, including pickup trucks, ambulances, fire trucks and panel vans.
The most desirable Microbus is the 21- or 23-window people mover that served as hippie mass transit in the 60's. It is especially popular in Japan, where enthusiasts have paid more than $30,000 for vans restored to better-than-new condition.
There is also a steady market for the Karmann Ghia, a VW built for those who wanted a sporty look but didn't care to go very fast. The coupe was first sold in the United States in 1956, and the convertible in 1958, and both cars ceased production in 1974, victims of smog and safety regulations. Due to extra sound-deadening materials, Karmann Ghias were never as quick as standard Beetles of the same year. Figure on spending $4,000 to $6,000 for a coupe in very good condition, or $6,000 to $8,000 for a convertible.
In general, Karmann Ghias, like other classic VW's, have modestly appreciated in the last decade, and prices are likely to keep rising. In general, the older the VW the more desirable it is among collectors.
My own family has not been immune to Beetlemania. While on a family vacation in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, our 17-year-old son, Eric, discovered that the Beetle was his fantasy car as well. After we picked up our rented Bug, he pronounced it "tight" -- which can be roughly translated as "groovy" -- and when he returned home he found a 1965 model in decent shape, with a few dents and dings, a loud exhaust and a CD player, for $650. He immediately joined the new generation of classic Beetle owners.
 More information on collecting Volkswagens is available from the Vintage VW Club of America, 5705 Gordon Drive, Harrisburg, Pa. 17112.

HEADLINE: The Greed-Fear Cycle

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In Peter Passell's Nov. 20 Economic Scene column, Robert Hormats, co-chairman of Goldman Sachs International, argues against "flat-out capital controls" despite the recent turmoil in global currency markets. I agree with his position, but he and his counterparts in the financial markets have brought the specter of additional regulation upon themselves by encouraging overinvestment abroad.
The level of greed required to cause the current crisis in Asia is profound. As always, however, fear is the check and balance for greed. Fear will drive Asian currencies down to the level where greed kicks in again to support them. 
 As for a bailout by the International Monetary Fund, the pattern was set during the Mexican currency crisis. Investors can now find comfort in the fact that the I.M.F. will cushion them from the consequences of their own greed. It appears that Mr. Hormats and his friends will be able to have their cake and eat it, too.
 
KEVIN R. CALLAHAN
Greenwich, Conn., Nov. 20, 1997

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Hits a 4-Month Low As Dispute With Iraq Eases

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell 3.2 percent yesterday, to a four-month low, after Iraq appeared to retreat from a standoff with the United Nations over arms inspections, defusing a dispute that threatened to disrupt Middle East oil exports.
Crude oil for December delivery fell 64 cents, to $19.16 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for a contract closest to delivery since July 22. Prices are down 26 percent so far this year. 
 "Iraq plays quite heavily in the market and now tension has eased," said Alan Struth, chief oil economist for Phillips Petroleum in Bartlesville, Okla., who said oil prices could soon fall below $19 a barrel.
Iraq agreed to allow American members of a United Nations team searching for biological weapons and other arms back into the country after expelling them on Nov. 13. President Clinton said the United States would "wait and see" whether the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, actually allowed the inspectors unfettered access to the country.
Also pushing prices lower were expectations that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting next week in Indonesia, would lift its production quota, currently 25.033 million barrels a day.
In other markets, natural gas and coffee also fell.
Natural gas fell 5.3 percent, to a two-month low, after a smaller-than-expected drop in inventories and forecasts for warm weather raised expectations for ample supplies in the months ahead.
American natural gas supplies declined 64 billion cubic feet, to 2.75 trillion cubic feet, last week, according to a report from the American Gas Association. The decline was less than the 70 billion cubic feet analysts expected and left inventories 5.1 percent higher than a year earlier.
Natural gas for December delivery fell 15.3 cents, to $2.708, for each 1,000 cubic feet, the lowest closing price since Aug. 18 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Coffee fell 3 percent as overseas growers, lured by this month's price rally, stepped up sales of freshly harvested beans.
Coffee for March delivery fell 4.65 cents, to $1.528 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Islamic Militants Taunt Cairo, Demanding Break With Israel

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The militant Islamic Group, which has claimed responsibility for the strike that killed 58 foreign tourists in Luxor, issued a statement today taunting the Egyptian Government, which it has said was the real target of the attack.
The organization, the largest Islamic militant group in Egypt, said it might be willing to halt its military operations "for a while." But the group said it would do so only if the Government took steps that Egypt has repeatedly rejected, including halting its security crackdown against the militants and severing relations with Israel. 
 The Islamic Group has said its attack on the tourists was part of a strategy aimed at hitting economic targets in order to topple President Hosni Mubarak's Government and install an Islamic state.
As part of the price for a suspension of its attacks, the group demanded in today's statement the release of thousands of prisoners, including its spiritual leader, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who remains in an American jail after his conviction in connection with the plot to bomb the World Trade Center and other prominent targets.
In its statement, the Islamic Group also mocked what has so far been the Government's main response to the attack: the dismissal of the country's Interior Minister and most of the upper echelon of its security chiefs.
"A movement that leads a people cannot be defeated," the group said. "The policy of removing ministers and replacing them with others cannot solve the problem of the Egyptian regime."
The statement came as President Mubarak convened a second emergency Cabinet meeting to weigh Egypt's response to the attack, which has dealt a heavy blow to Eygpt's economically significant tourism industry.
Mamdouh Beltagui, Egypt's Tourism Minister, said in a telephone interview today that in addition to tougher security measures, the Cabinet had decided to employ new political and economic means to combat the threat posed by Islamic militants. Mr. Beltagui declined to be more specific, but he suggested that the Government would do more to address concerns exploited by the militants to gain popular support.
But three days after the attack in Hatshepsut Temple in which 68 people died, including six assailants, the main thrust of the Egyptian Government response appears aimed at shoring up security holes.
Mr. Beltagui said that security at tourist sites from all over the country would be "stepped up drastically," and that policemen at those places would be provided more sophisticated arms. To lessen the possibility of attacks on remote areas, Mr. Beltagui said the Government would no longer permit tour buses to travel south by road from the southern city of Aswan.
At least for now, Mr. Beltagui said visitors to the world-renown Temple of Ramses II in Abu Simbel, a three-hour drive from Aswan, will have to travel by air. He said the Egyptian Government will subsidize air tickets to insure that tourists are not unfairly burdened by the new security measure.
In the aftermath of the attack, the tone of most Egyptian Government statements has also been primarily defensive, along lines set by Mr. Mubarak when he visited the temple the next morning and pointed out that no place in the world is immune from acts of violence. "Sometimes I feel afraid going to London," Mr. Mubarak remarked.
Today, however, Mr. Beltagui emphasized a spirit of regret. "We are all still under a shock, and our respects go out to the victims and their families," he said. "We address to them our apologies for what has happened."

HEADLINE: Edwin Mansfield, 67, Scholar Of Economics and Technology

 BODY:
Edwin Mansfield, a leading scholar of the economics of technological change, died on Monday at his home in Wallingford, Pa. He was 67.
He died of cancer, according to a spokeswoman for W. W. Norton & Company, publisher of his economics textbooks, which were used by millions of college students. 
 Investing government money in corporate research and development benefited the public far more than the private companies involved, according to Dr. Mansfield's research. But the technological advances that produced the biggest economic gains since World War II, he found, were not high-tech innovations, but low-tech developments that made clothing more affordable.
A consultant to corporations, governments and agencies like the World Bank, Dr. Mansfield was director of the Center for Economics and Technology at the University of Pennsylvania, where he taught until last month. He joined the university as a professor of economics in 1964 after teaching at Carnegie-Mellon, Yale and Harvard.
Dr. Mansfield received a number of honors for his scholarship, including the Special Creativity Award from the National Science Foundation, as well as Fulbright and Ford Foundation fellowships. After receiving his bachelor's degree from Dartmouth College, he earned a diploma from the Royal Statistical Society and a doctorate from Duke University.
He is survived by his wife, Lucile Howe Mansfield; a son, Edward, of Columbus, Ohio; a daughter, Elizabeth, of Gambier, Ohio, and a grandchild.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Securities Prices Lose Early Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose early yesterday, briefly sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to nearly 6 percent -- the lowest level in about two years -- before investors cashed in profits.
By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond had backed into negative territory, falling 11/32, to 100 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.06 percent, from 6.03 percent on Wednesday. 
 The late-day weakness came despite more signs suggesting that the economy may be slowing; generally, that would help the Treasury market because it would reduce the chances of higher inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. In one report, the Federal Reserve provided a weaker than expected survey of regional manufacturing conditions for October. In another, the Labor Department said that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose last week by 20,000, to 333,000, or more than expected, a sign that the labor market may be loosening.
But the market's inability to push below a 6 percent yield on the long bond indicated that investors seem to want more conclusive evidence that the economy is slowing and that inflation remains contained before placing any further bets on price gains in Government securities.
"Its going to take a few tries at testing the 6 percent level before we can break through," said Jack Ablin, executive vice president and fixed-income department head at Barnett Capital Advisors Inc., Jacksonville, Fla. "We haven't been below this psychological number since the beginning of 1996. It's one thing to get to 6 percent on the long bond; it's another to break below, and, of course, quite another just to stay there."
Some early support for bonds came from investor relief when the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, in remarks to the Senate Budget Committee's Task Force on Social Security, refrained from making any comments that might have unnerved investors.
But the recent decline in interest rates has itself fueled the buying, traders said. Expecting redemptions of mortgage-backed securities because the underlying mortgages are being refinanced, managers are buying Treasury securities to fill potential openings in portfolios.
But contributing to the late-day slide were recurring fears in the market that the Japanese Government might sell Treasuries to raise funds for a bank bailout plan.
Still, Ken Logan, a managing analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the decline was caused largely by a desire to lock in recent profits and did not signal a shift in sentiment. "Selling was by no means a bearish indictment of the market," he said. "Market participants for the most part remain constructive and were likely making room for the upcoming Treasury supply."
Supply figures to play a big role in the market over the coming days, with sales of new two-year and five-year notes scheduled for next week. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.69 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.77 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Soar as Turmoil in Asia Seems to Ease

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stocks rallied again yesterday, gaining some momentum after the global financial and political turbulence that has rocked markets around the world over the last few weeks eased somewhat.
Even though stock markets in Asia continue to be troubled by an infectious economic and currency crisis, the Japanese Government said yesterday that it would attempt to bail out that nation's wobbly banking system, a move cheered by investors who had feared the world's second- largest economy was bracing for an even sharper decline. 
 That decision sent Japanese shares soaring, and touched off a worldwide rally bolstered further in the United States by growing evidence that the domestic economy remains robust, with few signs of inflationary pressure.
After financial markets rallied overnight in Europe, American shares opened sharply higher yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 101.87 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 7,826.61.
This week, the Dow has gained about 3.3 percent, pulling it well above the position held just prior to the 554-point drop on Oct. 27.
Broader indexes also strengthened. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.39 points, or 1.52 percent, to 958.98, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company issues climbed 5.01 points, or 1.16 percent, to 435.70.
The rally this week has been fueled by a growing optimism among investors that the turmoil overseas will not subvert the spectacular bull market. Investors might have also been soothed by indications that a conflict in the Persian Gulf might have been averted.
"We've had sort of a shifting of the international sands in the past few days," said Robert J. Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Kemper Funds in Chicago. "It doesn't look like we're heading into a major Persian Gulf war, and we had some good signs from Japan."
Indeed, the American markets have weathered the worldwide developments better than most. While stock markets in Britain, France and Germany have lost between 8 percent and 12 percent from their recent highs, the Dow is down just 5 percent.
And even while the Hong Kong stock market has plummeted nearly 40 percent in the last two months, and the Nikkei in Japan is down 21 percent, the S.& P. 500 is having one of its best years ever, up nearly 30 percent so far this year.
"Investors here have become more confident," said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., a market strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. "The growing concerns about Hong Kong and the Japanese banking system seem to be behind the market right now."
One propeller in the market recovery has been the surge in the prices of financial and technology shares, which had led the market sharply higher earlier in the year. Yesterday, for instance, the shares of semiconductor and financial services companies gained sharply.
Analysts said that yesterday's gains might have been tied to expectations of further consolidation after the First Union Corporation announced plans to merge with Corestates Financial on Tuesday, and Merrill Lynch said it would acquire Mercury Asset Management Group, a London-based investment house, on Wednesday.
Indeed, Philip J. Purcell, the chairman and chief executive at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company -- one of the year's biggest combinations -- said that the consolidation would continue well into the future, and create even bigger companies.
"We're about to go from $20 billion deals to $100 billion deals," Mr. Purcell told a meeting of the Securities Industry Association earlier this month.
Whether such expectations were behind the surge in brokerage shares is unclear, but almost every brokerage firm stock closed sharply higher, with shares of Lehman Brothers -- a rumored takeover target -- climbing 6 percent, or 2.8125, to close at 48 3/8.
Technology issues were also strong yesterday, regaining some of their momentum after a few tumultuous weeks. Shares of Texas Instruments, for example, rose 5 3/4, to 103 3/4, after it was upgraded by an analyst.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 24 gained yesterday including AT&T, extending a remarkable rally in what had been, for a time, the year's worst-performing Dow issue.
Since C. Michael Armstrong was selected to replace Robert E. Allen as the chief executive of AT&T on Oct. 20, shares in the company have risen about 20 percent. It closed up 1 3/4 yesterday at 54.5625.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE ARABS;
Arab Capitals Are Relieved: No Need No Pick Sides

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Arab leaders and diplomats expressed satisfaction and relief tonight over the agreement that appears to have averted the threat of a military confrontation between the United States and Iraq.
There remains little affection for Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President, among fellow Arab leaders. But with sentiment on the street running sharply against the United States, even Arab Governments that sided against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war had made plain that military action would have only complicated matters in an already troubled region. For that reason, reactions to the resolution of the standoff were akin to sighs of deep relief. 
 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said tonight that he believed that the American decision was motivated in large part by a recognition that "the Arab people were not ready" for American use of force.
"I saw the situation as very sensitive," he said in a television interview. "We were afraid that the United States and other forces were going to launch attacks on Iraq, and people were going to lose lives."
The reason for that concern is the view that American military strikes against Iraq would have presented Arab governments with a nightmarish choice. By standing with the United States, they would have risked a backlash among citizens who perceive American favoritism toward Israel in efforts to broker a Middle East peace and American callousness toward the suffering of the Iraqi people through seven years of economic sanctions.
Siding with Mr. Hussein would have allowed Arab leaders to play to the sympathies of people who themselves feel put upon by the West. But that would have meant suppressing concerns about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction as well as risking vital economic and military partnerships with Washington.
Arab officials said they believed that efforts by leaders like Mr. Mubarak and King Hussein of Jordan to stave off a military threat had prevented a regional crisis and more.
"Saddam avoided a war in the region, and he made it known that sanctions cannot go on indefinitely," an Arab League official said in a telephone interview tonight. "He has made his issue the front-burner issue."
The official, who insisted on anonymity, said: "At the same time, Arab countries have not given him a blank check. The major Arab countries want him to understand his limitations and show some subtlety and flexibility, something for which he is not known."
Mr. Hussein's blatant aggression in ordering the invasion of Kuwait in 1990 made it possible for Egypt, Syria, Morocco and other Arab nations to justify sending troops into battle against Iraq. But those decisions were accepted grudgingly, and tempered by two ideas: that Iraq's ostracism would be short-lived, and that Arabs would be rewarded for their cooperation by American pressure on Israel to reach lasting settlements with its neighbors.
Increasingly, Arab frustration that neither goal is within reach has been expressed in complaints -- from ordinary people, politicians and the press -- that the United States has not kept up its side of the bargain.
"Those of us living in the area, friends of the United States and friends of the West, know that the slowing up of the peace process has meant that the American image is not what it might be," Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan said in a television interview at the beginning of the week. "So the use of force as a blunt instrument, I don't think would reflect well on the United States at the current time."
Arab leaders still do not disguise their exasperation with the Iraqi leader. In the interview tonight, Mr. Mubarak said that for now "he is not a threat for sure." But when asked why Mr. Hussein had ousted American weapons inspectors, the Egyptian President replied: "You should ask him. He started the war with Iran, then he started the war with Kuwait. It's a mess. I hope this will come to end."
Over the last three weeks, while American officials have warned that Iraq's ability to produce weapons of mass destruction was increasing daily, some Arab leaders were concerned that as long as the standoff continued, it would galvanize antipathy to the United States in a way that could have produced an anti-American explosion next month at an Islamic summit meeting in Teheran.
A Jordanian official who insisted on anonymity made clear that his Government would continue to press for a broader policy review. "The moral question that we have to ask ourselves is: How can you punish 18 million Iraqis when their leader is not suffering and does not care whether his people are being punished or not?"
