HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE POLICY;
A Shift to Diplomacy and Coexistence

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton came into office executing the policy toward Iraq that he had inherited: Keep Saddam Hussein cornered and respond to provocations with force.
But over time, Mr. Clinton's Administration adopted a much tougher line, plotting the Iraqi leader's ouster with covert operators on the ground in his country and planning ahead for an Iraq without him. 
 Now, in its handling of the most recent crisis with Iraq, the United States seems to be entering a new stage, unstated but apparent: Compromise and coexist, at least in the short run.
Mr. Clinton used force for the first time in his first two days as President, attacking an Iraqi position in January 1993 after Iraqi anti-aircraft guns fired at a Navy patrol. Later that year, after the United States uncovered what it said was an Iraqi plot to assassinate President George Bush, Mr. Clinton ordered the bombing of a military intelligence headquarters in Baghdad.
In 1994, after Iraq massed troops along the Kuwaiti border, the United States sent 40,000 troops, 770 military aircraft and about 30 warships to the region to force him to retreat.
Along the way, the Clinton Administration spent more than $100 million on a covert program to oust Mr. Hussein, run by the Central Intelligence Agency out of northern Iraq. Although the classified intelligence order calling for a change in the Iraqi regime is still in effect, the program itself was largely abandoned after American agents were forced to flee Iraq and many of their Iraqi supporters were killed by the Iraqi military last year.
The failure of the program and the meager U.S. military response after Mr. Hussein unleashed his forces in northern Iraq last year sparked criticism both on Capitol Hill and among military analysts within the Administration that the American strategy was no longer working.
In a Senate hearing, in fact, William Cohen, then a Republican Senator from Maine and now Mr. Clinton's Defense Secretary, challenged Administration claims that the American response had produced a victory; he pointed out that Mr. Hussein had boosted his standing with his people, splintered the American-led international coalition and consolidated his power in the north. Mr. Cohen even elicited from John Deutch, then the Director of Central Intelligence, an admission that Mr. Hussein had emerged from the military confrontation stronger.
As for American policy on international economic sanctions, whose main objective was to prevent Iraq from ever again amassing a strong military, it, too, has evolved over the years.
In an effort to "depersonalize" the conflict with Iraq, in early 1993 Mr. Clinton dropped Mr. Bush's demand that Mr. Hussein leave power as a condition for ending sanctions. What emerged was a policy stating that sanctions would be lifted if Mr. Hussein complied with all United Nations resolutions -- but adding that he was probably incapable of doing so.
Over time, Mr. Hussein complied with some resolutions, like the requirement that he recognize Kuwait's border. He also partially and grudgingly complied with the most important resolution, which required him to destroy all his weapons of mass destruction. Still, he kept the ability to produce chemical and biological weapons, setting the stage for the current crisis. Full compliance would mean he could freely sell his oil again.
But American policy toughened last March. At that time, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced that the United States would be willing to end Iraq's economic and political isolation -- but only after Mr. Hussein was out of power and not, as America's closest allies in Europe and the Middle East have said, after he complied with United Nations resolutions.
Now, although it may be only for tactical reasons, Administration officials are again saying that sanctions could be lifted if Mr. Hussein complies with United Nations resolutions.
As Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said on NBC's "Meet the Press" last Sunday, "It's always been the United States Government position that if he complied with Resolution 687, which is the one we're talking about here, that principally deals with weapons of mass destruction, and the other key resolutions that come out of the Gulf War, then we're prepared to lift sanctions."

HEADLINE: For Citibank, A Problem Plum;
Mexican Deal Survives, Despite Fraud Case and Political Turmoil

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Julio de Quesada, the head of Citibank's operations in Mexico, did not know that the chairman of a Mexican bank he was negotiating to buy had installed a secret door and an underground tunnel in a palatial mansion in northern Mexico.
Mr. de Quesada never guessed that the Mexican banker, Jorge Lankenau Rocha, would one day admit to the police that he had used the tunnel to escape from 20 rifle-toting officers surrounding the estate. 
 But what he did discover just as he thought he was about to successfully conclude his pursuit of Mr. Lankenau's company, Banca Confia, was that Mexican prosecutors were accusing Mr. Lankenau of fraud and malfeasance in his financial empire amounting to $350 million.
Nevertheless, Citibank went ahead. Just days later, on Aug. 27, it agreed to pay $45 million for Confia and to inject up to $175 million in capital into the bank.
An obvious question is why Citibank, whose parent, Citicorp, has assets of more than $300 billion and tentacles in almost every country in the world, would want to link up with a Mexican bank whose chairman was in so much hot water. The answer is that it saw its chance to get into street-corner banking in Mexico, a longstanding goal, and to do it with generous help from the Mexican Government's extensive bailout of the country's ailing banking system. Mexico agreed to back up all of Confia's bad loans, a commitment that will cost at least $1 billion in public funds.
For all its troubles, which also include signs of mismanagement, Confia is a plum for Citibank. It has 200 branches throughout the country and a reputation for service that is rare in Mexico.
The acquisition also fits in with Citibank's desire to become banker to the world's rising middle class. That strategy, in which the most global bank in the United States often finds the greatest opportunity in the least appetizing circumstances, emerged yet again this week in Thailand when it was reported that Citibank was eyeing First Bangkok City Bank P.L.C.
Mr. Lankenau, who was put under house arrest in late August, slipped though his secret door and tunnel in October and spent four days on the loose before turning himself in. On Monday, he was finally jailed, facing 12 criminal charges, including racketeering.
"The only association I ever formed was a financial group designed to provide banking services to the public," Mr. Lankenau testified in court this week after pleading not guilty to the charges. "I insist that association had and continues to have a completely legal purpose."
Meanwhile, though, a constant barrage of news in Mexico about Mr. Lankenau's travails threw an unwelcome light on Citibank's takeover -- and has helped make it something of a referendum for many debt-weary Mexicans on the Government's efforts to jump-start failing banks and revive an entire industry.
While similar bank rescue operations have been carried out in the United States and Europe, the program here is losing popular support because many Mexicans believe it benefits few people other than local bankers like Mr. Lankenau and deep-pocketed foreigners like Citibank.
Confia's case hit a nerve because it was the first Mexican bank snapped up by a United States corporation after three others were bought by Canadian and Spanish banks. And it was not just any United States bank; it was Citibank, the financial conglomerate that Mexicans have loved and hated for decades.
The acquisition also coincided with a political sea change in Mexico last summer, when opposition legislators, many inspired by the protectionist ideas that prevailed a generation ago, took control of the lower house of the Congress for the first time in decades.
"This deal is absolutely incomprehensible to me," said Ricardo Garcia Sainz, a new opposition lawmaker who is chairman of the powerful budget committee. "I don't see why we have to spend $1 billion of the Mexican people's money to clean up a bank so we can sell it to foreigners."
Criticism also came from the generally pro-business National Action Party, or PAN, one of the biggest opposition group. "These shady bailouts are only awakening the mistrust of the people," said Rogelio Sada Zambrano, economic policy coordinator for the PAN delegation.
Even Mexican bankers grumbled, although they welcomed Citibank's injection of capital into the system.
"The foreign banks are buying very healthy Mexican banks at very good prices because they get them with no bad assets," said Antonio del Valle, the chairman of Bital, a Mexican bank, and president of the Mexican Bankers Association. Mr. Del Valle bought Bital from the Government at top rates during boom times in 1992.
Mexican banks became vulnerable to takeovers after being crippled by bad management, soaring interest rates and loss-plagued loan portfolios in the wake of the peso collapse of 1994. Of 18 banks the Government sold to Mexican buyers in the early 1990's, only eight remain in business and in Mexican hands today.
Most Mexican businessmen say they realize the Government had no choice but to make huge investments -- now estimated at $47.5 billion over three decades -- to preserve the financial system. They also understand that foreigners are helping to modernize the system. "The two things foreigners are bringing in, capital and administration, are not available right now in Mexico," said Jonathan Heath, an economist here.
Moreover, many Mexicans remember with gratitude how Citibank, the longest-operating foreign bank here, hung in even after the turbulent nationalization of Mexican banks in 1982.
But the authorities have had a hard time explaining the bailout to working people, many of whom were ambushed by exploding debts after the peso collapsed. And recently, Citibank's image here has been tarnished by Washington's investigation of Citibank's handling of the accounts of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the wayward brother of the exiled former President. Moreover, United States prosecutors recently charged that middlemen for a Mexican narcotics cartel had used Citibank accounts to launder huge proceeds.
In the drug case, the prosecutors are not directly investigating Citibank itself. In the case of Mr. Salinas's accounts, Citibank has said that it is fully cooperating with United States authorities and has consistently denied any wrongdoing.
Citibank is counting on Confia's popularity with Mexicans to help it ride out the storm. Confia paints its branches forest green to project a warm ecological feeling and appeal to young, up-and-coming Mexicans. Its style and emphasis on service are largely the legacy of Mr. Lankenau, a jovial entrepreneur who once took planeloads of clients on all-expenses-paid trips to see the Super Bowl.
"We found that the staff thinks in terms of satisfying the customer," Mr. de Quesada, a 20-year Citibank veteran, said in an interview in his penthouse office overlooking Mexico City's smog-enshrouded sprawl.
Mr. Lankenau made his name by earning big profits as a stockbroker in the 1980's. He bought Confia from the Government in 1991. But after the peso crisis, Confia's troubles deepened. By this year, Mexican banking commission officials said, it was clear Mr. Lankenau was short by $150 million of the capital the Government had ordered him to raise to save his bank.
In April, after more than a year of sporadic talks, Citibank made an offer that banking authorities liked. But when the bank's officials examined Confia's books, they found chaos. There were no clear standards for extending credit. Collateral for loans had been artificially inflated. Other loans had no documentation.
"He was a one-man show who did everything with a point of his finger," said one banker who examined Confia's accounts. Mr. Lankenau traveled around Mexico ordering his staff to open branches at sites he chose by whim, bankers said, and he frequently overruled his own weak system for evaluating potential loan customers.
As negotiations with Citibank neared a close, everybody involved could see that Mr. Lankenau was growing frantic about losing his investment in Confia, worth tens of millions of dollars.
Even so, Citibank officials underestimated his desperation. Just days before Citibank was scheduled to announce its purchase, dozens of clients of Mr. Lankenau's brokerage firm, part of his financial group that also includes Confia, sued him for fraud. Soon the Mexican Government brought 12 criminal charges that could put Mr. Lankenau in jail for five years or more.
Mexican officials said that Mr. Lankenau does not appear to have willfully embezzled his customers, but rather that he grew reckless in his maneuvers to keep Confia and other holdings.
According to Mexican bank regulators and attorneys for those who are suing him, Mr. Lankenau sought to gather capital through offshore companies in the Cayman Islands, the Bahamas and Uruguay. On his orders, the authorities say, brokers at his trading house offered clients investments in dollars paying 11 percent.
Documents released by Mexican Government investigators show that Mr. Lankenau quietly moved $120 million from the offshore companies into Confia in operations that Mexican regulators called illegal. He also invested $40 million in Atlanta real estate, the documents show.
Early this year the offshore companies ran dry and the brokerage firm stopped paying. Clients discovered that the notes they received were "worth as much as a napkin" in Mexico, according to Gerardo Jimenez Cantu, a lawyer representing some of the investors.
At one point, Citibank considered pulling out of the deal, Mr. de Quesada said, but decided to stay the course. Then, in a meeting that lasted until dawn on the very day Citibank signed the contract, Mexican banking officials declared they had decided to take over Confia for several months before turning it over to Citibank. They apparently will remain in charge until the deal is officially closed.
Citibank officials, hoping to calm the furor around Mr. Lankenau, started an ad campaign about the Confia takeover, with huge green billboards and banners that said, "Good News!" in Spanish. It was no use; Mr. Lankenau continued to dominate the headlines, first by eluding the police officers who surrounded his residence in a chic suburb of Monterrey on Oct. 25, then -- looking haggard and sprouting a bristly beard -- by turning himself in.
A deferential district court simply returned him to house arrest, causing so much public outrage over favoritism for the rich that Monterrey officials finally jailed him this week. When he entered prison, newspaper photographs showed that he was carrying fresh garlic cloves and quartz crystals in his suit pocket, talismans he apparently hoped would protect him from harm.
Mr. Lankenau has strenuously denied that he defrauded any of his investors and has blamed the Mexican Government's intervention in his financial group for tangling his finances and making it impossible for him to meet his obligations.
Mexican regulators and Citibank lawyers said there was little chance that Mr. Lankenau's legal troubles would have any effect on Citibank's purchase. Citibank, which is awaiting approval for the purchase from the Federal Reserve in Washington, said it would leave the bank under the Confia name and hoped to complete the deal this year.
Confia depositors, initially nervous, have been reassured by Citibank's arrival. Their deposits stabilized. Mr. de Quesada said he remained confident that Citibank's investment would be good for its business and for Mexico.
But Mexicans are clearly thinking twice about how far they want to go to be part of international corporations that minimize borders.
"Everybody has seen that globalization, whether they like it or not, is inevitable," said Mr. Heath, the economist. "Mexicans see foreign ownership of the banks as part of that process. At the same time there is a fatigue syndrome setting in. There is starting to be a backlash."

Charts: "Good on Paper, Bad for Its Image"
In August, when Citibank agreed to buy a high-profile Mexican bank from Jorge Lankenau Rocha, it looked like a good deal. It still may be, but in the months since the acquisition of Banca Confia was announced, it has become a major headache for Citibank and its Mexican director, Julio de Quesada, below. Mr. Lankenau, right, has been arrested and charged with fraud, and the deal has become a lightning rod for Mexican criticism of foreign corporate ownership.
 
February 1997 -- Faced with mounting financial problems, Mr Lankenau asks Citibank to buy his bank.
April -- Banca Confia's capital reserves fall below regulatory requirements. The Government joins negotiations to sell the bank.
July -- The Government says it favors a sale to Citibank.
Aug 25 -- Some clients of Mr. Lankenau's brokerage firm accuse him of fraud.
Aug. 27 -- Citibank announces a deal to buy Banca Confia for $45 million and to provide an additional $175 million in capital. The Government agrees to assume responsibility for the bad loan portfolio, estimated at $1 billion.
Aug. 29 -- Mr. Lankenau is placed under house arrest.
September -- To counter the bad publicity, Citibank starts an ad campaign that boasts of its purchase of the bank.
Oct. 25 -- Mr. Lankenau escapes.
Oct. 28 -- Mr. Lankenau turns himself in.
Nov. 17 -- Mr. Lankenau is charged with 12 criminal counts and jailed. Citibank cancels its Good News ad campaign.
December -- Tentative closing date for Citibank's purchase of Banca Confia.

"Selling Mexico's Banks"

At the time, it offered no special subsidies for buying the banks, but after the economy turned down in late 1994 and early 1995 because of the collapse of the peso, some of the banks had to be bailed out. HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Widens; Impact From Asia Fell

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit jumped to an eight-month high of $11.1 billion in September, the Government said today, as financial turmoil in Asia helped widen the gap. The deficit with China and Japan widened significantly.
United States exports, whose growth has sputtered since early spring, declined, while imports rose, fueled by the strength of the domestic economy. 
 For evidence that the Asian turmoil has begun to affect the American economy, not just securities markets, analysts noted that the combined trade deficit with South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong doubled to $2 billion in September.
"This may be the first sign of what's to come with that region," said Carol A. Stone, deputy chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
The September figures were especially revealing because American financial markets were not seriously buffeted by the Asian turmoil until October.
Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley sought to minimize the effect of Asian disruption on the American trade deficit, declaring that while his department had not yet analyzed the situation, he thought the impact would be "fairly minor." But he also stressed that there could be an indirect benefit from higher imports because they restrain the prices that domestic producers can charge.
"As a consumer you would enjoy the fact that the prices may be coming down on some of the imports," Mr. Daley said.
Other Administration officials, however, have been emphasizing the risks in the situation. Only last week Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin warned Japan against attempting to export its way out of its economic malaise, fearing a ballooning trade deficit with Asia. The deficit is always a sensitive issue in Congress, which recently refused to restore President Clinton's authority to negotiate trade accords that could not be amended.
The report of an increasingly wide trade deficit came as the President prepared for a two-day summit meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, early next week to regain momentum for lowering trade barriers. Asian financial disruption is to dominate the agenda, but Mr. Clinton, Mr. Daley and other officials are also to discuss trade issues with Japan and other Asian nations.
Currency devaluations and weak growth in Asia could mean further increases in the American trade deficit, analysts believe, as low prices for Asian exports spur sales to the United States while flat Asian economies mean poor markets for more expensive American exports.
September's deficit with the Pacific Rim's newly industrialized countries "probably represents a harbinger of future trade trends," said Joel L. Naroff, economist at the First Union Bank in Philadelphia.
Mr. Daley, after citing such positive elements in today's report as a 25 percent surge in exports to Mexico this year, once again took the occasion to complain about China and Japan, with whom he said the trade situation "remains problematic."
He referred to barriers to trade and investment that have contributed to a record $5.5 billion deficit with China in September, up from $5.2 billion, and to a $5.1 billion deficit with Japan, up from $4.5 billion.
Mr. Daley acknowledged that these latest import surges included large volumes of holiday-related toys, decorations and electronic equipment -- figures for trade with particular countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal patterns. He also insisted that Asian nations needed to buy more American exports. Secretary Daley announced that the first task he had set for his newly confirmed Under Secretary for International Trade, David Aaron, was to conduct a review of how trading partners were complying with agreements the United States had negotiated and to study the effectiveness of the Commerce Department's year-old Compliance Center.
The September trade report showed that imports rose 1.2 percent from the previous month, to a new peak of $89.07 billion, mainly reflecting increases in apparel, diamonds, art work and industrial supplies.
Exports fell seven-tenths of 1 percent from August, to $78 billion, still a high total but below the levels early this year. Since March, exports have fallen in four of the six months that have been reported.
In publishing the September trade results, the deficit for August was revised sharply lower, to $9.5 billion from $10.4 billion.
For the first nine months, the United States deficit was $86.5 billion, 1.9 percent above the 1996 pace, which resulted in an eight-year high for the full year.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE IMPLICATIONS;
A Teetering Coalition

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 20

 BODY:
With Iraq's agreement to let all United Nations weapons inspectors return, the immediate crisis appears to have ended without use of military force, and the United States is declaring a victory for a united Security Council and for diplomacy.
American officials argue that Saddam Hussein had to back down and that they preserved the authority of the United Nations. They also insist that the United States gave Iraq nothing concrete in return -- at least for now. 
 But Mr. Hussein has lost nothing in this confrontation and may indeed have gained some ground. While the inspectors will resume their work, Mr. Hussein had three weeks to further hide his own work on weapons of mass destruction. And the American position of no deals with Mr. Hussein, no quick removal of United Nations inspectors and no changes in the sanctions is in greater jeopardy today than at any time since the end of the Gulf War in 1991.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke proudly of maintaining the unity of the Security Council and most of the coalition that the United States assembled against Iraq after the Gulf War.
But the future of that coalition looks increasingly shaky. The United States will find itself under more pressure from Russia, France and Arab states to bring the seven-year-old program of sanctions to a faster end.
Despite all the chest thumping by the American military, United States officials also understand that many of their allies opposed the use of military force. Although Washington insists that it did not and will not negotiate directly with Mr. Hussein, it came very close, using the agency of the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, instead.
What remains unclear is just what Mr. Primakov told Mr. Hussein that Russia would do, and what Mr. Hussein thinks he has been promised.
In the Russian-Iraqi statement published today in Moscow, the Russians promised Mr. Hussein that they would be an even more forceful advocate for the Iraqi demands to end weapons inspections and lift economic sanctions.
"Russia, for its part, will energetically promote the speedy lifting of sanctions against Iraq on the basis of its compliance with the corresponding U.N. Security Council resolutions," the statement said. "With this in mind, steps will be taken to increase the effectiveness of the Special Commission's activity on the basis of respecting Iraq's sovereignty and security."
While the Americans define "effectiveness" as better work in ferreting out Mr. Hussein's secrets, the Russians appear to define it in terms of speed.
The French Foreign Ministry, for its part, on Wednesday called for Iraq to be shown a "light at the end of the tunnel" on sanctions, once Mr. Hussein reversed himself. "There is a chronology that has to be respected," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine said today. But clearly the French and Russian clocks run at a speed different from Washington's.
The solidarity that Ms. Albright maintained and praised was easier to sustain when Iraq blatantly defied the Security Council by expelling inspectors. But this unity will not last on issues that require judgment calls, such as how much money Iraq should be able to receive from its oil, what it should be able to buy, how long the United Nations inspectors should stay and how much good behavior on Mr. Hussein's part is enough to lift the sanctions on Iraq.
That is perhaps the most important benefit of Mr. Hussein's defiance. It will not happen immediately, but he has managed to bring to the fore the essential disagreement among the great powers, and between the United States and a large part of the Arab world, about what should happen in the future. Those disagreements are bound to increase over time.
The United States retains its veto power in the Security Council. But Washington knows the costs of using its veto against the will of the majority, including some of its closest allies.
To American officials facing the prospect of diplomatic isolation, letting Russia make vague promises that the United States need not affirm and can veto later seemed a reasonable trade-off to make, as was the prospect of an expanded United Nations inspections effort to promote "efficiency" that also may just slightly reduce the percentage of Americans involved, but not their number.
And if Washington is willing to discuss allowing Iraq to sell more of its oil to pay for humanitarian and civil needs, now that Iraq is presumably complying with the sanctions again, this is not by any means an easing of sanctions, American officials argue. Instead, they insist, such humanitarian aid allows the rest of the world to salve its conscience about ordinary Iraqis and accept the harsh overall sanctions even longer.
Mr. Primakov also scored a victory in his quest to restore Russia as a player in Middle East policy. Russia remains a sponsor -- with the United States -- of the Middle East peace effort and is now better able to claim its place at the table. Mr. Primakov, who is an Arabic-speaking expert on the Middle East, has also put Washington in his debt, even though senior American officials who still do not trust him were careful not to praise him too highly today, saying simply that the Russian role was "helpful."
Mr. Primakov is likely to argue that the Russian role was critical, at least to an apparently quick ending of this crisis, and was exercised on the world's behalf, not merely Moscow's.
But in some ways his role was also easy. He could argue to the Iraqis that they were only hurting themselves by expelling the inspectors, because they could not hope for a lifting of the sanctions while they blocked their work. And Mr. Primakov could promise to fight even harder for the Iraqi contention that the United States is itself playing with Security Council language to find justifications to persecute Mr. Hussein until he is overthrown.
Mr. Hussein may have received another benefit. If the crisis was engendered by the United Nations inspectors coming too close to his biological and chemical weapons work -- and not by Security Council splits -- then he may have preserved the deterrent that he hopes will keep Iran at bay and Iraq's reputation high.
Whether he has succeeded in this aim, if indeed he had it, is almost immaterial, as one senior American official admitted. "Deterrence is about perceptions," he said, "not reality."
Asked if the same might be true of assertions of diplomatic victories and defeats, he smiled, shrugged and walked away.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON SAYS U.S. WILL WAIT AND SEE AS IRAQIS BACK OFF

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
With a "wait and see" edge of wariness, President Clinton welcomed Saddam Hussein's decision today to back down and allow United Nations inspectors to resume their search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.
"Saddam Hussein must comply unconditionally with the will of the international community," Mr. Clinton declared, as the Administration emphasized that its full Persian Gulf military buildup would proceed as previously announced in the three-week-long crisis. 
 "In the coming days we will wait and see whether he does, in fact, comply," Mr. Clinton said in brief, cautious remarks before a White House ecumenical breakfast.
In Baghdad, the state radio issued a statement after a meeting led by President Hussein, announcing, "Iraq has accepted the return of United Nations Special Commission inspectors, including Americans."
United Nations officials said today that a team of weapons inspectors will return to Iraq on Friday; they are to begin work again on Saturday. The team is to comprise about 77 people, the normal size for such a group, and will include Americans, although officials have not specified how many.
It was Iraq's sudden barring of Americans on the United Nations inspection teams that started the crisis and fed fears of another military showdown with Mr. Hussein.
The break in the standoff was announced after an emergency conference at 2 A.M. today in Geneva of representatives of the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council -- France, China, Britain, Russia and the United States. The meeting was called hastily after negotiations between Baghdad and Moscow.
After long, inconclusive hours, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright emerged to cautiously announce Mr. Hussein's "reversed course."
The meeting, while easing global tensions, was immediately followed by questions whether Iraq might have won some secret concession or understanding through Mr. Hussein's gambit of openly challenging the terms of his defeat in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
"There is absolutely no understanding," Samuel Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, insisted at a briefing. "There's no deal. There's no concessions."
His sentiments echoed those of James P. Rubin, Ms. Albright's spokesman, who summarized the Administration's view of the outcome by saying, "We protected all our rights and gave away nothing."
Mr. Hussein has sought to ease the United Nations' crippling economic sanctions and to speed an end to the on-site weapons inspections that began after Iraq's defeat in the war that began with Mr. Hussein's invasion of neighboring Kuwait in 1990.
Officials have expressed concern that the Iraqis exploited the last three weeks of foiled weapons inspections to hide evidence, destroy monitoring equipment and produce new arms or toxins.
Another issue is that the new team will have no better access than previous teams to certain secret sites, among them the presidential palace, according to Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's representative to the United Nations.
Administration officials took care today to hail only a "step in the right direction," rather than a full resolution, pointing to the American ships and warplanes undeterred in their mission to take up positions in the Persian Gulf area.
"This is not over," Mr. Berger said. "We have to maintain the two-pronged strategy we've been pursuing."
Mr. Clinton was equally guarded in reacting to the Hussein announcement. "The United States must remain and will remain resolute in our determination to prevent him from threatening his neighbors of the world with nuclear, chemical or biological weapons," he said.
This threat includes stores of the deadly nerve agent VX and of botulinus and anthrax toxins, according to United Nations inspectors who were pulled out of Iraq last week after the team's American specialists were expelled.
France and Russia, which have been holding heavy Iraqi debts through the long economic blockade, maintained support for the sanctions and inspections but have taken their own approaches to the current crisis.
In France, Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine was openly critical of the United States in a radio interview today, contending that Washington had left Mr. Hussein with the impression that "there would never be a way out of the tunnel," even if he got rid of all his weapons programs.
Another French diplomat, speaking anonymously, suggested that "the Americans bent a little" to reassure the Iraqi President.
In Baghdad, some officials said Mr. Hussein had agreed to allow inspectors to return only if Russia would guarantee an easing of sanctions and inspection procedures, possibly by changing the makeup of the inspection teams or by limiting U-2 surveillance flights over Iraq.
But Mr. Berger firmly denied this, noting that while Russia was free to speak up for Iraq at the United Nations, "we have a veto on the Security Council." He denied that Mr. Hussein had achieved a success of sorts in stirring world anxiety and underlining Western diplomatic differences.
"I have a hard time computing that as anything except a setback for him," Mr. Berger declared, adding that the United Nations had reaffirmed "the most pervasive sanctions regime in the history of mankind."
Through the day, American officials laced their expressions of relief with skepticism. They emphasized the Pentagon's orders to proceed full speed ahead to the gulf.
The dispatched armada includes 2 aircraft carriers and about 300 warplanes, including the latest F-117A Stealth fighters, plus a score of warships and defense units bristling with Patriot missile batteries, and 18,000 personnel.
Six B-52 bombers took off from Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana for Diego Garcia, the British base in the Indian Ocean. The Pentagon said its "air expeditionary force," a special 32-plane combat unit previously announced as being on standby, had been ordered to proceed to the region even before diplomatic progress was clear.
Mr. Clinton tracked the Geneva negotiations into the night, according to the White House. Twice, he slipped out of a screening of the film "Welcome to Sarajevo" at the residence to check with Mr. Berger on the news from Geneva. Later, he went to Mr. Berger's office and waited for word from the meeting, finally thanking Secretary Albright for the agreement that emerged.
The President stayed beyond midnight with security specialists, conferring on the steps needed to get United Nations inspectors back to their tasks, according to Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. Mr. Clinton also sought to assure that "our force posture in the region is consistent with what we think the reality of future behavior will be by the Government of Iraq," Mr. McCurry said.
The one possibility Mr. Berger mentioned -- an increase in the program that allows Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to purchase food and medicine -- might not be opposed by the Administration "at some point," he said. "Let me say that never even came up last night in the meeting in Geneva," he added.
Far from concessions, Mr. Berger emphasized continuing wariness at the White House in the face of Mr. Hussein's impetuous stratagems. "Skepticism is not a bad way to proceed through a matter like this," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Panel on Race Relations Is Itself Biased, Gingrich Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich today sharply criticized President Clinton's race relations advisory board, asserting that the panel did not seek the views of conservatives or foes of affirmative action to help it explore the means to bring about better race relations.
"Americans of all racial backgrounds believe that true diversity must include a wide array of opinions," he wrote. "The racial and gender obsessive focus that came out of the 1960's is outdated as we stand on the edge of a new millennium." 
 The Speaker's comments came in response to a meeting of the President's advisory board on race, at which the topic was the value of having a diverse faculty and student body and how to promote that. No opponents of affirmative action were invited to address the board.
Noting that Mr. Clinton had said he created the board to help him promote a dialogue on racial issues, Mr. Gingrich wrote: "When did your call for a dialogue become a monologue? Is your panel interested in educating our citizens -- or indoctrinating them?"
Mr. Gingrich's comments angered White House officials, who noted that the board's chairman, the historian John Hope Franklin, had written Mr. Gingrich on July 7, seeking his advice and suggestions on how the panel could carry out its job. The Speaker never responded, they said.
"If the Speaker now wants to get involved with the race initiative, his views will be welcome," said Joe Lockhart, a White House spokesman. "Unfortunately, to date he has been reluctant to become involved."
But Mr. Gingrich's office produced a copy of a letter dated Sept. 29 that it said was sent to all panel members, in which Mr. Gingrich outlined a 10-point program he said would help "close the racial divide."
Mr. Lockhart said the White House has been working for several weeks on setting up a meeting with conservative scholars and opponents of affirmative action to elicit their views on how to improve race relations.
But a check with some noted conservatives active in the race relations area and people opposed to affirmative action turned up none who said they had been contacted by the White House.
Among those contacted who said they were mystified by reports of the White House reaching out to conservatives were William H. Mellor, President of the Institute for Justice; Robert Woodson, President of National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise; Gwen Daye Richardson, editor of Headway Magazine; Stephen and Abigail Thernstrom, writers of "America in Black and White: One Nation Indivisible," and Glen C. Loury, an economics professor at Boston University.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Issues Call for Action To Rescue Social Security System

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged Congress today to act quickly to fix the looming problems in Social Security, saying the political and economic difficulties of addressing the impending shortage in the program's financing would only grow with time.
Mr. Greenspan, who was chairman of a national commission on Social Security in the early 1980's and has long used his platform at the Federal Reserve to warn of the problem's urgency, said the solutions to the retirement system's financial difficulties would not be painless, but were within reach. 
 "More important," Mr. Greenspan said, "most entail changes that are less unsettling if they are enacted soon, even if their effects are significantly delayed, rather than waiting five or 10 years or longer for legislation."
"We owe it to those who will retire after the turn of the century to be given sufficient advance notice to make what alterations in retirement planning may be required," he said. "If we procrastinate too long, the adjustments could be truly wrenching."
Mr. Greenspan's statements, to the lone Senator at a hearing called by the Senate Budget Committee's Social Security Task Force, came as Congress and the Clinton Administration are beginning to grapple with the problems of the pension program. Social Security will start running out of money in the decades after the baby boom generation begins reaching retirement age in 2010.
The task of the White House and Republican leaders will be made easier by projections that the Government will begin running budget surpluses in the next few years. Both parties are exploring how the surpluses could be used to shore up the system or to help create a new one that would give people more responsibility for retirement savings.
Yet neither the White House nor the Republican leadership has developed a plan or even a timetable for dealing with the issue, which is among the most politically sensitive facing either party and is certain to draw pressure from constituencies as diverse as the elderly and Wall Street.
Among the questions being debated is whether Washington should address Social Security before the next Presidential election in 2000 and whether a Social Security overhaul will have to wait until after Congress deals with similar problems afflicting the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly.
Mr. Greenspan said it would be a mistake to use any budget surplus to increase Government spending. Although he suggested that surpluses alone would probably not be enough to restore the retirement system's health, he offered no new solutions.
Instead, with Congress out of session, he conducted what amounted to a tutorial for Senator Judd Gregg, a Republican from New Hampshire who is the chairman of the task force.

HEADLINE: Spate of Skinhead Violence Catches Denver by Surprise

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The emergency call about a prowler seemed normal enough. But when a Denver police officer searched the working-class neighborhood this morning, a young white man with short cropped hair popped up from behind a bush and emptied an automatic pistol at him.
The bullets missed their target, but the ambush echoed as the latest of a series of attacks by racist skinheads that belie Denver's modern image of tolerance and affluence. 
 Two weeks ago, a 20-mile car chase ended in a blaze of gunfire and the arrest of a young man who proudly sported the tattoo "God of Hate." Last week, another car chase, this one stretching 30 miles, ended with the killing of a Denver officer and the suicide of a skinhead.
Tuesday night, two white men taunted a West African at a downtown bus stop and then shot him to death. A few hours later, at the station where the policeman who was killed last week had worked, someone dropped off a dead pig. The carcass was daubed with the drawing of a police badge and "Vanderjagt," the name of the dead policeman.
"The pig's head said that they are ready to go to war with the police," said Carl Raschke, a University of Denver religion professor who has studied white supremacist groups here and nationwide. "This is the worst outbreak of skinhead violence that has happened anywhere. Nowhere has there been such a direct challenge to the police."
The crude racial hatred flies in the face of Denver's image of an open-minded city where a white majority population has twice elected Wellington Webb, a black man, as mayor. The violence flies in the face of Denver's world image as a city proud of its $5 billion international airport and of its smooth handling of a summit of world leaders last June.
But Denver's unexpected outbreak of violence, most of it by young, white skinheads, is part of a national trend in which skinheads groups are growing while Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups decline, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center, a group based in Alabama that tracks hate groups nationwide.
According to the center, the number of Klan and neo-Nazi groups dropped by one-quarter from 1995 to 1996, hitting 140 last year.
"As the economy goes better for most people, you get less of this scapegoating rage," Mark Potok, a Center spokesman, said.
At the same time, the number of organized skinhead groups increased by 23 percent, hitting 37 in 1996. The difference seems to be demographic. The Klan often attracts a more middle-aged group. The skinheads draw on young people, often teen-agers facing job markets without high school diplomas.
The largest city of the Rocky Mountain West, modern Denver has occasionally seen eruptions of white supremacist activity.
In 1984, Alan Berg, a radio talk show host, was shot to death outside his home here. Three years later, two men were convicted of murder in the case. Members of a neo-Nazi gang, the Order of the Silent Brotherhood, the men apparently targeted Mr. Berg because he was Jewish.
Through the early 1990's, rallies on the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday regularly drew counterrallies by skinheads and Klansmen.
But, in general, reported hate incidents tapered off in Colorado through the 1990's.
The number of victims of hate crimes dropped 14 percent from 1994 to 1996, according to statistics from the Colorado Bureau of Investigation. Anti-Semitic incidents dropped by three-quarters during the 1990's, falling to 17 last year, according to the Anti-Defamation League.
"Police around Denver cracked down very hard on skinhead activity in the early 1990's," Mr. Potok said. "Last year, we didn't document the existence of any organized skinhead groups in Colorado at all."
The new outbreak started on Nov. 6, when two young men barricaded themselves in a house overnight, leading to a police siege. Escaping in a car the next morning, they traded dozens of shots with the police before surrendering unharmed.
One of the men, Jerald Dean Allen, sported such tattoos as "100% hate" and "God of Hate." "I believe in white pride," Mr. Allen told The Rocky Mountain News from jail. "I'm fighting for my own cause."
One week later, Matthaeus Jaehnig, led police on another car chase. According to the police, his girlfriend drove part of the way, while he fired at pursuers with an automatic rifle. Cornered, he shot to death a police officer, Bruce Vanderjagt, then committed suicide with the officer's handgun.
A longtime member of the Denver Skins, a loosely knit group of young men, Mr. Jaehnig, 25, had been arrested seven times since he dropped out of high school. One arrest was for ordering his dogs, a pit bull and a Rottweiler, to attack a police officer. The officer was Mr. Vanderjagt.
For all his arrests, Mr. Jaehnig spent about 30 days in jail. His affluent family routinely paid his bail and legal fees. Mr. Jaehnig grew up in a large house in a comfortable neighborhood and his father was a founder of the Denver Waldorf School, a school that teaches racial tolerance.
Dozens of skinheads attended Mr. Jaehnig's funeral. Death threats were telephoned to the condolence line for the dead police officer.
Late Tuesday night, two young white men approached Oumar Dia, a 38-year-old black immigrant from Mauritania who waiting for a bus after working his shift as a housekeeper at the Hyatt Regency Denver. They made fun of his hat, throwing it into the street. Then the two shot him twice, killing him on the spot.
When another person at the bus stop, Jeannie VanVelkinburgh, sought to intervene, the men shot her, also. Ms. VanVelkinburgh, a single mother of two boys, is now paralyzed from the waist down.
This afternoon, Bruce Ritter, the Denver District Attorney, announced that Nathan Thill, 19, was being held for investigation of first-degree murder. Arrested on outstanding traffic warrants, Mr. Thill appeared in court today, wearing a black leather jacket, his hair shaved to his skin.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Global Pact Bans Bribery In Victory For U.S. Business
Industrialized nations agreed to follow the United States' lead and formally outlaw the practice of bribing foreign government officials. 
 The United States banned foreign bribery 20 years ago, but its major trading partners had balked at such a restraint, arguing that bribery was a necessary reality for doing business with corrupt bureaucrats abroad. The agreement was seen as a triumph for American multinational corporations, which have complained for years that their foreign-based rivals enjoy an unfair advantage by bribing their way to success. Page A1.
 
Another Big Gain for Stocks
Stocks surged again, gaining momentum after the turbulence in world markets appeared to ease. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 101.87 points, to 7,826.61. D8.
 
Treasury prices were lower, despite early gains that briefly pushed the yield on the 30-year bond down to almost 6 percent. The yield ended at 6.06 percent, up from 6.03. D6.
 
Dow Jones Unit Said to Be for Sale
The board of Dow Jones met and voted to put the troubled financial information division up for sale, according to a person close to the company. The stock of Dow Jones, which had announced job cutbacks at the unit earlier this week, traded higher. Market Place. D8.
 
Cadillac of Sports Utility Vehicles
After months of insisting there was no room in the American auto market for another luxury sport utility vehicle, Cadillac, a division of General Motors, abruptly reversed course and announced that it would offer such a vehicle next autumn. Cadillac dealers had clamored for such a vehicle. D4.
 
Nabisco Chief in Surprise Departure
H. John Greeniaus, the chairman of the food unit of RJR Nabisco, said he would retire for health reasons, surprising analysts. He will be replaced by James Kilts, a former executive of Philip Morris's Kraft unit. D2.
 
Bid Seen for Hotel Company
Meditrust, one of the nation's biggest health care companies, has offered about $1.3 billion to acquire Interstate Hotels, which owns and manages hotels, people close to the negotiations said. D2.
 
Osteoporosis Drug Passes Hurdle
Promising new help against crippling osteoporosis, Government advisers recommended approval of a drug that mimics estrogen's bone-saving effects but without a risk of breast cancer. The drug is to be sold by Eli Lilly under the brand name Evista. A22.
 
Higher Bids for Safety-Kleen
Safety-Kleen, an industrial waste hauler that is fighting a takeover attempt by Laidlaw Environmental, agreed to be bought by a company being formed by investors and Philip Services of Canada. But Laidlaw afterward raised its bid. D7.
 
Visa: Everywhere It Wants to Be
Visa has been among the most aggressive marketers in exploiting its ties to the Olympics, and the coming Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, are no exception. Visa's multimillion-dollar advertising and promotional blitz is scheduled to begin tomorrow with a splashy television commercial. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D7.
 
Glendale Offers Settlement
Glendale Federal Bank offered to settle a longstanding lawsuit against the Federal Government over a 1989 accounting rule change that hurt its ability to profit from loans. The outcome of the case could determine how similar lawsuits by more than 100 other savings and loans are resolved. D2.
 
New Lives Turn Sour
More than two dozen workers who left Poland to work for Delta Air Lines in New York when the airline shut its base in Warsaw have seen their new lives turned upside down. Immigration officials have ruled that their work visas were issued by mistake and that they must leave the country. D8.

HEADLINE: 29 NATIONS AGREE TO OUTLAW BRIBING FOREIGN OFFICIALS

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 20

 BODY:
After years of lobbying by the United States, the world's industrialized countries formally agreed today to a treaty that would outlaw the practice of bribing foreign government officials.
The treaty, negotiated in Paris by 29 countries that belong to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, marks a victory for the United States, which outlawed foreign bribery 20 years ago but until now had never persuaded European and Japanese governments to follow suit. 
 American companies have complained for years that they lose billions of dollars in contracts every year to rivals that bribe their way to success overseas. Until recently, most other industrial countries had discreetly balked at outlawing foreign bribery -- indeed some had even permitted corporations to take a tax deduction for it -- arguing that corrupt government officials were an unsavory but unavoidable fixture of doing international business.
While outlawing bribery might seem as straightforward as being against sin, this treaty was only reached after long and prickly negotiations over the legal niceties of a black art. Last May, the O.E.C.D. countries agreed in principle to a bribery ban. Since then the countries have been defining precisely what kind of government officials should be covered.
The treaty's central provisions would, for the first time, force countries to prosecute corporations for paying bribes to foreign government officials in the same way that bribery of their own officials is illegal.
It would also outlaw most payments to members of parliament, something that Germany, Austria and Finland had resisted because it went beyond the laws in their own countries. In Germany, for example, it is permissible to make payments to Members of Parliament so long as the money is not directly tied to a vote.
Advocates of tough anti-bribery measures cautioned that the new treaty could prove a disappointment. For one thing, it would not outlaw most payments to political party leaders, even though party politicians are often central decision makers about government policy or simply proxies for actual government officials.
The treaty is also narrower than the United States had originally proposed when negotiations got under way more than a year ago. From the start, the United States wanted governments to embrace a detailed set of practical recommendations that would make bribery more difficult to disguise on corporate books and more costly if discovered. The treaty hammered out tonight focuses on defining crimes while merely alluding to an array of measures that governments may "consider" in policing bribery. One possibility is that a company found guilty of paying a bribe might be excluded from bidding on contracts awarded by its own government.
"Everyone should recognize that this is only one tool in a whole tool kit of measures to deal with corruption," said Peter Eigen, chairman of Transparency International, a nonprofit organization in Berlin that is supported by multinational corporations and has lobbied for the strictest possible measures. "We are afraid that countries will say they have agreed to the criminal measures and then leave the matter at that," Mr. Eigen said.
Nevertheless, even skeptics said the treaty marked an important breakthrough. Once ratified by individual governments, it would become a legally binding agreement. However, there was still disagreement tonight over how many countries would have to approve the treaty before it went into effect. The nations have agreed to present it to their parliaments for a vote by next April and hope to change their laws so that it would be effective by the end of 1998.
"This is the most important anti-corruption initiative yet that is directed at the supply side of corruption," said Fritz Heiman, counselor to the General Electric Company and head of Transparency International's American chapter. He said the treaty today grew out of America's experience with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which was passed in 1977.
In the early years after the law was enacted, several dozen American companies were charged with violating the anti-bribery law but no chief executive has been convicted.
Critics say the Federal Government has raised relatively few cases, though as recently as 1995 the Lockheed Corporation pleaded guilty to bribing an Egyptian legislator to win a $79 million sale of transport plans. Lockheed agreed to pay a $24.8 million penalty.
With more and more American corporations having expanded into developing markets in Asia, where bribes are common, the Justice Department said it had beefed up its investigations; legal experts contend that the Government has not been that aggressive lately. In fact, the Justice Department has issued interpretations of the law that have given business more leeway in doing business in foreign countries even with family members of heads of state.
For their part, business executives say the treaty agreed to today reflects growing support for anti-bribery initiatives among corporations in Europe and Japan that have openly opposed the idea. Some of Europe's leading industrial corporations, including a few that have been embroiled in recent allegations of bribery, have spoken out in favor of tougher measures and on the increasingly corrosive effect of corruption.
Some companies have been acutely embarrassed by allegations of serious bribery. Last year, five companies, including Siemens A.G. of Germany, were accused of paying millions of dollars to a Government official in Singapore to win a big contract to supply telecommunications equipment. Singapore prohibited all five companies from doing business with its Government.
But the O.E.C.D. negotiations over the last three days were nonetheless arduous, boiling down to three main questions. First, to what extent are executives at state-owned or state-controlled companies considered "public officials?" The issue was crucial, because many of the biggest contracts involve sales to state-controlled telephone companies, airlines, railroads and utilities.
American negotiators successfully argued that the bribery ban should include any company in which a government owns more than 50 percent of the stock. But European negotiators argued that a public official should also be engaged in some kind of "public function." According to American officials, who spoke tonight on condition of anonymity, the treaty defines these "para-statal" companies primarily on the basis of whether a government either owns or effectively controls the organization.
The second issue was whether the treaty should cover elected legislators or members of parliament. Most countries agreed that legislators should be covered. But Germany, Austria and Finland objected, arguing that the treaty would conflict with the way parliamentarians are treated within their own countries. American officials said tonight that the treaty now clearly included members of parliament.
But the United States failed to get its way on the question of whether a treaty should cover payments to political parties. Most countries refuse to support the American demand, arguing that the line between legal political contributions and illegal bribery is too murky. American business executives acknowledged, moreover, that the issue was hardly clear in the United States, where Washington has itself been engulfed in allegations about huge "soft money" contributions to the Democratic and Republican parties.
Another question that remains unclear is whether countries will in fact prohibit corporations from writing off bribes as tax-deductible expenses, as is now permitted in many countries. Last May, members of the O.E.C.D. pledged to stop that practice, but a number of countries insisted on waiting until the new treaty actually defined foreign bribes as a crime.
The new treaty is supposed to settle lingering questions about the tax deductibility of bribes, but it may not. Mr. Eigen, as well as some American executives, said that companies might only be blocked from payments that were identified and prosecuted as criminal bribes. If companies simply account for bribes as "commissions" or "consulting fees," and auditors do not investigate the payments more closely, they could skirt the rules.

HEADLINE: In Japan, Tricky Course on Bailout Calls for Double Reverse

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
First he flipped, then he flopped, then he flipped again.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan instructed the ruling Liberal Democratic Party today to devise a plan for using public funds to bail out Japan's shaky banking system. 
 His instructions were a 180-degree reversal of his position Wednesday, which in turn was a reversal of a comment he made on Tuesday. At that time, he indicated support for using taxpayer money to help the banks unload the trillions of yen in bad debts that they have carried since the bubble in the Japanese economy burst in the early 1990's.
"It's exactly what I would have hoped he would have done," Alicia Ogawa, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers, said of the Prime Minister's latest position. "Maybe it's finally the beginning of the end."
Most analysts have not put a precise price tag on a bailout of a banking system that includes some of the world's largest financial institutions. The Government estimates that the banks are saddled with bad debt worth some 20 trillion yen, or about $157 billion, but analysts believe the number is higher because many institutions do not reflect the full extent of the problems on their books.
The bailout could cost the Government from a fourth to a third of the amount of the bad debt, once bank assets are sold off, one analyst estimated.
Mr. Hashimoto's third change of heart in as many days came after a chat he had this morning with former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, who prodded him to find a way to inject public funds into the banking system before a meeting with President Clinton scheduled for this weekend at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation talks in Vancouver, British Columbia.
Earlier this week, Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, encouraged the Japanese Government to consider using public funds to rid the banking system of its problems, stressing Japan's need to be a leader in an Asian financial system that has suddenly gone awry.
"It's not that the Asian problems are Japan's responsibility, but since it's happening in this neighborhood, people, say in New York, are probably asking 'what is Japan doing?' " Mr. Miyazawa said in a brief interview at his office today. "So it's better that Mr. Hashimoto should have something explicit to say in Vancouver."
Additionally, as currency values have crumbled across Asia this fall, the Japanese banks' exposure in the region has come under intense scrutiny, and now even the most sound institutions here are paying a premium to borrow short term.
The banks have been slow to acknowledge problem loans that have been on their books since the real estate bubble burst as the 1990's began. Add the recent fall in Hong Kong property values, the devaluation of the Thai baht and the bankruptcy of several major South Korean corporations, and suddenly the problems seem overwhelming.
"The domestic bad-debt problem alone, they could probably grow their way out of," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company here. "But every day, there's another problem."
The rescue plan that Mr. Miyazawa sketched out includes elements of the system that Washington used in the late 1980's to bail out the savings and loan industry through the Resolution Trust Corporation. The Government would help troubled banks dispose of their problem debts, close the weakest banks and inject capital into those banks best positioned to regain their footing.
If the plan is adopted, Tokyo would create a fund that would issue bonds and guarantee them against default, using some of the vast pool of money that sits in Japan's postal savings system. The money raised by selling the bonds would be used to protect depositors whose banks would be shut down. It would also be used to buy preferred shares or subordinated debt of banks that need capital but are basically sound or too big to fail.
Over time, the fund would produce the money to pay back the bonds by selling the assets of failed banks. Mr. Miyazawa said that the fund, which would likely be set up inside the Deposit Insurance Corporation, would probably have a five-year life span, at the end of which the nation's banking problems would be resolved.
The rescue plan would save the biggest and best banks, but it would also open them to new types of competition at a time when the Government is already demanding that they raise their capital levels, carry their assets at market prices and adopt more rigorous accounting standards by next April.
Mr. Miyazawa's involvement in the rescue plan was unusual. Former prime ministers typically do not take a leading public role in sensitive debates. But using him to speak bluntly about the depth of the banking problems and the dire necessity of addressing them was seen as one of the most politically astute moves by an administration that has become known for its blunders.
"He has turned the public debate away from saving fat-cat bankers and toward the condition of the economy," Ms. Ogawa of Salomon said of Mr. Miyazawa. "He's got nothing to lose."
The use of public funds to bail out the banks is political dynamite here, where taxpayers have not forgotten the Government's 685 billion yen bailout of housing lenders just two years ago. That was perceived as throwing good money after bad for political expediency, and brought crowds of protesters to the sidewalks around the Ministry of Finance.
Unlike Mr. Hashimoto, whose public standing is at a low, Mr. Miyazawa, a former Ministry of Finance bureaucrat, has the experience and stature to speak plainly about the banking system's problems and why the public must step up to solve them.
It is going to be an expensive and painful task, however. For one thing, the Deposit Insurance Corporation is underfinanced. Analysts estimate that it will spend more to shutter the Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, which failed on Monday, than the 460 billion yen the corporation will take in this year in premiums.
The Government will probably raise premiums and issue bonds to strengthen its deposit insurance program.
David Atkinson, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs (Japan) Ltd., published a report Wednesday estimating that the Government would have to inject 5.5 trillion yen, or about $43 billion, into the banking system by March 1999 if the banks wrote off all their nonperforming loans, marked down the value of their stock portfolios to accurately reflect market prices and securitized as many assets as possible to offset the cost to the public.
In the worst case, Mr. Atkinson estimates, the cost of supporting the 20 largest banks would rise to 7.6 trillion yen, or nearly $60 billion, if the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell to about 12,000 points, from its current level of around 16,000, and each bank realized its losses but did not change its asset base.
Mr. Miyazawa said today that even with the Nikkei at 16,000 points, the bad debts at several banks outweighed their assets.
More so than is the case at their American counterparts, the financial strength of Japanese banks depends on stock prices. That is because of the Japanese tradition of companies and banks holding shares in institutions with which they do business.
That surely factored into Mr. Hashimoto's latest switch, since his comments Wednesday indicating he was cold to the idea of a bailout pushed the stock market down 5.3 percent, its biggest drop since the Kobe earthquake in 1995. The market bounced up today, with the Nikkei up 2.9 percent, to 16,308.49.
 In early trading on Friday, stocks continued their rebound. At midday, the Nikkei was up 320.08 points, or 1.96 percent, at 16,628.57.
But banking stocks were not big winners. Many investors have apparently concluded that those stocks are in for still more drubbing.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: South Korea Moves Closer To Requesting I.M.F. Aid

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Government today moved toward seeking a huge bailout from the International Monetary Fund, with the state broadcasting network saying the Finance Ministry had decided to request roughly $60 billion in assistance to avoid an economic crisis that would paralyze the world's 11th-largest economy and ripple around the globe.
There were conflicting reports on how close the Government was to making such a request, but it appeared the final decision rested with President Kim Young Sam. A spokesman for Blue House, the presidential mansion, said only that President Kim would make an address to the nation on Saturday. 
 President Kim could veto a decision to go to the I.M.F., for he would be severely embarrassed by the bailout, which would be seen as a humiliating national setback just as he is preparing to leave office. Still, it is not clear that he has any other options.
The bailout figure of $60 billion reported by the state radio would be approximately triple the amount of I.M.F. aid extended to Indonesia last month and nearly four times the size of the rescue package the fund extended to Thailand in August.
It also would confirm that the contagion that infected Southeast Asian countries in recent months had spread north. South Korea is also an industrialized country, with an economy more akin to those of Europe than to the smaller and less sophisticated Asian economies that have stumbled so far, and it has particularly close ties to the United States that would suggest a major American role in any rescue package.
This morning, the Finance Ministry denied that any final decision concerning an appeal to the fund had been made, saying that turning to the I.M.F. was only "one of a number of options," as one official who spoke on condition of anonymity put it.
At the same time, though, the state broadcasting network was carrying a telephone interview with Lim Chang Yuel, the newly appointed Finance Minister, in which he discussed the scale of an I.M.F. assistance package.
On Thursday, Mr. Lim had also seemed to signal the likelihood of an I.M.F. bailout, emphasizing that turning to the I.M.F. was an option that could resolve South Korea's crisis.
But at that time he continued to say the discussion of an I.M.F. bailout was premature and that South Korea would first try to raise funds from neighboring countries.
In a further sign that South Korea had softened its stance, Mr. Lim on Thursday did not bother beseeching the United States for help. American officials, rebuffing earlier aid requests, had insisted for days that any financial rescue must be led by the I.M.F.
South Korea announced an economic package on Wednesday, hoping that liberalization measures and bond issues would attract tens of billions of dollars to ease the country's liquidity crisis. But the markets were clearly unimpressed; the won, the Korean currency, tumbled its maximum allowable limit of 10 percent Thursday, and stocks fell 2.8 percent.
The heightened prospect of a bailout helped stem the won's retreat today and it rose slightly for the first time this week. But South Korea's stock market eased further, falling almost 1 percent by midday.
In his first full day on the job since his predecessor was dismissed as part of an economic reform package, Mr. Lim also elaborated Thursday on South Korea's extraordinary plea for help from the country's ancient enemy, Japan.
Mr. Lim said he was asking overseas banks, many of them Japanese, to extend the maturities of loans coming due. He also said that Japan could help by buying South Korean bonds, and he warned that Korea's problems could drag down Japan as well.
"Despite our sound economic indicators in Korea, we are currently experiencing financial market instability," Mr. Lim said. "Such instability, combined with a lack of international cooperation among financial institutions, is leading to economic crisis in Korea. If that becomes a reality, it will badly affect Japan as well."
The lack of cooperation Mr. Lim referred to apparently meant the refusal by some banks to renegotiate and extend loans coming due.
Asia's difficulties suggest that maybe there was something to the old domino theory after all. It did not hold true in ideology, for the fall of South Vietnam in 1975 did not lead the rest of Asia to topple like dominoes, but Asian trade and markets are now so integrated that market forces are proving much more mobile than Communist guerrillas ever were.
Since Thailand suffered a run on its currency this summer, currencies and markets have plunged throughout the region, with the Malaysian stock index tumbling 11 percent on Thursday alone.
South Korea, though, is far bigger economically than Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia or other places that have endured difficulties. In particular, South Korea carries a $110 billion foreign debt, with by some accounts one-fifth of that maturing in the next six weeks. Repayment difficulties could cause problems for international banks -- especially those in Japan.
To be sure, South Korea also has enormous underlying strengths. That point was demonstrated when the Government said Thursday that the economy grew a solid 6.3 percent in the third quarter, from July through September.
More broadly, South Korea -- its department stores packed with high-technology goods and shoppers, its Government ministries thick with Ph.D.'s from American universities -- does not remotely have the banana republic flavor that its financial policies have lately projected.
Because the underlying economy remains strong in many respects, what South Korea seems to face is a liquidity crisis coupled with a mountain of bad debts that have left many Korean banks with dubious solvency. Moreover, disclosure has been so poor that no one really knows whether confronting the bad-debt problem will be simply painful or downright agonizing.
The measures announced Wednesday might help resolve the banking problems, by liquidating bad debts and allowing bad banks to be taken over by stronger institutions. But the announcements did little to clarify how South Korea would raise the tens of billions of dollars needed to resolve its liquidity crisis.
"The direction of the measures is right, and we've been waiting for them for a long time," said Lee Won Il, head of research at KEB Smith Barney Securities here. "But it's not enough to stabilize overall sentiment. Although it's painful to our national pride, I think we've got to go to the I.M.F."
President Kim and other Government officials have been extremely reluctant to request emergency funds from the I.M.F., partly because the I.M.F. would presumably set tough conditions on Korea's economic policies and erode its financial autonomy.
"There's still a feeling in the Government and in the public that it would be giving up so-called economic sovereignty," said Han Sung Joo, a political scientist and former Foreign Minister. But Professor Han argued that turning to the I.M.F. might actually be good for South Korea in the long run.
"The reforms that the I.M.F. would demand are those that we should take by ourselves," Mr. Han said. "But we need the external impetus to do it."

HEADLINE: Asian Crisis Swells U.S. Trade Deficit

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit jumped to an eight-month high of $11.1 billion in September, the Government said, as financial turmoil in Asia helped widen the gap. 
 United States exports, whose growth has sputtered since early spring, declined, while imports rose. Analysts noted that the combined trade deficit with South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong -- some of whose economies have been reeling from a crisis in financial markets -- doubled to $2 billion in September.
Business Day, page D1.

HEADLINE: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "State Regents Get It Wrong" (editorial, Nov. 20): As a language teacher, I applaud the decision to require three years of foreign language study for a high school diploma. Dr. Rudy Crew, the New York City Schools Chancellor, fears that the rule will impede the progress of students at some troubled urban high schools, but I believe language study will add to their education.
Learning a foreign language according to current methods is not about memorization. Now, basic knowledge of another language provides access to an entire culture. Language study is writing, reading and listening. It is art, history and science. Above all, it is exploration. 
 Language study is also pragmatic. Americans have earned a reputation abroad for arrogant ignorance of foreign cultures, an ignorance that has grave political and economic consequences.
 
SUSAN KASSOUF
Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Nov. 20, 1997
 
The writer is an assistant professor of German studies at Vassar.

HEADLINE: Meet U.S. Energy Needs With Domestic Reserves;
Technology Investment

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You say (editorial, Nov. 17) "the United States can retain its energy independence while relying on foreign sources of supply, leaving much of its own untapped wealth in the ground as a strategic reserve." That would be like limiting the number of print journalists to preserve more of our forests as a "strategic reserve." The oil and gas we can produce domestically is limited by technology and not by the amount of oil in the ground. Increasing dependence on foreign oil increases the trade deficit and makes stabilizing the dollar harder.
You say "the Administration has also failed to focus on more efficient use of existing energy supplies and on stronger conservation efforts." Yet the Clinton Administration has increased investment in energy-efficiency technologies by hundreds of millions of dollars a year. 
 You suggest there may be a trade-off between stimulating oil production in the Caspian Basin and encouragement of democracy there. Yet Western expatriates have set a good example of how to operate in a free society, and Western investment has been a lever for economic and political reform. The greatest threat to human rights in the region has been Russian expansionism and now Islamic fundamentalism. United States engagement provides support against these pressures.
 
WILLIAM H. WHITE
Houston, Nov. 17, 1997
 
The writer, chairman of Frontera Resources, an oil and gas company, was Deputy Secretary of Energy, 1993-95.
