ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. On display is "The Nature of Diamonds," an exhibition that explores all facets of the mineral, from its geological origins to its popularity as an adornment to its modern uses in technology and research. Through April 26. Tomorrow and Sunday from 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. in the Kaufmann Theater, the "Festival of Diamonds on Film," with feature and documentary works about cultural, economic and scientific views on diamonds. Free with museum admission. "In the Kingdom of Imerina, Madagascar," a series of 19th-century photographs of the Merina people of Madagascar by the Rev. William Ellis, along with Merina woven silk textiles, will run through January. "Drawing Shadows to Stone: Photographing North Pacific Peoples 1897-1902," an exhibit that includes 100 photographs taken by the Jesup North Pacific Expedition anthropologists, runs through March 1. Tomorrow at 1 to 3:30 P.M. in the Kaufmann Theater is the first installment in a four-part film and lecture series about the Jesup expedition, a presentation by Sergei Kan, of the Dartmouth College department of anthropology. Free with museum admission. Permanent displays include the dinosaur and fossil halls and the Imax films "Survival Island," "Cosmic Voyage" and "Whales." Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200. 

 AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. The society celebrates medallic art and history with a retrospective of Gilroy Roberts, former chief engraver of the United States Mint, and works by members of the American Medallic Sculpture Association and the British Medal Art Society. Through Jan. 4. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this pe riod. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history from 600 B.C. to the present. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.
 CZECH CENTER NEW YORK, 1109 Madison Avenue, at 83d Street. The center has an exhibition on the composer Dvorak that includes photographs, letter facsimiles, musical scores and contemporary documents through today. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 288-0830.
 HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. A museum dedicated to Hispanic culture, with fine and decorative arts of the Iberian peninsula, from prehistory to the present. Current exhibitions include "Spain/ America, Circa 1840-1920: Small Oils by American and Spanish Artists"; "Spanish Paintings, 1860-1930," and "Portraits of the Spanish Generation of '98." Through Dec. 27. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M.; closed holidays. Free. Information: (212) 926-2234.
 HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. About 27 buildings from the late 1600's to the 19th century, many restored and furnished. This authentic village and outdoor museum complex depicts three centuries of the history and life of Staten Island and the surrounding region. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; closed most holidays. Admission: $4; the elderly and ages 6 to 18, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.
 INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A converted World War II aircraft carrier featuring two full decks of displays, including four theme halls: "United States Navy Hall"; "Pioneer Hall"; "Technologies Hall" and "Intrepid Hall." Also on view is a 1950's French naval fighter jet, the Etendard IV-M, given to the museum by the French Government. On view through Jan. 5 is "On the Waterfront," photographs of New York City's Hudson River waterfront by Maggie Hopp, focusing on the area from Battery Park City north to 59th Street. Free with museum admission. Tomorrow, as part of the Seaworthy Saturdays series, a program titled "Code Crackers" will be held from noon to 2 P.M. Participants will learn about the secret languages used by sailors from World War II to the present. Free with museum admission. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Admission: $10; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $7.50; ages 6 to 11, $5; 5 and under, $1. Information: (212) 245-0072.
 LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience as lived on the Lower East Side. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. A newly opened apartment, once home to the Confino family, allows children to explore the premises and interact with an actor playing a 13-year-old member of the family. The museum's two other apartments, which housed the Gumpertz and Baldizzi families, can be viewed through guided tours only. Current exhibits include "These Walls Can Talk," a collection of Chad Beer's photographs of murals, on view through Feb. 28. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tour times and prices vary. Information: (212) 431-0233.
 THE MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents materials related to the history of New York City. Tomorrow evening, from 7 to 9:30, the museum presents "Tellabration: New York's Evening of Storytelling." Designed for adults and teen-agers, the event is part of an annual festival being held in venues across the country. Audiences will have the opportunity hear tales from 15 storytellers. Program admission: $12. Registration is required: (212) 613-3117. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.  THE MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place (West Street and Battery Place), Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videotapes and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Exhibitions include "Life a Century Ago," featuring memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's, and "War Against the Jews," detailing the years of 1933 to 1945. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; closed on Saturdays and Jewish holidays.  NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, downtown Brooklyn. Exhibitions include "Engineering in Transit: Past Present, Future," about the building and maintenance of the infrastructure that keeps the city's trains and buses moving; "Building to Last: The Restoration of Grand Central"; "Steel, Stone and Backbone," a display tracing the construction of the subway system from 1900 to 1925 with photographs, construction tools, films and other objects; "Ceramic Ornamentation," a look at the mosaics, tiles and terra cotta used to adorn subway stations from 1904 to the present, and "Here to There: Signs for Moving Around Underground," an exhibition of more than 100 subway signs. HEADLINE: Clinton, Remembering Rabin, Sees Urgency of Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton warned the Israelis and Palestinians today that they were running short of time. He spoke at a ceremony at which he recalled the push for peace made by Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister assassinated for his efforts two years ago.
"Now both sides have got to realize the need for urgency," Mr. Clinton said in the East Room. "The window of progress will become smaller with time. The frustration of ordinary people, both Israelis and Palestinians, will grow in the absence of progress." 
 The President spoke as he received a peace award from Mr. Rabin's widow, Leah Rabin, and Mr. Rabin's old ally Shimon Peres, the former Prime Minister. Warm remembrances of Mr. Rabin's efforts for peace contrasted with grim assessments of the state of negotiations in the region today.
"In recent months," Mr. Clinton said, "you have to acknowledge at least that the pace of change has slowed, and that the bonds of trust have eroded on both sides."
Mrs. Rabin recalled that she seemed "to be hearing the flutter of history's wing" when Mr. Rabin and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, shook hands at the White House on Sept. 13, 1993. Today, she said, she and others returned here "as a symbol of the hope we have not lost, despite some discouraging events and skies that have darkened things."
Lavishly praising Mr. Clinton's leadership, Mr. Peres also said that "peace is not lost," citing two indicators. The first, he said, was that he did not know "anybody today in the Middle East, who is serious, who wants to have a sixth war." The second reason, he said, was that countries in the region were becoming more preoccupied with economics than politics.
"Politics is a business for politicians who seek glory," Mr. Peres said. "Economy is a business for people who seek food. And every country that goes over from glory to food, from trying to make an impression to render a service, is really leading the people to a new era."
Mr. Clinton has never established the kind of friendship with Benjamin Netanyahu, the current Prime Minister, that he had with either Mr. Rabin or Mr. Peres. He and his aides have expressed frustration with Mr. Netanyahu's handling of the peace effort, and the President did not see him during his recent trip to the United States.
Mr. Clinton only mentioned Mr. Netanyahu near the end of his remarks today, saying the Israeli and Mr. Arafat should "work intensively" on issues they had chosen to discuss, such as security cooperation. By contrast, he praised Mr. Peres for having "stayed true to the path they had chosen, even when the enemies of peace waged terror against the people of Israel." Mr. Peres and his Labor Party lost to Mr. Netanyahu and the Likud Party in elections in May 1996.
But Mr. Clinton today was speaking to both sides, a senior official said, acting out of a sense that the peace process "needs a kick."
"It's not a question of despair about the process," the official said, "but a message to both sides: 'You can't go on and on like this. The status quo is not sustainable.' "
In recalling Mr. Rabin's work for peace, Mr. Clinton said today, "It's so hard to say now, but, actually, from time to time, we had a lot of fun doing this."
The President told a story about Mr. Rabin that he has delighted in telling privately before. According to the President's account, just before they went out to the White House lawn to stand with Mr. Arafat in 1993, he warned the Prime Minister that "when we went out there it was going to be quite an extravaganza, and Mr. Arafat was an emotional person and there was going to have to be a handshake."
Mr. Rabin balked, but, as Mr. Clinton recalled, he reminded the Prime Minister that he himself had said that "you can't make peace with your friends."
There would be a billion people watching, Mr. Clinton said. "What are you going to do?" he recalled asking. "He said, 'All right -- but no kissing.' "
Mr. Clinton was the first recipient today of the Man of Peace Award, established by the Rabin Foundation and the Peres Foundation, two "peace centers" financed in part with money from the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize the men shared with Mr. Arafat. Mr. Clinton asked the foundations to devote the $75,000 in prize money to pay for scholarships for Americans to study in Israel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Rodham Clinton, Leah Rabin and President Clinton during a ceremony in the East Room of the White House yesterday at which Mr. Clinton received the Man of Peace Award from the widow of Yitzhak Rabin. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cutting the Supply of Bribes

 BODY:
In the past few years dozens of developing countries have begun programs to cut corruption and prosecute officials who take bribes. But little has been done by the developed world to crack down on bribe-givers. That changed Thursday in Frankfurt, when the 29 industrialized countries belonging to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed on a treaty outlawing bribes to foreign government officials.
The treaty, while incomplete, is a victory for the United States. The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, passed in 1977 in the wake of Watergate, made it illegal for American companies to bribe foreign officials. But no other nation followed. Many countries, including Germany and Australia, allow companies to deduct foreign bribes from their taxes as a business expense. 
 The spread of democracy, with the accompanying demands for governmental accountability, is one reason that more nations are trying to fight corruption. Another factor was the founding in 1992 of Transparency International, a Berlin-based organization that has helped many countries design anti-corruption strategies and has been pushing for years to make offering bribes illegal. A treaty gained support because nations were willing to give up this business advantage only if their competitors would also do so.
The treaty would force nations to prosecute any of their corporations that pay bribes to foreign government officials, legislators and executives of state-controlled companies. It has several shortcomings, however. It is not clear whether countries must stop allowing tax deductions for bribes. Corporations may continue to bribe officials of political parties. Provisions for enforcement are weak, and the treaty contains no specific steps countries must take, such as accounting changes that would keep businesses from disguising bribes as commissions.
Countries should ratify the treaty quickly and treat it as a minimum, adding their own measures to improve it. But the treaty itself is a significant accomplishment. If seriously enforced, it will reduce the number of bribes and add moral weight to the developed world's exhortations to poor countries to stop accepting them.

HEADLINE: Starting on a 'Long Road,' North Korea Agrees to Talks With Seoul, U.S. and China

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
North Korea agreed today to begin peace talks in Geneva next month with the United States, South Korea and China to bring a formal end to the Korean War more than four decades after the fighting stopped.
A delegation from North Korea agreed to join the talks after dropping a demand that the agenda for the negotiations include the immediate withdrawal of the 37,000 American troops dug in along the demilitarized zone in South Korea. 
 The agreement was a breakthrough in the Clinton Administration's efforts to entice North Korea out of its diplomatic isolation and to calm tensions on the Korean Peninsula. It was reached after a year and a half of preliminary talks and a final day of wrangling at Columbia University in New York City.
Although President Clinton and his aides welcomed North Korea's decision, the agreement did not begin to address the profound divisions between two countries ripped apart, first by warfare, then by four decades of cold war machinations.
In addition, Administration officials said they expected the talks to proceed slowly, hampered not only by North Korea's suspicions but also by South Korea's financial turmoil and approaching presidential election.
"We know that this is the beginning of a long road," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today in a statement released after she arrived in Vancouver, British Columbia, for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
Mr. Clinton said he was pleased that the peace talks he had proposed along with President Kim Young Sam of South Korea in April 1996 would at last move forward, and noted the awaiting difficulties.
"There is a lot of hard work ahead," he said in a statement issued by the White House. "But this is an important first step, and the United States is prepared to be a full partner in helping the Korean people build a future of peace."
It was not clear why North Korea had dropped its demands. Officials in Washington speculated that the North's Government had felt a need to move forward or risk losing international aid to help ease hunger caused by floods and drought in recent years -- though the Clinton Administration has insisted that there is no link.
The talks will begin on Dec. 9 in Geneva, with senior delegations from the two Koreas and their principal supporters in the Korean War, which ended in 1953 with an armistice signed by the generals but not a formal peace treaty.
That armistice was only supposed to last a few months, but peace talks in 1954, also in Geneva, broke down and never resumed. For the last 43 years, the border between the Koreas has been one of the world's most heavily armed potential flash points.
While senior officials from the two countries have in the past signaled a willingness to improve relations and move toward eventual reunification, the talks next month will be the first in which the two enemies directly negotiate the terms of a formal peace treaty.
In a brief statement released in New York, the four delegations said the talks would focus on "the establishment of a peace regime on the Korea Peninsula and issues concerning tension reduction there."
A senior Administration official involved in the process said that in aiming at a peace treaty, the talks could lead both sides to try to reduce tensions. Those interim steps could, for example, include pulling forces from the demilitarized zone.
"As you move toward a formal peace treaty," the official said, "you have an opportunity to whittle away at those things that remain dangerous flash points."
In a series of preliminary meetings over the last year in New York, the North Koreans had indicated a willingness to attend more formal talks but repeatedly raised objections, dragging out the discussions.
In meetings held at Columbia in August and September, even the agenda for the formal talks proved a stumbling block. At those discussions, the United States and South Korea rebuffed North Korea's efforts to include the withdrawal of American troops and a separate peace treaty between the United States and the North, which Washington has long opposed.
Since the last round of talks in September broke off in frustration, North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, has consolidated and strengthened his position by assuming the titles held by his father, Kim Il Sung. One official said the North Korean delegation had not seemed prepared to make any decisions in the weeks before Kim Jong Il completed his ascension.
He is one of the world's most isolated leaders, never having traveled outside the Communist world. But he has indicated a willingness to improve relations with South Korea and the United States. In an essay published in August, he called it "an urgent requirement."

HEADLINE: Case No. 3: Asian Illness Threatening Vital Organs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
As Thailand's economy imploded during the summer, the International Monetary Fund rushed in to try to confine the problem to one of Asia's most promising -- but still small -- economic powers.
It failed. Investors quickly turned their attention to other Asian nations plagued with wildly overextended banks, corruption and collapsing financial institutions. After a two-month hiatus, Indonesia erupted, requiring a far, far larger bailout, one that included for the first time billions of dollars in backup financing from Washington. 
 But the Asian contagion still could not be stopped. And now the impending bailout of South Korea -- a rescue plan that could easily exceed the $48 billion, American-led bailout of Mexico in 1995 -- raises the stakes for the United States and for investors around the world.
Korea is a critical fire wall in the effort to keep the contagion from engulfing the world's second-largest economy: Japan. The fear is that Japan's own teetering financial system -- one of its largest securities houses, Yamaichi Securities, is reported to be on the verge of liquidation -- could not withstand the collapse of one of Japan's biggest trading partners.
"We simply don't know where this goes next, and can't predict it," one senior Clinton Administration official said today. And if Japan heads into a precipitous decline, it would be all but impossible to prevent the United States from catching the Asian flu. Exports to virtually all the Asian markets would slow, and the effects would be felt from Wall Street to the factory floors of companies that have thrived in America's export boom.
It is for all those reasons that inside the Treasury Department, where Asia's woes have become as large a preoccupation as Iraq is in the Pentagon, few doubt that South Korea's troubles raise the Asian financial crisis to a new level. South Korea is the world's 11th-largest economy, roughly the size of Indonesia's, Malaysia's and Thailand's rolled into one.
"Korea makes this an entirely different ball game," David Hale, the chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments, said recently as economists tried to take the measure of a Korean meltdown. He estimates it could take $50 billion to $100 billion in outside assistance to aid Korea; the I.M.F. considers $30 billion an accurate estimate, though officials concede the sum could total more than that.
One thing is clear: Whatever it takes, the Clinton Administration will push to make sure that the size of the bailout is large enough to persuade investors to return. Part of the reason is strategic: Korea is a major American ally, with 36,000 American troops stationed along the demilitarized zone, and no one wants it to appear weak at a time of tense negotiations with the North. In fact, for Seoul it was a cruel coincidence that international help came on the same day that North Korea agreed to begin talks over a formal ending of the Korean War -- a concession that on any other day would be viewed as a victory for the South.
But the talks with North Korea will drag on for months; insulating Japan from the worst of the "contagion effect" is a far more immediate problem.
The worst case runs something like this:
Even with the I.M.F.'s help, Korea's pain spreads quickly across the Sea of Japan, reaching banks that lent to Korean financial institutions and cutting off business to Japanese companies that are major suppliers to what was once a Japanese colony. The Japanese institutions, already teetering, are forced into bankruptcy. Japanese exports fall. And with the Korean won sharply devalued -- it has already dropped about 20 percent this year -- Japan feels compelled to let the yen slide as well, so that its cars and computer chips remain competitive with Korea's on overseas markets.
"This is the scenario that could bring the Nikkei to 12,000 or lower," an investment banker in Asia speculated recently about Japanese stocks. And that in turn, would lead to the failure of more Japanese banks, which have long been permitted by Japanese authorities to count their unrealized stock market gains as capital. With the Nikkei index that low, there would be no gains, and, thus, far less capital. The banks would have to merge or be permitted to liquidate, as Japan's 10th-largest bank, the Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, did earlier this week.
Japan's pain, of course, would quickly become America's. The trade deficit with Japan would soar, and Japanese imports, made less expensive by a declining yen, would displace American products. Political tensions would rise geometrically. This is why Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has been escalating his warnings to Japan that it must pull itself out of its trouble by stimulating domestic demand, rather than exporting more and more goods.
Of course, that is the worst case. If Japan moves quickly to confront its problems -- injecting taxpayer dollars into its banking system to ward off collapse, finding innovative ways to bolster the domestic economy -- it could ward off much of the contagion from Korea. American officials are busily trying to come up with reliable estimates of how much Japanese banks are exposed to Korea. The early answer, officials say, is that they are not as vulnerable in Korea as many first thought.
"This is a case where the Korean enmity toward Japan may actually pay off for the Japanese," an Asian diplomat in Washington said recently. "The Koreans don't especially like the Japanese, and so they often went out of their way to cut out Japanese banks and companies."
And the best-case outlook is that South Korea will respond to the medicine the way Mexico did. In the Mexican case, a huge rescue package was organized, totaling more than $52 billion. But in the end, the Mexicans only used about half of that amount. The rest served as a psychological prop to investors, who knew that the country had a cushion of loans to fall back on in case the problems took a turn for the worse. And because the cushion was there, private investment quickly came back.
It is, in short, the financial equivalent of the Powell Doctrine, which was Gen. Colin Powell's insistence on the need to use "decisive and overwhelming force." It is a doctrine well understood in Korea, a country that has been focused on military security for a lot longer than it has been focused on economic security.

HEADLINE: Killing Wasn't Much, Skinhead Says

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Red hair shaved down to his skull, Nathan Thill lounged in a black leather jacket and mulled over why he shot to death a West African man at a bus stop here.
Without a trace of emotion, Mr. Thill, a 19-year-old skinhead, told a television interviewer that he "walked through town with my gun in my waist, saw the black guy and thought he didn't belong where he was at." 
 "How easy it would be to take him out right there," he continued. "Didn't seem like much to me."
While Denverites watched the jailhouse interview on the noon news today, about 1,000 people, including Mayor Wellington Webb, gathered at the city's largest mosque for the funeral of the slain Mauritanian man, Oumar Dia.
"Oumar was one of millions of people who come to the United States to improve their circumstances, fascinated by the American dream," Mohamadou Cisse, a friend, said after coming home from the mosque. "For Oumar, his dream was shattered."
Eight years ago, Arab authorities expelled Mr. Dia from his native Mauritania because he was black, his friends said. On Tuesday night, after work as a housekeeper in a downtown Denver hotel, Mr. Dia, a 38-year-old father of three, crossed paths with Mr. Thill, a burly, former meatpacker who carried a .22-caliber pistol, Celtic tattoos on his forearms, and a visceral hatred of people different than him.
"It was not a stray bullet that killed Oumar," said Mr. Cisse, a Senegalese vendor, in the thick French spoken on the West Coast of Africa. "The murderer knew exactly what he wanted to do: to kill someone who was black."
The killing, the latest in a two-week string of skinhead incidents, has shocked Denver, a city that prides itself for racial tolerance, country good manners and a booming, high-tech economy. Only a block from the site of the race killing, newstands prominently display the current issue of Fortune magazine which ranks Denver as North America's "second most improved city for business" -- below New York and above Boston.
But this month's parade of skinheads going before judges or engaging the police in shootouts has awakened dormant racial fears.
"I am walking around downtown looking over my shoulder," said Monette McIver, a black woman who is a graduate student in education. "I am just wondering if this or that person is going to take me out because of the color of my skin."
Farther down the 16th Street pedestrian mall, Joseph Chinn, a black man who is studying criminal justice, said bluntly, "It makes me want to go out and buy a gun, O.K.?"
On Saturday, a rally to protest the attacks is to be held in Five Points, an historically black neighborhood.
A white woman who tried to help Mr. Dia was also shot by the skinhead. The woman, Jeannie VanVelkinburgh, a 36-year-old single mother of two boys, was shot in the back, the bullet severing her spine. Doctors say she will be paralyzed for life.
"I was trying to help someone who needed help and didn't have any idea I would end up in this situation," Ms. VanVelkinburgh, a nursing home aide, said from her hospital bed. "But I would do it again if I thought there was a chance that I could save someone's life."
The shootings followed a spate of skinhead incidents: a high-speed car chase that ended with the arrests of two skinheads and another car chase that ended with the killing of a police officer and the suicide of a skinhead. After the skinhead's death, police stations started receiving death threats. The word "pig" was scrawled on a police car and a pig carcass scrawled with the name of the dead officer was left at the officer's old police station.
Mayor Webb, who is preparing for a visit by President Clinton on Saturday, said the Denver police and the Federal authorities were trying to determine whether the incidents were linked to a single skinhead organization. "There is no conclusive evidence to suggest that it is an organized effort," the Mayor said.
Mr. Webb, who is black, argued that the city remained a tolerant place, adding, "Denver is a city where the African-American population is 12 percent, and where, in 1991, both candidates for mayor were African-American."
In adjacent Jefferson County, where the two car chases originated, John Stone, a county commissioner, threatened on Wednesday, "If we need to go to war with skinheads, we'll do that."
But some critics say that Colorado has become too complacent.
"The whole leadership of Colorado is caught off guard by this," said Carl Raschke, a University of Denver religious studies professor who studies local hate groups. "There has been this sugary image about Denver: that it happens everywhere else but here."
Indeed, a police intelligence unit credited with disbanding skinhead groups in the early 1990's was recently redirected to other projects.
"Law enforcement needs to come down hard on them again," said Bobbie Towbin, associate director of the Anti-Defamation League here. "Let them know that their activities are not welcome here."
Denver police have in custody two other skinheads. Jeremiah Barnum, 24, surrendered on Thursday after learning that he was wanted for questioning about the Dia killing. On Wednesday, the police arrested a skinhead who had stockpiled in his motel room bomb-making parts, ammunition and a Mac 90 semiautomatic assault rifle.
The police are searching for three more who may have been involved in the attempted ambush of a Denver policeman on Thursday morning.
While Denver awaits the outcome, residents ponder the words of Mr. Thill, a gas station clerk who saw himself as a soldier in a race war.
"In a war, anybody wearing the enemy's uniform is an enemy and should be taken out," he said of his victim, who was waiting for a bus. "I guess I was kind of thinking about him because he was black."

HEADLINE: Cigarette Tax Urged to Cover Health Costs

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
A state health panel recommended today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and lawmakers consider raising the cigarette tax to help New Jersey hospitals cover the cost of free medical treatment for the uninsured.
The 36-member advisory committee concluded that the state's $16 billion budget should finance the estimated $400 million annual cost of the free health care, known as the charity care hospital program. The committee is made up of representatives of hospitals, insurers, consumer and business groups and organized labor. 
 The panel's members unanimously endorsed an increase in the state cigarette tax to help replace money from the state's general funds, but they did not specify an amount.
The committee also offered mixed support for other options for the Governor and legislators. Those measures include raising a tax on hospitals, imposing an annual assessment of $18.83 on each person in the state who has health insurance, and continuing to depend on payroll taxes that are designated for the state's Unemployment Insurance Trust.
"The tobacco tax enjoyed universal support," said the State Health Commissioner, Len Fishman. "Everybody agreed that a tobacco tax made sense, at least as a partial solution to charity care." He said there was less support for the other revenue choices.
Although Mrs. Whitman recommended raising the cigarette tax by 25 cents a pack for the charity care program two years ago, she has not embraced the increase this time, her aides said. The Legislature refused to consider her proposal in 1995.
A 25 cent increase would raise the state tax to 65 cents a pack from 40 cents and increase the average cost of cigarettes to $2.60 a pack from $2.35.
A 25 cent increase would raise about $100 million in revenues annually and provide about one fourth of the money needed to cover the entire cost of the health care program.
"The cigarette tax is one of several options," said Michael P. Torpey, the Governor's chief of staff, "and we consider all of the options to be on the table. We just got the report, and it is going to be the basis of discussion with the legislative leadership of both parties."
Republican legislative leaders also said that all of the options were on the table and that they would seek support from Democrats before agreeing on a plan.
Jack Collins, the Assembly Speaker, has proposed raising the cigarette tax to help cover the cost of renovating and building new schools around the state. The Assembly approved his plan last year, but the tax increase failed in the State Senate, in part, because it did not receive support from Democrats. Democrats have been reluctant to support tax increases after voters punished them for supporting a $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990 under Gov. Jim Florio.
State Senator Richard J. Codey, a Democrat from West Orange who is expected to be the minority leader, said that he did not think there were enough votes in the Senate to support a cigarette tax increase. He also said that the other recommendations in the report, for a tax increase for hospitals and a new tax on insured people, were not viable solutions.
New Jersey is one of about a dozen states that require hospitals to provide free treatment to uninsured patients who are not eligible for Medicaid or Medicare and who are unable to pay their bills. There are no public hospitals in New Jersey.
The current financing system, which relies heavily on the state unemployment insurance compensation fund, expires on Dec. 31. Both organized labor and business groups oppose the state's practice of diverting money from the unemployment fund to pay for the program of free medical care.
Since 1993, the state has used more than $2.2 billion from the unemployment insurance fund to pay for the program.
Mrs. Whitman and lawmakers said they were committed to finding a permanent financing solution by the end of the year. Two years ago, the last time the financing system expired, hospitals across the state were forced to trim staff and postpone payments to vendors while the Governor and legislators took more than six months to agree on a plan.
Mr. Fishman, the state health commissioner, said that hospitals, particularly those in urban areas that provide the most free medical treatment, need a swift and permanent solution. "These hospitals are not in a position to survive a protracted debate over charity care financing," he said.
Gary Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, said his group was fiercely opposed to raising a tax on hospitals.

HEADLINE: Norman Topping, 89, Scientist Who Guided the Rise of U.S.C.

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Dr. Norman H. Topping, who helped to develop the typhus vaccine and went on to lead the University of Southern California's transformation into a prominent research center, died on Tuesday. He was 89.
Dr. Topping was president of the university from 1958 to 1970 and chancellor from 1971 to 1980. He then was chancellor emeritus until his death. 
 The university had been known as a locally oriented campus with strong sports teams, but under his leadership, it gained respect for its academic program, particularly in science, medicine and engineering.
Beginning in 1961, Dr. Topping led a drive to expand the university with a multimillion-dollar construction program and larger graduate program. Under his leadership, it was elected to the Association of American Universities, a body of 62 leading research universities in the United States and Canada.
"Norman Topping is the father of modern U.S.C.," said Steven B. Sample, the current president of the University of Southern California. "Until he came, we essentially had no research."
Dr. Topping began his career as a researcher with the United States Public Health Service in Bethesda, Md. In the 1930's, he helped develop a vaccine against typhus that was used by millions of Allied soldiers in World War II. The vaccine is still in use. Typhus, which causes a high fever and is primarily transmitted by body lice and fleas, has killed thousands of people during epidemics since ancient times.
Dr. Topping also helped develop the first effective treatment against Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a tick-borne disease native to the West.
In 1948, Dr. Topping was appointed associate director of the National Institute of Health and Assistant Surgeon General of the United States. From 1952 to 1958, he served as vice president for medical affairs at the University of Pennsylvania.
After retiring as U.S.C. president, he served as president of the Los Angeles Transit Authority. He was also appointed to a civic board overseeing urban redevelopment in Los Angeles, an issue he became interested as part of U.S.C.'s effort to improve the inner-city neighborhood around the campus.
Dr. Topping was born on Jan. 12, 1908, in Flat River, Mo. He graduated from high school in Los Angeles and earned both his bachelor's and medical degrees at U.S.C.
His wife, the former Helen Rummens, died in 1989. Dr. Topping is survived by a son, Brian B., of Baltimore; a daughter, Linda Topping Badgley of Isla de Culebra, P.R.; five grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Humbled By Debt Crisis, Seoul Seeks I.M.F. Aid
South Korea formally requested an emergency $20 billion aid package from the International Monetary Fund to help avert economic paralysis caused by rising debts and a loss of investor confidence. But the total amount of I.M.F. aid could surpass $60 billion, many economists say, which would make it the largest bailout by the lending agency ever.
 
 The decision to seek the aid made South Korea the latest victim of Asia's financial flu and marked a humiliating retreat for the country, one of the economic showcases of the late 20th century, rising from poverty and war to become the world's 11th-largest economy. Although terms of the I.M.F. aid have yet to be worked out, they will probably impose harsh restraints on South Koreans. Page A1.
 
Blue-Chip Stocks Rally
Despite concerns over Asian's financial troubles, stock markets around the world strengthened. In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.46 points to close at 7,881.07, pushing the blue-chip index up 4.1 percent on the week -- its best weekly gain in five months. But the broader market was weaker, as technology issues retreated after strong gains on Thursday. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, fell 5.81 points, to 1,620.75. D14.
 
G.M. to Close a Plant in Flint
General Motors plans to close its 2,900-employee Buick City car factory, above, in Flint, Mich. The closing is another setback for Flint, the troubled city chronicled in the documentary "Roger and Me." The closing is also the latest sign that auto makers expect Americans to continue shifting from cars to sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups. After the closing, in 1999, G.M.'s vehicle production in Flint will be limited to pickup trucks and commercial trucks. D4.
 
Clinton Clears F.D.A. Overhaul
President Clinton signed into law a major overhaul in the Food and Drug Administration intended to quicken approval of drugs and medical devices. But the President gave no indication of when he would choose someone to replace Dr. David A. Kessler, who left as commissioner of the regulatory agency nine months ago. A13.
 
TRW in $942 Million Deal
TRW plans to acquire BDM International for $29.50 a share in cash, or about $942 million. TRW said the acquisition would allow it to broaden its scope into civil, commercial and international markets. D3.
 
Judge Faults Dow Corning Plan
Criticizing what he called numerous legal flaws in Dow Corning's proposals for disposing of breast implant damage claims, a bankruptcy judge ruled it would be a "monumental waste of time" for claimants and other creditors to vote on a reorganization plan containing the proposals. D2.
 
Gerstner Staying At I.B.M.
Louis V. Gerstner Jr. agreed to extend his contract as chief executive of I.B.M. at least until his 60th birthday in March 2002, saying his turnaround work at the computer company is incomplete. In return, I.B.M. said Mr. Gerstner's compensation would include two million options for I.B.M. stock, which has increased fivefold since he joined the company in 1993. D3. .
 
Copper Prices Tumble
Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday on growing concerns that the financial crisis in Asia -- the world's largest copper-consuming region -- will hurt demand at a time when production is rising. D2.
 
Teamsters' Election Delayed
A Federal judge ordered a 45-day delay in the teamsters' election to give investigators more time to look into accusations that the leading candidate, James P. Hoffa, received improper campaign contributions in the previous election. Ballots were to have been mailed out beginning in February. A7.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Fear of Lower Asian Demand Hurts Copper

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Copper prices tumbled yesterday on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange as concern grew that Asia's financial crisis would sharply depress demand.
Problems in Asia, the world's largest copper-consuming region, come as mining companies are increasing their output. Copper production exceeded demand by 200,000 metric tons in the first eight months of the year and surpluses will extend into 1998, according to the International Copper Study Group. Copper for December delivery fell 0.9 cent, or 1.1 percent, to 84 cents a pound, the lowest price since Jan. 13, 1994. 
 Orange juice prices jumped 4 percent as the second cold snap of the season was forecast for Florida. Though no damaging frost is expected, the lower temperatures brought expectations that colder weather during the main frost season in Florida, beginning in mid-December, could harm this year's crop. Orange juice for January delivery rose 3.1 cents, to 81.65 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: Dissident's Advice to Clinton: Only Pressure Sways Beijing

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

 BODY:
Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent democracy advocate, said in an interview in New York yesterday that he would tell President Clinton that only continued pressure from the West could help free more Chinese political prisoners. He said he intended to use his time in exile to act as a campaigner for human rights.
"This will be the very first issue that we discuss," said Mr. Wei, who is expected to meet Mr. Clinton later this month or early in December. "If you want to have a dialogue with a Communist Government, you have to use pressure, otherwise they will never talk with you." Excerpts, page A5. 
 Still weakened by his 16 years of imprisonment, Mr. Wei nonetheless appeared to be in fairly good health. Reports that he was suffering from life-threatening illnesses appear now to have been part of a strategy by family members and rights groups to press Beijing's Government to release him on medical parole, as it did last weekend.
Mr. Wei's assertions that he intends to become a strong public advocate for improvements in China's human rights situation could complicate relations between Washington and Beijing.
Mr. Wei's message may prove controversial to the Clinton Administration, which won praise yesterday from rights organizations for pressing Mr. Wei's case in private meetings with Chinese leaders in the last three years. Mr. Clinton has stepped back from the campaign of trade pressure on China that he advocated at the outset of his Administration, arguing that "engagement," not confrontation, was more likely to produce improved rights conditions in China.
Speaking at a news conference in New York and in an interview afterward, Mr. Wei said he saw himself becoming an evangelist for greater freedom and democratic reform in China using the Voice of America, Radio Free Asia and other news media that would enable him to build an audience among the Chinese.
Many people in China do not recognize his name because it is banned from being mentioned by state-run news outlets and because he has been imprisoned almost continuously since March 1979.
"Most of the Chinese people would very much like to hear other voices," he said. "Otherwise they would not know that they have choices. That is why this is very important."
He quarreled good-naturedly in the interview at being labeled a dissident. "Most of the Chinese people all want democracy," he asserted. "And the people who are different are just this little group of ruling elites of the Chinese Communist Party, so they are really the dissidents."
In the news conference, he exhorted China's democracy forces, saying, "You should not pay attention to the immediate low tide, because after a low tide there is always a high tide that follows."
The State Department earlier this year reported that political dissent in China had effectively been completely stifled through a campaign of repressive measures including jailings and forced exiles.
Mr. Wei's entrance this morning into a large hall at the New York Public Library packed by waiting reporters and well-wishers was greeted by applause and cheers. The 47-year-old activist wore a brown corduroy jacket and a red plaid shirt, his uneven prison crew cut looking in need of a trim.
In an opening statement, Mr. Wei thanked the "people and governments around the world that have made enormous efforts to press the Chinese Government for the release of political prisoners" and admonished those who already live in freedom in the world not to become complacent about those who do not.
"Democracy and freedom are among the loftiest ideals of humanity, and they are the most sacred rights of mankind," he said. "Those who already enjoy democracy, liberty and human rights, in particular, should not allow their own personal happiness to numb them into forgetting the many others who are still struggling against tyranny, slavery and poverty, and all of those who are suffering from unimaginable forms of oppression, exploitation and massacres."
Though he evaded questions during the news conference about what message he would deliver to Mr. Clinton, during the interview afterward, Mr. Wei was emphatic that he would seek continued pressure from Washington and other Western capitals for improvement of rights conditions in China and the release of prisoners.
The only reason Chinese leaders have ever engaged in dialogue over the country's internal human rights conditions has been pressure from the United States and other countries whose markets have become important export destinations for Chinese goods and a source of technology for China's modernization.
Mr. Wei said he would like to visit all parts of the United States in the coming months. While in New York, he has been assigned a New York police detective as a bodyguard. Columbia University and the University of California at Berkeley have offered him office space and living quarters to pursue academic studies and pro-democracy work.
His immediate plans are to write a book about the beatings, abuse and psychological pressure that the Chinese prison authorities used to try to break him and, ultimately, to force him into exile by refusing him further medical treatment in prison.
Among the techniques were shutting off heat in his cell, using other inmates to torment or beat him and housing him in a cell where lights were left on 24 hours a day as a way of denying him sleep.
Mr. Wei was released from Jidong Prison, about 150 miles southeast of Beijing. "When I was a prisoner there in 1989, they used to brag that they were the largest salt factory in Asia, exporting to Japan and many other countries. But when I returned in 1993, I asked them if they were still exporting salt to other countries, and they denied it."
Mr. Wei indicated that international criticism of China's use of prison labor for exported products had caused the prison authorities to change their story.
He said that if he becomes active as an opposition figure in the United States, he is concerned that the Communist authorities might retaliate against members of his family left behind in China.
"I am concerned about their security," he said at the news conference. "They have suffered a lot. But there are hundreds of millions of Chinese who have been oppressed, and I am concerned about them equally."
Beijing's leaders are apparently calculating that with Mr. Wei out of the country, his threat to rekindle a democracy movement has been neutralized and his effectiveness as a political troublemaker will be minimized by his distance from China.
But rights groups based in the United States, with Mr. Wei's cooperation, already appear to be developing a strategy to give him a new voice in China, something he has scarcely had since 1978-79, when he pasted his pro-democracy essays on a stretch of wall in central Beijing that became known as the Democracy Wall.
Among Mr. Wei's first interviews yesterday were with correspondents for the Chinese-language service of the Voice of America, Radio Free Asia and a major Chinese daily newspaper in Hong Kong. He was also interviewed by The New York Times.
For a man who has spent long years in solitary confinement and watched as more than a dozen teeth dropped out from years of malnutrition because of a poor prison diet, Mr. Wei seemed to enjoy parrying the questions of a New York news conference.
Asked about his views on Taiwan and Tibet, where there are strong independence movements with support in the United States, Mr. Wei was careful not to challenge China's claims of sovereignty over both territories.
"On Tibet," he said, "this is a rather complex question. I don't agree with the Government's policy of oppressing and killing Tibetans and carrying out the destruction of Tibetan culture, but as to how to resolve this issue, I think that calm Chinese and Tibetans should sit down and figure out a good solution."
Asked to tell the greatest lesson he learned from his 16 years of imprisonment for the views he expressed during the Democracy Wall period, Mr. Wei said: "I have learned many things in prison, but the most important thing is that for a human being, there is no difficulty that cannot be overcome. You just have to rely on yourself and you can get through anything."
The man most responsible for Mr. Wei's jailing was Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader who emerged in the years after the death of Mao in 1976 and opened an era of economic reform that is turning the nation of 1.2 billion into an Asian powerhouse.
Mr. Wei's trenchant essays on Democracy Wall pointedly criticized Deng for failing to carry through with his promises of democracy as part of the program for China's modernization. When Mr. Wei called Deng a dictator in early 1979, he was arrested and Democracy Wall was torn down.
Mr. Wei said he sent a letter of condolence to Deng's family when the 92-year-old leader died in February.
"If he could have expanded reform to the political arena," Mr. Wei said, "then -- even if he had abused me even worse than he has -- I still would not hate him."
Mr. Wei took questions for a little more than 40 minutes at the library hall and then asked politely that he be excused because he was feeling tired and dizzy.

With him was his sister, Wei Shanshan, and Liu Qing, chairman of Human Rights in China. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)(pg. A5)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Seoul Plans to Ask the I.M.F. For a Minimum of $20 Billion

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 21

 BODY:
In a remarkable humiliation for one of the most glittering economic success stories of the late 20th century, South Korea announced tonight that to avert a financial crisis it would seek a bailout from the International Monetary Fund.
The amount will be negotiated in coming days, but many economists say the package of assistance will have to be enormous, perhaps exceeding $60 billion. 
 That would easily surpass the previous record of $48 billion in I.M.F. aid committed to Mexico nearly three years ago. Mexico ultimately used about half of that amount.
The vulnerability of Japan in particular to the South Korean mess has become a major preoccupation for American monetary officials, who are now viewing Asia's growing economic crisis as a more urgent threat to United States interests because previous I.M.F. efforts to contain it have failed. Analysis, page D1.
Finance Minister Lim Chang Yuel told a late-night news conference that South Korea would seek $20 billion in I.M.F. loans, plus an additional open line of credit in case that amount was insufficient. Mr. Lim also said he expected the United States and Japan, which had rebuffed requests in recent days to provide direct aid to South Korea, to participate in an I.M.F.-led rescue.
With Mr. Lim's bleak announcement, South Korea became the latest in a string of Asian nations to redefine the term "Asian miracle." Once it referred to the stunning march of East Asia from mud huts to skyscrapers in a single generation, but now it seems more a reminder of how far and how quickly these countries' economies and currencies and stock markets have tumbled.
In particular, the transformation of South Korea from industrial giant to international pauper suggests that the Asian financial flu that began in Thailand in the summer and spread throughout Southeast Asia has now begun to spread in Northeast Asia. South Korea's plummeting currency and mounting bad debts may reverberate on to America and the West.
It was just a week ago that South Korea called the idea of I.M.F. aid unthinkable. The Government agonized over the choices, changing its mind several times before making the final decision tonight.
Mr. Lim described South Korea's problems as a "temporary funding shortage" but said international help was the best solution.
"To overcome the nation's financial and currency crises, we've decided to request emergency funding from the I.M.F.," he declared.
"Although Korea's fundamental macro-economic conditions are relatively healthy, with rising exports, a string of corporate bankruptcies have decreased Korea's creditworthiness and produced calls for debt repayments," Mr. Lim said. He said of the decision to turn to the I.M.F.: "The Korean Government hopes that this measure will bear fruit."
The money is likely to be used primarily to help distressed banks repay debts they owe, giving them a chance to rework an estimated $50 billion in unrepaid loans owed to them. Reversing the process of defaults is critical to restoring confidence, which will help ease the crisis further by encouraging the return of foreign investors who have been abandoning South Korea.
But the I.M.F. aid will undoubtedly come at a painful price for South Korea by making the rules for borrowing money more stringent. That could have the immediate impact of increasing interest rates and forcing some companies out of business and raising unemployment for South Koreans, who until recently had barely understood what a layoff meant.
An I.M.F. delegation group will visit Seoul next week to negotiate the exact size and terms of the rescue, Mr. Lim said, and the money will start arriving in three to four weeks.
 In a nationally broadcast speech Saturday about the decision, President Kim Young Sam told South Koreans: "As the head of national affairs, I am truly sorry. Our economy has grown relatively quickly and smoothly, but such rapid development itself has given birth to structural problems." He said the country must endure "bone-carving pain."
Rumors about the prospect that Seoul would turn to the I.M.F. gave a strong lift to Korea's financial markets today. Stocks rose 3.6 percent and the currency, which had plunged for the previous four days, rose sharply as well.
The news also helped strengthen most other financial markets on optimism that South Korean investments need not be written off.
 In abbreviated trading on Saturday, South Korean stocks retreated again, falling 4 percent.
South Korea suffers from what is known as a liquidity crisis, or a lack of money flowing through the economy, which is causing defaults on corporate loans like falling dominos.
It descended to this point partly because of reckless lending by South Korean banks -- particularly in other developing markets not only elsewhere in Asia but also in Latin America and Eastern Europe. Billions of dollars in unrepaid loans have forced these banks to borrow from foreign banks that have grown increasingly unwilling to lend more.
In addition, many of the giant South Korean industrial conglomerates like Kia Motors, Hanbo Group and Sammi Group that helped build the country have fallen, the victims of too much debt.
The decline in lender and investor confidence in South Korea has been reflected in the diminished value of the won, South Korea's currency, which has fallen by 20 percent against the dollar this year. That has made it even more expensive for South Korea to repay loans.
Even so, South Korea's economy is still growing at an annual rate of more than 6 percent, considerably faster than the American economy. That is partly because the diminished value of the won has helped the country increase its exports, from computer chips to Hyundai Motor sedans. South Korea also has underlying strengths like a passion for education and a reputation for a diligent labor force.
In the long run, some economists suggest, I.M.F.-imposed changes to resolve the bad debts and modernize the banking system may be a boon for South Korea. In particular, they may lead to the establishment of an efficient capital market and banking system, essential if the two Koreas reunified and the South had to rebuild the impoverished North.
The Korean Government had been loath to turn to the I.M.F., partly because of the stringent conditions the I.M.F. will undoubtedly set, breaching what some South Koreans describe as their economic sovereignty. Indeed, the nation seemed to collectively lament as word of the bailout spread today, bracing for a period of austerity.
In a prime-time evening news commentary, the MBC television network declared, "Leaving behind our glorious economic development, our country must suffer the humiliation of going bankrupt."
Moreover, the I.M.F. rescue is a stinging humiliation for President Kim, who had been reluctant to admit economic failure before his New Korea Party faces presidential elections on Dec. 18.
Mr. Kim is barred by law from running again, but the ruling-party candidate, Lee Hoi Chang, is already lagging far behind in the polls. The beneficiary from the bailout may be the longtime opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, who is already leading in the polls by a healthy margin. The business establishment has long been contemptuous of Kim Dae Jung's command of economics, but these days it is equally dismissive of the ruling party's economic management.
President Kim and Mr. Lim met tonight with the presidential candidates to discuss the decision to turn to the I.M.F. Afterward, the Government said that it had the support and understanding of all the candidates. Invariably South Korea's economic difficulties also have a security dimension, because North Korea has more than a million troops next door and by some accounts is always sniffing for weakness and an opportunity for military adventure.
In addition, South Korea and North Korea, which technically remain at war, are now preparing for landmark peace talks that are supposed to reach a lasting peace to replace the armistice that suspended fighting in the Korean War. South Korea would prefer to enter the negotiations at a time when it feels more secure, but instead North Korea is relishing the chance to offer its own analyses of South Korea's problems.
"There is no way of saving the defective economy that has contradictory structure and cancer of the colonial dependent economy," the official North Korean press agency declared today.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Finance Minister Lim Chang Yuel announcing South Korea's decision to ask the I.M.F. for assistance. Mr. Lim said Seoul would seek $20 billion, but some economists estimated that the amount would be much higher. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. D2)

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1608 words

HEADLINE: Health-Maintenance Groups Are Seen Entering a Troublesome New Phase

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City is shutting down 11 of its health maintenance organization's 22 clinics, laying off 30 of its 65 primary-care doctors and cutting the salaries of the rest.
Humana has dismissed 4 pediatricians and 2 ophthalmologists from among the 89 salaried doctors at its 7 clinics here. St. Luke's Hospital, one of Kansas City's biggest, says that the incomes of its cardiovascular surgeons will drop 40 percent to 50 percent next year. 
 Such are the latest throes of the revolution in American health care. The managed-care industry, once widely seen as a panacea for the nation's health care woes, is now entering a troublesome new phase: struggling with the consequences of its extraordinary expansion this decade, forced in many cases to raise premiums, lay off doctors and close clinics.
In Kansas City, as in most of the rest of the country, big insurance companies like Aetna, the Cigna Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and big health maintenance organizations like Kaiser Permanente, United Healthcare and Humana, find themselves up against two hard-to-reconcile phenomena: a seething consumer and political backlash over delays and denial of care on one hand and their own financial reversals and excess capacity on the other.
Up to now, patients in managed-care plans have felt little pain in strict economic terms. Insurers and managed-care companies held the line on premiums by chopping out the excesses and by swallowing the losses they incurred in scrambling for subscribers and a big share of the market. Lately, however, the industry's losses and plunging profits have begun to sting.
 
Sudden Changes In Health Care System
No city quite mirrors all the turbulence in health care. The wholesale shift to managed care started later in the two Kansas Cities, with a population of 1.7 million straddling the Missouri-Kansas state line, than in Boston, Los Angeles, Minneapolis or Rochester. But in few places is the competition fiercer than here, where any new national health system is most likely to be defined. The city's economy and demographic mix, like its site, is mainstream American, and by moving relatively late toward managed care, Kansas City can pick among the features that have survived the tests of other markets.
As in the rest of the country, the Kansas City area long relied for its health care on the entrenched fee-for-service system, in which consumers sought care from whatever doctor they wished and the doctors prescribed whatever they wanted. The system was built upon Blue Cross and Blue Shield, then and still the area's leading insurer, as well as self-employed doctors and 24 hospitals, most of them affiliated with a religion, like Baptist, Menorah, Bethany, Trinity Lutheran and St. Luke's.
But in just three years, the onset of managed care has shattered those traditional arrangements. Half the city's doctors work for somebody else, often a hospital. Many hospitals, local insurers and managed-care companies have merged and affiliated into two large health-care networks, one dominated by St. Luke's, the other by Health Midwest and Blue Cross. Outsiders, like Kaiser, Humana, Columbia HCA, United Healthcare, Cigna, Prudential and Aetna have moved in, too, often to ally with the members of the indigenous groups and often, too, to compete with them.
"I guess I wouldn't call it mayhem here," said Joe Tilghman, regional administrator for the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which writes Medicare checks for the elderly and Medicaid checks for the poor. "There's certainly some confusion, some trepidation and anxiety because the changes are taking place so fast. That's pretty much true all over the country."
Nationwide, premium increases of at least 5 percent next year have already been negotiated for most participants in health care groups.
To avoid the political firestorm and flight of customers that big premium increases could ignite, and to survive in a rapidly changing environment, health care companies are groping for a magical new mix of good care and cost-efficient care.
 
New Plans and Choices Take Their Toll
New approaches to care are emerging, each with new buzz words. Nationwide, consumers have joined the debate with calls to Congress and state legislatures like Missouri's for rights of "open access" to doctors so they can bypass health care organizations' gatekeepers, who control cost by controlling access to specialists, and for a "bill of rights" to appeal delays and denials of care to outside arbitrators.
Insurers, managed-care companies and groups of doctors are combining into seamless "integrated delivery systems" that offer, through a single entity, conception-to-grave care and devising cost-efficient methods of "disease management" to monitor chronically ill patients to keep them healthy longer and out of emergency rooms.
"What you've seen is an explosion of health plans, each offering a little different choice, a different twist," said Tom Bowser, executive vice president of the Blue Cross organization here. "What's happening is that these plans are having to compete more on quality, a consumer's perception of good physician care, good hospital services and choices within health plans."
More choice and quality, Mr. Bowser said, spells higher cost and thus higher premiums.
Here, as elsewhere in the country, companies arrested the rise in health care costs in part by disregarding profits in a battle for big enough pools of subscribers to spread the risk among the sick and the well and to assure profits later.
"Some of the flat pricing was artificially constructed in order to gain market share," Mr. Bowser said.
In wringing waste from the system, companies also curbed consumers' choices of care, in part by halting unnecessary surgery, excessive testing and long stays in hospitals. They squeezed doctors' fees and salaries and per-patient capitation rates, often $11 or $12 a month per subscriber.
Jeffrey O. Ellis, the head health care lawyer at the Kansas City firm of Lathrop & Gage, said companies had gone too far.
"You see cuts in compensation without a sense of what the costs should be," Mr. Ellis said. "A lot of primary-care doctors in this market are being hurt very badly. It's just an irrational cut, cut, cut."
 
Good Fortune Comes To Biggest Employer
The industry's No. 1 prize here is the Sprint Corporation, the telecommunications company with 10,000 local workers to insure. Sprint is the largest private-sector employer in the two cities.
"It's a very competitive world," said Randall T. Parker, director of corporate benefits planning and strategy at Sprint. With so many contenders for the Sprint work force, the company can play one against another in bargaining for services and low premiums.
With so much bargaining clout, Sprint can hold its employees' premium increases below the 4 percent to 9 percent that the Blue Cross group is negotiating with its customers here.
But Sprint's influence and its employees' good fortune in paying stable premiums could soon evaporate. Nothing protects even such favored employers from the laws of the marketplace. As the competition among the many health plans drives out the weak, the rich variety of plans from which Sprint can choose could shrink and leave just two or three, each with enough muscle to stand up to the company.
Along with renewed pressure to raise premiums is very likely to come reductions in services.
By all accounts, the Kansas City metropolitan area has 50 percent to 60 percent more hospital beds than it needs. Yet hospitals keep opening new outposts in affluent suburbs because if they do not, some other hospital will get the patients.
The same goes for doctors.
"In general we have probably twice as many physicians as we need," said Kathryn A. Paul, president of the Rocky Mountain Division of Kaiser Permanente.
The surplus, Ms. Paul said, generates excess demand, with underemployed doctors hustling for patients.
Doctors here say that they were surprised by the onset of managed care. When it began, they became salaried workers, or they negotiated cuts in their fees and control over their services so they could keep patients who had been in managed-care plans.
Dr. Richard Hellman, an endocrinologist and diabetes specialist, said that he sometimes lost patients because they enrolled in a managed-care organization to which he did not belong. The patients will show him the doctors on the organization's list, Dr. Hellman said, and ask him to recommend one.
Initially, he said, he would call the doctor first to say he was referring the patient. But no longer.
"They'd call and say, 'Rich, please don't send those patients to me. I only get $11 a month for them,' " Dr. Hellman said.
Doctors acknowledge that in view of incomes that start at more than $100,000 a year, they cannot elicit much sympathy.
"But what most galls physicians," Dr. Hellman said, "is not being allowed to do what they think is best in terms of care. It causes much more anger than being told you'll have to take a pay cut."
The Missouri Insurance Commissioner, Jay Angoff, said, "Kansas City can handle some more consolidation."
But it could also go too far. If the few survivors shrink to one or two, Mr. Angoff said, they could exert monopolist powers, cutting corners on care and raising premiums with abandon. So the Government will have to be watchful, he said. "If the antitrust agencies are vigilant," he said, "and the consumer protection agencies are vigilant, I think we can have a pretty good system."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "What you've seen is an explosion of health plans," said Tom Bowser, above, an official with the Blue Cross organization in Kansas City, Mo. (Craig Sands for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Russia Presses U.N. To Ease Sanctions on Iraq
Russia asked the governing board of the United Nations commission in charge of disarming Iraq to declare Baghdad free of nuclear weapons and near compliance on prohibited missiles, as a first step to easing sanctions. A1 

United Nations arms inspectors returned to Iraq to search for a supposed arsenal of biological and chemical weapons, including up to 25 Scud missiles, whose existence has been suggested by six and a half years of inspections and reconnaissance photographs. A6
 
Dissident Presses China
Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent democracy campaigner and, until last week, political prisoner, said in an interview that he will ask President Clinton to keep up the pressure on China's Communist Party rulers to free thousands of political detainees still being held. A1
 
North Korea Agrees to Talks
A delegation from North Korea has agreed to join talks in Geneva next month with the United States, South Korea and China that may bring the Korean War to a formal end, more than four decades after the fighting stopped. The North Koreans dropped their demand that the agenda for the talks include the immediate withdrawal of the 37,000 American troops stationed along the demilitarized zone in South Korea. A5
 
Clinton Urges Mideast Talks
President Clinton received a humanitarian award from Leah Rabin, the widow of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, who was assassinated two years ago for favoring the peace process with the Palestinians. Mr. Clinton warned Israelis and Palestinians that the bonds of trust were eroding and urged them to make haste to restart peace talks, which have withered in recent months. A6
 
Social Tension Mounts in Iran
Police in Iran used tear gas to disperse a crowd in the holy city of Qum, 75 miles south of Teheran, that had attacked a religious school where the director had criticized the supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khameni. The incident was the latest in a series of tense confrontations between forces wanting to liberalize Iranian society and others who want to keep it strictly conservative, a friction which has come increasingly into the open since the election of a relatively moderate cleric, Mohammed Khatami, as president in May. A3
 
Key Promise Given in Somalia
Somali factions promised not to attack aid workers delivering help to flood victims. Factions have kidnapped and killed aid workers in the past, leading Agostino Paganini, director of Unicef's Somalia operations, to seek such assurances. Relief agencies estimate that 2,000 Somalis have drowned and 220,000 have been forced from their homes since heavy rains began a month ago. About 80 percent of the lower region of the Juba River has flooded. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A7-13, 16
 
Reno Urged to Reject Independent Prosecutor
In a memo to Attorney General Janet Reno, Justice Department officials have urged her to reject an independent prosecutor to investigate fund-raising telephone calls made by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, law enforcement officials said. A1
 
Teamster Election Postponed
A Federal judge ordered a 45-day delay in this winter's teamsters' election to give investigators more time to look into accusations that the leading candidate, James P. Hoffa, son of the legendary union leader, received improper campaign contributions in the previous election. A7
 
Clinton Signs F.D.A. Overhaul
President Clinton signed into law a major overhaul for the Food and Drug Administration, saying the agency would earn "a gold medal for leading the way into the future," but he offered no indication of when he would choose someone to lead the agency on that path. A10
 
Mother Holds a Septuplet
The mother of the first septuplets born alive in the United States was able to hold one of her babies, shortly after doctors decided the boy was doing so well that he could breathe on his own, without the help of machines. Bobbi McCaughey, looking frail and a bit nervous in a royal blue bathrobe, also made her first public appearance since the babies were born on Wednesday. A7
 
Sun Satellite Malfunctions
The space shuttle Columbia's astronauts struggled in vain to capture a satellite after the craft malfunctioned moments after its release. Within an hour, NASA had lost any chance of conducting solar observations with the satellite, now or later in the mission. The space agency still wants the satellite back for reuse on a later flight, and considered another attempt to recapture it. A12
 
Arlington Names Released
Army Secretary Togo D. West Jr. released the names of 69 individuals who were given special permission to be buried at Arlington Cemetery during the Clinton Administration, in an effort to halt Republican charges that cemetery plots were traded for campaign contributions. A13
 
Court Rules on Foster Notes
A Federal appeals court declined to reconsider an earlier ruling that the notes of one of Vincent W. Foster Jr.'s last conversations with his lawyers could be surrendered to the Whitewater independent counsel because they are not absolutely protected by the lawyer-client privilege. A9
 
Mental Evidence Considered
The judge at the trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski indicated that he would permit the defense to present evidence that the man accused of being the Unabomber is mentally ill, but he indicated he might not permit testimony of defense psychiatrists who examined Mr. Kaczynski. A16
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5
 
Affirmative Action Case In New Jersey Is Settled
An affirmative action case that began at a New Jersey high school and was evolving into a potentially major Supreme Court test of the role of race in the workplace ended abruptly when the parties announced an unusual financial settlement. A coalition of leading civil rights groups, not directly involved in the case but increasingly concerned that a broadly worded Supreme Court decision could prove disastrous for affirmative action, agreed to provide the major share of a $433,500 settlement that the Piscataway Township Board of Education will pay to Sharon Taxman, a white teacher whom the school board dismissed to preserve a black teacher's job. A1
 
Identity of Suspect a Mystery
Investigators pieced together most of a brief and brutal rampage across New Jersey that left one police officer dead, another wounded and the lone suspect dead, but the two central questions of the case -- the identity of the assailant and his motive for killing an officer at random -- remained a mystery. A1

Bill Guerin signed a multi-year contract with the New Jersey Devils, ending his season-long holdout, and allaying fears of a boycott among hockey players already named to the United States Olympic team, many of whom are insisting that the right wing join them at the Winter Games in Japan next year. HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Jobless Rate Declined To 5.2% in October

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The state's unemployment rate dipped to 5.2 percent in October, tying a seven-year low for the third time this year, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.
The rate, down from 5.4 percent in September, matches unemployment levels for April and August, and has not been lower since August 1990, when it hit 5.1 percent, said Kevin Smith, a department spokesman. 
 A record 65,000 jobs were created in October, the second straight record increase, Mr. Smith said.
