HEADLINE: On Language;
The Non-Crash

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
Like the conservative New Year's Eve celebrator who wanted to purchase a noisemaker that wasn't too loud, headline writers were recently faced with a challenge: how to deal with a precipitous ("steep," not precipitate, "abrupt, rash, headlong") decline in the stock market without encouraging a panic. (Come to think of it, precipitate would be accurate, too, if you wanted to describe the behavior of the professional investors rather than the graph showing stock movement. Celebrator is New York Times style for celebrant.)
The onomatopoeic crash was a word that Wall Street Journal editorialists were unafraid to use, but the front page of that publication chose a verb less evocative of 1929: "Stocks Plummet 7 Percent." (That verb was formed in this century from the noun plummet, a weight used to sound, or fathom, the depth of water; in Shakespeare's "Tempest," Prospero says, "Deeper than did ever plummet sound/I'll drown my book," a sentiment quoted by excessively modest authors.) 
 "Massive Sell-Off" was the choice of USA Today. The adjective massive lent urgency to the stock-market term sell-off, a noun first reported in 1937 by the Baltimore Sun and still specialized enough to retain its hyphen in most citations. The New York Times disagrees; the bank, or infixed subhead, of its Hong Kong article read, "The Hang Seng sets the scene for a global selloff," unhyphenated. USA Today also used the noun rout (military origin) and the verb dived (from swimming, with that past tense preferred to dove). Its columnist, Walter Shapiro, later used a less-alarmist word picture: "Watching the Dow snow-plow down the mountain."
Plunge (from a 1380 use about baptism by immersion) got a nice play in the Baltimore Sun (but if I first reported the use of sell-off, I'd stick with it proudly). In Newsweek, C. K. Binswanger and Lucy Howard noted the panic prevention in newspapers: drop (International Herald Tribune), tailspin (Jiji Press Ticker of Tokyo), tumble (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel) and tremble (Montreal Gazette).
In the synonymy of the bears, decline, sag, sink and slump are mildest; drop, more sudden; tumble, not shocking; dive and plunge, precipitous; plummet, precipitate; sell-off, technical; correction, interpretive or euphemistic; free fall, alarming; collapse, sudden and steep, and crash, better lock that window.
Television journalists, who could immediately affect the market with their demeanor, were careful; NBC called it "the Big Drop" and Fox chose "Blue Monday."
Now we are into the color of the day. Oct. 19, 1987, was called Black Monday on the analogy of Black Thursday of Oct. 24, 1929, and Black Tuesday of Oct. 29, 1929. These were antedated by Black Friday of Sept. 24, 1869, when Jay Gould drove brokers into bankruptcy with his attempted corner of the gold market. It all began with Blue Monday in the Middle Ages, supposedly the first Monday before Lent, when revelers felt hung over from pre-Lenten flings; later, it became the day to feel depressed about returning to work after a weekend. Several commentators dubbed last month's sell-off (in retrospect, that seems the best word, but who knew at the time?) to have happened on a less-than-calamitous day: Gray Monday.
I confess to having used the euphemistic correction two months before October's financial fibrillation. My technical analysis went, "You're going to see a correction one of these days that will curl your hair." This was an obscure allusion to a figure of speech that sent a shiver through the financial markets 40 years ago. In a 1957 news conference (in those days called a press conference), Eisenhower's Treasury Secretary, a former steel man named George Magoffin Humphrey, was asked if he saw any hope of cutting defense spending in the coming years. He replied that such spending was "a terrific tax take we are taking out of this country," and that if we did not reduce defense expenditures, "over a long period of time, I will predict that you will have a depression that will curl your hair."
I enjoy making arcane allusions like that; a few in the codger crowd catch them. One such is Herbert Stein, who once noted how a fellow economist, Sol Fabricant, described a period of less-than-robust expansion by calling it a growth recession. Stein satirized this at the time with an imaginary conversation:
Stein: That's a handsome dog you have there, Sol.
Fabricant: That's not a dog. It's a horse.
Stein: But Sol, it's so small.
Fabricant: It's a growth horse.
Since that time, just as brokers have eschewed the word crash, economists have avoided the word recession, especially those in which hair is curled to depression levels. In 1982, I asked a couple of economists how they would define depression. Alan Greenspan said, "A depression is either a 12 percent unemployment rate for nine months or more, or a 15 percent unemployment rate for three to nine months." Prof. Alfred Kahn of Cornell defined it as unemployment above 10 percent with two quarters of consecutive decline in real G.N.P.
When serving in the Carter Administration, Kahn was chastised for even using the word depression in public. He vowed to White House spinmeisters that whenever he had to refer to such a calamity, he would substitute the word banana.
I still think the market is due for a hair-curler one day, but not so severe as to lead to anything like the Great Banana.
 
WATER, WATER EVERYWHERE
"As I travel around the country," said Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, "people ask me, 'What's in the water in Tennessee these days, with so many Presidential contenders?"' These include Vice President Al Gore for the Democrats and Senator Fred Thompson and the former Tennessee Governor Lamar Alexander for the Republicans.
That led to the metaphor of the month from the former Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker, a Tennessean who now lobbies in Washington: "If Al Gore runs for President," Baker said, "and Lamar Alexander and Fred Thompson run for President, we'll pump so much money out of Tennessee that the surface will subside and the Mississippi River will run in and flood us all."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 6; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1187 words

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Balanchine's Baby Reaches a Certain Age

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
FOR 10 YEARS BEFORE HIS DEATH IN 1983, George Balanchine advertised the premieres in his company, the New York City Ballet, as Ballet No. 1 and Ballet No. 2. The troupe's new season, which opens on Tuesday at Lincoln Center, has the same number of nontitles, and for the same reason, one that has nothing to do with secrecy. The company simply wants to keep its options open until the last minute.
But ask Peter Martins, City Ballet's artistic director, about the big picture and he will disclose wide-ranging thoughts about plans for the company's 50th-anniversary season in 1998-99, new concepts about touring, money and programming. 
 Tributes are also on his mind. In an interview at the New York State Theater, he reflected on the special contributions of Stanley Williams, a great teacher and mentor who died recently, and of Merrill Ashley, one of the company's most popular stars, who will retire soon. This winter's season will honor both in different ways, just as in the spring Mr. Martins hopes to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Jerome Robbins's association with the company.
Economic realities have forced Mr. Martins to consider less expensive ways to present City Ballet at home and on tour. The question he often asks himself these days, he said, is, "Do I want to be a puritan or a businessman?" And the reply, he said in exasperation, is, "I feel like a Gemini."
The opening gala on Tuesday is a special event, having been transformed into a farewell to Ms. Ashley, who is retiring after 31 years with the company. But it is also an event isolated in its splendor; it will be followed by the annual "Nutcracker" run (Nov. 28 through Jan. 4) rather than by mixed programs (they resume on Jan. 6). Mr. Martins regrets that the company can no longer afford the one or two weeks of repertory programs that had preceded "The Nutcracker" until three years ago.
Mixed bills at the start of the season do not sell as well as "The Nutcracker," which for the second year will be extended to five weeks from four. Nonetheless, with 21 weeks at the State Theater, City Ballet still has more performances in its home city than any dance company in the world. Lopping off the two weeks in November helps keep the company in the black, and major projects are possible "because we always end up in the black," Mr. Martins said.
Recently, he has had more personal concerns, however. Mr. Martins has been deeply affected by the death last month of Mr. Williams, the teacher to whom he was closest in his native Denmark. Balanchine saw Mr. Williams teach at the Royal Danish Ballet and invited him, in the early 1960's, to the School of American Ballet, City Ballet's school. For the last decade, Mr. Martins and Mr. Williams were chairmen of the faculty. Now Mr. Martins will pay homage to his mentor on Jan. 22 with the premiere of a ballet set to Pergolesi. As usual, it is called Ballet No. 1. Ballet No. 2 that night will be by Richard Tanner, who frequently choreographs for the company.
For his part, Mr. Martins wants to honor the "quality" that Mr. Williams instilled in City Ballet's dancers. "When you see New York City Ballet, it is Balanchine who comes to mind, and rightly so," Mr. Martins said. "What does not come to mind is Stanley Williams: he is the unsung hero in both the school and the company."
While giving other teachers their due, Mr. Martins asserted that Mr. Williams, with the dancers he trained, had refined the company's look. "He was not your all-around teacher," he said. "Balanchine was the expert on toe work." But prize pupils like the young ballerinas Gelsey Kirkland and Darci Kistler flocked to Mr. Williams's men's classes, which had guests like Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov. "When you pare things away, you get to the essence of classical dancing," Mr. Martins said. "What Stanley Williams taught was more pure and distilled. It has taken eight teachers to replace him at the school."
As for Merrill Ashley, he said, her effect was primarily on Balanchine himself because she brought out something new in his choreography. "There was a side of Balanchine that was fascinated with dancers who could do more -- more turns, more everything," Mr. Martins said. "It was a turning point for Balanchine to find a female virtuoso in Merrill."
Asked about his plans for the company's silver anniversary, Mr. Martins took a step back by noting that the troupe split in half for an international tour in September. Forty-two dancers went to Brazil and 42 to Korea, Taiwan and Australia. Each group had three conductors, an equal number of principal dancers and some of the same ballets. "This was the full New York City Ballet, but cloned," Mr. Martins said.
In his view, the experiment was a success and is a model for a projected 50th-anniversary national tour. By halving the company's usual weekly fee, about $500,000, local sponsors might be able to present City Ballet in American cities that have not seen it in decades, if at all.
In New York, Mr. Martins plans "a huge bash," an alumni party for all staff and dancers employed by the company since its founding in 1948. After the opening, "The Nutcracker" will incorporate willing and able alumni dancers in its cast.
Six to eight premieres are scheduled for 1998-99. Three by Mr. Martins will have commissioned scores by, respectively, Wynton Marsalis, John Adams and Charles Wuorinen. The version of "Swan Lake" that Mr. Martins rechoreographed for the Royal Danish Ballet last year will be danced by City Ballet in the spring of 1999.
THAT PRODUCTION WILL BE PART OF A weeklong Tchaikovsky Festival, with two more weeks devoted to Stravinsky ballets and three to American composers. For the first time, viewers will be offered a joint subscription to the winter and spring seasons; no ballet in the spring will repeat works from the winter.
The January 1999 season will, in fact, open with a series of Balanchine works that Mr. Martins calls "black and white ballets" because they are danced in leotards and T-shirts. An inside joke will be the inclusion of "Symphony in C," with its women in white tutus and men in black tights. Later there will be a selected overview of 50 years of works by other choreographers.
In the meantime, Mr. Martins will encourage new choreographers to use music as a springboard. Unlike American Ballet Theater, which recently presented a ballet based on "Othello," City Ballet focuses on plotless works. "No, I don't want 'Macbeth' or 'Hamlet,' " Mr. Martins said. But he voiced no objection to narrative as long as the story was told through the classical vocabulary. "That is our language," he said.
Laughing, he recalled how the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj "went his own way" in creating "La Stravaganza" for the Diamond Project last spring. "I asked him to use pointe work, an orchestra and to cut down on costumes and scenery," he said. "He disregarded all this and ended up with a work that was strange and quite beautiful."
Is there a moral here? "I don't think we have rules," Mr. Martins said. "I think we have preferences."

HEADLINE: Peekskill Group Rallies to Stop Development of a Battle Site

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
IN 1777, Colonial militia unsuccessfully defended Peekskill against a British invasion. More than two centuries later, citizens' groups are fighting to prevent the battle site here from being developed.
Rallying around Fort Hill, the 47-acre Hudson River bluff where the Battle of Peekskill took place, is a consortium of preservation and conservation groups. 
 "We were organized to stop development of the Fort Hill area and to gain official recognition for Fort Hill as a historic site,"said John McAndrew, co-chairman of Friends of Historic Peekskill. "We envision a historic park being established to draw tourists to the area."
The organization said it hopes to stop a plan by the developer, River View Partners, to build 258 luxury apartments and 20 single-family dwellings, which would destroy part of the hill and cut down 22 acres of trees. River View Partners, owned by Louis Cappelli, is based in Valhalla. The company has extensive holdings, including the Summit office park in Valhalla.
"River View's plan would create a blacktop scar on the hill," Mr. McAndrew contended. "With 560 parking spaces, it would destroy the beauty and historic significance of this site forever. Once it's gone, you never get it back."
The historical significance of Fort Hill is not a question to Col. James Johnson, who teaches military history at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Colonel Johnson called the Fort Hill site a seat of the war. Recently, he spoke at a meeting of residents here on the role the fort played in defending the Hudson Highlands.
Musket balls and uniform buttons have been found at the site and correspondence and maps belonging to both the Patriots and the British have survived, but archeologists, who will be chosen by the city and paid for by the developer, will search for more artifacts.
In a letter to the editor in The Peekskill Herald this summer, Marge Schneider, a spokeswoman for River View, said that archeologists hired by the developer to search the site in 1984 -- when a permit to develop the area was granted -- reported that there was "no evidence of prehistoric occupation within the site."
The letter continued, "No structures or roadways of prehistoric or historical significance were discovered." Ms. Schneider contended that the River View development would help the city's economy by providing housing for residents with an average annual income of $60,000, with the total population of the project having an annual disposable income of $4 million. The letter also said that the developer's plan called for preserving half of the property as open space.
In an interview, Ms. Schneider said that Fort Hill could have been a pasture. "We've just redone the archeological study," Ms. Schneider said. "Our report determines that there is no historical significance. There are no artifacts to prove there was any kind of fort there; the rubble wall could be boundary for a pasture."
The City Historian, John Curran, said that a large pile of semicircular rocks, which have caved in toward the center, were once the back wall of a foundry where musket balls were made.
As for concern about the removal of trees for the development, Ms. Schneider said: "If you do any kind of development, you are cutting down trees. There will be a tree preservation plan."
Patrick Garvey, the Peekskill City Manager, said: "How much of it can we preserve? What can we get the company to do in terms of prospective development? There could be a very clever design with a fort and observation decks. They could preserve historic redoubts if we could reconstruct them.
"A private party owns the property. It's not a question of whether the city is going to allow development. That decision was made several years ago that development could take place there. There's an existing permit. We're not in a position to buy it. We can't just take it." He said the developer had spent $1 million to buy the property. The question is how to do this intelligently.
"The issue of the historic site is only part of the problem; the other is density," Mr. Garvey added. "The traffic generated by the complex is a great concern. A road in and out would have to be constructed. It would be expensive."
Besides the cost, new roads would change neighborhoods, Mr. Garvey said. "Those are quiet streets now. They're talking about jitneys to take people to the railroad. This is a city with 4.5 square miles. We have no more acreage. We have more greenscape and parks than anybody can imagine. We need green -- the other kind that pays taxes."
Residential development of the kind envisioned for Fort Hill could end up costing the city revenue rather than providing it, according to a study published in June, which was commissioned by Scenic Hudson, an organization formed in 1963 to protect and enhance the Hudson River Valley's ecosystem and landscapes.
"Peekskill is a city in renaissance," said Jeffrey Anzevino, a waterfront specialist and planner at Scenic Hudson in Poughkeepsie. "There's a lot of new interest in the city related to its history and perch on the Hudson River. The density of the River View proposal warrants a hard look at just how much of the scenery and Fort Hill encampment would be compromised and whether any compromise is acceptable.'
In the Battle of Peekskill, which lasted three days, starting on March 23, 1777, more than 500 British soldiers attacked Fort Hill, which was defended by about 250 soldiers. Retreating, the Continental troops burned their workshops, mills and warehouses. A Patriot and 13 British soldiers were killed, and in October 1777 the British returned to destroy the village of Peekskill.
Involved in the battle were Col. Pierre Van Cortlandt, Gen. George Clinton, later to become New York's first Governor; Gen. Alexander McDougall and Col. Marinus Willett, whose silver sword is on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan. Black soldiers, including John Jacob Peterson, a cannoneer, and Lieut. William Moshier also took part in the battle. In 1990, Lieutenant Moshier's family dedicated a cannon in his name, which was placed in front of the Peekskill Museum in downtown Peekskill.
As for saving the site, Mr. McAndrew of the Friends of Historic Peekskill, said: "We feel that the city of Peekskill has an obligation not just to its citizens but to anyone who lives in or visits the Hudson Valley to preserve Fort Hill as a part of our history and our part of the Hudson River Greenway."

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Curran, Peekskill Historian, above, at property that residents and a developer are fighting over. Mr. Curran and Eileen Yajure of a preservation group, far left, and some items recovered from site. (Photographs by Richard Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Suit in Oyster Bay Stymies Redevelopment

BYLINE: By VIVIEN KELLERMAN 

 BODY:
A SUIT between the Town of Oyster Bay and an oil company operating in the hamlet appears to be the only flaw in an otherwise ambitious plan to revitalize the downtown harbor.
The plan includes the recent purchase of a 200-year old shipyard, plus an adjacent piece of land, extensive work by the Long Island Rail Road, which would provide more access to the downtown shopping district, and a proposal to build a railroad museum. 
 Although the litigation will not hamper those efforts, the town is concerned about future implications if the oil company's request to dredge its basin should prevail.
"The entire wetlands project is designed to revitalize the area," said Anthony Sabeno, the Oyster Bay deputy town attorney. "The expansion of a fuel oil company is not consistent with that." Nicholas Damadeo, the lawyer for the oil company, Commander Oil, contends there are no plans to expand.
Commander Oil has been operating in Oyster Bay since 1929. Until 1995, the company had a lease with the town that allowed it, among other things, to conduct maintenance dredging in the vicinity of its dock. When the lease ran out, the company applied to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the Army Corps of Engineers for a dredging permit. On March 28, 1995, the Department of Environmental Conservation granted the permit.
Believing that the department should not have issued the permit, the town sued the agency. It also sued the Department of State, which manages the state coastal plan arguing that the it should have stepped in to prevent the dredging, citing Commander Oil as a co-defendant. The suit against the Department of Environmental Conservation was ultimately dismissed.
On April 7, 1997, the State Supreme Court ruled in favor of Commander Oil. In his decision, Justice Geoffrey J. O'Connell wrote, "consideration was given to the environmental concerns implicated in the project, including those which would be entailed in alternative home heating oil delivery systems for Nassau and western Suffolk Counties."
The town has appealed that decision.
In addition to the environmental agency permit, Commander must secure a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers, which is being withheld until further testing of the material to be dredged has been completed.
Despite rumors to the contrary, said Mr. Damadeo, Commander has no plans to expand its operation. "It simply wants the right to have access to its dock," he said. A right, he continued, the company has enjoyed for 70 years.
But the town believes that Commander's request to dredge both sides of its dock basin, when in the past it only dredged the western side, proves that it plans to expand. "The only reason Commander wants to dredge both sides is to bring more oil into the harbor," said Mr. Sabino. "They don't need two basins for what they are bringing in now."
Moreover, he said, in the 20 years since the basin was last dredged, an entire sand spit with marine life and a potential for ecological impact on the rest of the harbor, has been deposited. "This fact itself is evident that this is no longer maintenance dredging," he said.
Mr. Sabino argues that the town owns the underwater land by virtue of a colonial patent granted in 1677, and therefore has the right to control mooring, shellfishing and dredging. "We say that Commander should have come to us for permits," he said.
Michael Deering, the director of Friends of the Bay, a volunteer group concerned about development of the harbor, said that even as the litigation with Commander Oil proceeds, the other pieces relating to the harbor's future continue.
One is an agreement with the Long Island Rail Road, which has a maintenance yard in Oyster Bay, the last stop on the line. With only two streets crossing the tracks, said Mr. Deering, the downtown shopping district and the harbor are essentially divided.
After much negotiation, he said, the railroad has agreed to renovate the entire yard, consolidating its equiment, to allow for more access from the downtown. Moreover, the northeast corner of the yard will be turned over to a local historical group, which hopes to create a railroad museum and to display an old railroad engine on the property. This project, which recently went out to bid by the railroad, will begin next year.
The recent acquisition of the 5.2 acre Jakobson Shipyard property, said Mr. Deering, came about after several years of effort by state and town officials, who secured $5 million towards the $6 million purchase price using funds from the 1972 Environmental Quality Bond Act. The remaining $1 million was paid for by the town.
Senator Carl Marcellino, who is chairman of a steering committee for the development of the harbor, called this purchase the linchpin that links together the existing 45-acre Roosevelt Memorial Park and Beach with other town property, to create a half-mile stretch of public waterfront land.
Mr. Marcellino said that before any decision on development of the property is made, the town will hold several public hearings. At the first hearing in October, he said, so many people showed up, they had to be put into small groups in order to be heard.
Representatives of several organizations put forth an idea that included an educational center, a fire department water-rescue training center, off-season boat mooring for baymen, a regional office for the Department of Environmental Conservation, a fish and wildlife office and a maritime museum, with a proposal to bring in a destroyer to be on permanent display. After the hearings, a written comment period will allow for further input.
"This is the first time to my knowledge that the public has been invited before any plans have been made," Mr. Marcellino said. "Despite the range of ideas, there are no preconceived notions. Whatever we decide, we want it to be something that the public has selected."
Mr. Marcellino said that a decision on the property will be made in March. Mr. Sabino said that a decision on the Commander Oil litigation could take a year or more.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/866 Third Avenue;
For One Building, Three Uses: Retail, Medical, Hotel

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
A LARGELY vacant office building at 866 Third Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, is about to be converted to an unusual mix of uses as a result of a complex agreement announced last May and made final in recent weeks.
The transaction demonstrates how creative use of a property can add previously unrealized value. The process by which it happened also illustrates the complexities of the tangles of negotiating strategies and interests among buyers, sellers and the brokerage companies who sometimes find themselves on both sides of the negotiating table. 
 When renovations are complete, the former Macmillan building will be divided three ways. The top floors, 14 to 31, will be converted to a 320-room hotel to be operated as a Marriott Courtyard. The first two floors will be used for retail purposes. The Witkoff Group, which bought the 454,000-square-foot building in October 1996 for $50 million, will retain ownership of the upper and lower units, which are condominiums.
On the floors between those operations, a condominium unit extending from the 3d through 11th floors has been purchased by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for providing outpatient care.(The 12th floor is mechanical; there is no 13th.) The hospital, which paid $24 million for about 220,000 square feet of space, plans to spend $30 million to convert office floors into doctors' offices and examination, diagnostic and treatment spaces.
Hospital administrators said the new facility would enable them to provide services in a location more central than the main campus on the Upper East Side between First and York Avenues and 67th and 68th Streets. Officials of the hospital said they would offer radiology and chemotherapy treatments at the center as well as screening programs for people at risk of developing cancer.
"Most treatment is done on an outpatient basis today," said Clarice Albright, the hospital's administrator. "People getting chemotherapy need to make frequent trips to their doctor." Since many current treatments do not have as pronounced side effects as older approaches had, patients can integrate treatment with their regular activities, she said.
"People will go in for a few hours and then get on with their lives," she said. Because of the more central location, she said, "we can get them in and out faster."
The additional space will also allow the hospital to offer "wellness" programs that would include screenings for those genetically disposed to cancer. The program would provide the screenings without requiring a hospital visit.
"We will have screening programs, nutrition programs and patient and public information programs," Ms. Albright said.
. To keep hotel guests separate from outpatients, the hotel and the treatment center will have separate entrances, lobbies and sets of elevators. The hotel is expected to front on Third Avenue, while the treatment center will face 53d Street.
Hospital officials and real-estate executives said the path to an agreement was a rocky one. When Metropolitan Life, the previous owner, announced that it would auction the building, the hospital was one of the bidders, in association with Stephen M. Ross of the Related Companies. But Steven Witkoff, then a partner in Stellar Management Company, bid higher and was able to complete the purchase in association with Credit Suisse First Boston. Stellar has since split into residential and commercial operations, with the Witkoff Group owning and managing the commercial portion.
Mr. Witkoff said he had had applications other than office use in mind when he offered his bid. "When we bought that building, the New York office market had not recovered enough that you could justify paying $110 a foot for office use," he said. "We needed to find other uses, and the economics of a hotel looked favorable."
Knowing of the hospital's interest in the building, Mr. Witkoff contacted the administrators within weeks after completing the purchase and asked if they were interested in purchasing a condominium in the building, which he was planning to convert into condominium usage. Because of the hospital's status as a nonprofit institution, he said, it pays no real estate taxes on property it owns, while a landlord would have to factor taxes into the rental rate if the space was simply leased.
Hospital officials describe in negotiations in late 1996 as difficult, with Witkoff Group executives demanding a higher price than the hospital was willing to pay. "The economics did not make sense, so we walked away," said John R. Gunn, executive vice president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering.
OFFICIALS of the hospital note that executives of Insignia/ESG, the current name for the Edward S. Gordon Company, were representing both Mr. Witkoff and the hospital in the negotiations and suggest that this was at least part of the reason for the initial lack of progress. "It was a very curious situation," Ms. Albright said of the initial negotiations with Mr. Witkoff. "My suspicion is that Gordon felt we wanted the space so bad that he had a tenant."
Steven Simkin, the lawyer for Memorial Sloan-Kettering, said that the Gordon firm, in addition to being on both sides of the table in the talks with Mr. Witkoff and the hospital after the sale, had represented both Met Life and the hospital in Sloan-Kettering's original bidding for the building. He said hospital officials were uncomfortable with the Gordon firm's position.
"I think there was a conflict given these multiple roles," Mr. Simkin said. "It is hard to effectively represent parties on both sides of a transaction." Nevertheless, the hospital was required by contract to continue with Gordon until the expiration of the agreement early this year.
Executives of the Gordon concern vigorously reject any suggestion of conflict of interest, saying that there is a clear distinction between the company's property group, which represents building owners, and its brokers. They say the property group's executives are paid salaries to represent owners, while the brokers receive a commission only if a transaction closes.
"Is it an arm's-length negotiation?" said Mitchell E. Rudin, an executive managing director of Gordon and head of its property group. "Absolutely." He noted that it is commonplace to have executives from the same firm representing buyer and seller.
"Some owners engage us to sell properties because of our ability to bring in a buyer," Mr. Rudin said. "It happens all the time, and we are very forward about it."
When Gordon's exclusive right to represent the hospital expired, the hospital, at Mr. Simkin's recommendation, signed Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, to find another location for the care center.
Mr. Gosin said he became convinced that the location on Third Avenue made sense if the financial terms could be changed, and went back to Mr. Witkoff. "I was able to convince Steve that he was better off selling to the hospital rather than trying to rent the space in the commercial market," Mr. Gosin said. "We were able to get a good price for the hospital, and Steve will do well with the hotel on top."
Mr. Gosin said that on a per-square-foot basis the hospital paid a little less for its condo than Mr. Witkoff paid for the entire building. He noted that the floors the hospital purchased were the least valuable in the building, since they did not have the views available in the tower and did not include the first two floors of retail space, which rent for far higher rates than middle floors.
Ms. Albright said the revised transaction cost the hospital $12 million less than the original proposal. Mr. Witkoff said there was never a set price, and noted that the second floor was included in the hospital's space in the original plan, but was withdrawn so the first and second floors could be combined to lure big-box retailers.
Mr. Gosin agreed that the terms changed as the negotiation went forward, with the amount and location of the hospital's space different at the end than the beginning. Although the transaction only closed recently, demolition work has been under way, and Ms. Albright said interior construction for the hospital's space would start in January, with the opening scheduled for October. Hospital officials said the new facility would help attract international patients, many of whom could be expected to stay in the hotel part of the building.
Carol Nelson, a Gordon broker who first showed the space at 866 Third to hospital officials, said the neighborhood has a residential component that should make it less intimidating for first-time visitors to New York. In addition, she said, parking is available nearby, and the traffic patterns in the area make for easy access.
Despite the successful carving up of the building, real estate executives say they do not expect to see many other mixed-use conversions, as the market for office space continues to heat up. "It was an opportunity in time," Mr. Witkoff said, that is not likely to be repeated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sloan-Kettering says that space in the Third Avenue building about to be converted will give it a more central location than its Upper East Side campus to provide services to cancer patients. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Scientist Says Sleepy Teen-Agers Aren't Just Tired

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
MORNINGS are not pretty for 15-year-old Lizzy Schulzinger, a high school sophomore. On school days, her parents begin her day by waking her at 6 A.M. Usually, she falls promptly back to sleep. Sometimes, Lizzy's parents sit her up in bed and then make sure her feet are on the floor. On really bad days, her little sister pries her eyelids open.
By 6:45, Lizzy staggers onto the school bus, where she joins dozens of other sleepy teen-agers on their way to Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, which begins at 7:45. There, as in other high schools starting from 7:15 to 7:50 A.M., teachers, students and administrators describe early morning classes where teen-agers sit bleary eyed while trying to focus on biology, math and other first-period subjects. Students arriving late, toting cups of coffee and slumping with their heads on their desks are not uncommon in the early hours of the day in high school. 
 To be sure, every age group has its share of "morning people," and there are students who are bright eyed and ready to learn soon after sunrise. Nor is it startling news that teen-agers are not their best in the early hours. But now sleep researchers are discovering that adolescent sleepiness in the morning has a physiological basis. And educators are beginning to take notice of the research and questioning whether the school schedule -- originally based on an agrarian economy when students were needed home in the afternoon to do farm chores -- is optimal for teaching today's teen-agers. When Dr. Mary Carskadon, director of chronobiology/sleep research at E. P. Bradley Hospital in Providence, R.I., and a professor in the department of psychiatry and human behavior at Brown University School of Medicine, began researching adolescent sleep patterns, she assumed that teen-agers stayed up at night for psychological and sociological reasons. Factors ranging from teen-agers needing to assert themselves to increased academic and social obligations all tend to push bedtime later. But after more than a decade of study, Dr. Carskadon has discovered that most adolescents sleep differently than children or adults.
In studies, Dr. Carskadon found that as children move into puberty, their biological clocks undergo a shift, pushing their preprogrammed period of wakefulness about an hour later than it was in their early teen-age years. Older teen-agers secrete melatonin -- a hormone that regulates the body's circadian rhythms, or biological clock -- about 10:30 P.M., whereas younger teen-agers release the hormone roughly one hour earlier. Dr. Carskadon's findings were published in 1996 in the medical journal Sleep Research.
Not only is the onset of sleep delayed for older teen-agers but also the various phases of the sleep cycle are pushed back -- including an important final hour of dreaming, known as REM, or rapid eye movement, sleep. Researchers say that this final phase of sleep -- which in older adolescents generally does not end until 7 A.M. -- is critical to the feeling of being rested and refreshed.
When Dr. Carskadon brought teen-agers into her sleep lab and woke them up at their usual times -- between 5:30 and 6:30 A.M. -- and then measured their brain waves at 8:30, which is roughly the time of second-period classes in most high schools, she said she found, "these kids' brains weren't fully awake." The teen-agers also quickly fell back into REM sleep, another sign that they were not adjusted to early rising, Dr. Carskadon said, adding that this was true of 40 to 60 percent of teen-agers.
The findings have several implications for high school students. First, since biologically sleep comes later to teen-agers, the obvious solution of putting tired teen-agers to bed earlier is not always the answer. Tara Speisman, 14, a freshman at Irvington High School said, "Even when I'm really tired and I can get to bed earlier, it's hard for me to fall asleep before 11 P.M."
Further, since teen-agers must awaken for school before the final phase of sleep is complete, grogginess in early classes is nearly inevitable. "They're being asked to be in school when their brain essentially is still asleep, so it's not surprising they sleep through first and second period," Dr. Carskadon said in a phone interview. "There are some youngsters who do adjust and seem to manage O.K., but we also have data showing that many teen-agers are awake at the wrong time, because their brain hasn't adjusted its temporal time phrase."
Dr. Carskadon said that, optimally, adolescents need about 9 hours and 15 minutes of sleep a night. She added that 8 hours and 15 minutes is considered a reasonable amount. But in her studies, she found teen-agers getting an average of seven hours of sleep, so that by the end of the week, they had "an accumulated sleep deficit." This is why so many teen-agers sleep until noon on weekends.
Researchers have not yet quantified the academic cost of sleep deprivation by charting waking times with grades or test scores. But it is known that sleep deprivation interferes with cognitive functioning -- particularly that part of the brain needed for creative thinking. It is also established that lack of sleep affects reaction time. Not only is this relevant to teen-agers' studies but also to their safety when driving. Exhaustion and alcohol are another dangerous mix.
Also in question is how sleep deprivation affects an adolescent's already turbulent emotional state. Initial studies have shown that sleep deprived teen-agers report more negative feelings, like anger, fear and sadness, than well-rested ones, Dr. Carskadon said.
Of course, biological sleep rhythms are not the only reason adolescents are so tired. Teen-agers lead busy lives. Many spend hours at sports practice. Students returning from some games do not get home until 8 P.M. and then begin their homework. Then there is student council, play practice, dance class, community service, jobs and more.
"We know that most competitive colleges will tell the student that it's not good enough to have high SAT's and grade point averages," said Dr. Robert Maher, principal of Briarcliff High School, where classes start at 7:50 A.M. "They have to be well rounded. They have to participate in sports, have work experience, community service, co-curricular activities. And there are only so many hours in the day."
Brenda Smith, principal of Mount Vernon High School, which opens at 7:40 A.M., said: "When you have juniors and seniors who have a need to work, and they're getting home from work at 10 P.M. and then they have homework, it's difficult. And some of those individuals go straight from school to work."
Dr. Carskadon said she has heard from school districts nationwide that are interested in her research. But moving school openings is problematic, and for reasons that go beyond after-school schedules. Primarily, it is a financial issue. Few districts can afford to transport their students without double or triple "tripping" their buses -- that is, districts stagger school starting times so they can use the same school buses more than once to save money. Rather than have elementary school children out at a bus stop at 6:45 A.M., when it is often dark and even more dangerous for them, schools choose to send their older students in early.
Other issues come into play. Several years ago, Chappaqua considered having middle and high schools open after elementary schools. Some parents objected because they counted on their teen-agers to be home earlier to baby-sit their younger siblings after school.
Last year, in Katonah-Lewisboro, where John Jay High School opens at 7:15 A.M., the school's planning team of parents, teachers and administrators identified the start time of school as an issue they wanted to address, partly based on the research on teen-age sleep patterns. But when the district proposed a plan that would have allowed the high school to open later but would have cost the community more in transportation costs, it was voted down.
Dr. Maher of Briarcliff said that despite all the seemingly immutable features of the current school schedule, he believes that the issue merits examination. "I think there needs to be a consideration of a later start time despite some of these issues which dictate an early start, because you really do need to think of what our mission is, and of course it's academic," he said. "If you keep that in the forefront, maybe you start school at 8:30 A.M."
That would be good news to one of his sophomores, Rachel Suna, 15, and her friends. Rachel, who uses two alarm clocks to wake up, so she can be on time for her 7:50 A.M. global studies class, said, "When I think about it, just about everyone I know is tired."

HEADLINE: Rare Voice, Gracious Neighbor

BYLINE: By JAY AXELBANK 

 BODY:
ON a cold Easter Sunday, April 9, 1939, Marian Anderson, standing at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington before 75,000 people, sang her way into history. She was already acclaimed as the greatest contralto of her time. Now her fortitude and serenity, in the face of exclusion from Constitution Hall on account of her color, would touch millions of hearts around the world.
The road to legendary status had been arduous: Childhood poverty, discrimination, lost musical opportunities. In 1928, Marian Anderson had begun touring Europe to find the recognition denied her at home. It was in Salzburg, Austria, in 1935, that the conductor Arturo Toscanini heard her and said, "Yours is a voice such as one hears once in a hundred years." That same year she returned in triumph to America. 
 From then on, until she retired in 1965, everywhere Marian Anderson appeared, she sang to thunderous, packed houses. Music critics ran out of superlatives rhapsodizing about her soulful delivery, nearly three-octave range (low D to high C) and immense dignity, on and off stage.
From Franklin D. Roosevelt to George Bush, Presidents paid homage to her, as a singer and as spiritual symbol, as did the Empress of Japan, the kings of Sweden and Denmark, Albert Einstein and a host of musical greats including Jan Sibelius, Isaac Stern and Vladimir Horowitz. She toured the world as a good will ambassador. Dozens of universities, including the University of Connecticut in 1987, conferred honorary degrees. Cities gave her their keys.
But behind the legend of the singer there was another legend, one rarely glimpsed except by those closest to her: the homespun Marian Anderson, the woman who lived on a farm in Danbury for the better part of 50 years. Now it is in Danbury that a decision must be made on how to best honor her -- a decision centering on the studio built for her that is threatened with demolition or relocation.
The people close to her in Danbury knew a soft-spoken, shy woman who shopped in town for fabric to make into curtains and slipcovers -- and who took along a portable sewing machine on tours to finish projects. She also insisted on waiting her turn like any other customer in stores and restaurants, and was never too busy to stop and chat in town or at the Danbury State Fair.
Despite the demands of her career, Miss Anderson made time for Danbury and for Connecticut. She sang at Danbury City Hall for the lighting of the Christmas decorations and at the Danbury High School; she appeared in recitals throughout the state. Miss Anderson served on the board of the Danbury Music Center and supported the Charles Ives Center for the Arts. She was host to gatherings for the Salvation Army and other causes and contributed to the Danbury chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. She served on the State Commission on the Arts and testified in Hartford for more support of the arts.
It was at the time of her Lincoln Memorial recital that Marian Anderson was searching New York State and Connecticut for a retreat from the tumult of fame. Bigotry blocked some plans, but she finally found what she was looking for in 1940 in the Mill Plain section of Danbury: a 100-acre property with pastures, wooded hills and a swimming pond. It came to be known as Marianna Farm.
Miss Anderson and her husband, the architect Orpheus (King) Fisher, whom she married in 1943, gardened, raised cattle and sheep, and kept and rode horses. She surrounded herself with dogs, cats, birds and fish. Marian Anderson said she found freedom and peace at Marianna Farm, where she had a view of a distant ridge across what is now Interstate 84. Unlike many celebrities who live in gated estates or secluded residences, Marian Anderson was accessible at her Danbury home when she was not touring.
There were always visitors, youngsters and aspiring singers among them. Miss Anderson spent more and more time at Marianna Farm as the years went by; after retiring in 1965, she lived there quietly, devoting herself to the farm and philanthropic and community activities.
Miss Anderson and Mr. Fisher resided in a three-bedroom ranch house that they had built after selling half the original 100 acres; it was decidedly not a mansion, marked only by a weather-beaten rural mailbox and a sign, Marianna Farm. Mr. Fisher -- who is said to have pursued Miss Anderson for more than 20 years before they married -- built a 25-by-30-foot cottage for her studio; it nestled among trees overlooking the pond, not far from the main house.
Now half a century later, and four years after Marian Anderson's death, a campaign is underway to move the cottage and preserve it as a memorial and museum at another location. The 50-acre Marianna Farm itself was named last year as one of 60 sites on the Connecticut Freedom Trail.
It was in the studio that Miss Anderson would sing for her own pleasure and rehearse without "bothering people," as she once put it.
They weren't bothered. "I will never forget that haunting voice," says Max Brownstein, 87, of Waterbury, who rented a guest cottage for 30 years on Marianna Farm. "You could hear her singing from Joes Hill Road," he recalled. "Sometimes people would stop their cars to listen."
As he strolled sadly around Marianna Farm on a recent afternoon, past sagging fences, a crumbling white barn and piles of firewood and debris, he sighed.
"If Marian saw her farm now, she would be terribly sad," he said. "She worked so hard to keep it neat and beautiful."
The home itself and the music studio, however, are still in good repair, and, in fact, are now temporarily occupied.
For a while last year it appeared that the studio, with its concave, acoustical ceiling, fireplace and picture windows, could be a casualty of development plans by the farm's present owner. A proposed road would have gone straight through the studio.
But a group of Danbury residents, including the developer, moved in to save it, led by Danbury Mayor Gene Eriquez and State Senator Mark Nielsen and State Representative Lew Wallace, who represent Danbury. In April a bill to allocate $250,000 for the project stalled in committee. Now Mr. Wallace is looking for support from the Department of Economic and Community Development and the State Commission on the Arts. Proposed sites for the studio are the headquarters of Scott-Fanton Museum and Historical Society on Main Street or next to the Charles Ives home, both in Danbury.
But before the studio is moved, a dispute over housing development plans must be resolved. The development firm, led by Robert H. Wilder Jr. of Elmsford, N.Y., is at loggerheads with the city of Danbury over the length of the driveway that will go through the cottage site. The owner has offered to pay for moving the studio. But as long as the impasse continues, the cottage stays put and the one-room structure runs the risk of deterioration.
Deborah Grover, a Danbury lawyer and board member of Scott-Fanton Museum, and Daryle Dennis, president of the greater Danbury chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., are leading a fund-raising drive. "We want to honor the memory of this great singer who lived in our community," says Ms. Grover. "We especially need a beacon to show young women that they can excel in our society."
June Goodman of Danbury, one of those who first expressed concern over preserving the studio, speaks reverently of Marian Anderson, not only as a great singer but as the "most unassuming and gracious person I ever knew" -- a description echoed by all who knew her. Ms. Goodman, who first met the singer in the 1940's, is chairwoman of the Marian Anderson Award Foundation that annually presents a $20,000 prize to promising singers in mid-career.
Virginia Wren, of New Fairfield, who lived a stone's throw from Marianna Farm in the 40's and 50's, said "The first thing you noticed about her was that she almost never used the pronoun I, but always we or one in referring to herself. She was the one great singer you would never call a prima donna." Mr. Brownstein says that in all the years he knew her, "I never once, not once, heard her say a bad word about anybody. Not even about racists."
Even though her Lincoln Memorial appearance became a clarion call in the civil rights movement, Miss Anderson, in her 1956 autobiography, "My Lord, What a Morning," said she strived to lead by the impression she left as an artist and as a human being. She said she did not consider herself a "fearless fighter."
As a teen-ager in Philadelphia she was rejected by a music school, which did not take "colored" students; she was excluded from certain hotels and restaurants at a time when she was received by royalty and heads of state; she was barred from pursuing the operatic career she always dreamed of because the Metropolitan Opera would not admit blacks, until she became its first black soloist in 1955. Among those who acknowledge their debt to Marian Anderson are Leontyne Price and Jessye Norman, for whom she was a trailblazer.
Allan Keiler, a professor of music at Brandeis University, who is completing a biography of Miss Anderson, says, "Without diminishing her greatness as a symbol of freedom, I try to refocus in my book on her neglected musical reputation. Beyond her incomparable voice, she had the artistry to capture any vocal style, from Schubert lieder to a spiritual."
When Marian Anderson retired from the concert stage at the age of 68, Professor Keiler attended one of her farewell concerts in Ann Arbor, Mich., in 1964. He recalls: "She walked on stage to begin the recital wearing a white dress that lent her a regal aura. Before she sang a note, the audience immediately rose as one and gave her a long, standing ovation. There were few dry eyes in the house."
Professor Keiler says he has reservations about making the Marianna Farm studio a museum.
"This only accentuates a trend," he says, "to mythologize Marian Anderson as a symbol, to distance her from us as a singer whose art we know less and less about as the years go by. Many of her important recordings haven't been available for decades. Let's remember her through her vocal art."

HEADLINE: Labor's Story in Wartime Bridgeport

BYLINE: By JARRET LIOTTA 

 BODY:
BRIDGEPORT was a different city in 1944. Many of the men were overseas fighting the war. Though industry, particularly war-related production, thrived, the labor shortage demanded that women go into the work force.
Marjorie Nordstrom Schneider was part of all that. She became a safety advocate for the women workers at the Bridgeport Brass Company, which, among other things, produced shell casings for the Navy. 
 "Bridgeport was a mecca for all kinds of industry," she said. "Because of the war, different jobs were created that didn't exist before. Industry was hiring anyplace you wanted to go."
It took the then-23-year-old Marjorie Nordstrom about 20 minutes to walk the six or so blocks down East Main Street to the factory, where she would change into coveralls, safety shoes and peaked mesh hat.
"East Main Street in those days had some good restaurants," she said. "They had department stores that were top quality."
The experiences and impressions of Mrs. Schneider will not be lost. Thanks to a project at the Bridgeport Library, the history of labor and the working class in the once-great industrial city will be documented. The relationship between Bridgeport's development and that of the United States during the 20th century will come alive through an oral history, available through a interactive Web site.
"This is something that I've been thinking about for years, so I'm really excited," said Mary Witkowski, head of historical collections at the Bridgeport Library. "My interest is in urban geography and the histories of cities and the growth of cities." Ms. Witkowski came from the Detroit area, where she worked in urban planning before earning a master's degree in library science.
Since 1986, Ms. Witkowski has entertained a regular procession of Bridgeporters who visit at the library. "They would drift into my office and tell me their personal stories and I would wish I had a tape recorder," she said. "The only thing that everybody had in common was that they all came for work."
Ms. Witkowski sees several parallels between Bridgeport and Detroit, including the rise and ultimate failure of the local industries, not to mention the influx of immigrants that continued even after the jobs were gone.
"In many ways I think of Bridgeport about 10 years behind Detroit," she said. "Detroit has seen a bit of a renaissance, while I think Bridgeport has just gotten to the cusp of that."
The project will span the entire century, with a list of about 30 residents set to be interviewed.
"For the Web site we'll probably only be doing 10 or less," she said, "but we want to get the process in place. That way if someone interesting comes along we can go out and interview them."
Ms. Witkowski will be working closely with Cecelia Bucki, an associate professor of history at Fairfield University who is a specialist in labor and social history. Several of her students will help conduct interviews as part of their course work.
"Bridgeport has some very unique qualities to it that aren't readily apparent today," said Dr. Bucki, a Bridgeport native who did her doctoral dissertation on the city's labor movement in the 1920's. "It was a very dynamic industrial center, even though it was very small."
She spoke of the importance of oral histories as providing valuable documentation for scholars, as well as preserving the culture. "What we're trying to get at is ordinary people's lives," she said.
Jeremy Brecher, a West Cornwall writer who has done numerous oral history projects, wrote the book "History From Below: How to Uncover and Tell the Story of Your Community, Association, or Union." a guide for conducting oral histories. He recently gave a workshop for those participating in this project.
"Oral history often opens a window into the lives of working people and other non-elite groups," he said. "You're getting the experience of people who lived through historical events, what they saw, what they felt, what it meant to them."
Unlike major historical figures or groups, the histories of working people can't usually be obtained through conventional sources. "There's generally no video tape or oral tapes, and often much less in the way of correspondence," he said.
City librarian Nancy Johmannsaid of the Bridgeport project: "One of the things that I think is unique about it is this concept of making it available on the Web. It permits a lot of people who wouldn't get that interested to tune in and see a living piece of history."
"Many individuals will not pick up something in writing," she said, "but if it flashes on a computer screen or on a television set they'll read it."
The site will feature an audio element, as well as photographs and text. While a similar Web site exists involving oral histories, which was done through Brown University in Rhode Island, Ms. Witkowski said hers would be more of an exhibition.
The Connecticut Humanities Council gave a grant of $9,500 for the first phase of the project and probably will assist with the Web site.
"This is a project we like and will carefully monitor," said Laurie Rayner, associate director. She said the council has never had a request to fund a Web site project and reasoned that it would be an accessible and efficient venue for teaching the humanities.
Another $5,000 came from retired Superior Court Judge Margaret Driscoll, 82, a Bridgeport native who, before this project, had wanted the library to do a labor exhibit in memory of her husband, John Driscoll, the head of the Connecticut State Labor Council A.F.L.-C.I.O. from 1968 to 1985.
"I wanted them to do a history of labor in Bridgeport because I thought that would be appropriate," said Judge Driscoll. "I think it's important for people of the younger generation to know what happened, how they got the benefits they got" -- including pensions, job security and safety regulations.
"They don't know what unions brought with them," she said.
The interview process began last week and will probably go through the end of January. Ms. Witkowski said she hoped to have the Web site up sometime in the spring.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Norwalk, Conn.;
No Longer That 'Hole in the Doughnut'

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN the 70's the Norwalk Chamber of Commerce tried to attract business to the city by calling it "the hole in the doughnut." "They thought it would appeal to businesses as an undiscovered place on the Gold Coast -- a good area on the cheap, " said former Mayor William A. Collins.
But the phrase backfired and just emphasized the economic and social problems that set the struggling city apart from Darien, Westport, Wilton, Weston and New Canaan -- the wealthy residential towns at its borders. 
 Today, benefiting from an influx of corporations moving from or bypassing the expensive Stamford-Greenwich market, it has drawn corporate employees who found homes in neighborhoods indistinguishable from those in adjacent towns. And over the last decade, Norwalk has established an urban, diversified cachet all its own.
Estates on the wooded, rocky waterfront, handsome back country colonials and Tudors, luxury condominium complexes and a rash of smart new clustered, single-family houses cost some 20 percent less than their counterparts in neighboring towns. Condominiums and houses needing fix-up or situated in marginal neighborhoods can be found at five- and low six-figure prices.
Alfred Zellerkraut from Marseilles is typical of the new Norwalk resident. For the last three years he has worked for Swiss Bank in New York, while living in New Jersey with his family.
Last month he was transferred to Swiss Bank's new headquarters in Stamford and after much searching he bought a house from the developer's plans on North Taylor Avenue in Norwalk -- 2,200 square feet, 4 bedrooms on about a fifth of an acre -- for $250,000. It will be completed in January to his specifications. "I was surprised at prices in Westchester and Fairfield County," he said. "Houses 60 years old in terrible condition cost what I am paying. I got a bigger house for less money and I like the location, the coziness of the town."
"We have had lots of buyers from Swiss Bank," said Carol Ann Falasca, a Norwalk broker with Coldwell Banker who was not involved in the Zellerkraut sale. "Everybody wants new, and corporate people know that the houses they buy must be resalable -- no problems like old lead paint or underground oil tanks."
As of last month 532 units of housing in single-family subdivisions, cluster housing developments and multifamily condominium complexes were being built,proposed or approved for construction here.
Five homes have been sold and five more are under contract at the 29-lot subdivision at Linden Heights, off the Main Avenue and Merritt Parkway intersection. Priced from $273,000 to $311,000, they offer 42 optional features in addition to 3 and 4 bedrooms, full basements, up to 2,260 square feet and 2-car garages. On the upscale waterfront off Canfield Avenue, 1- to 3-acre building lots with buried utilities, roads and sewers are available for $965,000 to $1.1 million.
Silvermine, Wilson Point and Rowayton are some of the more expensive, established neighborhoods. Heavily wooded and secluded Silvermine has attracted celebrities such as the actress Eileen Heckart, the writers Vance Packard and Evan Hunter, the sculptor Solon Borglum and Lawrence Eagleburger, a former Secretary of State.
Wilson Point contains a private beach club and handsome homes on wooded, hilly roads overlooking Norwalk harbor. The more densely populated Rowayton, also on the water, has its own shopping district, beach, park, art center and yacht clubs. "People who can't afford Darien hop over to Rowayton," said Janet Ryducha, a broker with Preferred Properties.
LAST March John Delner moved out of Darien after his divorce and into a 3-bedroom colonial at Getner Farms in Norwalk, where homes range in price from $240,000 to $270,000. "It was affordable in my circumstances," he said. "I can stay in the same golf club and see my friends and I have room for my children to visit. The big thing in coming to Norwalk is higher taxes -- but properties are priced lower than elsewhere in the area."
Taxes vary by about $5 per thousand dollars of assessment in Norwalk's nine taxing districts, and while the mill rate, or amount of tax for each $1,000 of assessed value, is the third highest in the state, there is sufficient compensation in price to satisfy most buyers.
Norwalk's 12 elementary schools, four middle schools and two high schools, long regarded as inferior by many home buyers, have improved academically. But average SAT scores of 477 in math and 483 for verbal are still below state figures of 507 in math and 509 for verbal.
"The top 10 percent of high school graduates score in the high SAT ranges," said Dr. Susan B. Weinberger, spokeswoman for the Norwalk school system. "This year we had a National Merit Scholarship semi-finalist and six commendations."
Various steps taken to bring underperforming students up to par include a mentor program in which 800 employes from 44 area corporations invite students, one on one, to spend one day a week at the company. A school-to-work program that creates internships for high school juniors and seniors, college-bound or not, is based on their special interests and coordinated with schoolwork. Both programs have been replicated around the state, even in Gold Coast towns, according to Dr. Weinberger.
Academically and artistically gifted children are placed in special programs from grade 3, and the citywide curriculum contains a comprehensive music and art component through grade 12. Brien McMahon High School offers a year of courses in Japanese history, language and culture, culminating in a two-week trip to Japan. A large number of students from other Fairfield County towns are enrolled in the program.
Norwalk has no private schools, but there are several in adjacent towns.
Inviting to many buyers is Norwalk's emergence as a lively city, with two multiscreen movie theaters, an art moviehouse, dozens of restaurants catering to a range of pocketbooks and palates and the boutiques, restaurants nightclubs and art galleries of the Historic District on Washington Street. Other draws are the Maritime Aquarium, a symphony orchestra, the Norwalk Museum (a treasury of city history and products including the original Raggedy Ann and Andy), two large beaches and 1,200 acres of parklands, ballfields and playgrounds.
Oak Hills, an 18-hole municipal golf course, charges residents $14 and $15 a day for weekday or weekend play, and $4 or $5 an hour to use one of 40 city tennis courts.
Cove Marina and Rex Marina, typical of many public marinas, fill up quickly for the coming season, charging from $45 to $90 a foot for boats of various sizes and around $40 for winter storage. The city maintains a boat launch at Veterans Park.
The city's several private clubs include Silvermine and Shorehaven golf clubs and the Norwalk and Rowayton yacht clubs.
Norwalk Brewhouse -- a microbrewery, restaurant and brew museum -- opened a year ago near the historic district for lunch and dinner, serving its own beers. Dinner for two runs around $50. Amberjacks on Washington Street features dry aged steak and seafood. Dinner for two is about $60.
ONE of several new South Norwalk nightclubs is called The Loft, where cigars, 20 flavors of martinis and a live band are the principal attractions.
Commuters have a choice of three railroad stations and easy access to the Merritt Parkway, Route 7 and Interstate 95. The South Norwalk station redevelopment was completed last year at a cost of $13 million.
A total of 50,860 people, more than half Norwalk's population, hold cards at the city's four libraries. Residents get their area news from The Hour, a daily newspaper, The Norwalk News, a weekly, and the WNLK-AM and WEFX-FM radio stations.
Each year thousands of visitors flock to the Scottish Games in July, the SoNo Arts Festival in August and the Oyster Festival in September. Antique car shows, one of the largest in-water boat show on the East Coast, hot-air-balloon races and sailboat races, concerts in the parks and on the beaches are other seasonal events. At the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion, a Victorian-Gothic National Landmark, splendidly restored, residents and others may attend lectures, concerts and outdoor festivals.
Norwalk was founded on land bought from the Indians by Roger Ludlowe in 1640 and declared a town by the General Court of Connecticut in 1651. "The British burned 135 patriots' homes and two churches there during the Revolutionary War, but the patriots burned Loyalist homes in retaliation and used traitors' portraits for target practice," said Ralph Bloom, the city's historian.
The city thrived on agriculture for two centuries, until the arrival of the New York & New Haven Railroad in the mid-19th century, stimulating manufacturing and leading to the construction of summer homes for wealthy New Yorkers. "We had a huge hat industry," said Mr. Bloom, "downtown shops and theaters."
But from the late 50's through the 70's South Norwalk became a haven for drugs and prostitution, damaging the city's reputation. And according to Mr. Bloom, the ubiquitous automobile encouraged people to work, shop and ultimately live elsewhere.
Beginning in the 80's, however, the redevelopment of South Norwalk turned this around. Residents and shops returned as drug dealers and prostitutes all but vanished. And the neighborhood's prosperity has helped bring about the city's recovery.

ISLAND HOPPING: An archipelago of 16 islands strung across Long Island Sound off the Norwalk shore range in size from the 1.1-acre Ghost Island that is mostly submerged at high tide, to 70.2-acre Chimon Island, containing the only heron rookery in New England. Discovered in 1614 by Adrian Block, for whom Block Island was named, several islands are now privately owned as summer or year-round homes. A nonoperating 125-year-old lighthouse on the National Register of Historic Places and the Stewart B. McKinney Wildlife Refuge on 52.8 acres make Sheffield Island a popular spot for summer picnics, boaters, sightseers and environmental cruise stopovers. An 1835 house on Tavern Island, still in private hands, was rented in 1938 to Lillian Hellman, who is said to have written "The Little Foxes" there. In 1958 it was purchased by the late impresario Billy Rose, who embellished it with fine art and gave extravagant parties.
