HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
On East End, a Transfer Tax for Land Preservation?

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
SHOULD property buyers on the East End be required to pay a 2 percent tax on a portion of the purchase price as a contribution to future land preservation?
If state enabling legislation is adopted, the five easternmost towns would each have the option of putting that question to voters next year. A bill to be submitted to the Legislature in January is being drafted. 
 The enabling legislation that would permit a so-called real estate transfer tax would apply only to East Hampton, Southampton, Riverhead, Southold and Shelter Island. Revenues would be placed in a special fund that could be used only for land acquisition or other preservation measures, such as the purchase of development rights.
Each town would hold a separate referendum and a majority of voters would have to approve before a town board could impose the tax.
With the revival of the real estate market, farmland on the East End is being developed at an alarming rate, said Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork, a nonprofit land preservation organization in Bridgehampton, which is advocating the transfer tax.
"The history and the character of an important part of Long Island are being lost," he said. "We need a funding coordination strategy and a land protection strategy, or the East End as we know it will be gone forever."
Although the transfer-tax proposal has the backing of many East End business and civic leaders, there is concern that such a measure could set a precedent and be used elsewhere in the state for other purposes.
"The only way we see not opposing this is if it's really restricted to the East End and preserving the East End," said Robert A. Wieboldt, executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute. "But opening up this new funding source in general is a frightening proposition."
The proposed legislation, which would expire in 2007, could generate $80 million to $100 million over the 10 years if adopted in all five towns, said Mr. McDonald of the Group for the South Fork. And, he added, it could raise enough money to protect 10,000 acres either through outright purchase or through the purchase of development rights.
Under a new law that allows municipalities to pay for land purchases in installments over several years some land could be immediately purchased and paid for out of future income, Mr. McDonald said.
Towns would appoint advisory committees to select the most appropriate land, with emphasis placed on scenic vistas and maintaining contiguous farmland.
A previous bill affecting only East Hampton was approved by the State Legislature in August. Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed it on the basis that it should have applied to all the East End towns and that it should have exempted farmland sold to farmers and land already protected by conservation easements. The bill now being drafted includes those provisions.
To protect low- to middle-income buyers, part of the purchase price would be exempted from the tax, with the amount left up to each town. This year's East Hampton bill would have exempted the first $250,000 on improved property and the first $100,000 on vacant land.
In such a case, the buyer of a house costing $250,000 or less would pay no tax, the buyer of a $500,000 house would incur a $5,000 tax and the tax on vacant land selling for $500,000 would be $8,000.
"There is so much going on so quickly, that if we don't get in and buy open space in a hurry we'll lose the battle and we'll become the same place as everywhere else," said Edwin M. Schwenk, the co-director with Richard Amper of a nonprofit organization in Southampton called East End Forever. Mr. Schwenk formerly was executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute.
To illustrate the pressure of development, he noted that the number of permits issued for new construction in the Town of Southampton and its incorporated villages increased from just 380 in 1993 to 1,344 in 1994. Last year, 3,009 permits were issued in the five towns -- 1,621 permits in Southampton alone.
"Out here is the last bastion of the way it was," said Paul Brennan, vice president of Sotheby's International Realty in Bridgehampton. "There is no place else to go, so if people want to maintain the rural character that this area has enjoyed all these years, something has to be done."
WHILE maintaining that they are not against land preservation, critics of the proposed tax call it unfair because it singles out a small group of people -- new buyers.
"I've always supported land conservation," said Fritz Mayer, the owner of Boxwood Realty in Bridgehampton. "But it's the method of paying for it that I am opposing. If I move to California or Utah should I have to pay a tax because I'm moving there? What kind of nonsense is that?"
"It's a soak-the-rich tax," said Richard Pellicane, a Southampton lawyer who organized a successful opposition to a transfer tax in 1984. "And to compound that, you are soaking a class of people from another area. If the objectives are good, then the money should come from the general tax base."
In past years, funds raised locally for open-space acquisition have been derived from a .25 percent sales tax imposed on Suffolk County residents and separate bond issues approved by voters in the five towns. Voters in Southampton and East Hampton, for example, approved $50 million in bond issues over the last eight years. Last year, Southampton voters also approved a special assessment in addition to property taxes.
Nevertheless, more funding sources are needed, said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning group based in Manhattan. "There is so much subdivision activity on the East End that we simply don't have the funds in place right now to stay ahead of the bulldozers on important conservation properties," he said.
Noting that a real estate transfer tax had worked successfully for years in Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Block Island, he said, "People who buy into a resort community are buying an amenity package and part of that package is open space, countryside and farmstands."
Long-term residents have already paid to preserve those amenities, he said, insisting that a transfer tax on buyers was fair. "People are buying in because it's a really nice place," he said, "so they should pay their fair share."
Nantucket was the first place in the nation to create a land bank with a real estate transfer tax. The 2 percent tax in effect since 1985 has so far raised about $37 million and has enabled the town to purchase about 1,600 acres of land, said John D. Pagini, the director of Nantucket's Planning and Economic Development Commission. "It's had a very big effect on the efforts to preserve community character here, which is the reason why it was first proposed," he said.
ALTHOUGH some real estate brokers fear a transfer tax would hurt sales, others say it would have no effect. "People are willing to make a commitment because land and beauty is very important to them," said Michael DeSario, a partner of the Cook Pony Farm brokerage in East Hampton.
Others warn that the downside of taking so much land off the tax rolls is the danger of keeping out people with moderate incomes.
"Every time you add such a tax, you do two things," said William W. Esseks, a Riverhead lawyer. "You increase the cost of land and, by using the money to buy permanent open space, you further increase the cost and reduce access for middle- and lower-income people."
But Stephen M. Jones, director of planning for Suffolk County, said open space programs help preserve the area's way of life. "Historically people of all income groups have lived on the East End and we see these programs as preserving the type of life that has existed out there," he added.
The county has had a farmland preservation program in effect since 1977. Most of the $32 million spent so far has gone to preserve land on the East End where most of the farms are situated. A Farmland Protection Plan adopted by the County Legislature last year recommended increasing the level of spending. The issue of development pressures on the East End will be discussed in public meetings to be held Dec. 6 in Southold High School and Southampton College.
If a transfer tax comes to a vote next year, will local residents support it?
Speaking for Southampton, Town Supervisor Vincent J. Cannuscio said:
"If history is a guide, where environmental matters have been placed before the voters in the Town of Southampton they have overwhelmingly supported them."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1322 words

HEADLINE: RELIGION;
From Different Paths, Muslims Seek Common Ground

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
On Friday afternoons, the parking lot of the new Muslim Center of Middlesex County is often jammed. Once the white-lined spaces are full, the cars double up in the driving lanes.
Inside the brick building, built by Muslims who met in a Piscataway ranch house for the last 10 years, several hundred men pray aloud, together, in the main chamber. Upstairs, a few dozen women, hidden by screens and draped in cloth from head to ankle, silently follow along. Most are Pakistani or Indian immigrants. A few are blue-eyed American converts. There are almost no black worshipers here. 
 This is the face of Islam in New Jersey, the state with the fourth largest Muslim population in the nation.
Islam, which is believed to have at least 5 million adherents in the United States, draws on two main sources in this country: immigration and the heritage of conversion among black Americans. Both are strongly represented in New Jersey, which has at least 37 masjids, or mosques, and more than 20 Islamic schools. Estimates of the number of Muslims in the state range from 200,000 Muslims to 1 million.
Whatever the number, it is growing, with immigration -- from South Asia and other Muslim strongholds -- abreast or ahead of growth through conversion and heredity. And that highlights the gap that often exists between indigenous Muslims and immigrant Muslims, a divide neatly expressed over Labor Day weekend in two national conventions. One, in Secaucus, drew 20,000 Muslims, mainly black; the other, in Chicago, drew 22,000, mainly immigrants and their descendants.
"That definitely pulled some people who would have come to Secaucus," said Ayesha K. Mustafaa, the editor of the Muslim Journal, a Chicago-based national weekly newspaper serving black Muslims. "There is some talk to trying to have them together next time."
Part of the separation has to do with the Nation of Islam. Many Muslims, black and immigrant, see its tenets, including its central idea of black supremacy, as antithetical to orthodox Islam. The organization, founded by Elijah Mohammad in 1933, split after his death in 1975. His son has taken the larger faction, now called the Muslim American Society, in the direction of orthodox Sunni Islam, while the Rev. Louis Farrakhan kept the name Nation of Islam for his smaller group and continued its separatist teachings. But many people do not realize that the Nation of Islam is not the mainstream of American black Islam.
That mainstream has a patchwork history. In the 1500's, some Africans imported as slaves were practicing Muslims; Moorish explorers and settlers also brought Islam. A few decades after the Civil War, Edward Blyden encouraged black Americans to turn to Islam. In the early 1900's, Muslim emigres from the Ottoman Empire begin arriving. And in 1913, Newark took a leading spot in the nurturing of Islam in America with the establishment of the Moorish Science Temple of America, which was dedicated to black conversion to Islam. During exactly the years the Nation of Islam was forming, some of the Moorish members, including Muhammad Elzadeen, were studying Sunni Islam in Egypt.
Heshaam Jaabar, 66, an imam in Elizabeth, was an Elzadeen protege. "I did Malcolm X's funeral," he said. "It was we that helped pull Malcolm out of the Nation of Islam."
The civil rights movement, both a cause and an effect of growth in black Islam, indirectly helped bring more Muslim immigrants to the United States. In 1965, with calls for racial equality ringing in its ears, the nation scrapped longstanding immigration policies preferential to Europeans.
Black Americans, coping with the bitter history of slavery and social inequity, have sometimes seen these immigrants as interlopers. W. Deen Mohammed, the son of Elijah Mohammad, found it necessary specifically to combat that attitude. "I have on my mind the way some of you treat immigrant Muslims," he wrote in a book based on his speeches, "Al-Islam Unity and Leadership." "You look for an excuse to write them off. And that is really ugly."
Economic disparity was a clear cause. "Someone comes in and runs the store successfully and does something progressive in the same physical environment that another couldn't progress in," he wrote. "So they are hated simply because they have shown up your bad record. That same weakness may be motivating us to say, 'Brother, don't trust those old Arabs!' "
And, even absent bad feeling, economics can easily separate the immigrant Muslims, who are often professionals, from the struggling black communities in which mosques were often first founded. Immigrant communities sometimes build their own, as with the Muslim Center of Middlesex County. As a result, mosques are often either black or immigrant.
"I don't think its willful," Ms. Mustafaa said. "But where you live dictates where you go to worship. There are economic variants that will always make a difference. And God blesses whom He pleases."
For their part, immigrant Muslims have been slow to acknowledge the leadership of black Muslims or to mingle socially. Zakiudin Sharfi, an imam who came from Pakistan in the late 1970's and who, as chairman of Islamic Educational Services, a religious center based in Mount Holly, visits mosques throughout the state, said few black Muslims knew Arabic as well as immigrants. And in a faith dedicated to heeding and preserving the exact language of the Koran, he said, that is a huge obstacle.
Socially, Imam Sharfi said, there are subtle and powerful gaps that time will bridge. "Immigrants have very strong family backgrounds and are often coming from tribal groups," he said. "They have not undergone industrialization and all these pressures."
Some New Jersey mosques do have blended congregations. In Elizabeth, where the center on Salem Avenue is undergoing renovation, Imam Jaaber said, "We have Egyptians, Afghans, Anglos, Pakistanis and Palestinians."
Jimmy Smalls, an East Orange Councilman who attends a mosque in Irvington, said he was involved in several initiatives to bring black and immigrant Muslims together. One, the Majlis Ashura of New Jersey, is a monthly gathering of Muslim leaders meant to solve problems collectively. "When we meet, there is a mutual respect at the table," he said. "Doesn't matter if you're a white Turk or a black American, or are of an Indian background from the Caribbean or an Arab from Egypt itself."
He said both black and immigrant Muslims were deeply concerned with the problems their teen-age children were facing. The agenda at a recent meeting included a discussion about a proposed state oversight committee composed of three sheiks: one black, one Bangladeshi and one Arab. And he said one of his constituents, Earl Sadiq, with the New Jersey Muslim Business Association, was trying to put together a mini-convention in which successful immigrant business owners would teach black Muslims about enterprise.
Some leaders say the non-Muslim world discriminates between black and immigrant Muslims more than Muslims do.
"We are all Muslims," said Armiya Nu'Man, imam at the Masjid Mohammad in Jersey City. "We look at our immigrant brothers as that, as brothers. They see us as their brothers in the West." But after the World Trade Center bombing, he acknowledged, immigrant Muslims suffered a more painful backlash from the general public. "We've been pretty fortunate," he said, "because they don't look at us with the same eye that they look at the immigrants."
And at the Muslim Center of Middlesex County, the pain of stereotyping was as raw as the eagerness to portray Muslims in a positive light, as a devout people with a faith that could solve America's worse social problems.
"Islam is the most misunderstood religion," Imam Sharfi said. "People think of the long beards; They think maniacs!" Protesting such prejudice, he shook his head and said, "Was it not enough, the Crusades, one after another?"

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2116 words

HEADLINE: And Now, the Next Four Years

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
ON the morning after her narrow re-election victory, Governor Whitman stood before the television cameras, appearing unfazed by her near-defeat and promising to tackle the two problems that dominated the campaign: auto insurance and property taxes.
But two hours later, one floor above her State House office, came the first sign that the Governor could encounter some turbulence pushing her agenda through the Legislature even though her fellow Republicans remain firmly in control. 
 The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, announced that the plan Mrs. Whitman had promoted throughout her campaign to lower auto-insurance rates was dead. The next day, Assembly Speaker Jack Collins agreed. And a few days later, both Republican legislative leaders joined Mrs. Whitman at a State House news conference to announce that a newly created legislative committee, not the Governor, would come up with the way to lower premiums sometime next year.
So began the unofficial start of Governor Whitman'ssecond and final four-year term. Of the eight governors elected since the revised state constitution of 1947 set four-year terms, Mrs. Whitman is the fifth to gain a second term.
What can voters expect from this lame duck who won with only 47 percent of the vote? Will she have the vision to formulate an ambitious agenda and the clout to push it through the Legislature? Since both Mr. Collins and Mr. DiFrancesco are said to be jockeying for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in 2001, will it be Mrs. Whitman's agenda or theirs that will dominate state government over the next four years? What role will a vanquished Democratic Party play: spoiler, deal maker or both? And will her own political ambitions, as yet unclear, draw her focus away from the state, or persuade her to stick close to home?
For now, it appears that the balance of power has tipped a bit toward the Legislature. Unlike Mrs. Whitman, most lawmakers escaped voter wrath over paying the highest auto-insurance rates in the nation. Overall, they fared better on Election Day than the Governor, whose razor-thin victory over the Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, has weakened her political standing within the State House and in the national Republican Party.
But Mrs. Whitman can easily reclaim much of her standing in January when she will have three chances to outline her hopes for a second term in her inaugural address, her annual State of the State speech to the Legislature, and her fifth state budget.
Former Governor Thomas H. Kean, whose two-term administration ended in 1990, said that a second term offered Mrs. Whitman opportunity to impose policies and programs that might not have been politically possible during her first four years. "You don't have to run for re-election," he said. "You don't have to worry about the politics. You can have your own agenda.
"If she comes out of the box with a State of the State address that has some exciting things and you see the popularity cliff moving, the Legislature will come along," he said. "The more the state is with you, the Legislature is with you, too. They don't want to take you on."
Every governor wants to leave a legacy, and lowering auto-insurance premiums is not something historians are likely to cite as a major accomplishment decades from now when they review Mrs. Whitman's tenure. What voters can expect to hear Mrs. Whitman talk about in January, as she formally begins her second term, is education.
Mrs. Whitman said in an interview last week that she hoped her legacy would be that of a Governor who improved education beyond the needs of the State Supreme Court order to resolve the decades-old dispute over the spending disparity between the state's richest and poorest school districts.
In May, the Whitman administration met the court's demand that the state send an extra $248 million to 28 urban school districts. The court has also ordered the state to identify more programs to help students overcome disadvantages and find money to pay for them. Last week, state officials estimated the cost of rebuildings dilapidated school buildings in urban districts alone would be about $1.8 billion.
"I would like to be recognized for having established the best educational system," Mrs. Whitman said. "We will have addressed the court's concerns. We will have gotten the core standards and early childhood education programs in place.
"To me, a solid educational footing helps with all the other problems that we have to deal with, whether it is unemployment or crime," she said. "If people don't have the education, they can't get the jobs. We know the relationship between jobs and crime. So cracking the nut on education is the top priority, not just for the 28 special-needs district, but across the state."
Mrs. Whitman may not wield as much political clout with the Legislature as she did in her first term, but she remains undaunted by all the talk that she will face considerable trouble winning approval of her legislative agenda in her second term.
"We work together well," she said, referring to Mr. Collins and Mr. DiFrancesco. "I don't worry about that."
For the most part, there is agreement among Mrs. Whitman, and the Republican leaders about what challenges need to be addressed, and improving education, lowering auto-insurance rates and reducing property taxes is on everyone's list.
As she starts a second term, however, Mrs. Whitman might find herself, playing more of the role of politician than chief executive if she wants her agenda approved. Lawmakers have long complained that her administration has not been responsive to their needs and concerns They have also said she has not always brought them into the process and consulted with them before announcing major policy initiatives.
"I think it is going to be a little different, but that we will be together, pretty much as we have been," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "I think that the education issue will loom large again, not necessarily around standards, but rather people will be looking for ways to deal with the educational funding system and how it is tied to local property taxes. I think it is our intent, as a group, to address property taxes so that we can provide some kind of financial help."
Mr. DiFrancesco said he expects that there will be more give and take. "If she has ideas, I want to be on board with her," he said. "But I think it is going to be more wide open and that she will be more open to suggestions from us."
Mr. Collins said that he expected much will be accomplished in the coming months. For one thing, he noted, Assembly members are up for re-election in two years, unlike their colleagues in the Senate. "We have a shorter time frame," he said. "We have to be right on top of the program."
Also, Mrs. Whitman may have to bring Democrats to the table for the first time because she may not always be able to rely exclusively on Republican support for her programs. It will be interesting to see if Democrats, who now wield little power in the State House, participate or lay in wait until their next chance to regain control.
Although Mrs. Whitman said that education would be the primary focus, she also said that she was determined to address concerns about local property-tax rates. The state, of course, does not set property tax rates, but more state aid for school districts, for example, could keep rates low.
In her first term, Mrs. Whitman kept state aid to municipalities flat, and increased spending for schools only this year. However, she offered local governments several new tools to control spending, such as making state budget officials available to make recommendations on how local spending could be curtailed.
Now, Mrs. Whitman said, she does not think that an increase in a statewide tax, like the income tax or the sales tax, is what voters want to reduce their property tax bill.
Mrs. Whitman said that she has no "magic solution" to ease the property-tax burden on homeowners. But, she said, there will be no solution until New Jerseyans understand that they will have to be make some tough choices regarding the state's cherished home-rule tradition, before homeowners see some relief.
"If we are going to be serious about property taxes, we have to talk about serious civil service reform," she said. "We have to get serious about sharing services and changing the way we reward municipalities. It is just frightening when you look at all the layers of government that we have. You cannot just nibble around the edges. We have already done a bunch of things that have had an impact, and that is why the rate of increases have gone down, but there is much more to be done."
In New Jersey, she points out, there are 566 municipalities, 21 counties, 611 school districts, 225 local authorities and 188 fire districts.
"One of the consequences of our strong tradition of home rule is that our public services are not always delivered in the most effective or cost-efficient manner possible," she said. "Who pays for the overlapping and overlaying of services? The property taxpayer."
But before tackling property taxes, school financing, and auto insurance, the most immediate problem that Mrs. Whitman and lawmakers have to address is charity care. They need to find up to $400 million a year for hospitals that are required under state law to provide free medical treatment to uninsured people. The current system, which relies heavily on payroll taxes deposited into the state's Unemployment Compensation Fund, expires on Dec. 31. Both business groups and organized labor fiercely oppose continued dependence on this fund, and hospitals are insisting that the state provide them with a permanent financing solution.
There are also other areas of concern that more than a dozen public policy experts identified in interviews last week that range from solving the solid-waste disposal crisis to campaign-finance reform to maintaining strong environmental protection laws to reviving the state's cities.
Then there are relatively new problems that need to be addressed. Tremendous growth in some parts of the state has put new pressures on municipalities to build schools, as well as to cope with traffic congestion along two-lane country roads that were not designed for heavy commuter travel. And how does the state replace disappearing manufacturing jobs that provided good wages and benefits to workers?
"How do we grow our prosperity and how do more people participate in our prosperity?" said Dr. Saul K. Fenster, the president of the New Jersey Institute of Technology. "I believe that an awful lot of this has to do with the maintenance of business in the state, and the growth of small business in the state."
What Mrs. Whitman and lawmakers have not discussed is the prospect that the economic expansion will come to an end. Every challenge facing the state, with the exception of lowering auto-insurance rates, carries a hefty pricetag. The bill for rehabilitating and building new schools across the state stands at almost $10 billion, according to one estimate last week.
During Mrs Whitman's first term, a strong economy poured a steady stream of unanticipated tax dollars into state coffers that economists say will dry up as soon as the state hits an inevitable economic downturn.
Then Mrs. Whitman and Republican lawmakers will be faced with the prospect of tearing programs apart rather than proposing new ones.
"We are going to have a recession sometime in the next four years," said James Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy at Rutgers University. "The national expansion is now 80 months long. The average post-war expansion is 50 months. We are two and a half years beyond the average expansion. There will be a downturn, which will then put us under real strain.
"What normally happens is that state revenues fall short of the budgetary requirements," he said. "That means means raising taxes or massive cuts. And that is going to be a crisis when it comes."
For now, the state's economy is adding more jobs. And if some of Mrs. Whitman's advisers have their way, she will be out of the State House before a state fiscal crisis looms. They would like to see her run in two years against Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who vows he will run for another term. Then, maybe, think about running for President in 2004 or 2008.
But after her bruising campaign this fall, Mrs. Whitman may not be looking forward to the prospect of another race. And before any talk resumes about Mrs. Whitman's national ambitions, she first needs to take care of business at home.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Newark's Science Park Takes Another Step Forward

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH $60 million in state financing and leases from three tenants in place, plans are moving forward on a 161,600-square-foot medical research building that will anchor the second phase of development at the 50-acre University Heights Science Park in Newark's Central Ward.
Half of the $66 million International Center for Public Health, which is expected to be completed in two years, will house the new headquarters of the Public Health Research Institute, a private organization now based in Manhattan that conducts research on infectious diseases. 
 It will also be home to the National Tuberculosis Center and the department of microbiology and molecular genetics, both part of the Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.
The university is one of the four institutions of higher education in the city's core that 12 years ago began discussing turning the ramshackle neighborhood in their backyard into a university-related science park. The others are Rutgers University, the New Jersey Institute of Technology and Essex County Community College.
The three entities in the International Center for Public Health track, treat and seek to prevent the spread of infectious diseases, from tuberculosis to AIDS. The existing two smaller buildings totaling 45,000 square feet, which were completed last fall, house offices, the New Jersey Center for Biomaterials and Medical Devices and incubator space for 17 start-up technology companies. They alsoinclude a day-care center for 100 children.
The newbuilding is to rise on three acres -- the site is yet to be determined --within a 14-acre area bounded by Lock, Warren and Norfolk Streets and Central Avenue that will be acquired under the state financing. The land acquisition will cost $12 million.
Dennis E. Lower, executive director of University Science Park Inc., the nonprofit entity created in 1992 to develop the park with the city, community and private industry as partners, said the remaining $18 million needed for the project was expected to be secured from public and private sources by next fall.
The $350-million park is intended to draw emerging high-technology and biotechnology companies to Newark by forging links to the 35,000-student, faculty and employee population of its academic neighbors and, in the process, promote economic development.
The park, which will need additional financing for land acquisition and construction, could take as long as 15 years to build. And the project will include demolition of commercial buildings and housing.
Eventually, the park will consist of one million square feet of office, laboratory and incubator space, as well as housing and shops.
If fully realized, the park could produce 6,000 jobs, including 700 at the International Public Health Center, Mr. Lower said.
EXPLAINING the significance of the new building, the result of 16 months of discussion among industry, local, state and Federal Government leaders, Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the University of Medicine and Dentistry, said: "This gives us credibility and proves a science park can be created in Newark."
Apart from the building itself, the park also will gain something Mr. Lower said it never had before -- the ability to market 11 acres of developable land on which three more structures could be built, with up to 150,000 square feet of space each.
"This project," he said, "breaks the park wide open for private investment."
Before year's end, Mr. Lower said, a developer also will be named to turn two blocks adjacent to the new building into up to 80 new and renovated mixed-income residences. And by next spring a site, outside of but close to the park, will be selected for the science and technology high school, which is expected to have 800 students.
The announcement of the International Public Health Center is the latest bit of good news for Newark, whose slow revitalization has recently gained momentum. Glenn A. Grant, the city's Business Administrator, said that about $1 billion had been invested in Newark in the last four and a half years in developments that are beginning to bear fruit.
Last month the $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center was completed, and ground was broken on Oct. 16 for a 100,000-square-foot speculative industrial building that will be called the South Ward Industrial Park. Two weeks later the St. Barnabas Medical Center of Livingston announced plans to build a commercial laundry on an undetermined site, which will employ 400 people. Additionally, hundreds of mixed-income residences have gone up in Newark's neighborhoods.
"The Science Park project, like the others, marry housing with jobs and economic development," said Mr. Grant. "To revitalize the city we cannot have a single-development oasis, but communities where people can live, work and shop."
There are 140 such research parks in the nation, including two others in New Jersey, according to the Association of University Related Research Parks, a trade group in Washington, D.C. The two others in New Jersey are the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center in Plainsboro and South Brunswick and the 50-acre state-sponsored Technology Center of New Jersey in North Brunswick.
The majority of such parks are in suburban centers, so launching one in Newark, with its checkered redevelopment history, carried its share of risks. But the sponsors felt in 1985, as they do now, that the city's central location and mass-transit links, with access to Manhattan, combined with the $100 million in research done annually by the universities would attract science-based companies to the park.
THOSE factors are what attracted the Public Health Research Institute, said Lewis M. Weinstein, president of the 56-year-old biomedical research group. It will relocate from the 60,000 square feet it has occupied for 30 years on First Avenue, at East 26th Street, in Manhattan to 80,000 square feet at the new building.
"We needed to grow," said Mr. Weinstein. "And the advantage of the Newark building is that it provides us with the space and the intellectual environment we need in a location close to New York."
The institute now employs 115 people, a number that is expected to grow to about 200 in the next five years, he said. Other factors, he added, were the potential for interaction between his group and the building's other tenants and the state's $60 million commitment to the science park.
The National Tuberculosis Center and the department of microbiology and molecular genetics, both of which also need to expand, will fill the remaining space in the building. They will occupy 33,600 and 48,000 square feet, respectively.
Under the terms of the financial agreement, the state will provide $18 million in grants and $42 million in loans, the latter raised through the sale of bonds. The state loans initially will be repaid through lease payments, which will be kept at or below the $30-a-square-foot market rate for new lab space, said Mr. Lower.
At the end of its 12-year lease, the Public Health Research Institute will purchase its space for $12 million. The other two tenants will rent for 30 years and then assume ownership of their space. Since his group will retain ownership of the land tenants will also pay a yet-to-be-determined ground-lease payment, Mr. Lower said.
Science- and technology-related companies are considered a growth engine for the state, whose large concentration of pharmaceutical firms conduct 85 percent of the industry's research, providing a strong resource for young companies. The state is home to some 500 biotechnology, biomedical and health-care-related firms as well as 6,000 software and information technology concerns, according to the New Jersey Technology Council, a Princeton-based nonprofit trade group.
In a statement, State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr. said that the International Center for Public Health would "enhance New Jersey's reputation for being a leader in the field of biomedical research."
"It not only provides an international research magnet," said Mr. Lower of University Heights Science Park Inc. "But it primes the pump and sets up a level playing field for us to compete head to head for our share of technology-based companies in the region."

HEADLINE: Report Projects Fuel Savings From More Efficient Vehicles

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The average New Jersey family could save more than $500 a year in gasoline costs if tighter fuel-efficiency standards were in place, according to a study by environmental groups.
Automakers countered that the report was flawed because the bigger vehicles that American drivers prefer would become prohibitively expensive under the standard advocated in the study. 
 The report, released on Thursday by the Environmental Working Group and the Surface Transportation Policy Project, based its savings estimates on standards of 45 miles a gallon for cars and 34 miles a gallon for light trucks like sport utilities, mini-vans and pickup trucks. Current standards average 27.5 miles a gallon for cars and 20.7 miles a gallon for light trucks.
Congress annually sets the Government's fuel economy standard, known as the corporate average fuel economy.
The study said the higher mileage requirements would cut nearly half the amount of gases needed to reduce emissions to 1990 levels between the years 2008 and 2012 -- a goal that the Clinton Administration plans to take to next month's global warming summit in Japan.
Critics of the Administration effort say it will drive gasoline prices skyrocketing.
But the report said the average family in New Jersey would save $1,975 with more fuel-efficient vehicles over a 10-year period of phasing in the new standards. The national average was calculated at $2,160.
Once the standards were fully in place, the average annual savings in New Jersey would be $540 a family from current annual spending, which averages $1,039. Projected savings in New Jersey range from $460 a year in the Atlantic City area to $648 in the Trenton area.
"American automakers have fought virtually every Government-mandated improvement in automobile safety, fuel efficiency and pollution control proposed or adopted over the past 30 years," the report said. "In every case they were wrong. And in fact, Detroit automakers now brag about the benefits of safety, fuel efficiency and pollution control features that they once vehemently opposed."
Automakers say a larger car that gets 45 miles a gallon would be too expensive to make in today's market.
Some smaller cars do exceed 40 miles a gallon, but they account for fewer than 1 percent of vehicle sales.
"We would be at those levels if it was cost-effective and efficient to be there," said Mike Stanton of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, talking about larger cars that get better mileage. "There's no free lunch."
Car companies also say they must take into account the safety concerns of making lighter-weight vehicles that would get better mileage but fare worse in accidents.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The High Cost of Education Means Fixing Schools, Too

BYLINE: By Abby Goodnough; Abby Goodnough reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Shortly after Jack Collins became Speaker of the Assembly last year, he proposed raising the cigarette tax to provide $6 billion for repairing dozens of old schools and building new ones. The Assembly went along with the plan, even though Republicans are reluctant to raise taxes of any kind these days. But the Senate rejected the proposal, and Governor Whitman offered only lukewarm support.
Now, as part of its response to the State Supreme Court's order to end the disparity between rich and poor school districts, the Whitman administration acknowledged last week that at least $1.8 billion was needed -- and soon -- to refurbish school buildings in the state's 28 poorest districts. 
 No sooner were legislators gasping over that news than Mrs. Whitman announced that the cost would actually be significantly higher. While the court has ordered the state to address the needs of urban districts, the Governor and Republican legislative leaders recognize the political impossibility of ignoring their suburban counterparts.
Education has long been an issue that decides the political fate of lawmakers who represent the suburbs, where tax-weary voters want top-notch schools but do not want to foot the entire bill for maintaining them. Last fall, when the Legislature was scrambling to pass a court-ordered school financing law that would equalize spending between the richest and poorest districts, suburban legislators went to great lengths to make sure the schools in their districts would not be shortchanged.
And the Governor, who was facing re-election, repeatedly assured suburban voters that in meeting the court order, she would not take money away from their schools.
Mrs. Whitman may not have to worry about running for governor again, but she said last week that education would be the primary focus of her second term. She said she wanted her legacy to be a better quality of education for all the state's 1.2 million schoolchildren. Both Mr. Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco have long been committed to addressing the needs of all 600 districts. They have a particular interest in doing so because both are considering running for Governor in four years.
"As a state, we cannot limit our view to only 28 districts," Mrs. Whitman said on Tuesday, one day after the Department of Education released its report on construction needs in the poorest districts. "As Governor, I have to be concerned about the infrastructure needs of every school, not just the special-needs districts." If Mrs. Whitman and the Senate had gone along with Mr. Collins's proposal last year, they might have avoided this problem.
Mr. Collins's plan would have provided $2 billion for urban schools, with the remaining $4 billion targeted to school districts across the state.
Now, thanks to the court order, they have no choice but to come up with another plan. The first sign that Mrs. Whitman was eager to do so came last month, when she ordered the Education Department to conduct a study assessing the needs of every district. And last week, with the department's report and another, from the Public Affairs Research Institute, hot off the press, legislators turned their attention to the problem once again.
With cost estimates for school construction needs statewide ranging from $3 billion to $16.4 billion, taxpayers are facing what could be one of the largest capital investments in the state's history. Where will the money come from?
Mrs. Whitman said last week that the state would seriously have to consider issuing bonds to pay for school construction, a move that would provide a large amount of money but sharply increase the state's debt. Senator Robert J. Martin, a Republican who is to become chairman of the Senate Education Committee in January, said bonds were the surest source of revenue, especially if the construction is to be completed in 10 years or less.
"It always becomes problematic when you tie up revenue and make decisions for future generations of taxpayers," he said. "But with education, it's not a problem that's going to go away."
Senator Robert Littell, a Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he opposed using bonds to pay for school construction because it would increase the state's debt too drastically. He said he would rather depend on the annual growth in state revenues to pay for school construction from year to year, a questionable solution, given that the state's economy is always in flux.
As for Mr. Collins, he said he would once again consider raising the cigarette tax to help pay for school construction. But both Mr. Littell and Mr. Martin said that proposal was still unpalatable. Mr. Martin said he did not think it was appropriate to build schools with revenue from cigarette sales because there was no link between smoking and education. He said it would be wiser to use such revenue for a health-related program, like charity care in the state's hospitals.
Mr. Collins begged to differ.
"The link is that it's money," he said.

LENGTH: 765 words

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Over There, Monetary Union. Over Here, an Opportunity.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN HAKIM; Jonathan Hakim is a managing director of Lehman Brothers.

 BODY:
WITH less than 14 months to go before European monetary union, much of the American business and investment community has still not awakened to the big changes and opportunities it will create.
A single currency will bring with it a fundamental reshaping of Europe's financial markets. The markets themselves will become much bigger. To keep deficits under control -- a continuing requirement of monetary union -- governments will be obliged to cut social spending, thus opening the door for private pension funds. This will lead to a substantial new class of equity investors. In turn, these investors will bolster European stock markets, which, apart from Britain's, remain less than half the size of the United States' market in relation to their economies. 
 The new unified market for government bonds will rival the United States Treasury market, both in size and liquidity. The euro will become the world's second reserve currency, behind the dollar. And European investors will be obliged to shift away from their traditional focus on currencies and look instead at credit risk -- leading to the growth of a European junk bond market.
Over all, the new single market will look much more like the United States market, complete with a powerful central bank whose every move will be scrutinized for its impact on world interest rates.
The coming events provide an enormous opportunity for American banks and fund managers to capitalize on their strength and experience. The Americans, after all, have the advantages of a fiercely competitive and professional fund-management industry, the most sophisticated trading expertise and a long familiarity with assessing credit risk in bond markets.
The opportunity in Europe is especially timely because monetary union will create its own difficulties for European banks. Europe is "overbanked" -- bloated retail branch networks mean that their costs are high and profitability low. Many banks are still state-owned. Despite rigid employment laws, which make layoffs expensive, a wave of American-style mergers is under way. Only last week, the third-largest banks in the Netherlands and Belgium agreed to combine to form Europe's 12th-biggest bank. Similar consolidation is occurring in insurance and other financial services.
While the big American investment banks are strengthening their operations, many people in the investment community still doubt that monetary union will occur on time -- or that it will prove very durable. But Europe's leaders have invested too much political capital to contemplate failure. Moreover, the French and German economies are beginning to pick up steam. Exports are growing strongly. (The mark has quietly fallen by more than 10 percent against the dollar in the last 12 months.) As growth resumes, deficits will drop, unemployment will start falling next year and the transition to the new currency will be far less painful than now seems possible.
The single currency will bring a new market for European pension plans and the expertise to manage them; the big customers will initially be large corporations. Monetary union will also open up retail financial products like mutual funds, insurance and credit cards. Until now, currency barriers have enabled local operators to maintain cozy cartels. The new market will offer economies of scale and the potential for high-volume, low-cost direct selling.
Europe's retail investors, accustomed to a steady diet of bond funds and simple savings accounts, remain conservative and relatively unsophisticated. The equity culture will eventually take hold, but it will require patience and local marketing partners to overcome popular prejudice on the Continent against British- and American-style financial products. An avalanche of junk mail is unlikely to yield results.
A FEW American companies -- retail brokers and investment managers -- are already betting on this vision of the future. And the local European knowledge that they acquire will also serve them well back home. As Europe's capital markets unify, the new-found liquidity and transparency will make them much more accessible to American investors. The rise in European stock markets this year (in terms of local currencies) has been significant. Even after the recent selloff, the German market is up 37 percent; the Dutch market, 39 percent, and even the beleaguered French market, 23.5 percent.
With a big single market, a wave of corporate consolidation and the start of an economic upswing, the potential for continuing gains in Europe will be hard to ignore.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1556 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lexus GS 300 and GS 400;
Now What the Devil Has Gotten Into Lexus?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
A COUPLE of years ago, over dinner with Jim Press, the general manager of Lexus, the conversation turned to passion -- the kind stirred up by a handful of high-performance luxury cars.
While complimenting Mr. Press on the quality and technology of his products, I pointed out that they arouse little passion, a sentiment I share with many people who test-drive new cars. While Lexus models are fine machines, I said, they seem cold -- bordering on sterile -- and lack the soul of the German cars on which they are modeled. 
 With a knowing smile, Mr. Press politely nodded, indicating that he understood my point. He knew something I did not: My criticisms were being addressed. The 1998 GS 300 and GS 400 were in the works.
Indeed, the two new GS models represent a radical departure from any past Lexus. Every bit as luxurious and comfortable as the flagship LS 400, the GS models are also packed with the power and spirit to go head-to-head with the E-Class Mercedes and, even more directly, the BMW 5-Series. More than simply competitive, the GS 400 outperforms its rivals on virtually every count.
To herald this new breed, which began arriving in dealerships in October, Lexus is running a mischievous advertising campaign that draws on the Gothic imagery and Elizabethan syntax of Shakespeare. The GS models stir up a tempest wherever they go, whether on a gentle tree-lined road or an otherwise calm lake. Using as its theme the line "Something wicked this way comes," from "Macbeth," the ads are aimed at an intellectual baby-boom crowd whose youthful vocabulary used "wicked" to mean awesomely good.
After spending nearly two weeks driving both GS models, I have to agree that they are ba-a-a-d -- in the good sense, that is.
The GS 300 replaces an easily overlooked model of the same name. That car sold poorly because of its tepid performance, lack of personality and hefty sticker price.
The new GS 300 goes directly against the six-cylinder BMW 528i and Mercedes E320; the GS 400 faces off with the V8-powered BMW 540i and the Mercedes E430, which will replace the E420 next year. Both GS models are priced between the entry-luxury ES 300 and top-of-the-line LS 400. But the GS models are aimed at an altogether different buyer than the people who have driven Lexuses until now.
The buyers are likely to be younger than LS 400 owners. They wear Armani instead of Brooks Brothers, one Lexus executive said.
Lexus seems to be hitting its mark. In the new models' first month on the market, 3,500 have been sold, putting them well on the way to meeting an annual sales target of 25,000.
The GS 300 and GS 400 sit on an all-new, rear-drive Lexus platform. Only the battery, the basic front suspension components and the engine crankshaft are carried over from the previous GS 300, Lexus says. The general proportions and profile, however, are similar to that of the previous car but are bolder and more aggressive. Six inches shorter than the car they replace, the GS 300 and GS 400 have virtually no front and rear overhangs, which give them a compact, ground-hugging, muscular look. In fact, the GS models have the same general proportions and stance as the BMW 5-Series.
Still, I was surprised by how much attention the test car, a royal blue GS 400, attracted. On a sunny Saturday afternoon in the ritzy Detroit suburb of Birmingham, Mich., a car full of young men in their early 20's honked and hooted in approval as I wheeled into a parking spot. Earlier that day, my GS 400 had caught the eye of a 30-something man, who quickly pulled a U-turn in his Lexus SC 300 coupe to follow me into my friend's driveway for a closer look.
Inside, the new GS has more space than the car it replaces, including additional headroom and legroom. The five-passenger sedan is swathed in creamy leather and trimmed in real walnut, as one would expect in a Lexus. All of the luscious luxuries are there, too: comfortable 10-way power front bucket seats, dual climate controls, express up-and-down windows, an outstanding sound system, an integrated electronic opener for garage doors and security gates, and an automatic hydrocarbon air pollution sensor that switches the air to re-circulate when certain levels of outside air contamination are detected. A satellite navigation system is optional and features touch-screen controls for navigation as well as for adjustments to the climate and audio systems.
The location and feel of the controls were first rate. My favorite feature was the optional CD changer in the glove box. It eliminated the bother of loading a trunk-mounted changer before starting a trip, yet left plenty of storage space in the glove box.
The instrument panel is innovative and functional, with the gauges housed in three circular indentations. The gauge markings and needles are backlit for a three-dimensional quality. Unusually bright and constantly illuminated, the gauges are easy to see in any kind of light, automatically dimming when you drive through a tunnel or parking deck.
The GS models feature dual air bags that deploy with less force than their predecessors to help prevent air-bag injuries, particularly to small women who sit close to the steering wheel. Side-impact air bags are integrated into the front seats.
The trunk, at 14.8 cubic feet, is generous, larger than that of the previous GS 300 or the current BMW 5-Series.
The GS models, particularly the GS 400, differ most from other Lexuses in the way they perform. While sitting at the wheel, you get an overwhelming sense that you are in a Mercedes, and once on the move, the Lexus shows the responsiveness of a BMW. Only the Lexus actually performs better, according to the numbers.
No matter which enthusiast magazine has conducted the testing -- Car and Driver, Road & Track or Motor Trend -- the numbers show the GS 400 outperforming the 5-Series and the E420 in virtually every category. It races from 0 to 60 m.p.h. in about 6 seconds. As for braking, the GS's world-class stopping distance is shorter than that of a Ferrari F355, Motor Trend notes.
And the GS 400 certainly feels quick and agile. The car is powered by a new generation of Lexus's 4-liter, 32-valve V8, rated at a whopping 300 horsepower and 310 foot-pounds of torque. It is the first V8 to be equipped with continuously variable valve timing, a system that controls combustion so that the car has both a strong takeoff from a standing start as well as solid power in passing-lane maneuvers at highway speeds. Yet the overall fuel economy of about 24 miles per gallon is respectable for a car of this substance.
While BMW still offers a manual transmission on the 5-Series, the GS 300 and 400 do not. Lexus figures that too few buyers would choose one. Instead of a manual, the GS 400 offers a clutchless five-speed automatic that can be shifted manually. The setup is similar to that of Formula One race cars and Porsche's Tiptronic. The console-mounted shifter has the normal park, reverse, neutral and drive positions. A second gate, marked "M" for manual, allows the driver to shift by pushing buttons on the spokes of the steering wheel. The button to downshift is on the front of the spoke; the button to upshift is on the back. I fooled with it for a while, but found the car shifted before I would have anyway, so I simply left the shifter in "D."
Though not nearly as brawny as the GS 400, the GS 300 also performs with spirit. It is powered by a 3-liter twin-cam engine that produces 225 horsepower and 220 foot-pounds of torque. It, too, has continuously variable valve timing and gets an overall economy rating of about 25 m.p.h.
Both GS models have standard anti-lock brakes and traction control. Tied into both systems is vehicle skid control, similar to Mercedes' ESP and Cadillac's Stabilitrak. The system senses whether the vehicle is behaving as the driver wishes. If it is not, the system transparently employs the anti-lock brakes and traction control to help avoid skids and spins in quick lane changes or emergency situations.
At the wheel of both GS models, I had the sense that these cars were firmly planted on all fours, in keeping with their ground-hugging look. Both had plenty of grip in hard cornering, yet maintained Lexus's signature smooth ride.
A GS buyer can expect a nearly bulletproof car. Lexus models are recognized year after year for outstanding quality and long-term durability in surveys conducted by J. D. Power & Associates.
In addition to the improvements and the new-found personality, the GS 300 costs nearly $9,000 less than the car it replaces. starting at $37,395 including delivery. The GS 400 starts at $45,295. Options on both cars are few: a power moonroof, CD changer, upgraded tires and the $2,300 navigation system.
Never before have I had so much fun in a Lexus. While I haven't driven the 1998 Mercedes-Benz E430 due out next year, I'd easily select the Lexus GS 400 over the previous Mercedes E420 for performance and personal comfort. Would I pick it over the BMW 5-Series? That's a tougher choice. The 5-Series has a rich sporting heritage that Lexus lacks. Still, the GS combines outstanding sports-car performance with luxury sedan comfort and practicality at a competitive price. It is a wicked combination indeed.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A Lexus as you like it.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1831 words

HEADLINE: Tea and Conversation 101

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
"OH my goodness, lucky me!" Judith Re exclaimed. "Everyone is coming!" The 15 children before her stared.
"Can you learn and have fun at the same time?" she chirped. The boys shifted in their chairs, looking miserable. 
 Welcome to of "A Day of Social Savvy With Judith Re" at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. For the next 11 hours these children, ages 8 to 12, would learn everything from table manners to flower arranging to the art of small talk, led by Miss Judith, as she prefers to be called. As her charges eyed each other and sipped their cocoa, she watched them.
"I can see now who's a leader, who needs assistance," she said in an aside, dropping the chirp while three girls played once-twice-three-shoot at the end of the table.
"There's a method to this," she continued. "It's like going on a blind date with 15 people."
The cost for the complete day is $245, though some children come courtesy of grandparents or aunts if their own parents can't afford it. The program is now in its 10th year, and Miss Judith said, "No one even bats an eye at the cost -- it's a proven product."
In fact, she adds, the current demand for her services is so great that she would need to clone herself to meet it. The reason may be the booming economy when people have time and money for the niceties, she said, or perhaps it's that so many children are growing up in homes where both parents work and neither can supervise mealtimes.
But when these parents want to travel with their children or present them to long-distance grandparents during the holidays, they want them -- somehow -- to know how to do the right thing.
Though Miss Judith used to conduct the program nationally, she now has children of her own and spends the majority of her time teaching socially challenged corporate executives, both American and Japanese. Her book, "Social Savvy" (Fireside, $11), is in its seventh printing.
As the children finished their cocoa, Miss Judith walked behind their chairs. With her black bangs and lacquered flip, she looks a little French, a little proper, but not quite forbidding. Even though she addresses the group as "ladies and gentlemen," she makes liberal use of "honey' and sweetheart" as well.
Though this Saturday's participants were mostly from the Boston area, Jessica Johnson, 11, and her sister, Diana, 8, came from Eagle Springs, N.C., where they are schooled at home.
Erin McGaffigan, 8, of Groton, Mass., was there with her cousins Megan and Shauna Twohig of Stoneham, Mass. "Our grandmother is into tea," Erin explained. "She thought if we came here, we'd have better manners."
Miss Judith called for attention. "Ladies and gentlemen," she began. "Today we will be learning about social savvy, which means respect, responsibility, sensitivity and compromise. It's about treating other people as you want to be treated yourself. I believe children should be seen and heard. Today is about being heard."
Everyone listened closely. "First, we will be taking a tour of the hotel," she said. "Ladies first, then gentlemen." As she led them out, the boys dutifully hung back. The girls were thrilled, each reveling in the chance to be Eloise for a day.
The tour continued through the dining room, lobby, boardroom and ballroom. Then it was time for flower arranging. Gathered around a long table strewn with flowers, each child was given a bubble bowl. The girls worked quickly and intently, cutting the stems to fit the bowl. The boys' stems were all longer, especially Dan Adair's. "It's not stable," he warned as Miss Judith picked it up.
"It's an architectural delight," she said cheerfully.
"It's an architectural dilemma," Dan, 12, retorted.
Miss Judith smiled gamely. "I think it's a high-maintenance floral arrangement," she said, setting it down.
Sam Barcelo, 11, moved toward it for a closer look. "Touch it and die," Dan said.
Once everyone's bouquet was applauded by the group, it was time to set the table for lunch, complete with fish forks and knives. Then the class folded the napkins like accordions before putting them in water glasses and fanning out the pleats. Except for Dan, who used his as a blindfold.
"I am going to be your hostess today," Miss Judith said. Across the table, Max Rausch, 11, leaned his head on his hand, elbow on the table. She shot him a look. The elbow came off. "When your host or hostess places their napkin on their lap, everyone follows," she said. They did.
The waiters served the appetizer, shrimp cocktail, ladies first. Small fingers poked suspiciously at the tails. "Please don't touch your food, folks, thank you," Miss Judith said.
The children picked up their forks, Neanderthal style, in clenched fists. "Your index finger is your power finger," Miss Judith said. "You place it at the stem of the fork." They complied. "How many mouths do you have?" she asked.
"One," they answered.
She nodded. "You cut one piece at a time. Think of your plate as a clock. Once you cut, you place the tip of the knife at 12 o'clock, the handle at 3. And bring the food all the way to your mouth. In this culture, we don't lean over the plate, going to it."
Suddenly the room looked less like a school cafeteria and more like a restaurant. "Freeze! freeze!" Miss Judith called out. Two or three hapless souls had reverted to cave manners, forks in fists. A quick review of the power finger was in order, followed by a discussion of turning one's head away from the table to cough and sneeze. This led to a round of coughing.
The main course was chicken breast, tortellini and vegetables. The tortellini, which required only a fork, disappeared first.
Someone soon dropped a fork on the floor and was instructed to leave it there and ask the waiter for another. "Are you supposed to hop up and get a fork from another table?" Miss Judith asked.
"Yes!" came the reply.
"No!" she said, exasperated. "This is fine dining, folks."
Erin mumbled under her breath, "Sometimes my dad tells me to."
Miss Judith then instructed the children on the final signal -- placing the fork and the knife together at 4 o'clock on the plate to show the waiter they were finished.
Paul Chamandy-Cook, 9, from Montreal, who was there with his cousin Emily Forse, 9, of Brookline, Mass., raised his hand. "We didn't talk about burping," he said.
Miss Judith raised her eyebrows. "Didn't we?" she said. "Well, if you burp, just say, 'Excuse me,' and don't draw any more attention to yourself."
Before a round of burps could begin, Henri Boubee, the Ritz-Carlton's general manager, stopped in to offer a treat: a surprise visit to the hotel's Presidential Suite, which includes a living room, dining room and superior view of the city. The children swarmed into the bathroom.
"There's a phone in here!" someone called out excitedly.
Finally, the class was ready for the pastry workshop, where they would make the pastries they would eat during afternoon tea, which followed. Tea was also time to learn the art of small talk.
"Would you use politics for small talk?" Miss Judith asked. "No," they chorused. "The movie you last saw or music you like?" "Yes," they agreed.
"It's like a volleyball game or a tennis game," Miss Judith said. "If you're asked a question and just say yes or no, does the ball drop? It sure does."
She paired up the students. Monica Niedermeyer, 9, asked Diana Johnson, "Who's your favorite band?"
"I don't have one," Diana said.
Monica stared. "Now you have to," she prompted, but to no avail. Silence.
She tried again. "Who's your favorite singer?"
"Garth Brooks," Diana said while Monica waited. Silence. "Who's your second favorite?" Monica asked. Diana shrugged. "I don't know."
Across the table, Max asked Shauna, "How do you feel about being here?"
Before she could answer, the girl on Max's other side whipped her head around. "Are you copying me?" she demanded.
Monica sighed out loud. "This is hard," she lamented.
After tea came social correspondence, or as Miss Judith put it, "Writing thank-you notes for gifts you don't like without lying."
"Let's say you got a green sweater from your neighbor," she said. "Now, if you didn't like it, what would you say?"
Diana raised her hand. " 'I'm not wild about it'?" she offered. Miss Judith looked distressed.
"Uh, no, dear," she said. "There is not a golden rule that says anyone has to give you a gift. It is a choice. It would hurt someone's feelings to say that the gift wasn't so good."
Dan volunteered, "You can say it fits perfectly and then small talk in a letter." Miss Judith nodded, and everyone wrote a thank-you note.
A lesson followed in proper introductions, meaning a firm handshake, making eye contact and smiling. When Miss Judith properly introduced herself to Dan and asked him a question, he answered by saying, "Yeah."
"Yeah?" she repeated. "What are we, Swedish? It's yes, yes, yes. Humor me please, everyone. Repeat after me."
"Yes, yes, yes," they all said.
"Music to my ears," she murmured.
After the introductions and a visit to the health club to exercise, the children repaired to the restrooms to change for dinner in the Ritz-Carlton Dining Room. Everyone looked spectacular. The boys were in jackets and ties, the girls in satin and velvet.
They all sat up straight in their chairs, almost instinctively. "Good evening," the waiter said. "Would you like a cocktail before your dinner?" They ordered Shirley Temples and Roy Rogerses. A piano played in the background, and other diners came in, looking approvingly at the well-behaved group.
The first course was soup. Before entering the dining room, everyone had been instructed to move the spoon from 6 o'clock toward 12. They did so carefully, with great concentration.
Next came Caesar salad, prepared tableside. Miss Judith kept the conversation moving, asking the children about their interests. Emily Forse said, "I enjoy reading," and started to describe her favorite book. Her companions listened, and suddenly, a real conversation began. It seemed as if the low lights, the clink of glasses, the women's perfume floating by from other tables all inspired them. Bread was buttered over the bread plates, heads were turned to cough, without anyone's even asking. These children seemed to be having a marvelous time.
Following the main course, some of the ladies went to the restroom, and when they returned, some of the gentlemen stood, unbidden, and pulled out their chairs. All of them blushed.
The dinnertime glow lasted into the elevator as they went upstairs for ice cream sundae-making and social dancing. But as they neared the room and learned that social dancing meant slow dancing, they started to nervously gauge each other's height. The glow disappeared. They were kids again.
Emily sat at a table with Diana, while her cousin Paul hesitated, looking where the other boys were sitting.
"Sit here, Paul," Emily said, but Paul stayed standing, undecided.
"Sit or I torture you," she hissed.
He sat.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Looking For Cheap Stocks? Try Japan

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Japan's policy toward one of its most important economic issues is reminiscent of the old saw about New England's weather: If you don't like it, wait five minutes and it will change.
As a result, last week saw a series of wild swings in Japanese stock prices as the Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, first indicated he would favor doing something to bail out sick banks, then reversed and reversed again. If this goes on much longer, someone will begin to suspect that the governing Liberal Democratic party is raising campaign funds by playing the stock index futures market just before Mr. Hashimoto changes his policies. 
 It would be nice if the Government ended up doing what is needed: letting the sickest banks fail, with the Government eating the loss for at least some depositors, and allowing the banks that can survive to do so without being forced to take the risk of bailing out their dying brethren. But that is not the most important question for investors.
Nor are all the other things that scare people now. Japan is suffering from the weakness of its Asian neighbors. Its Government made a big mistake in tightening fiscal policy. Absurdly low interest rates have led to excessive capital investment. More financial firms will go bankrupt. None of those are good things for Japan's economy.
But the question faced by an investor deciding whether to put money into the American stock market or the Japanese one is not which country has a brighter outlook for economic growth and corporate profits. The United States wins hands down on those issues. It is the extent to which share prices reflect those outlooks. In this country, share prices reflect a very rosy outlook. But in Japan, stock prices are generally below where they were in 1986, and some companies, particularly smaller ones that cater to domestic customers, seem to be trading as if disaster is imminent. "If they manage to avoid a depression, there is opportunity in Japan," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
"Almost half the companies in Japan are trading below book value," added David Briggs, the research manager for Peter Cundill & Associates, a Canadian mutual fund manager that has bought a lot of Japanese stocks this year. Nearly a quarter of them, he figures, are trading below liquidation value. He points to stocks like Mitsui Marine and Fire, trading for little more than the value of stocks it owns in other companies -- and at 13 times earnings under American accounting rules -- and to the Fuji Electric Company, a profitable company that trades for less than the value of its stake in Fujitsu.
Some managers with a bent for value -- the growth and momentum players long ago abandoned Japan -- are still dubious, wondering what will unlock the stocks' intrinsic worth. But there are signs of progress. Some companies now hand out stock options to executives and some are buying their own shares, tactics that are new there. Mr. Briggs predicts that Japanese shareholders are going to get more aggressive in forcing managements to act in investors' interest.
He knows his views are unusual. "There is a lot of pessimism," Mr. Briggs said. "Everybody you talk to in Japan, or among global money managers, is worried. Nobody wants to buy Japan."
Yet fear produces opportunities. Even with gyrations, the Nikkei 225 went up 11 percent last week, and there are still plenty of bargains. For long-term investors, Japan looks good.
