HEADLINE: Democratic Values;
Clinton's Way Isn't His Party's

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WILL Clintonism outlive Bill Clinton?
In fits and starts across his Presidency, with a lurch to the left and a tack to the right, Mr. Clinton has tried to fashion what he once described as a "different kind of Democrat." This was a Democrat who would heed middle-class concerns about crime and welfare and family values. A fiscally responsible Democrat. A Democrat who would embrace the information age and the new global marketplace as engines of economic growth. 
 But in his fifth year in office, despite national prosperity, Mr. Clinton is still having trouble persuading his fellow Democrats to follow his mantra. "Now we can't turn back," he implored recently. "And our party can't turn back. We need a new economy for the 21st century, a Democratic Party for the 21st century to lead the way."
When most House Democrats answered by bucking him on "fast track" trade legislation, they were delivering a warning: Mr. Clinton's party is already looking beyond him. And that party is facing deepening divisions over whom Democrats should represent and what their philosophy should be.
The split isn't precisely the liberal-moderate divide of old, for the debate does not extend to social issues. The Democrats gathering around House Minority Leader Richard A. Gephardt accept Mr. Clinton's focus on family values, but want to represent those left behind in the new economy. Allied with organized labor, they want another minimum-wage increase, expanded health care coverage, and a trade policy that does more to protect American workers from competitors in developing nations.
Vice President Al Gore, Clintonism's standard-bearer, in a clear shot at Mr. Gephardt, derided the "huffing and puffing of out of shape and out of date dogmas trying to keep up with the dynamism of the new economy." But in some ways these Democrats sound like Mr. Clinton in 1992 -- before his economic stimulus package died, before his national health care plan perished.
Some of the Democrat ferment is positioning for the 2000 election. But much of it is driven by a paradox of the Clinton era: as he has prospered, so have Republicans.
 
Losing Control
 Yes, Mr. Clinton brought Democrats out of a 12-year drought to win the White House. Yes, he was the first Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt to win re-election. Yes, most Democrats agree, he helped the party shed an image dating from its 1968 convention and the Vietnam war years that it had lost touch with mainstream America.
But Democrats lost control of both houses of Congress in 1994. Even riding Mr. Clinton's coattails in 1996, Democrats could not regain either chamber. Now only the House is considered even contestable in 1998.
At lower levels of government, Democrats had 31 governorships in 1993. Now they have 17. The election day just past was another black Tuesday for them.. And with the party buffeted by controversy over Mr. Clinton fund-raising in 1996, the Democratic National Committee is $15 million in debt.
Just as troubling to House Democrats was a recent briefing by Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster. He told them that national polling data shows the Democrats' traditional advantage with voters on issues like education, Medicare, and the environment is narrowing, while Republicans are starting to lose their image as the party of the rich.
The blurring of party images is a logical outgrowth of Mr. Clinton's cooperation this year with the Republican Congress. "The problem is that these bipartisan deals have blocked the Democrats in Congress, and other Democrats, from being heard," said Stanley B. Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's 1992 pollster. "It's that all the Democratic angles are smoothed out and ruled out and Democrats are left with no defining purpose, which electorally weakens them."
With an eye to next year's fight for control of the House, Democrats want to re-emphasize differences between the parties. This doesn't mean they reject all that Mr. Clinton has taught them -- most Democrats this year voted for the balanced budget. And Congressional leaders are working with the White House to assemble a "families first" agenda for 1998 that will emphasize health care, education and family issues.
But many Democrats are restless for something bolder and more muscular than Clinton policies like voluntary national education testing. And it is over the economy -- Mr. Clinton's proudest achievement -- where the left-middle divide is reopening.
Mr. Clinton has tried to tilt his party toward upscale suburban independents and an embrace of the global economy. For those displaced by the changing economy, he prescribes education and training. Mr. Gephardt and his wing look toward those who have been left behind and a more interventionist economic policy.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gephardt can sound like they are speaking of different countries. Mr. Clinton boasts that "America is stronger than it has been in a long time -- our economy the healthiest in the world."
Mr. Gephardt, assessing what has hurt Democrats in recent years, says, "The average American is working much harder and longer and not making enough money. The standard of living is down so people quite naturally are very upset about their own economic situation and about taxes. And the Republican message ---- to the extent there is one -- is about taxes. So I think we have to be addressing those issues."
 
Wooing the Working Class
 Some of the most fervent opponents of Mr. Clinton's bid for authority to negotiate free-trade deals believe that their call for a trade policy that emphasizes labor and economic conditions will help them win Republican working-class support. "You're not going to see a complete realignment," said Representative Sherrod Brown, an Ohio Democrat. "But more Republicans -- not country club Republicans, but Main Street Republicans -- will be voting for Democratic candidates."
Moderate suburban Democrats fear that this kind of thinking guarantees the party permanent minority status. "If the legislative branch of the party ever hopes to gain a majority, it has got to go in the direction that Clinton has led us instead of the direction that labor and the Democratic caucus is pulling us," said Representative James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat.
For now, Congressional Democrats have enormous incentives to heal their breach with Mr. Clinton. His ratings are high. They need him to use the singular pulpit of the Presidency to plead their case next year and to help them raise campaign money.
But whether they think they need Clintonism is another question. The battle to define the post-Clinton party has begun.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton confers with the House's ranking Democrat, Richard A. Gephardt. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Big, Beautiful Numbers: 820, 834, 960

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
NANCY RICHARDSON, a longtime Fifth Avenue resident, calls it a "juste milieu." That, she says, is "a silly French phrase" that means finding the right tone or happy medium for her way of life.
To some, a happy medium can be found at 960, 834, 820, 740 and 720. For some, these are meaningless numbers; for others, they constitute a code -- what Tiffany stationers call "beautiful addresses." They are the addresses of Fifth and Park Avenue apartment houses -- A-plus buildings -- that signify that you are wealthy and social, that you have made it to the pinnacle of what many consider world society. 
 To live at one of these addresses is "a privilege and congenial way of life," said Ms. Richardson, who was recently divorced from the financier Frank Richardson.
What exactly is an A-plus building? And what happens in them at the height of a real estate boom, when the stock market has multiplied people's wealth enormously? A new genre of apartment-seeker bidding into "the teen millions" (as real estate brokers put it) for homes like Ms. Richardson's is desperately trying to get behind the velvet rope. But supply and demand is making it very difficult.
"It's the same amount of product," said Louise Beit, a vice president at Stribling & Associates. "But there are more customers than ever. More than even the height of the 80's." Standing in apartment at 820 Fifth Avenue, surrounded by paintings of French landscapes, she said that about one or two apartments come available each year.
The facts of life are these: Even when apartments do come up, sellers first turn to their own friends (they are rarely advertised). Co-op boards are feeling more powerful than ever, rejecting people with $60 million to $100 million in assets. It takes the veto of only one person you've crossed. (The chairman of Revlon, Ron Perelman, did not make it into 820 Fifth Avenue.)
A list of A-plus buildings circulates among what the primary gatekeepers -- so-called social brokers -- who size up clients before showing an apartment. "I call their bank officer," said Hall Willkie of Brown Harris Stevens, a real estate firm. "That is, of course, if they have a bank officer."
What are the criteria for getting into an A-plus building? Payment in full in cash; impeccable social credentials (private clubs, schools and the location of your summer home counts); substantial philanthropic contributions (tithing scores well) and having $60 million to $500 million in assets, a substantial portion liquid.
Rest easy. Buildings on the East River require a bit less. (There are ways, with a bank's help, to arrange your finances so that co-op boards do not know the source of your cash.)
What goes into the rating of an A-plus building? First, location: all of the Upper East Side, especially Fifth and Park Avenues between 60th and 79th Streets, and the East River. West Side apartments do not make the list, although devotees of the Dakota, Beresford and San Remo consider those buildings A-plus.
Then there is the "quality" of tenants like Lawrence Rockefeller, Ann Bass and Cynthia Phipps. And, finally, there's the architecture: the magic name is Rosario Candela, a 1920's architect known for grand flowing apartment layouts.
Most A-plus apartments have 8 to 20 rooms and features like wine cellars, walk-in vaults, linen rooms the size of studio apartments and extensive servants' quarters.
There is a certain irony at play. In the early 1900's, when some of these buildings were built, they were closed to anyone who was not born or did not marry into the right families. But economic ups and downs opened the doors. Now some of the very people who bought floor-through Park Avenue apartments for perhaps $80,000 in the early 1970's are trying to close the doors, even tighter than before.
Why? Exclusivity sells. "Buildings are making a conscious choice to become more unreasonable so they will appear more exclusive," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates and a co-chairman of the board of the residential division at the Real Estate Board of New York. "It's really infuriating."
But it is working. But this time tenacious buyers, with enough financing, are trying even harder than their predecessors to climb in. "I tell people they are not going to make it past the co-op board, but they want to try anyway," said Sharon E. Baum, director of the exclusive property division at the Corcoran Group, sitting in her Rolls-Royce on her way to show an apartment at 19 East 72d Street. "Before, people were embarrassed if they didn't pass. Now when they get turned down, they want to try again." She has had two board decisions reversed.
There are people who do not want to live on Park and Fifth Avenues because they find the screaming status of the address like wearing a label on the outside of a dress. They prefer to live in what are considered more discreet social buildings, like 1 Beekman Place, 1 Sutton Place South or even 19 East 72d Street (the building famous for turning down Richard Nixon, though it is rated A-minus because it is on a side street).
"It's a great way of life: You go home and never feel like you're in New York -- just the wind off the river," said Juliet Hartford, 27, the daughter of Huntington Hartford, the A.& P. heir, who lived at 1 Beekman Place for 35 years, later selling the duplex to Philip Niarchos, the son of the late Greek shipping magnate Stavros S. Niarchos. That high-luxe building has a swimming pool, gardens and private rooms at its base, all overlooking the East River, and apartments with servants' quarters the size of some Connecticut homes.
Deluxe apartments on Fifth Avenue were started in 1911, at 998 Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, according to Andrew Alpern, the author of "Luxury Apartment Houses of Manhattan" (Dover Publications, 1992). Builders, he said, "Touted the fact that it was more convenient to live in an apartment because you could very quickly close up shop and go off to your country place or Europe. When you came back, the service people in the building would get the apartment ready for you."
The builders and architects also billed apartments -- mansions stacked on top of each other -- as more practical, secure and even a more economical way to live than in separate homes.
When Ms. Richardson was looking for a place, she said, "I just wanted as nice things as we could afford put in a cozy setting, and this was the best value for the space." She added, "The market was nothing like it is now." And, she said, "While these buildings have this reputation of maybe being exclusive, it's really all about who would make a congenial neighbor and getting enough of space."
The great apartments are truly palatial, with sweeping entrance ways downstairs and upstairs, endless numbers of rooms and museum-quality design detail on the ceilings, windowsills and doorknobs. The Picassos and Renoirs on the walls do not hurt the ambiance. Still, even then some lives within those walls do not always find that juste milieu.

GRAPHIC: Photographs by Barbara Alper for The New York Times
 
820 FIFTH AVENUE, at 63d Street
 
Walking into these apartments brings to mind stepping into a hotel particulier, or private mansion, in Paris. The building was constructed in 1916 as a 12-story version of an Italian Renaissance palazzo, and the rooms make you feel as if you're in a country estate.
 
CACHET: Each floor contains one 18-room apartment, 7,000 square feet, with four rooms overlooking Central Park. The elevator opens onto each floor. In one apartment visited recently, seven miniature dachshund puppies ran over the front rooms' herringbone floors, all overlooking Fifth Avenue.
The apartment opens onto a gallery, 12 feet by 43 feet (the size of many Manhattan studio apartments), which displays 19th-century French paintings. This gallery, or hallway, leads into what is called the reception rooms: the living room, sitting room, dining room and conservatory. And these open into each other along the line of windows, as in many Parisian homes. There are his-and-her bedrooms and his-and-her bathrooms.
 
REQUIREMENTS: A potential owner must have at least 10 times the net worth of the apartment, which can cost in the mid-teen millions. Maintenance is about $14,000 a month.
 
960 FIFTH AVENUE, at 77th Street
 
What's especially interesting about this building, besides the wealth of the residents (most are worth over $100 million), are the amenities. The staff includes an in-house chef, and there is maid service and laundry service (shirts are washed, ironed and brought to the back door within two hours).
 
"It's the premier building in Manhattan," said Louise Beit, a vice president at Stribling & Associates.
 
CACHET: Room size. Duplexes run 8,000 to 10,000 square feet. One even has a ballroom with a 16-foot ceiling and floor-to-ceiling windows.
 
Behind the lobby is the Georgian Suite, formerly a private dining room, where all the residents dined together. The room can be rented out by residents for private parties, and once a month the chef prepares dinner for the tenants to dine together.
 
Tenants can order up picnic basket for the weekend or a casserole to tide them over (the chef doesn't work weekends).
 
COST PER APARTMENT: Around $15 million. About one apartment comes on the market every year. Maintenance runs about $8,000 to $10,000 a month; food is extra.
 
834 FIFTH AVENUE, at 64th Street
 
Several doormen in white gloves descend on the visitor who steps one inch inside this building, either to help with packages, check a coat in the cloakroom or see if you belong in the lobby (which looks dark and unassuming).
Past the gate, the apartments upstairs are huge. In one visited recently, Renoir paintings hung on the walls and a red-carpeted staircase looked as if Norma Desmond were going to sweep down at any moment.
 
CACHET: The size of the apartments in a building designed by Rosario Candela. A duplex can run 7,000 to 8,000 square feet: five bedrooms, five maids' rooms and a walk-in safe in the kitchen (for the silver). Some maids' rooms could be turned into bedrooms. ("Oh, no, you would never do that," said one broker.) Oh, well.
 
REQUIREMENTS: No financing. All cash. Required net worth: $50 million to $100 million. A duplex costs about $10 million, with a $12,000 monthly maintenance fee. "Look, anyone can afford the maintenance," said Sharon E. Baum, director of the exclusive-property division at Corcoran Group. "It's not about that."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Heavy Bets on a Few Stocks Pay Off

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN

 BODY:
ON a list of the 100 best-performing domestic stock funds of the last 12 months, those that buy the shares of small and midsize companies dominate. Only a handful that focus on large companies are scattered throughout this stratosphere. But flying highest among these, and eighth on the overall list, is a young fund that hails from an insurance company family and favors big, fast-growing businesses.
Transamerica Premier Equity, the largest of seven funds started since October 1995 by the Transamerica Corporation, has returned 52.9 percent for the 12 months through Thursday, well above the 31.3 percent gain of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the average 24.0 percent total return of its peers in the "large growth" category, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago. Since its inception on Oct. 2, 1995, it boasts an average total return of 33.9 percent a year through Thursday, compared with 28.9 percent for the S.& P. 500 and 23.2 percent for its peers. 
 Behind the numbers is an investment philosophy that runs counter to common wisdom: the fund concentrates holdings in a few stocks rather than broadly diversifying to reduce risk. "People invest in our fund because they want to outperform the market," said Glen E. Bickerstaff, portfolio manager of Premier Equity. "If we owned several hundred stocks, the fund would behave like an index."
Mr. Bickerstaff says he generally owns from 30 to 40 stocks, far fewer than the average of 125 for a large-cap fund.
The powerful moves by some stocks in his portfolio explain why Premier Equity has done so well this year, even as big companies in general were being outperformed by the smaller segment of the market in the third quarter. Dell Computer, its biggest holding, is up 223 percent this year through Thursday. Other big gainers include Pixar, up 78 percent; Charles Schwab, 86 percent, and Franklin Resources, 105 percent.
"Dell Computer -- that will do it right there," said Russel Kinnel, equity editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds. "You don't need too many of those" to beat the averages, he added.
Yet Premier Equity, a $105 million no-load fund, is not the only achiever in the Transamerica family, which is spending about $1 million on advertising this year, up from $4,000 last year. Premier Balanced, with $25 million in assets, leads its group of funds that invest in both stocks and bonds with a total return of 34.8 percent this year through Thursday, according to Morningstar.
Their common fortune is not surprising, considering that the fund family shares research and a growth-oriented investment style, a foundation that has also helped its two newest funds. Since their start-ups in July, Premier Small Company has returned 28.8 percent through Thursday, compared with 13.4 percent for its small-growth group, and Premier Aggressive Growth is up 23.4 percent, versus 14.3 percent for its mid-cap growth peers.
In addition, all but these newest Transamerica funds are clones of pension accounts run by the insurance parent. That experience figures into the funds' success, said Mr. Kinnel of Morningstar. "An insurance company has a lot of money-management experience," he said. "They have huge portfolios of their own to invest. It's not like a new fund from Transamerica started off the same as a mom-and-pop fund."
Still, he and other fund and insurance analysts said there was no evidence that insurance companies like Transamerica enjoyed any edge over mutual fund companies in investing. "It's just the skills of the manager," said Arthur Fliegelman, a senior analyst at Moody's.
THAT seems to be the case for Premier Equity. As the bull market has gained ground, Mr. Bickerstaff's policy of placing large bets has paid off. But if big companies sputter again, the fund may find its approach tested.
"Concentration is more likely to take you to an extreme performance," Mr. Kinnel said. "You are more likely to end up in the top quartile or the bottom quartile."
Mr. Bickerstaff argues that his fund's performance is no fluke, pointing to the 25 percent compound annual return he has earned managing its twin pension account over the last decade through Sept. 30, versus 14.7 percent for the S.& P. 500.
"Our portfolio is protected by the fact that we own great businesses" that share several traits, he said, including fast growth rates, dynamic leadership and strong advantages over rivals. One such company is the fund's second-largest holding, Mirage Resorts. Mr. Bickerstaff said Mirage's management built superior properties in places like Las Vegas, Nev., insuring a steady stream of traffic. "Visitors to Las Vegas go by the Mirage just to see it," he said.
In assessing growth, the fund focuses on a company's excess cash flow. Mr. Bickerstaff's logic is that companies able to generate excess cash flow can finance growth by expanding product lines or making strategic acquisitions or it can return capital to shareholders in the form of stock buybacks or increased dividends.
But companies must also have an edge over rivals. In the technology stocks that make up the biggest portion of his fund -- 21.3 percent -- Mr. Bickerstaff likes Dell, Intel, Microsoft and Cisco Systems because each dominates an important niche in the computer market. Dell is a low-cost computer distributor; Intel is the industry's leading hardware supplier; Microsoft is its biggest software maker, and Cisco, he said, represents "the best way to participate" in the trend toward linking personal computers. Perhaps because technology is so heavily represented in the portfolio, the fund's average price-to-earnings ratio of 33 is 5 percent above that of the average growth fund.
In the final test of a stock, Mr. Bickerstaff meets with management to determine its ability to handle change. Once he makes an investment, he sticks with it unless its price rises above his most optimistic projections. On average, he holds stocks about four years. "One of the biggest mistakes investors make is to sell too soon," he said.
Although Premier Equity does not restrict its holdings to large companies -- the median market capitalization of its holdings is currently a midsize $4.5 billion -- Mr. Bickerstaff is unapologetic about his belief that bigger is better in today's economy. Big companies have the capital to invest in technology, which improves productivity, he said. They also have economies of scale, enabling them to bolster profits through cost cuts rather than price increases.
But, ultimately, size is only one factor. "The best way to get superior returns," Mr. Bickerstaff said, "is to own companies that consistently exceed your expectations."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Glen E. Bickerstaff manages Transamerica Premier Equity, which generally holds just 30 to 40 stocks. He stood atop Transamerica's Los Angeles office building. (Edward Carreon for The New York Times)
 
Charts: "Trends in 401(k)'s: How Does Your Plan Compare?"
Overall employee participation in 401(k) plans has remained fairly steady at around 77 percent over the last five years, but new investment options have been emerging, more plans are offering loan options and plan participants increasingly find them-selves talking to electronic voices when they call for information. These are some of the findings by Buck Consultants, a human resources consulting firm based in New York, in its latest survey of 401(k) plans. The survey includes inform-ation on 668 organizations with 401(k) plans and is based on year-end 1996 data.
 
EQUITY FUNDS LEAD THE OPTIONS
While 97 percent of respondents offer stock funds or other equity investments in their 401(k)'s, a few employers provide options that throw the door wide open to employee choice. A mutual fund window offers participants access to a fund supermarket or a fund family; a self-directed brokerage account lets participants to buy securities or funds through the account. Both are being offered most often in the plans of professional practices, like law firms, whose participants may have more investment knowledge and more money to invest.
 
MOST COMPANIES MATCH CONTRIBUTIONS
Eighty-eight percent of the respondents make contributions to their 401(k) plans to match employee contributions. The rate varies by industry but the average company match is 60 cents per employee dollar.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2649 words

HEADLINE: Land Rich, but Cash Poor, in the West

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN

DATELINE: DUGOUT RANCH, Utah

 BODY:
HEIDI REDD is living out a cowgirl's dream in a Technicolor landscape.
She plays the part to the hilt, dressed in jeans and denim shirt, dirty leather chaps, boots and a cowboy hat pulled low over a tanned, weather-lined face. And at 55, she does the work, too: riding, roping, branding and herding. 
 Ms. Redd's Dugout Ranch is a perfect setting for a Western dream come true. The ranch embraces 5,167 acres of privately owned pastures and 250,000 acres of grassland that she leases from the Federal Government for cattle grazing. Ensconced among steep, red-rock cliffs on the edge of Canyonlands National Park in southern Utah, Dugout is about an hour's drive south from Moab, a boomtown bulging with tourists and second homes.
The ranch got its name from caves that the first settlers dug in the sandy banks of Indian Creek for shelter from the scorching summer sun and winter snow. A parade of people from around the world now drive past the ranch in rental cars and recreational vehicles on their way to Newspaper Rock and the Needles district of the park. And though the value of her property has skyrocketed, as the West's open spaces have lured yuppie emigres from the cities, Ms. Redd wants nothing more than to keep ranching here.
"I've always figured cowboys and cowgirls have the best jobs," she said, saddling a horse one day recently to round up cattle. "They probably have the lowest wages, but they don't have to wait till the weekend to enjoy life."
This free-spirited way of life almost ended for Ms. Redd in the wake of her bitter divorce from Robert Redd, her husband of 23 years, and the ensuing need to sell the ranch. That it did not end took a combination of true grit, sophisticated tax and estate planning and the donations of more than a thousand people from around the country who did not want to see Dugout -- and other places like it -- fall into the hands of developers.
The ranch, which has been a favored setting for movies and commercials, was the couple's only home together and their main asset. Over the years, it had soared in value as big-money buyers swarmed into the area, looking to turn places like Dugout into rustic private playgrounds or patches of sprawling condominiums.
The ranch's sale to outsiders seemed inevitable, too. Neither of the Redds had enough money to buy the other out, and they and their two sons needed to get on with their lives. The family was not only facing the loss of its homestead, but also a big chunk of the sale price, which would be eaten by capital gains taxes.
What kept Ms. Redd riding and roping was the creative intervention of the Nature Conservancy, one of a number of environmental groups around the country that works to protect private property as open space and nature preserves.
Often these groups buy land only to turn around and sell it to a Government agency for a park or wildlife refuge, thus getting money to make more deals.
But like Ms. Redd, the Nature Conservancy did not want to change Dugout. So the group is buying the property and making a commitment to maintain it in perpetuity as a working ranch, ecological preserve and a model for how cattle grazing and conservation -- at odds throughout the West -- can go hand in hand.
Last month, the nonprofit conservancy, based in Arlington, Va., closed on a complicated deal to buy the ranch for $4.6 million, raised from donations by individuals, foundations and corporations. The deal permits Ms. Redd to spend the rest of her life at Dugout. Public visits will be limited to researchers and tours arranged by the Nature Conservancy, beginning next spring.
The closing, which followed intensive negotiations among the four family members and their lawyers, came three years after Ms. Redd approached the conservancy for help and eight years after her divorce put the ranch's future in play.
While the arrangement may have been bad news to the likes of Christie Brinkley and Ralph Lauren, both of whom once made overtures for the property, it was a sweet moment for the conservancy and the Redds. Indeed, at a time when pressure is growing to develop what is left of the wild West, the deal demonstrated many of the sophisticated financial tools that environmental groups are increasingly using to keep the land pristine while giving owners a way to cash out. The tax advantages will allow the Redds, who are partners in the ranch, to clear about as much as they might have from a commercial sale, even though the ranch was recently appraised for $6.3 million.
By selling for less, they not only reduce their taxable capital gains on the transaction but can also deduct their share of the difference between the appraised value and the sale price -- $1.7 million -- from their income taxes over the next five years as a charitable contribution to the Nature Conservancy.
In addition, a third of the sale proceeds will go into separate charitable remainder unit trusts for Ms. Redd and her former husband. (Ms. Redd's share was reduced by the value of her lifelong tenancy and of a 10-year lease for cattle grazing.) The trusts will produce taxable income for them during their lifetimes. But the principal will go to the Nature Conservancy upon their deaths, allowing them to deduct the value of the principal from their income taxes for the next five years. The structure also ultimately reduces the conservancy's purchase cost and effectively recycles the money for other land deals.
FOR the conservancy, the purchase is a cornerstone in its efforts to preserve "representative ecosystems" within the canyon lands of the Colorado River. It will also keep a spectacular gateway to a remote national park from being cluttered with commercial and residential development.
"The Dugout was begging to become a resort or golf course/condo complex," said Bill Hedden, a former supervisor of Grand County, which includes Moab. "It would have completely ruined that incredible entrance" to the park.
"The Nature Conservancy threw itself into the breach," added Mr. Hedden, who works for the Grand Canyon Trust, a group trying to buy out and retire grazing leases held by ranchers in the nearby Escalante-Grand Staircase National Monument.
The Nature Conservancy has gained a reputation for helping keep family ranches from being broken up in environmentally sensitive areas in the West. But it has also been busy elsewhere, including the Northeast, buying private parcels of undeveloped land. With 1,340 properties in the United States, Latin America and the South Pacific, the group owns the largest private network of nature sanctuaries in the world.
The conservancy is sometimes called the real estate arm of the conservation movement, but it seldom waits for property to be listed on the open market and it rarely deals with real estate brokers. The group prefers to work directly with landowners on package deals that address estate and tax planning in tandem with land preservation.
The hottest area for such environmental wheeling and dealing may be the West, where property values near popular tourist destinations have multiplied and families face difficult decisions about how to pass on their new wealth to the next generation. Some 60 percent of ranches in the West will change hands in the next 20 years, according to Utah Open Lands, an organization advocating preservation of these properties.
Because about half of the land in Western states is owned by the Federal Government and is thus out of the reach of developers, it is the private land that is likely to be built up over the next couple of decades in a process of "rural gentrification," said William Riebsame, editor of the "Atlas of the New West" (W. W. Norton).
"There seems to be a real estate demand for ranch land even in deeply rural areas," said Mr. Riebsame, a professor of geography at the University of Colorado. As rising real estate values eclipse potential profits from farming, the land is "being carved into smaller and smaller pieces," he said.
Like many other ranching families, the Redds were "land rich and money poor," Ms. Redd said, "because everything was tied up in the land."
Ms. Redd moved here 30 years ago when she and Robert were married. They raised two sons, Matthew and Adam, in a modern ranch house they built beside Indian Creek, under the forbidding prow of a petroglyph-pocked red mesa, 35 miles from the nearest town and with no electricity or phone.
Heidi Redd had dreamed of being a cowgirl since she was a child in Blackfoot, Idaho, watching Roy Rogers in Saturday matinees. She took to the remote ranch life with zeal. Even today, a cardboard cutout of Roy Rogers stands by her fireplace; she calls him "the man of the house."
After the couple divorced in 1989, Mr. Redd remarried and moved to Virginia. Matthew, now 28, and Adam, 23, also eventually moved away.
But they all wanted a piece of the ranch, and Dugout was almost torn apart as the family fought over what to do with the property, which had cost only about $350,000 when Robert's father bought it in 1962.
The ranch is a naturalist's prize. It is home to rare wild flowers, like the kachina daisy; natural sanctuaries atop steep mesas that have never been grazed, and 42 miles of free-flowing creek, a rarity in this dry land, where most streams are dammed and diverted for irrigation.
In their divorce settlement, the Redds turned the ranch into a partnership in which each family member held shares, and Ms. Redd then created a company to lease the ranch from the partnership. The company ran about 700 head of cattle, bringing in $100,000 to $150,000 a year in gross revenue, depending on beef prices. The ranch, in turn, earned modest profits from the lease and from serving as a location for movies like "City Slickers II" and advertisements including numerous Marlboro ads.
BUT it became clear that the ranch had become both an emotional battleground and an underperforming asset. The Redds agonized about whether to sell it and split the proceeds or divide the property. That is when Ms. Redd approached the Nature Conservancy.
It took delicate negotiations to close the deal -- talks, Ms. Redd said, that were as much about "family counseling" as about finances and land. Each family member brought a lawyer to the meetings.
At the first meeting, Dave Livermore, the Utah state director of the Nature Conservancy, said he asked Matt if he wanted a cup of coffee. Matt turned to his lawyer and asked, "Can I answer that question?"
Ms. Redd said Mr. Livermore "related to my two boys and what they were going through and let them talk to him about what they wanted," while his colleague, Chris Montague, focused on the parents. "We were real jerks," Ms. Redd said. "There were many times I would have thrown my hands up in the air and said, 'I've had it.' "
Mr. Livermore said "the love of the land" was "the thing that kept us going."
Robert Redd added that the same love "also made it hard to get where we are."
"If it wasn't for Dave and Chris playing good cop-bad cop, we never would have made it," he said.
In some ways, resolving the fate of the ranch brought the family back from the brink of completely splitting apart. Heidi and Robert Redd still don't talk to each other. But Matt Redd works for his mother. And Mr. Redd is moving back to Salt Lake City from Virginia to be closer to his sons and the land he loves.
"For 30 years, the Dugout was my life," Mr. Redd said. Selling the ranch "gives me a sense of loss," he said, "but also a sense of gift."
"I'll have financial benefits I haven't had for eight years. For eight years the property I inherited from my family has been of no benefit to me, and quite a drain because of the legal bills," he said.
"I always assumed the boys would have the ranch someday. But I think the land and the ranch would have been damaged the most by a division. The next thing to be damaged would be the lives of all four of us. Now Matt and Adam can be independent. That's a good thing. And the ranch won't have condos."
The sons say they still would rather have inherited the ranch. When the Nature Conservancy bought an option to buy Dugout a year ago, the sons issued a statement that spoke of their "poignant loss." They tried to negotiate a deal to sell the conservancy a scenic easement, restricting further development of the land, for around $2 million; that way, the property could be passed down to them and used for cattle ranching but never subdivided. But that plan fell apart over thorny issues such as the sons' future development rights and Mr. Redd's right to visit the ranch.
Matt Redd compared selling the ranch to "selling your sense of place and losing your soul." He returned to the ranch to help his mother with the fall roundup. Dressed in dirty khaki riding pants, boots and a cowboy hat, he seemed very much at home on the range as he discussed the coming transfer.
"Land isn't valued anymore for agriculture or its production value," he said. "It's valued for its esthetic or mythical value," a change that he blames on the "gentrification of the West."
But, he said, "I'll admit I'm very spoiled growing up here; there's no place like home." Matt hopes to move back to the ranch with his wife, Kristen, and someday work as its foreman for the Nature Conservancy.
Adam is now in college in Salt Lake City. "Early on, I wanted to be on the ranch and stay on it and work on it," he said. "I still think it's the perfect job. But I have a house in the city now. And there's a lot of things I like to do. I'll try to build up some finances before putting everything into a ranch."
THE Nature Conservancy is still raising the money to pay for the deal, which is six times bigger than any of its previous purchases in Utah and ranks among the organization's biggest preserves nationwide.
It made the Dugout a centerpiece of a national fund-raising drive, pulling in 1,200 individual contributions from around the country. But most of the money has come from Utah. The George S. and Dolores Dore Eccles Foundation of Salt Lake City, based on the Eccles family's fortune from Utah's First Security Bank, contributed $1.3 million.
As he drove out some weeks ago to visit Ms. Redd at a remote corner of the Dugout Ranch, Mr. Livermore returned fund-raising calls on a cellular phone.
"This is a property we always dreamed about," he said, scanning the horizon. "We were worried it would be a Coney Island, 7-Eleven, Imax theater. What we're protecting it from is all this," he said, pointing out "trophy homes, or as a friend calls them, 'starter castles,' " on the Moab outskirts.
"Imagine a home site every 10 acres here," Mr. Livermore said as he approached the ranch headquarters. The Nature Conservancy hopes Ms. Redd can be "an ambassador to the livestock community" in the "war for the West," which these days, he said, is not between ranchers and environmentalists, but between "cows and condos."
He found Ms. Redd gathering cattle in a mountain pasture. From there, she, Matt and a hired hand, Whit Hill, would herd the cows about 20 miles to the home ranch. The calves would be weaned from their mothers and sold.
As she discussed the transfer of her property, Ms. Redd sported a nasty black eye from chasing a cow through the oak scrub thickets the day before. She rides every day. "I'll never lose my awe at how gorgeous it is and how very lucky I am to be here," she said.
And she is happy with the deal. "I got out of it what I want: to stay here till I die, and when I'm gone it won't be subject to development."
Ms. Redd also believes that the deal is good for her sons and her former husband. "Financially, it gives them a lot of freedom to do what they choose," she said. "They ended up with money enough to pursue whatever in life they want. We're all in charge of our own lives now."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Heidi Redd, 55, can spend the rest of her life on Dugout Ranch thanks, in part, to the efforts of Dave Livermore, the Utah state director of the Nature Conservancy. By selling their sprawling Utah ranch to a nonprofit group, the Redd family fended off developers -- and kept the land intact. Charts: "Open Space Under Assault"
Since the early 1980's, population growth and the sprawl of urban and suburban development have been drastically altering land use in the states of the Far West and Southwest. Farmland is under the most direct assault, but forest and range lands are steadily shrinking in many states as well. Map of U.S shows population growth outside of metropolitan areas. "Location, Location, Location"
The Nature Conservancy is in the forefront of efforts by environmental groups to buy ecologically valuable properties threatened by development. The group often structures its deals to provide tax benefits to the sellers while ultimately returning all or part of the purchase price to the conservancy for future acquisitions. Here are some prominent examples.
 
LOCATION Placentia Island, Maine
YEAR 1989
DESCRIPTION 500-acre island that is a nesting site for bald eagles.
THREATS Tourism, summer vacation homes.
SOLUTION Conservancy purchased a remainder interest in the land, providing a lifetime income for its elderly, cash-poor sellers and minimizing their capital gains and estate taxes.
 
LOCATION Lucas County, Ohio
YEAR 1997
DESCRIPTION 100-acre oak forest near Lake Erie, next to a 500-acre nature preserve that is home to rare species and oak woodland habitat.
THREATS Subdivision for housing in a fast-developing region. Development of this tract would have endangered the neighboring preserve.
SOLUTION Conservancy purchased land, with half the proceeds going into a charitable remainder trust that limits the owner's tax exposure and returns the principal to the conservancy after the owner's death.
 
LOCATION Red Canyon Ranch, Wyoming
YEAR 1993
DESCRIPTION 34,000-acre ranch near Lander (including 4,738 privately-owned acres and 29,547 acres of leased Federal land) that provides winter range for antelope, moose, bighorn sheep, deer and elk and contains rare plants.
THREATS Subdivision into ranchettes.
SOLUTION Conservancy purchased parts of the property, setting up charitable remainder trusts that pay lifetime income to the owners, who donated the remainder of the private holdings.
 
LOCATION Mill Brook, Mass.
YEAR 1992
DESCRIPTION 530 acres of undeveloped grassland and heath on Martha's Vineyard; home to rare species.
THREATS Intense development pressure and sharply escalating real estate prices.
SOLUTION Sellers donated a conservation easement to the Conservancy, giving them a lifetime charitable deduction that shelters other income; deal also reduced property taxes and value of sellers' estate.
 
LOCATION Gray Ranch, New Mexico
YEAR 1994
DESCRIPTION 324,000-acre ranch that includes scenic mountains and habitat of rare species, including jaguars.
THREATS Subdivision into ranchettes and hobby ranches.
SOLUTION Conservancy bought property and then resold it to a local foundation after establishing conservation easements that protect the land from development. Other area ranchers are allowed to graze cattle on the ranch in exchange for conservation easements on their land, which by lowering their properties value help reduce their estate taxes.
 
LOCATION Mission Creek, California
YEAR 1997
DESCRIPTION 1,200-acre property with desert wetlands on the edge of Palm Springs. This is a desert oasis that is home to 55 mammal species, 38 reptile and amphibian species and more than 100 species of birds.
THREATS Condominiums, luxury hotels and golf courses were planned for the area, which is in one of California's fastest-growing resort regions.
SOLUTION Conservancy bought the land using a charitable gift annuity, providing the owners with an immediate tax deduction and lifetime incomes. On their deaths, the principal reverts to the conservancy.
 
(Source: The Nature Conservancy)(pg. 11)

PUB-DATE: November 23, 1997

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1154 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Germany the Unloved Just Wants to Be Normal

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
IMAGINE the political cartography of Europe a decade from now: at its hub, the reunified Germany, encircled by lands it once occupied yet locked in peaceful step with them by a common European currency and by common membership in the NATO alliance.
That is the utopian vision of strength and normalcy that Chancellor Helmut Kohl would like to mold as his legacy -- a goal, he is given to saying, that will decide between war and peace in the 21st century. 
 Yet, as Germany teeters between prosperous postwar introspection and the unfamiliar assault of economic globalization, a question intrudes: how will Germany achieve normalcy on a continent that still defines its relationships by caricatures drawn from the same history it seeks to overcome?
For most nations, one measure of normalcy is their relationship with the past. And as the so-called Nazi gold affair in Switzerland and France's acknowledgment of its ambiguous wartime history have displayed in recent months, historical truth has become a spectral force across Europe.
 
History, History Everywhere
 On the surface, Germany has all the trappings of a "normal" post-industrial society. A traveler from the United States initially finds Frankfurt or Dusseldorf perfectly familiar: the highways and high-rises, talk shows and discos, businesses and churches.
But then come the subtexts that are not so familiar.
Every manifestation of late 20th-century life in Germany finds a counterpoint in the past: the point of reference for the nation's record postwar unemployment of 4.5 million is the mass joblessness that preceded Hitler's rise to power in 1933; the fear of inflation that propels Germans' misgivings about the planned European currency harks back to the ruinous inflation of the Weimar Republic.
Indeed, German society is latticed with taboos -- some evident, some less so.
At the most obvious level, displays of Nazi insignia and gestures -- swastikas and stiff-arm salutes -- are illegal. It is a criminal offense to trivialize the Holocaust. In more subtle ways, the past plays itself out in responses that sometimes strike outsiders as bizarre.
German officials rail against the Scientology movement, for instance, because they fear it is a totalitarian movement growing, like the Nazi party, from inconsequential beginnings -- even though the official response smacks of the Nazi era's authoritarianism. In a low-key debate about smoking in public places, the authorities are said to be reluctant to be too stern because the Nazis frowned on public smoking, especially by women.
It is that tracery of unspoken taboo and inhibition that some, to the political left and to the right, now depict as the greatest barrier to normalcy, a source of self-doubt and even self-loathing.
"One almost has the impression that Germans have set out not to be loved at all," Peter Schneider, a left-wing author, wrote recently in Der Spiegel. "Or do they not love themselves? Is this absence of self-love a result of Hitlerism, or, conversely, the cause of Hitlerism?"
The argument gets more complicated because, throughout the postwar era, Germany rebuilt itself on a notion of consensus designed specifically to swallow the extremes of the past in a society of checks and balances, and, above all, in the denial of nationalism in favor of a broader Western identity.
That was simpler to achieve before reunification seven years ago, but since then another Germany has returned -- Europe's most populous land, with 82 million people, that was once the crucible of hegemony.
And, according to some on what is called the "new right," a loose assembly of writers, intellectuals and historians, that huge, geopolitical shift has opened the way for a self-assertive Germany to eschew the reflex of contrition for the past, a reflex they blame on such stalwarts of the left as the author Gunther Grass and the philosopher Jurgen Habermas.
That conflict between national pride and historical shame now defines the "German question": how can Germany draw a line under its history without seeming to discard it?
In the 1920's, the deadly mix of World War I humiliation and repressed nationalism nurtured Nazism, albeit under completely different circumstances.
Even today, many younger Germans chafe at being held accountable for history. Virtually all of Germany's neighbors (except Switzerland) were occupied, annexed or invaded at some point during World War II; all harbor stereotypes of an aggressive Germany strutting through the generations.
In fact, no other European country has done as much as Germany to confront its history. Of 700,000 visitors each year to the former concentration camp at Dachau, 350,000 are Germans, many of them schoolchildren sent there to reinforce the message drummed home in schools and politicians' speeches: never again. Germany has spent some $58 billion in reparations and is still called upon -- by former slave laborers, for example, or by victims of Nazi persecution in Greece -- to pay more. But does any of that make the past any easier to live with? The answer is no, simply because there is no statute of limitations for the Holocaust.
Two years ago, Chancellor Kohl commemorated the 50th anniversary of the end of the war by seeking to cast ordinary Germans as the victims of a Nazi occupation of their state. Just one year later, though, "Hitler's Willing Executioners," by the American writer Daniel J. Goldhagen, sought to prove exactly the opposite: that ordinary Germans were the perpetrators of genocide.
The debate has left contradictory strains in German society. Among the intellectual elite, the preoccupation with history remains: the two major art shows in Berlin this fall, for instance, deal with German division and with the work of artists forced to flee by the Nazis.
In less public circles, though, the inhibitions seem to be weakening. When Germany's generals discovered recently that, three years back, foot soldiers had made home videos showing themselves giving Nazi salutes, their conclusion was not just that taboos were being eroded in the barracks, but that they were weakened in the homes and schools where the soldiers grew up -- particularly in East Germany, which never accepted the same responsibility for the past as West Germany.
 
A Plea for Assertiveness
 And, increasingly, the postwar inhibitions collide with Germany's need to reinvent itself in a global economy that challenges it to tap hidden reserves.
In his essay in Der Spiegel, Mr. Schneider recalled Germans' "courage, boldness, spirit of discovery and invention." Had Germans forgotten, he asked, that they were co-inventors of cars, telephones, faxes, rocket technology and computers? "Should these positive energies and talents of the Germans remain suspect as Nazi virtues," he wrote, "all in the name of an effort to overcome the past that is more obedient than actual?"

HEADLINE: Bailout Time;
The Stock of 'Asian Values' Drops

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS Asia's economic ascendancy in the 80's and early 90's moved from the astounding to the mildly terrifying, the world began to look for the magic formula that built such prosperity from poverty. Asian leaders themselves were the first to give the recipe a label, writing about "the Pacific way" and lecturing about "Asian values."
Even those who doubted there was an answer to the miracle conceded that there was something different about the way Asians were organizing themselves for the next century. It struck anyone watching Thai workers singing a Japanese company song after calisthenics in the Toyota factory near Bangkok. Or anyone who watched young mothers in Seoul quiz their children with math problems as they waited for the school bus. 
 Economists pointed to Asia's phenomenal savings rates, sociologists to its low divorce rates. Business schools offered case studies of firms that guaranteed lifetime employment and built low-cost housing for workers. One of Singapore's top diplomats gushed in Foreign Affairs only two years ago that modern Asia had "emerged as the most dynamic region of the world" because it fused "the best practices and values from many rich civilizations, Asian and Western."
 
The Dark Side

Underneath all that fusion, though, was a good deal of fraud. While the world was enthralled with the best of Asian values, phenomenal growth rates obscured the worst: crony capitalism, corruption and secrecy eating away at the region's accomplishments like termites in a forest of fast-growing bamboo. In the name of "cooperation" between governments and the businesses that supplied them with ready cash, no one would be forced to disclose embarrassing financial information, give shareholders real power, or expose powerful friends to true global competition.
Now, as the International Monetary Fund races in to clean up the wreckage and put together bailout packages -- last week South Korea became the latest erstwhile juggernaut to plead for its help -- it is clear that the darker side of Asian values helped turn the Asian miracle into the Asian mess. As Daniel Tarullo, President Clinton's international economic adviser, noted before Mr. Clinton's departure this weekend for an inopportunely scheduled annual meeting of Pacific Rim leaders, "The Asian miracle did not repeal the laws of economics."
South Korea now knows this only too well. It is still a world-class producer of steel, semiconductors and cars, and its economy is still growing impressively. But it is suffering an acute cash crisis because its banks lent billions mindlessly -- often at government insistence -- to projects and companies that are now collapsing left and right. The banks, in turn, were depending on a river of foreign cash. And they are failing because that river has been abruptly rerouted as investors have begun to steer clear of Korea -- and the I.M.F.'s other wards, Indonesia and Thailand.
In South Korea as in Indonesia and Thailand, the darker Asian values encouraged politicians to use national banking systems as their personal kitties. They ordered up loans for projects that enriched their friends. They dotted the skyline with ego-gratifying symbols of modernity: the world's tallest buildings, highways through rice paddies, the next Silicon Valley. Until disaster loomed on the horizon, governments and corporate titans together managed to cover up bad news that might warn investors that some of that dynamism was really a lighted bundle of dynamite.
 
'European Values'
 The fear of criminal libel suits kept a tight rein on what the press said about politicians. While it was hardly a secret that the family of President Suharto of Indonesia had swept up most of the nation's lucrative businesses into its own government-protected monopolies, it was unhealthy to explore in public how corruption could undermine Indonesia's future.
Fraud, deception and influence-peddling are hardly uniquely Asian; it was less than a decade ago that all three contributed to America's savings and loan crisis. In fact, there may be no such thing as "Asian values," good or bad: even at the height of Asia's boom it seemed improbable that a salaryman trudging off the train in Yokohama shared much of a world view with an ethnic Chinese executive in Indonesia. Think what it would take to get a German and a Frenchman to agree on "European values."
But in Asia the talk about common values contributed to arguments that there was something unique, perhaps even innate, about the region's material success. And that bred an overbearing arrogance in the business world. Business leaders boasted in the early 1990's that Asia would soon be generating enough wealth to become the world's banker. The Americans could staff the global granary. And Europeans would run a series of national boutiques, so that the rest of the world had somewhere to drink wine, buy art and go skiing before returning to the important business of making a fortune.
"There was a great deal of myth-making throughout Asia about the real sources of prosperity," said John Dower, a historian at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "They believed their own spin, and we believed it too, because who could argue with success?"
One question now is whether Asia's present and no doubt temporary humbling will lead to any fundamental reassessment of the link between its authoritarian ways and its success. Until now, Asia's need to keep building prosperity -- putting "economic rights" first, in the lingo of the "Asian values" argument -- has been used as a justification to keep a lid on individual freedom.
 
Helping Themselves
 President Jiang Zemin of China used a muted version of that argument during his visit to the United States last month. And that argument has been the constant subtext as the founder of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, has jousted with the West over the relationship between economic progress and the "Asian value" of "respect for authority."
The roots of Asia's economic troubles, however, make a pretty convincing case that authoritarians can mess up the operations of fast-growing economies as skillfully as anyone can. They did so chiefly by trying to manipulate markets to help themselves and their friends.
The toughest job facing the I.M.F. may be changing that culture -- convincing countries that they have to reveal financial figures that could expose the dealings of the politically well-connected. The I.M.F. will undoubtedly insist on austerity, which means canceling big dams and family-owned car projects.
No doubt many in Asia will declare that the I.M.F. is acting as a proxy for the Americans. The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, has already warned against "re-colonization." What is really happening, though, is the true "fusion" of Asian and Western values. And it may not make for a very pacific time.

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: The World;
For Iraq, a Dog House With Many Rooms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
WHAT if Saddam Hussein really means it? Suppose all the doors in Iraq, even those in sumptuous presidential palaces, open to United Nations weapons inspectors and all that anthrax and VX poison, those stashed warheads and secretly imported missile parts, are carted away into history. Iraq is then free of sanctions, right? Not exactly.
Over the last few years, to the consternation of European, Chinese and Japanese members of the Security Council, the Clinton Administration from time to time has reminded the Iraqis and anyone else listening that the omnibus Security Council Resolution 687, which served as a cease-fire agreement ending the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf, has other requirements. 
 The resolution, which established the Special Commission that has been disarming Iraq ever since, swept up a list of other demands on Iraq that had not been met. Among them: accounting for 604 missing Kuwaitis and others of various nationalities who disappeared during Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait in August 1990.
Iraq also had to return stolen Kuwaiti property and to make good on "any direct loss, damage, including environmental damage and the depletion of natural resources, or injury to foreign governments, nationals and corporations, as a result of Iraq's unlawful invasion and occupation of Kuwait." A compensation commission in Geneva has been working on that, using confiscated Iraqi assets and money from the limited oil sales that Iraq is allowed to make. But over the last few years, only $727 million has been paid on claims totaling $220 billion.
When President Clinton said this month that "the sanctions will be there until the end of time, or as long as he lasts," Mr. Clinton may have been referring -- as aides hastened to explain later -- just to Mr. Hussein's recent challenge to American arms inspectors, but the phrase had a familiar ring at the United Nations. When Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was the United States representative here, she left the impression among other Security Council members that the Clinton Administration had its own measures of Iraqi compliance that went beyond destruction of its weapons.
 
Sanctions for Eternity
 Other Security Council members said the Clinton position went beyond what they had agreed to accept when the Bush Administration was in charge. Other nations' understanding of Resolution 687 is that the embargo on oil sales is linked directly to the weapons destruction, and not to other issues.
Diplomats say that this vague threat of eternal sanctions by the Americans has only fueled Iraq's sense that it might as well be troublesome. There is only one reward Iraq wants: the freedom to sell oil. A number of diplomats here believe that the United States, too, has a single priority: the end of Saddam Hussein.
Fortunately for Washington, the Iraqi President is prone to making things worse for himself at critical moments, and any hopes of seeing the Special Commission declare him weapons-free are very dim for the foreseeable future.
There has long been a feeling among Europeans and others that if Iraq met all the requirements of the weapons-elimination program, the United States would be in trouble in the Security Council if it tried to prolong sanctions by other means. This was previewed only a month ago when the Americans failed to pile new sanctions on Iraq. But the situation was reversed after the Iraqis, true to form, overreached and disrupted the work of investigators, and were punished with travel bans on their officials.
It would come as no surprise if the United States were to appear quite generous in coming discussions on allowing Iraq to sell more oil under the emergency measure known as the "oil for food" resolution, which went into operation early this year after years of Iraqi indecision on whether to accept the limited program. Washington is aware of the growing pressure to relieve the suffering of Iraqi citizens, whose economy has collapsed around them during seven years of sanctions. Even United Nations agencies, among them the World Health Organization and Unicef, the children's fund, have been critical of the harsh sanctions.
No one sitting in the Security Council in April 1991, when the cease-fire resolution was adopted, expected sanctions to last this long. Richard Butler, who took over last summer as executive chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, said recently that inspectors had thought they would accomplish the task in a matter of months. There is ample evidence that Iraq also believed that if it gave up a little of this and a little of that -- and then hid the rest away -- the inspectors would leave and Mr. Hussein could resume building his illegal arsenal.
 
The Luxury of Stalemate
 It did not work that way. Because of the dogged sleuthing of the Special Commission, the Iraqis have been exposed as major stockpilers of some of the most lethal biological and chemical weapons known to science. They have been shown to have been secretly working on nuclear weapons, and they have never ceased trying to convert their permitted defensive missiles and warheads into longer-range threats.
And Washington has enjoyed the luxury of not needing to develop alternative policies. From the vantage point of some other countries, the two sides will not be able to maintain this equilibrium forever. The alternative, however, could be grim. As recent events have demonstrated, Iraq is capable of serious challenges to the Security Council. The United States, now the lone superpower, with dwindling support for a military option, may have to take on the Iraqis alone next time.
Or, if Iraq should be declared free of weapons, the Americans may have to accept living with Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: The World;
A Century Later, Letting Africans Draw Their Own Map

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Congo

 BODY:
FROM the earliest days of Africa's postcolonial era, a critical pair of thoughts have been virtual articles of faith for generations of African intellectuals.
Africa must unite in order to prosper, according to the first tenet, most famously associated with Kwame Nkrumah, the founding father of Ghana whose brand of Pan-Africanism went so far as to prescribe a United States of Africa. 
 The corollary, which has taken on ever greater prominence as contemporary Africa's political woes have multiplied, is that the European partition of the continent at the Berlin Conference of 1885 is at the root of much of Africa's instability.
Guided by their own conservatism -- and a will to hold onto power and a fear of an even greater instability -- most of the continent's early independence leaders recoiled from Mr. Nkrumah's vision. In its place, they enshrined among Africa's most widely accepted political rules a pledge of non-interference in one another's affairs.
As a result, Africa's political elites have spent much of the last 40 years insisting that the current hodgepodge of states be maintained at all costs, even as African intellectuals curse their borders as the creation of arrogant outsiders who took no heed of this continent's ethnic, historical or economic realities.
Gaining little notice at first but recently acquiring dramatic force, events in this decade are shaking Africa's old geopolitical order as never before. With the implosion of Somalia, the breakup of Ethiopia and the narrowly averted disintegration of Liberia and Sierra Leone, Mr. Nkrumah's challenge to Africa's acceptance of its inherited fragmentation has assumed renewed relevance, even urgency, in the 1990's -- just as Europe is blurring its own political and economic boundaries.
Moreover, with the end of superpower alliances that helped keep the map of Africa neatly frozen during the cold war, African states have clearly abrogated the old non-interference axiom and openly challenged precolonial borders.
The stiffest challenge to Africa's old state system has come in a string of Central African conflicts that began with the nine-month war in Zaire (now known as the Democratic Republic of Congo). Congo's war ended in May with the victory of Laurent Kabila, the leader of an insurgency, who was heavily supported by troops from Rwanda, Uganda and Angola.
That this war would be radically different from the continent's many other post-independence conflicts was announced at its outset a year ago when the Rwandan President, Pasteur Bizimungu, openly called for a "Berlin II, so that we can reflect on the disorders created by Berlin I."
The immediate complaint of Mr. Bizimungu's Government was that Zaire, led by the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, was harboring Hutu militiamen who mounted constant attacks against Rwanda's Tutsi-dominated Government. But many saw in the President's outspoken invocation of the Berlin Conference the reflection of another grief, this one with its roots in the colonial history of Belgium, which once defined and possessed both Rwanda and Congo. Tiny Rwanda has one of the world's highest population densities, and may never find a way to accommodate the warring Hutu and Tutsi within its confines. Next door, meanwhile, Congo is a geographic colossus with one of Africa's lowest population densities.
Rwanda's intervention in the former Zaire was followed last month by an Angolan blitzkrieg in the neighboring Congo Republic, decisively ending that country's four-month civil war in favor of Denis Sassou-Nguesso, a former dictator who has now been returned to power. And this month Angola reportedly helped plot a narrowly averted coup in Zambia, its southern neighbor, because of Zambia's suspected assistance to Angolan rebels.
 
On Its Own Behalf
 As Rwanda did in Zaire, Angola was intervening out of coolly calculated national interests. In the Congo Republic, these included knocking out rear bases of support for long-smoldering Angolan rebellions and securing the strategically precarious Cabinda enclave -- a tiny land mass sandwiched between the two Congos that ranks as one of Berlin's most perverse constructions, but which also happens to contain two-thirds of Angola's vast oil wealth.
For many who specialize in African affairs, unless this continent's leaders can peacefully rethink the map of Africa together, wars like these, driven by population pressures or competition for scarce resources, will be the wave of the future.
"A certain number of principles that date from the independence era are already being shattered, notably the principle of non-interference," said Edem Kodjo, a former Prime Minister of Togo and former Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity. "The intangibility of borders is likely to be next, because many of our states are inviable, either for economic or political reasons, or because of their population or ethnic composition."
Mr. Kodjo, a lifelong Pan-Africanist who has written about the need to reconfigure the continent's states, says Africa is bound to move toward what he called larger political ensembles in a process that risks being bloody. "Perhaps we can spare ourselves the violence, but if you look at history most political units have been built through war," he said. "Take the example of Germany and Bismarck, or of Italy, or of the United States itself."
Other African intellectuals fear that any sweeping reconsideration of Africa's borders would prove too costly to the world's poorest continent, threatening gradual gains in economic development and institution building. And, citing the bloody breakup of India and Pakistan at independence in 1947, they say no one can predict the cost in lives.
 
The Ethnic Spaghetti
 Then comes the vexing problem of ethnicity. Europe's imperial cartographers have been criticized for more than a century for casually drawing up borders that separated ethnic groups or placed longtime rivals in the same colony. Africa's ethnic complexity, however, makes doing any better on this score an almost insurmountable challenge.
Some experts in African affairs say any change to political geography is unlikely to come through costly European-style wars of conquest or ethnic-based redrawing of the map. Africa's reconfiguration, these experts say, is already well under way but involves a more subtle process in which regional economic and military powers emerge and express their hegemony without seeking to extend outright sovereignty beyond their borders.
Some of these new powers -- like South Africa within its region, Nigeria in West Africa, Angola in Central Africa and a tandem of Uganda and Rwanda in the east -- are already known. Others that may emerge in time could include Congo, Kenya and Tanzania, and the Ivory Coast.
In a scenario of this type involving regional powers and tributary states, an already powerful Nigeria will continue to consolidate its influence in a collection of West African states that would, at a minimum, include Benin, Niger, Chad and Cameroon.
"A lot of Caribbean leaders don't sneeze without first consulting Washington, and I suspect that things could become much the same in parts of Africa," said Will Reno, an Africa specialist at Florida International University, referring to such emerging regional powers.
"In 15 or 20 years, the map of Africa is going to look pretty much as it does today, but a visit to Africa could feel very different," he added. "By then, Benin, Niger or Chad could feel like mere extensions of Nigeria, in the same way that when I travel 50 miles east from Miami, the Bahamas feel like a county of Florida."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
A Yawning Trade Deficit
The United States trade deficit grew to $11.1 billion in September, the widest in eight months, the Government said, with Asia's financial problems worsening the gap. Other economic reports were far less worrisome. Consumer prices rose by a modest two-tenths of 1 percent again in October, helping limit inflation over the last 12 months to 2.1 percent, the lowest level since oil prices collapsed a decade ago. United States industrial output advanced in October for the 15th consecutive month, although at an unexpectedly subdued rate of 0.5 percent, indicating an absence of any inflationary threat. 

MARKETS
The Bull Is Back
Markets rallied strongly, fueled by a growing optimism that the turmoil in Asia would not subvert Wall Street's spectacular bull market and by indications that a conflict in the Persian Gulf might have been averted. The Dow Jones industrial average gained about 4.1 percent last week, pulling it well above its level just before the 554-point drop on Oct. 27. It ended the week up 308.59, at 7,881.07. The Nasdaq composite index rose 37.24, to 1,620.75. The bond market also enjoyed a strong week, with the yield on the 30-year bond hovering near a 21-month low at 6.03 percent.
 
TEAMSTERS
A Blow to Carey and Labor
The nation's labor movement, on the ropes since the Reagan Administration delivered a knockout punch to striking air traffic controllers, seemed on the verge of a comeback, particularly since Ron Carey, left, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, led 180,000 United Parcel Service workers in a successful and popular strike in August. Now a court-appointed union monitor has delivered his own punch. Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge, barred Mr. Carey, who had long been considered a leading crusader against corruption, from running for re-election, contending that he had diverted members' dues to his campaign coffers in last year's nullified election. That leaves James P. Hoffa, the son of the legendary teamsters' leader, as the clear favorite in the coming election.
 
ADVERTISING
P.& G.'s $1 Billion Move
Procter & Gamble made the biggest assignment in the history of advertising, consolidating responsibilities for planning and buying television commercial time in the United States -- with an estimated $1 billion to $1.2 billion in annual spending -- at a single agency, Televest, a unit of MacManus Group. Televest specializes in media services, and the P.& G. decision is the most recent in a skein of consolidations by giant advertisers that have come to view media buying as a specialty that needs its own expertise, just like creative work.
 
TECHNOLOGY
A Nation of Nerds?
Digital technology -- often defined as both computing and telecommunications, along with a variety of consumer electronics products -- is now the nation's largest industry, ahead of construction, food products and automotive manufacturing, according to a study sponsored by the American Electronics Association and the Nasdaq market. Sales in the field have grown 57 percent in the 1990's, to $866 billion. The businesses generated 6.2 percent of the nation's output of goods and services in 1996 and employed nearly 4.3 million people. The study represents perhaps the most comprehensive statistical portrait to date of what is called "the new economy" -- one populated by high-technology companies that generate new wealth, new work practices and new challenges in public policy.
 
DEALS
Merrill, on Winged Feet
Merrill Lynch & Company agreed to acquire Mercury Asset Management Group. of Britain, one of Europe's largest investment firms, for $5.3 billion in cash. It would be the most expensive acquisition ever in the money management business and reflects a push by financial service companies, including banks, brokerage firms and investment companies, to move into the rapidly growing business of money management.
 
BANKS
The Big Get Bigger
Accepting the richest price ever for a United States bank, Corestates Financial of Philadelphia agreed to a $17.1 billion offer from acquisition-minded First Union of Charlotte, N.C. The combined bank would have the largest share of deposits in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and a branch network spanning the East Coast from Florida to southern Connecticut. The deal would leave Philadelphia, the nation's first banking capital, without a major bank that calls it home. . . . An even bigger bank merger is being discussed in Britain. Barclays and National Westminster were said by people close to the talks to be weighing a $20 billion deal.
