LENGTH: 736 words

HEADLINE: The Fortunate Seven

BYLINE: By Gene Jones; Gene Jones is the director of the Des Moines Coalition for the Homeless.

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
The birth of septuplets here in Iowa last week has produced a reaction that reveals the strange, perhaps even warped character of American compassion and obligation.
These babies are special. They are special because of the odds against their conception. They are special because of the mix of faith and medical skill that sustained their gestation. They are special because, after birth, they are vulnerable. They are special because all at once there are seven new lives in the world, with all the joys and all the sleepless nights that seven new lives promise. 
 But all babies brought into this world, no matter what the circumstance of their birth, are special. All children are special.
This fact brings into focus the contradictory mix of private compassion and public scorn that characterizes American moral sensibilities today.
With the birth of these babies came offers of food, diapers, a new Chevy van, furniture, even full college scholarships. All this is wonderful. These acts of kindness are, by definition, "good," given our moral sensibilities, because the compassion is immediate, uncalculated, a matter of personal choice.
But these compassionate acts also reveal moral contradictions. The best example of this is the offer by Iowa's Governor, Terry Branstad, to provide a house for this family. The Governor has already assured us that this is a matter of private compassion, that he has simply used his office to secure private donations to make this offer a reality.
The paradox of this is that Mr. Branstad has been Governor for nearly 15 years, a period in which homelessness has increased so that there are at least 9,000 homeless children in Iowa, according to a study that is three years old. The study, conducted by the state Department of Education, found that 52 percent of the homeless people in Iowa are children. This is one of the highest proportions in the nation.
Every child is special.
Governor Branstad has presided over a state with an astounding number of low-income households -- up to 200,000 in all -- that are "shelter poor," meaning that they are paying so much for their housing and utilities that they do not have enough for food or clothing or transportation. The Iowa Department of Economic Development has estimated that it would take an investment of at least $3 billion to resolve this crisis.
This is the point: there are too many poor, single women with children living in Iowa who every month face the cruel choice of what not to buy for their children so that they can pay for rent and utilities. And it is this Governor, who celebrates private compassion and who has been identified as a leader in so-called welfare reform, who adamantly stands in the way of every effort made by nonprofit housing groups to dedicate a meager $8 million to $10 million in real-estate transfer taxes to the building or rehabilitation of low-cost housing.
Every child is special.
In the last two years, more than 2,000 families -- with 6,000 to 8,000 children -- have been disqualified from welfare and placed in Iowa's "limited benefits program," which gives some aid, including food stamps, for a maximum of one year. A recent study of this program found that 49 percent of the 137 families surveyed that had been disqualified from welfare saw their incomes drop an average of $384 a month within eight months of being placed on limited benefits.
The study does not identify the average income of the disqualified families. But given the national average for families on welfare, the average loss of income would have left the families with about $5,500 a year, or $460 per month. These families are experiencing nothing less than economic destitution within eight months -- that is, shortly before they drop completely off society's radar screen, since the state so far has not been tracking them after the year of limited benefits runs out.
Every child is special.
Our moral sensibilities are hypocritical. Private compassion is good; public compassion and responsibility are bad. Every governor, indeed every President elected to "end welfare as we know it," is complicit in perpetuating this moral hypocrisy.
Only when we acknowledge that, yes, private compassion is good, but it can never match the need, only when we refocus on public compassion, can we truly acknowledge the wonder of all new lives. Yes, every baby, every child, is special.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bosnian Vote Could Backfire on West

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Acrid cigarette smoke hovered in the room of the Book Lovers' Club of Banja Luka, with its worn wicker chairs, steady clink of small coffee cups, noisy chatter and shelves of well-thumbed Serbian literature.
Groups of unemployed teachers, unpublished writers, journalists and others who pass for the intellectual lights of a small Bosnian city, most in threadbare coats, gathered to ward off an unseasonable chill and to escape from the political debacle that has engulfed Serbian-held Bosnia. But with rival Serb leaders facing off in this weekend's election, discussion inevitably reverted to politics. 
 "We hope the power struggle will end this weekend with the parliamentary elections," said Divna Damjanovic, 43, a reporter for a small magazine. "But we expect not. It may have only begun. People are frightened, tired, burned out. It is as if the war just refuses to end."
The latest round in the battle by Washington to replace Radovan Karadzic, the powerful former Bosnian Serb president who has been indicted on war-crimes charges, with his rival and successor, Biljana Plavsic, turns on a parliamentary vote this weekend.
But the vote, given Ms. Plavsic's waning support, appears increasingly likely to backfire on its Western patrons. To the chagrin of many Western diplomats, who feel that Ms. Plavsic is more likely to cooperate with them in carrying out the 1995 accords that ended the Bosnian conflict, the likely beneficiaries may be the extreme nationalists in the Radical Party, led by Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian paramilitary leader.
Radical Party leaders condemn Ms. Plavsic for "selling out" to the West and have promised to ally themselves with the Bosnian Serb hard-liners if elected.
"Plavsic's support is eroding," said Dorde Latinovic, 36, the parliamentary candidate from the Liberal Party, the only party in the Bosnian Serb republic that has doggedly condemned the nationalist movements that fueled the war. "The party officials she denounced as corrupt have not been arrested, but instead have switched sides and now run her party, making a mockery of her promises to clean up the government. Corruption and smuggling continue.
"Worst of all, she is perceived by most Serbs as a stooge of the West."
"There is little chance that Plavsic will control the new parliament," Mr. Latinovic added. "The elections will boost the authority of the one man the West seems to hate as much as Karadzic, Vojislav Seselj," the ultranational who is the leading contender in next month's presidential elections in Serbia.
If Dr. Karadzic's governing Serb Democratic Party, which expelled Ms. Plavsic last summer, and its allies in the Radical Party retain a majority in the 83-seat assembly, it will be a humiliating defeat for the United States, which has helped orchestrate the election in an effort to bring about a parliament free of Dr. Karadzic's dominance.
NATO troops, in moves that have antagonized many Serbs, have seized police stations in towns in the western part of Serbian-controlled Bosnia and installed police officers who have pledged loyalty to Ms. Plavsic. The troops have also taken over key television transmitters that allow a studio in Ms. Plavsic's office building in Banja Luka to dominate the airwaves, often with propaganda as crude as that of her rivals.
"Our best hope now is that Plavsic gets enough votes to build some kind of a coalition with other parties, perhaps the Socialists, who are closely linked with Milosevic," said a Western diplomat, referring to the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic. "If this does not work it will be a disaster."
The Social Democratic Party remains in control in the eastern half of Serbian-held Bosnia. Last Saturday, the police refused to allow Ms. Plavsic to cross the border from Serbia until NATO troops intervened.
Ms. Plavsic's newly formed party, the Serb People's Party, suffers from poor organization. And because it is dominated by former Social Democratic leaders it has been largely discredited. Rallies have failed to draw more than a few hundred lukewarm supporters and Ms. Plavsic's fiery denunciations of Dr. Karadzic and his allies for corruption, along with her vows to improve the economy, have yet to be matched by results.
The election campaign, which is being financed with $1.4 million from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, has been marred by violence and threats of intimidation, including the arrest on Wednesday by police officers loyal to Ms. Plavsic of a woman they said was trying to hire an assassin for $3 million to kill the president. Also this week, a bomb exploded under a car belonging to a pro-Karadzic editor of the state-run Glas Srpski daily in Banja Luka.
Last week, Ms. Plavsic's campaign headquarters in the eastern town of Bijeljina suffered severe damage when two gunmen fired off more than 90 rounds at the building and tossed smoke grenades inside. No one was inside at the time.
The United States' special envoy to Bosnia, Robert Gelbard, quietly moved last month to prevent the balloting from also including a vote for the presidency, believing that Ms. Plavsic could not be re-elected, Western diplomats said.
Nikola Poplasen, 48, leader of the Radical Party in Serbian-held Bosnia, is a close protege of Mr. Seselj.
Before the war, the two men taught together in the political science department at Sarajevo University. They went on to lead Serbian paramilitary units accused by human rights officials of widespread atrocities against Muslims and Croats, as well as looting and extortion.
"We did very well in the local elections this fall and will do even better in these parliamentary elections," said Mr. Poplasen, sitting with several burly bodyguards in a large wood-paneled office in the Hotel Bosna.
"We have six seats in this parliament and expect that number to triple. People know that we are not tools of the Americans. We stand for a Greater Serbia, but one free of corruption. When Mr. Seselj takes power in Serbia, the border along the Drina will disappear, if not in name then in reality. We will all live in one state."
The Radical Party was given $40,000 by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe for its campaign. Varying amounts were given to other parties depending on their size, organization officials said.
The election was called by Ms. Plavsic after she dissolved the Karadzic-dominated Parliament in July that voted to oust her from office. The United States then worked to persuade her political rivals to join in the election.
Whatever the election's outcome, some voters simply long for an end to the struggle within the Bosnian Serb leadership.
"Most people are sick of this political squabbling," said Stana Danilovic, 36, who has been unemployed since the war and sat with friends in the Book Lovers' Club. "There is a deep desire for one, strong party that can lead us out of this morass."

HEADLINE: To the U.S. Envoy in Hanoi, the Future Is Paramount

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 17

 BODY:
For Pete Peterson, a former Air Force pilot who spent six and a half years as a prisoner here during the Vietnam War, coming to Hanoi six months ago as the Ambassador of the United States was "the final act in a cathartic process."
"You have to make the decision to heal after an experience like that," he said of his long incarceration in Hoa Lo Prison here after his plane was shot down in 1966. 
 Both the United States and Communist-ruled Vietnam made a similar decision to heal by establishing full diplomatic relations in mid-1995, 20 years after the collapse of the American-backed South Vietnamese Government ended a war in which 58,000 Americans and millions of Vietnamese died.
Mr. Peterson took up his post in May after a long Senate confirmation process.
The young generation of Vietnamese that has grown up since the country's struggle for independence will succeed, he clearly hopes, in putting the past behind them and moving their country into the global economy. As the Communists allow business to flourish here, Mr. Peterson is confident that greater freedoms will follow.
"If they can get a strong economic engine going, that will allow the Vietnamese to improve the quality of life across the board," Mr. Peterson said in an interview in the new American Embassy, which is being jury-rigged in a tall building far from the elegant chanceries of the main diplomatic colony in Hanoi's colonial-era French quarter. He hopes negotiations may eventually allow the embassy to move to more attractive quarters.
The Ambassador, now 62, was shot down on Sept. 10, 1966, on his 67th mission over Vietnam. He bailed out over the Red River Delta, landing in a tree beside an irrigation ditch in the village of An Doai, halfway between Hanoi and Haiphong.
Two village militiamen captured him, made him take off his uniform, and forced him to walk to a local storehouse until military authorities could pick him up and take him to Hanoi.
This past Sept. 10, he said, four months after his arrival, he traveled to the village to meet again with the men who captured him.
"They had wanted me to go right away, but I was reluctant to go out there," he said. "It gave me some butterflies. It brought back memories. It was useful. I had tea with members of both of their extended families, and, mostly, we talked about how we as combatants were able to reconcile."
"Your life becomes so much more clear and unburdened -- you're not always lamenting the past," he said of the healing process. "I am reconciled to all of the past. If I hadn't been, when I went home, I would have wilted away."
A cease-fire agreement in 1973, which failed to end the war, ended imprisonment for him and the rest of the Americans in the prison, which became infamous as the "Hanoi Hilton." A new hotel called the Hanoi Opera Hilton is now under construction near the beautifully restored 19th-century Opera House in the French colonial center of the city, to be operated by Hilton Hotels International.
"When I left the 'Hilton' that day, I essentially said, 'I've got to leave hate at the gate here,' " Mr. Peterson said. "But I was a real Rip Van Winkle -- I had to catch up with an awful lot of things I missed, and I finally said I can't reconstruct the entire six and a half years."
He had never seen his youngest child, 7 years old at the time. His two other children, teen-agers by then, felt he had abandoned them, he said. He and his wife, the late Carlotta Ann Neal Peterson, had to become reacquainted, and he had to try to resume his military career.
"All those things were stressful," he said. "Some of those things I accomplished successfully, and some I did not."
Mr. Peterson ended his military career as a colonel in 1981 and, a decade later, was elected to Congress as a Democratic from Florida. President Clinton nominated him to be the first United States Ambassador to Vietnam early in 1996, but Senate confirmation of him was delayed by debate over whether the Vietnamese were cooperating with the American effort to determine the fate of more than 2,000 soldiers then listed as missing in action.
American concern about prisoners of war and other soldiers listed as missing was long the driving force of American reluctance to move beyond suspended hostility to engagement with Vietnam, but, Mr. Peterson said, "we are now able to certify significant progress on the part of the Vietnamese in that area."
Though about 1,560 Americans are still listed as missing, the Ambassador said that identification of remains had been established conclusively for about 150 men whose families and military superiors believed might have survived into captivity, despite Vietnamese assurances that all surviving American prisoners were released in 1973.
"Of 194 discrepancy cases, only 38 to 40 remain to be determined," he said. And, he added, American records and testimony by individual American veterans had enabled the Vietnamese to find remains of some of their own missing in action, a legion that totals 300,000.
"As we come to a more normalized relationship with Vietnam, it becomes much more complex," Mr. Peterson said.
With American investment here now over $1 billion even without a bilateral trade agreement, snagged in complex negotiations, Vietnamese-American trade has the potential for tremendous growth, he said.
"Our focus is now on moving toward economic issues, and we have more than 500 American companies and more than 30 universities working in one way or another in Vietnam today," he said.
The way the Vietnamese handle emigration of those who want to leave, and the return of emigres who agree to come back, is one of the main criteria Congress will use before granting the low-tariff trade status most countries have with the United States. Before Congress will lift the remaining restrictions on trade between the United States and Vietnam, American officials say, Vietnam will have to live up to a promise to speed up exit permits for the 7,000 people who still want to leave. Earlier this year, Vietnam had issued far fewer than the 1,500 permits a month it had promised.
But Mr. Peterson said some applicants may now be starting to think about staying instead. "A lady who ran a restaurant I visited in Can Tho recently told me she had a friend who couldn't get documents," he said. "But she told me, 'That's O.K., living in Vietnam now is O.K.' We're seeing a number of applicants now who are no-shows," he said.

HEADLINE: 10 Heroin Deaths in Texas Reflect Rising Use by Young

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

DATELINE: PLANO, Tex., Nov. 18

 BODY:
This suburb of about 190,000 people hardly looks like a place where young people regularly die of heroin. Plano, 20 miles north of Dallas's forlorn downtown, is all big and new, with similar sprawling houses crammed side by side.
It is a modern Texas boom town, having grown from a population of under 4,000 in 1960. People move here to avoid inner-city schools and urban crime. Many arrived for well-paying jobs at companies like the computer services concern EDS, which has its headquarters here. In 1989, Plano's median household income of $53,905 beat the national figure of $30,056 by 79 percent. 
 But since January 1996, nine young people living or going to school in Plano have died of heroin overdoses, and another young person died at a party here.
Although the number of heroin deaths is startling for a city of this size, drug experts say that the rising use of heroin among young people is a growing phenomenon. The number of high school students nationally who have used heroin almost doubled last year -- rising to 2 percent of all students -- as what was once considered a narcotic for down-and-out junkies became fashionable and moved to the suburbs, said Alan I. Leshner, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.
Heroin coming into this country is now much purer, allowing it to be snorted like cocaine, ingested in a capsule or smoked with marijuana, Dr. Leshner said, adding, "Kids who would never inject themselves will snort it." At the same time, Dr. Leshner said, the price of heroin dropped and some fashion industry advertising seemed to glamorize the use of heroin.
The city's Police Chief, Bruce D. Glasscock, said: "It's not just Plano. It's a national problem."
He pointed to the 48 people who died in the Orlando, Fla., area in 1995 and 1996, 10 of them 21 or younger. Only six died from heroin overdoses in the same area in 1994, said a medical official in Florida.
The latest Plano victim was a 16-year-old Plano Senior High School student, Erin Baker. She was found dead on Nov. 9 after staying all night at a friend's apartment in nearby Denton. The youngest heroin victim was a 14-year-old boy who was found dead in April in a church parking lot where friends had dumped his body, officials said.
More than 1,500 parents and students came out for a town meeting last week to discuss the problem and to search for ways to prevent more deaths. Some parents were surprised that they had to deal with heroin at all, that teen-agers reared in comfortable homes, with nice cars to drive and money to spend, would turn to such a a hard drug.
"It's very bizarre," said Henry Kliman this week as he picked up his daughter, Aliyah, 16, a classmate of the dead girl, at her high school. "We grew up in the 60's. Heroin was the taboo. We played with marijuana and booze."
But then he saw another parent picking up a child in a Porsche and said that Plano might be a town where parents had "a little too much money and too little time." Mr. Kliman told of friends of his daughter who spent the night with her with their parents seemingly unconcerned about where they were.
Some residents here recall the national attention Plano received in 1983 when seven of its young people committed suicide.
"Parents need to spend more time with their kids," said James Russell, as he trimmed a customer's hair at his Plano Barbers shop, one of a long block of turn-of-the century storefronts that hint at downtown Plano's quaint past. "My kids don't go out and run the streets. I'd be standing in the doorway."
In 1994, the Plano City Council realized there was a problem and passed a curfew to keep young people under 17 off the streets at night. Parents were grateful, Chief Glasscock said. For the last several years, school officials have used drug-sniffing dogs on school campuses, and two drug counselors were added to the high schools this year.
Few of the young people interviewed seemed surprised by the presence of heroin in their community. "It started with my friends last year," said Aliyah Kliman, 16, who said that she did not use the drug and that it was stupid to do so.
"It's like, 'Oh, I only do it once a week,' " she said, mimicking some drug users. " 'I know what I'm doing. I'm only taking it in capsules.'
"No matter how you take it, that stuff will kill you," Aliyah said.
Jarrett Watkins, a 15-year-old 10th grader at Vines High School in Plano, said he had seen an eighth grader with heroin. "Last year was when the scene got a whole lot bigger," Jarrett said, an assessment seconded by Chief Glasscock.
Trey Watts, 17, was a friend of Miss Baker. He and some others had been playing pool at a friend's house that night and had tried repeatedly to reach the girl on her pager. The next morning, he said, her parents called the home where he was, looking for their daughter, only to learn later that she was dead in another friend's apartment in Denton.
"We tried to stop her," Trey said of his friend and her heroin use. "But she got back with other dealers. She was nice. She got hooked on a bad drug."
George Malina, 48, a consultant for business development, whose son, Milan Malina, died of a heroin overdose in Plano when he was 20, said the family had moved to one of Plano's gated communities on a golf course "to get away from these things." Milan was 17 when his father noticed something wrong.
"He became lethargic," Mr. Malina said. "He became argumentative. He became unemployable." Before that, he said, his son had been "extremely warm, loving, caring -- nicest kid in the world."

HEADLINE: How Tough Questions and Shrewd Mediating Brought Iraqi Showdown to an End

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
As an unarmed U-2 spy plane soared high over central Iraq two weeks ago, President Clinton was poised to order the biggest military operation of his Presidency.
In a military command center in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, senior American and Saudi officers nervously tracked the progress of the flight, ready to unleash an overwhelming barrage of bombs and missiles against an array of targets if President Saddam Hussein carried out his threat to shoot down the plane. 
The United States would have considered an Iraqi attack on the high-flying U-2 "an act of war," a senior Pentagon official told reporters. Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said in an interview that American retaliation would have meant a "horrendous result" for Iraq.
But by last weekend, even as more American warships steamed toward the Persian Gulf, Mr. Clinton was on the telephone with the Russians, French and British in search of a diplomatic solution.
In the end, the crisis did not get resolved on the battlefield but in a predawn meeting with officials from five countries in the glittering Palais des Nations in Geneva after a diplomatic initiative by a most unlikely mediator: Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia, a wily former spymaster and longtime friend of the Iraqis who has never been trusted by the United States.
During the three-and-a-half-week standoff over United Nations weapons inspections, Mr. Clinton and his national security advisers veered between the desire to hit Mr. Hussein hard for forcing the withdrawal of a United Nations inspection team and fear of the risks. Mr. Clinton longed to find concrete ways to relieve the suffering of the Iraqi people after seven years of economic sanctions -- including the possible dispatch of more food and medicine -- but without looking soft on Mr. Hussein.
 
A Situation That Needs 'Constant Tending'
Along the way, amid the Administration's discussions of how best to punish Mr. Hussein, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright raised a provocative question intended to obtain a realistic answer: if the United States was going to use force, was it prepared to use the force necessary to solve the Iraq problem once and for all by overthrowing Mr. Hussein?
By far the most important lesson for the Americans was that even the most immense strikes against Mr. Hussein would not necessarily destroy Iraq's ability to make chemical and biological weapons or produce the desired political result, forcing Mr. Hussein to reverse his decision to expel the American weapons inspectors.
Although the crisis was averted -- or at least postponed -- when 75 weapons inspectors flew back to Baghdad on Friday morning to continue their mission to destroy Iraq's remaining weapons of mass destruction, Mr. Hussein won at least one point: a commitment by Russia to argue his case with the goal of lifting crippling economic sanctions as soon as possible.
The situation in Iraq "clearly requires constant tending in terms of keeping, making it clear to Saddam Hussein that he is not going to get out of his box," Ms. Albright admitted to reporters on Friday. "It's going to require a long-term view. He does have some staying power."
Iraq had been frustrating the United Nations inspectors for months, denying them access to some sites and hiding and moving materials and documents. But the situation became untenable at the end of October when Iraq branded American weapons inspectors spies and ordered them to leave the country.
In a meeting of President Clinton's national security advisers on Oct. 30, followed by their meeting with the President the next day, the Administration defined its primary objectives with Iraq: to contain Iraq so that it cannot threaten its neighbors militarily and to achieve the return of the weapons inspectors without granting Iraq any concessions.
After Ms. Albright asked that the group discuss whether American policy ought to be directed at removing Mr. Hussein from power, Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, replied that it should not. Such a plan would require a huge commitment of American ground troops to Iraq, an unthinkable option.
"Cohen and Shelton were strong on one point: one should assume that short of the use of ground forces you cannot get rid of Saddam," said an official who took part in the discussions, referring to the Defense Secretary and the new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry Hugh Shelton.
Even at this early point, Mr. Clinton was not optimistic that the standoff could be resolved without the use of force, although he shared the frustration of his team that there was no clean, effective military option.
General Shelton, a gulf war commander who had been in his new job for only six weeks, presented charts and maps to make the case that if it came to the use of force, it would be a broader use of military power than President Clinton had ever made.
A strike would have required "many more than dozens" of targets, he said. These included not only Mr. Hussein's palaces and command and control centers, but also known weapons production sites and the infrastructure supporting them: military bases, roads, power plants, industrial sites.
General Shelton also explained the potential for civilian deaths and destruction of nonmilitary property. Particularly ominous was concern that hitting a chemical or biological weapons depot could spread a toxic cloud that could kill thousands of innocent people.
 
What Five Pounds Of Anthrax Can Do
The White House decided to prepare the country for war. In a meeting of Mr. Clinton and his top aides on Nov. 14, the decision was made to begin a public campaign through interviews on the Sunday morning television news programs to inform the American people of the dangers of biological warfare.
The most vivid show-and-tell came when Mr. Cohen placed a five-pound bag of sugar on the table, proclaiming that if the sugar were anthrax, it could kill half the population of Washington.
More important, Mr. Clinton made an impassioned plea to his advisers in that Friday meeting to come up with concrete steps the United States could take to relieve the suffering of the Iraqi people.
Mr. Clinton was painfully aware that continuation of tough sanctions had been a crucial part of the American strategy -- albeit unstated -- to destabilize Mr. Hussein's Government. But now the sanctions were doing more to erode the international coalition that had once stood firm against the Iraqi leader.
And Mr. Clinton knew that the collapse of the Middle East efforts had robbed him of much of his clout.
Although Washington's allies in Europe and the Persian Gulf agreed that Mr. Hussein must allow the United Nations inspections to continue as before, most were opposed to using force to make it happen.
The Administration launched a diplomatic blitz, with Mr. Berger and Ms. Albright making dozens of phone calls to their counterparts in Europe and the Middle East to drive home the message that the Iraqi action was not just against American members of the inspection team, but against the United Nations and the world.
The results were mixed. After days of consultations, there was only enough support to pass a modest resolution at the United Nations on Nov. 12 limiting travel by senior Iraqi officials.
In a meeting at the White House two days later, King Hussein of Jordan told Mr. Clinton that finding a peaceful solution was particularly important because of Arab rage at the United States over the collapse of the Middle East peace process, which Arab leaders attributed to Washington's support of an intransigent Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
"A military solution at this time will not help the United States," a participant in the meeting paraphrased King Hussein as saying.
Other allies, particularly Presidents Jacques Chirac of France and Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, wanted to find a formula to lift economic sanctions against Iraq eventually.
Both were said by aides to have been alarmed when Mr. Clinton seemed to toughen United States policy by saying that Mr. Hussein's actions against the United Nations inspectors insured "that the sanctions will be there until the end of time or as long as he lasts."
Mr. Clinton softened his line in telephone calls the next day.
He tried to assure the French and Russian leaders that the United States did not want the sanctions to last forever, French and Russian officials said. He also asked them to use their long-standing ties with the Iraqi leader to persuade him to readmit inspectors.
President Chirac said that there had to be some light at the end of the tunnel for Mr. Hussein, that it was necessary to have some sort of carrot approach, said a senior French official. Mr. Yeltsin made the point even more strongly, arguing that "now is not the time to use force," said an official familiar with the conversation.
The Saudis, meanwhile, gave no indication that they would be willing to allow American warplanes to use bases on their soil to launch air strikes if they became necessary.
In its zeal to find a diplomatic solution, the Administration violated its own pledge not to negotiate with Mr. Hussein. To help the Russians and French in their diplomacy, the United States, working with Britain, drafted a joint position paper that offered a plan to allow Iraq to buy more goods with its oil.
American officials said they would consider a number of incentives: increasing the amount of money that Iraq could raise through oil sales, extending the agreement so it would not be subject to review every six months, and allowing Iraq to buy more goods, like spare parts and civilian vehicles.
The resolution of the crisis would probably not have happened without the intervention of one man: Mr. Primakov, the Russian Foreign Minister.
 
The Man at the Heart Of the Negotiations
Mr. Primakov -- Arabist, former journalist and spy -- had never been trusted in Washington, even less so after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 when he presented the Bush Administration with what Washington considered a ludicrous proposal: to allow Mr. Hussein to keep two Kuwaiti islands and part of its main oilfield in order to prevent a war.
But Mr. Primakov had known Mr. Hussein for more than 25 years. So there he was last Tuesday, seated next to Mr. Yeltsin in Moscow, negotiating with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, with the blessing of the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Aziz had one main concern: winding up the inspections and getting the sanctions lifted, Russian officials said.
But the Russians made the point that throwing out the inspectors or prompting a confrontation with the United Nations was the wrong way to go about getting the sanctions lifted.
Mr. Primakov and Mr. Aziz negotiated a joint Russian-Iraqi text with the same passion and precision of an arms control treaty. "Russia, for its part, will energetically promote the speedy lifting of sanctions against Iraq on the basis of its compliance with the corresponding U.N. Security Council resolutions," it said.
Mr. Primakov was so eager to get on with a long-planned trip to Latin America -- and perhaps keep the spotlight on himself -- that he threatened to meet with his counterparts from the other permanent members of the Security Council without Ms. Albright, who was in India. "Yevgeny, this isn't the way to do business," she told him. He finally compromised, summoning them to Geneva at 2 A.M. on Thursday.
Mr. Primakov announced that Iraq would allow United Nations weapons inspectors, including the Americans, to return. No strings attached. In return, he said, he had given his word that Russia would use its influence to speed up the work of the inspectors.
"Yevgeny, you must understand our red lines," Ms. Albright said, warning him that any commitments he made were only on Russia's behalf.
"I speak on behalf of no one except Russia," he assured her.
After he read his version of a draft communique, Ms. Albright insisted on changes. She demanded that the text refer to the "unconditional return" of the inspectors. She insisted that it also include a mention of Security Council Resolution 1137 because it specifically states that the inspectors can be as intrusive as they see fit.
Even after the five officials had agreed on the text and it was being typed, she demanded another condition: that any change to the work of the inspectors had to be approved by the Security Council.
On Friday, United Nations weapons inspectors returned to Baghdad. In the Persian Gulf, the United States continued its huge military buildup.
At the United Nations, the Russians began their pitch on behalf of the Iraqis. As a first step, they believe the United Nations should certify Iraqi compliance on disarmament of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, officials said.
The Russian approach already had some success, shifting the subject from Iraqi noncompliance and forcing the United States to explain how long the sanctions have to be maintained and why.
"I consider this a great success of Russian diplomacy recognized by all, absolutely, a great success of President Yeltsin first of all, who's been in the lead of everything that's been done recently," Mr. Primakov said after the Geneva meeting.
But in Washington, there was no celebration. During the inspectors' absence, Iraq may have been able to hide evidence, destroy monitoring equipment and produce new weapons or toxins.
"The President was cautious about what the implications would be," a top official said. "He can't say he even now feels this is necessarily over."
As for the eventual lifting of economic sanctions, Ms. Albright made clear on Friday that full destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction was not enough. There were other resolutions to be obeyed, including one that requires Iraq not to repress its own people. That may mean sanctions indeed will stay as long as Mr. Hussein continues to be the President of Iraq. Or perhaps forever.

HEADLINE: Clinton Rejects Call By Russians to Ease Sanctions on Iraqis

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton today rejected Russia's call for an easing of sanctions on Iraq, saying Baghdad continued to impede United Nations weapons inspectors.
Mr. Clinton said he was grateful for Russia's diplomatic help in defusing the three-week crisis, which began when Iraq barred the American members of a United Nations weapons inspection team on Oct. 29. The entire team then left Iraq, raising fears of a new military confrontation between that country and the United States. 
 Today, the President said he remained wary about the willingness of Iraq's leader, President Saddam Hussein, to abide by the international arms monitoring regime and said a strict inspections program must continue.
Mr. Clinton called President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this morning, and the two leaders spoke for 40 minutes, according to White House officials. Mr. Clinton relayed his opposition to any immediate relaxation of the onerous economic sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
"The United States is concerned about the welfare of the people of Iraq," Mr. Clinton said in an airport statement on arrival here today for a pair of Democratic fund-raising events. "We don't want to see them suffer unnecessarily. We took the lead in putting in place a policy in the United Nations that permits us to expand humanitarian assistance there.
"But the most important thing is that those inspectors need to be back at work and they need to work without impediment," he said.
He cited a report today from the leader of the United Nations inspection team, Richard Butler, that Baghdad continues to block access to suspect sites. Mr. Butler recommended a "more robust" inspection regime.
"That is what we need to focus on," Mr. Clinton said.
He thanked Mr. Yeltsin for Moscow's role as an intermediary this week in persuading Mr. Hussein to readmit the arms inspectors "at least temporarily."
Mr. Yeltsin has argued that the inspections have demonstrated Iraqi compliance with demands to end its development of nuclear weapons and medium-range missiles to deliver them, thus justifying a partial lifting of the sanctions. He told Mr. Clinton that Iraqi progress should bring a speedier end to the sanctions, according to a White House official.
But Mr. Clinton said not enough had been done.
"Keep in mind, it is more difficult for these inspectors to do their work with regard to biological and chemical weapons than it is with regard to missile and nuclear issues under their jurisdiction," Mr. Clinton said. "And we have to do more."
He said the ultimate judgment about Iraqi compliance must be made by the technical experts of the inspection teams, not diplomats or politicians.
The inspectors reported that Iraq is near compliance on scrapping its nuclear program, but not on biological, chemical or missile programs.
"What I emphasized to President Yeltsin is we have come a long way by working together, and we have to continue to work together," Mr. Clinton said. "And the decisions about what to do with the inspections should be made based on the evidence, the facts, and the professional judgment of the inspectors. Neither the political inclinations of the United States nor of our allies should control these decisions."
A senior Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, rejected Mr. Hussein's appeal to exempt certain "presidential sites" in Iraq from weapons monitoring. He said the United Nations inspectors, not Baghdad, would dictate what sites come under scrutiny.
"I would just note here, when talking about presidential palaces, that Saddam Hussein has 47 presidential palaces, at least one of which is as large as the District of Columbia in land mass," the official said. "So we're not talking here about little country homes."
Mr. Clinton was in Denver on his way to the annual Pacific Rim economic summit meeting, which is being held this year in Vancouver. His planned stopovers in Denver and Seattle en route to Vancouver were to raise more than $1 million for the Democratic Party.

HEADLINE: Hotel Business Is Growing Bigger, Busier and Faster

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
The American Radiator Building, the Gothic tower on 40th Street whose gold crown was once lighted to resemble a hot radiator in a tribute to the automobile age, is being recast as a hotel in the midst of an extraordinary rush by developers to meet the soaring demand for hotel rooms in New York City.
Philip Pilevsky and Brian McNally, owner of 44, the restaurant at the Royalton Hotel, have signed a $16.5 million contract to buy the landmark 1924 building at 40 West 40th Street, which overlooks Bryant Park and the New York Public Library, and plan to convert it into a luxury, 170-room boutique property called the Bryant Park Hotel. 
 In addition, an Atlanta hotelier is buying the adjoining structure for a residential hotel, for long stays, with about the same number of rooms. The company, Homestead Village, plans to retain the existing facade and add a 32-story tower behind the building, which was originally an annex to the American Radiator Building, also known as the American Standard Building.
The two deals at the American Radiator Building bring the number of hotel projects announced or begun this year to 18. Hotels are often jammed to capacity these days and the average room rate has soared 30 percent to $174.71 since 1994, so investors and hoteliers are spending more than $1 billion to add nearly 6,000 rooms to the city's inventory of roughly 60,000.
Memories of the industry's last recession seem to be lost in the rush to build on the rare development site or to convert stray warehouses and old office buildings to hotels.
"The price for existing hotels has gotten so high that it justifies the new construction and renovations that are springing up all over the city," said Jonathan Mechanic, the real estate partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, who has worked on a number of recent hotel deals. "It's fueled by a resurgence in New York City, both by business and tourism.," he said. "Rates are moving up because there's a scarcity of rooms in the city and that's why everyone's looking to do hotels."
The average occupancy rate at New York hotels will likely be about 86 percent for 1997, up from 74 percent in 1993, according to Coopers & Lybrand Lodging Research Network, meaning that during peak seasons there are few, if any, rooms available in the entire city.
The rush to build is far from over. On Tuesday, the developer Robert Gladstone and Intell Real Estate Investment are to close on a deal to build the first Planet Hollywood Hotel, a 50-story, 500-room property at Broadway and 47th Street.
Early this year, Sofitel, a French hotelier, announced plans for an $80 million, 400-room hotel on 44th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, while Marriott, the city's largest operator of hotels, is building a modest 244-room Courtyard Hotel on 40th Street, near Seventh Avenue, as well as a new 384-room hotel in downtown Brooklyn. Embassy Suites is building a 400-room hotel at the north end of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan.
"Even with all the hotels opening up, it still may not be enough," said Daniel H. Lesser, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield who specializes in the hotel industry.
Euphoria surrounds the current hotel market, but hoteliers, consultants and investors have overlooked the boom-and-bust nature of the business in the past. Six years ago, many hotels were left with empty rooms and heavy debts, as the recession, layoffs and the war in the Persian Gulf cut room and occupancy rates.
"Unless somebody is buying, building or renovating very judiciously, you could get banged very easily," said Bernard Goldberg of Gotham Hospitality, which owns five midmarket hotels in Manhattan.
Nine of the hotel projects announced this year involve conversions of existing buildings, which is far less expensive than new construction. Unlike the projects of the 1980's, when a number of very large hotels went up in midtown, many of the new projects are aimed at smaller niche markets.
"We're seeing some fundamental differences with the boom in the late 1980's," said Arthur Adler, lodging partner at Coopers & Lybrand in New York. "We're seeing smaller hotels and properties built in emerging parts of town, like lower Manhattan and Times Square."
The Ritz-Carlton chain plans to operate a five-star, 325-room hotel in a former office building at 17 Battery Place, at the foot of Manhattan, aimed at chief executives and wealthy tourists. The Cipriani restaurant family has similar plans for 55 Wall Street, where it announced plans for a banquet hall and 160-room luxury hotel.
In contrast, Ian Schrager, a partner of Mr. Pilevsky in the chic Royalton and Paramount hotels and now his competitor in New York and Miami Beach, recently bought the headquarters of WNET-TV, once known as the Henry Hudson Hotel, on West 58th Street for conversion to a 1,000-room hotel where rates will run about $75 a night.
Mr. Pilevsky and Mr. McNally, who no longer see eye to eye with Mr. Schrager, hope to replicate the upscale success of the Royalton and the Paramount at the American Radiator Building, which will cater to entertainment and fashion clients.
"There are so many things going on for hotels right now," Mr. Pilevsky said. "People are coming in from out of town who need to eat and stay in midtown. And this building is really spectacular."

HEADLINE: Asia Nations Limp Into Fiscal Talks As Turmoil Rages

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Since first meeting as a group in 1993, the leaders of the United States, China, Japan and other nations of the Pacific Rim have swaggered into their annual gatherings, almost arrogant in their confidence that the region would be the 21st century's economic engine and the new locus of world power.
But as they assemble here this weekend, President Clinton and his counterparts from 17 Asian and North and South American members will nearly all be limping, wounded by global economic forces beyond their control and, in Mr. Clinton's case, undercut by domestic political defeats. 
 On Friday, the financial turmoil that has been coursing through Asia claimed its largest victim, South Korea, the nation with the world's 11th-biggest economy. The Government in Seoul was forced to call on the international community for a financial bailout, a humbling step that has already been taken by Thailand and Indonesia.
The upheaval has also hit hard in Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Philippines, and could even dent Japan. As a result, the turmoil and how to stop it will no doubt dominate the discussions among the leaders, although they are unlikely to take any action beyond offering reassuring words about their determination to restore calm in financial markets and prosperity throughout Asia.
But the problems in Asia will have some concrete effects on American policy and on Mr. Clinton's ability to use the two-day gathering, which formally convenes Monday, to advance his own economic agenda championing free trade. The United States, particularly since Mr. Clinton became President, has based its approach to the region largely on expanding trade, a strategy embodied in a 1994 agreement with the Asia-Pacific countries to create a free-trade zone as early as 2010.
Asia's economic woes are already reducing the region's demand for American exports and are showing signs of sending the trade deficit in the United States to new highs. Consumed by their domestic economic problems, and by their associated political difficulties, few of the Asian leaders here will have much stomach for new market-opening initiatives that might bring objections at home.
Moreover, having failed this month in his all-out effort to win new trade-negotiating authority from Congress, Mr. Clinton clearly has less standing to demand that other nations take politically painful steps to drop their tariffs and other trade barriers.
And if Mr. Clinton cannot quickly convince liberal Democrats in Congress to change their position and grant him the negotiating power, his opportunity to pursue new trade deals in many product categories will be all but closed off, even if Asian trading partners are willing.
Mr. Clinton is also still smarting from Congress's rejection last week of his request for $3.5 billion in additional financing for the International Monetary Fund, the vehicle through which the bailouts of South Korea and other nations are being coordinated.
Mr. Clinton has been pressing for more I.M.F. financing all year to deal with exactly the kind of situation that has now erupted in Asia. Although Administration officials are confident that Congress will approve the financing next year, some foreign officials said the situation hurts the United States in its efforts to maintain its effective control over the terms of the international bailouts.
The mix of difficulties make this year the first real test of the annual gathering, known as the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or Apec. Founded in 1989 as a way for lower-level officials of Pacific Rim countries to discuss common interests, it was elevated to the status of a regional summit meeting by Mr. Clinton starting in 1993 as part of his effort to shift the nation's sights toward the economic opportunities and security challenges presented by a rapidly growing and modernizing Asia.
The leaders "face the most critical and difficult series of issues in the history of this young institution," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics. "Their ability to respond effectively and decisively will go far toward determining whether Apec will become a central player in resolving regional and global crises."
White House officials, while acknowledging the difficulties the Administration faces here, said the gathering would still be an effective stage on which to exert global economic leadership and, in particular, to highlight the benefits of trade and the need for Mr. Clinton to be granted so-called "fast-track" trade authority by Congress. With such authority, he can negotiate trade deals that Congress can approve or reject, but cannot amend.
They said the meeting was expected to give formal approval to the policies at the heart of American strategy in the region: that nations need to take responsibility for dealing with their financial problems by adopting more prudent economic policies, that the I.M.F. should take the lead when a bailout plan is necessary, and that countries should still work toward freer trade even while coping with economic difficulties.
That policy was embodied in an agreement worked out by American and Asian officials in Manila this week. The agreement effectively scuttled an idea first floated by Japan, and strongly opposed by the United States, to create a bailout fund for Asian nations that would operate outside the I.M.F., which typically requires stringent austerity programs in return for its financial assistance.
"In the past four years, obviously, with the enormous success of economies in Asia, there's been a good deal of emphasis upon what more can be done and how to take advantage of the rapidly growing economies," said Daniel Tarullo, Mr. Clinton's adviser on international economic affairs.
"Obviously, this year, with the recent turmoil in a number of East Asian financial markets, there is a different tone and different atmosphere," Mr. Tarullo said.
But he added the annual summit meeting would prove to be "a good instrument in trying times as well as good times."
American officials said that while they did not expect any big new trade deals, they were confident of winning agreement to drop trade barriers among the Pacific nations in one or two product categories ahead of the general deadline they have set of 2010 for the more developed nations.
There is also likely to be some discussion with Asian countries of their willingness to agree to a proposed World Trade Organization plan to allow banks, investment firms and other financial services providers more freedom to do business in other countries.
Mr. Clinton will also use the gathering to meet individually with leaders of several other countries, including Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan. Analysts and government officials are increasingly concerned that Japan's weak economy and the huge number of bad loans weighing down its banking system leave the country vulnerable to the spillover effects of the troubles in South Korea and Southeast Asia.
Mr. Clinton may also meet with President Jiang Zemin of China. American officials said they would like to build on the Chinese leader's release last weekend of the prominent political dissident Wei Jingsheng and to discuss Mr. Clinton's planned visit to China next year.
The leaders will also exchange ideas about how to deal with global warming in advance of an international meeting on the topic next month. And they are likely to consider inviting several new members into Apec, including Peru, Vietnam and Russia.
The current members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

Stocks Plummet in South Korea
 SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- Stocks plunged more than 4 percent here today in response to South Korea's decision to seek a loan from the I.M.F.
"Investors turned skeptical as they realized the I.M.F. bailout package would not be like a free lunch," said Choo Hee Yup, a broker at Dongwon Securities. The composite stock index shed 4.08 percent, or 20.64 points, to close at 485.43.
South Korea said late on Friday that it had asked the I.M.F. to provide about $20 billion in standby credits to overcome the country's financial crisis.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Scott, Rejected by Cardinals, a Stalwart for Giants

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
Lance Scott was having a really bad Monday. It was 6 A.M. last Aug. 18. The phone rang in his bedroom. "Bring in your playbook," the voice on the other end of the line said. "Coach wants to see you."
Lance Scott knew his third season as a center with the Arizona Cardinals was about to end. 
 He walked into the room of his son, Tucker, who was 5 weeks old that day. There Scott found his wife, Stacy. She had spent the night in the nursery to be near Tucker, who had been having trouble keeping any food in his stomach.
Lance told Stacy about being cut by the Cardinals. He went to work, came home unemployed and then was told Tucker would need emergency surgery to correct a stomach condition called pyloric stenosis.
It took Tucker's doctors two days to schedule the surgery. "That was hard," Scott said. "Watching your baby with an IV in his head, lying on the bed crying."
During that time, Scott's agent, Neil Schwartz, called other National Football League teams, trying to draw interest in his client.
"People told Neil, 'If he can't make the Cardinals, how's he going to make our team?' " Scott said.
On Thursday, Aug. 21, Tucker had surgery to expand a muscle in his stomach, alleviating most of his eating problems. He began a recovery that is happily on schedule three months later.
The same day, the phone at home rang for Lance. The Giants wanted him to fly to New Jersey for a tryout.
Four days later, they signed him to do the long snapping for punts and field-goal attempts.
Five weeks later, he was the starting center in the Giants' pivotal victory over the Dallas Cowboys.
Tonight against the Washington Redskins, he will make his seventh consecutive start. And as team officials have privately conceded that neither the veteran center Brian Williams, who has an eye injury, nor Williams's replacement, Derek Engler, who has a broken ankle, will return to play this season, Lance Scott is the Giants' center of the present and future.
A guy the hapless Cardinals did not want and other teams passed on is the center of the Giants' attack in a late-season playoff chase.
No Giants play tonight can begin until Scott points his right index finger at the Redskins' middle linebacker, then barks out coded blocking assignments. Even the wide receivers do not know what pass patterns they may have to run until they hear the orders from Scott.
As the Giants' offensive line coach John Matsko said: "At one of the most important positions on the field, we're playing with a guy we pulled off the street. And he's playing really well."
Scott, meanwhile, looks back across the past 14 weeks and smiles at the wonder of it all.
"My wife and I talk about it every day," he said, sitting in a room off the Giants' locker room. "It is amazing how well things all worked out."
But then, Lance Scott's Giants journey is full of coincidences and happenstance that would seem the product of destiny.
For example, do you know how Giants Coach Jim Fassel knew that Scott might be able to help his team?
He remembered Scott as the 15-year-old camper at the Jim Fassel Football Camp in 1987. Scott was a high school sophomore in Salt Lake City. Fassel was the head coach at the University of Utah.
"I remember he was a tough, aggressive player," Fassel said of Scott after practice Friday. "We recruited him at Utah."
Said Scott, "Oh, sure, I've known Coach Fassel forever."
Fassel left Utah before Scott arrived there. Scott nonetheless had an honor-filled collegiate career. When he became eligible for the N.F.L. draft in 1995, however, he was worried that a senior-year injury might keep him from being selected.
"I was thinking I'd call Coach Fassel, who was then with the Oakland Raiders," Scott said. "But I figured that would be kind of tacky."
Said Fassel, "I had kind of lost track of him."
Scott, who is 6 feet 3 inches and 300 pounds, was a fifth-round draft pick of the Cardinals. But he never played a down for Arizona, spending time on its developmental squad and on injured reserve. This year, the Cardinals cut Scott, 25, after their third exhibition game.
But Fassel had briefly re-entered the picture. In Scott's second year in Arizona, Fassel was the offensive coordinator. "I saw that he could do the long snapping even if they didn't ask him to," Fassel said. "And he learned my offensive system."
When Scott's name appeared on the waiver wire last August, Fassel knew what he wanted to do. "It could have been a permanent case of out of sight, out of mind," Fassel said. "But when I saw he was cut, I remembered that he was a tough kid even as a teen-ager. I knew we needed a long snapper, and I had confidence he would be the right fit."
Scott did the long snapping for four games. Then came Engler's broken ankle on Sept. 28, and a week later, Scott's first N.F.L. start, against the Cowboys. "My grandpa dialed up that game on his satellite dish for my family and friends in Utah," Scott said. "People were pretty excited because I hadn't played a game since college. But there I was playing in the N.F.L., just like I pictured it as a kid. And I was going against America's Team. And I played well, and we won. I've been getting calls from friends I haven't heard from for years ever since."
Said offensive tackle Scott Gragg: "That is the dream of everyone who is waiting for his shot -- you finally got your chance, you start, you play well, you start for the rest of your life. You never know how it's going to happen. You just wait and hope."
Said Matsko, "I've always believed that guys of high character who get second chances usually make the most of them."
Tucker Scott, meanwhile, is gaining weight, and, like his father, is doing well. Tucker, in fact, was on hand for a heavyweight exhibition in dining last week when Scott and Toni Gragg had all the offensive linemen over for dinner. "Yeah, we had a little steak fry," Scott Gragg said. "Well, it wasn't so little. We probably ate up the whole cow."
Lance and Stacy Scott had a good time. "It was a nice day," Lance said. "When you think of it, and we do all the time, everything has turned around pretty nice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Giants center Lance Scott, stretching at practice on Friday, has moved from the waiver wire to a playoff run. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL 3-16
 
Pacific Rim Leaders Meet In a Humbler Mood
Pacific Rim nations gathering in Canada do not have the swagger they showed at past meetings. Instead, President Clinton and most of his counterparts will be limping, wounded by global economic forces beyond their control and, in Mr. Clinton's case, undercut by domestic political defeats. On Friday, the financial turmoil that has been coursing through Asia claimed South Korea, the world's 11th-biggest economy. 1 

U.S. Opposes Russia on Iraq
President Clinton rejected Russia's call for an easing of sanctions on Iraq, saying Baghdad continued to impede United Nations weapons inspectors. The President said he remained wary about the willingness of Iraq to abide by the international arms monitoring regime. 1
 
In the end, the crisis with Iraq did not get resolved on the battlefield but in an unusual predawn meeting after an initiative brokered by an unlikely mediator, the Russian Foreign Minister, who is a longtime friend of the Iraqis but who has never been trusted by the United States. 8
 
Uphill Task in Bosnia
Western efforts to shift power from Radovan Karadzic, the powerful former Bosnian Serb president who has been indicted on war-crimes charges, to his rival and successor, Biljana Plavsic, turn on a parliamentary vote this weekend. But support for Ms. Plavsic is waning. 10
 
Back to Vietnam, to Heal
Pete Peterson, who spent six and a half years as a prisoner in North Vietnam, is now the United States Ambassador there, in what he hopes is an act of catharsis, both personally and symbolically. 6
 
NATIONAL 22-34
 
Reno's Loner Image Belies the Reality
The popular impression of Attorney General Janet Reno is that she is an individualist unfettered by the constraints of high office. But it fails to elucidate one of the most inscrutable, difficult and driven personalities in Washington because it does not distinguish her persona from her performance. 1
 
World of Embryo 'Adoption'
Kathy Butler, a 47-year-old New Jersey woman, is pregnant with triplets. But the babies are growing from ready-made embryos that she and her husband, Gary, selected and paid for at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. The Butlers are part of a quiet but fast-emerging new world of assisted reproduction in the United States. 1
 
A Brother's Regrets
David Kaczynski, who turned in his brother, Theodore J. Kaczynski, as the suspected Unabomber, said in an interview that he had been misled by investigators and prosecutors into believing that they saw his brother as a mentally ill man who would "be happier in jail." His brother's psychiatric condition has become the central issue at his trial on four of the string of mail bombings that began in 1978. 22
 
Texas Heroin Deaths
Plano is a modern Texas boom town, having grown from a population of under 4,000 in 1960, to 190,00. People move here to avoid urban schools and crime. But since January 1996, nine young people living or going to school in Plano, 20 miles north of Dallas, have died of heroin overdoses, and another did so at a party there. 30
 
NEW YORK/REGION 37-43
 
Language Barriers
As the population of the United States becomes ever more diverse and the languages spoken multiply, growing numbers of hospital patients who speak no English are being isolated by language barriers. And hospitals have begun searching to find ways to communicate with them. 1
 
Tactical Retreat
For civil rights advocates, the decision by black leaders to help settle a reverse discrimination suit against a school board in Piscataway, N.J. represented a tactical retreat to avoid a larger legal catastrophe. 37
 
Detective as Executive
As part of an investigation into mob ties to New York City's garbage-hauling industry, a police detective posed as the vice president in charge of running 55 Water Street, one of the largest privately owned buildings in the nation. He did such a good job that the owners hired him as the real vice president in charge of the building. 37

HEADLINE: Mean Streets

BYLINE: By Sara Mosle; Sara Mosle is an editor at The Times Book Review.

 BODY:

The Corner
 A Year in the Life
 of an Inner-City Neighborhood.
 By David Simon and Edward Burns.
 543 pp. New York:
 Broadway Books. $27.50. 
 Your average American is far more likely to spend a weekend in Paris, Moscow or even Beijing than two days or nights in one of America's slums. Consequently, discussion of America's urban underclass is typically so statistical, ideological or otherwise abstract as to amount to little more than an educated guess: how the other half probably lives. Being there, of course, is only the first, insufficient step to understanding a place, but even many writers on issues like welfare, race, poverty or drugs have spent scant time in the ghetto and some show no evidence of having been there at all. (Why do the hard work of reporting when everyone already knows what to think?) As A. J. Liebling once put it, "When information becomes unavailable, the expert comes into his own."
Just what the experts are missing is illustrated by "The Corner," a brave, unblinkered and heartbreaking look at the residents of a few blocks of West Baltimore's ghetto from the winter of 1992 to the fall of 1993. David Simon, the author of "Homicide: A Year on the Killing Streets," about Baltimore's Police Department, and Edward Burns, a former police detective who appears in "Homicide," don't just parachute into the neighborhood once every two or three months. Practicing what they modestly call "stand-around-and-watch journalism," they camped out on the corner of Monroe and Fayette almost every day for more than a year.
Their title pays homage to "Tally's Corner," Elliot Liebow's 1960's study of street-corner life, but a better comparison might be to "Rosa Lee," Leon Dash's book based on his Pulitzer-Prize-winning series for The Washington Post. (For four intense years, Dash trailed Rosa Lee Cunningham, a destitute, drug-addicted mother of eight in Washington.) "The Corner" isn't as good as "Rosa Lee," but it's still so far above most reporting on the underclass as to demand attention. In one sense, Simon and Burns's subjects remain uncooperative: their lives don't hew to liberal pieties, or conservatives' often pitilessly reductive arguments, about the poor. But in every other respect, the authors engender a trust that enables them to witness the kind of private moments -- a teen-age mother with her newborn, an addict injecting heroin, an officer roughing up a suspect -- that few outsiders see. Their intimacy is earned the way all intimacy is earned -- by the amount of time they devote to their subjects. "If we, as a society, are ever to come up with viable solutions to poverty," Dash wrote, "we must agree on what the facts are, regardless of our political viewpoints." Simon and Burns's achievement is to demonstrate again just how short of such facts we are.
There is a moment in "Homicide" where Simon acknowledges the almost inescapable perspective of his middle-class readers. The police have descended on a gutted West Baltimore row house, without electricity or running water, that is home to some two dozen glue sniffers, heroin addicts and prostitutes. Stacks of soiled diapers, discarded clothes, plates of weeks-old food and pans filled with urine litter almost every room of the roach-infested house. The stench is oppressive. The detectives' disdain for the residents has nothing to do with their poverty or potential criminality, Simon writes, but derives from an unspoken "standard," which says that "even in the worst American slum, there are recognizable depths beyond which no one should ever have to fall." Armed with such details and a tidy moral, most other reporters would have retired for the night. But Simon sticks around. After painstakingly searching the house, the police begin hauling suspects to the precinct. A child asks an officer if he can get something from his room before they go. It's well after midnight. "What is it you need?" a detective asks. "My homework," the kid replies. The cop is incredulous. But sure enough, the boy trundles upstairs and pulls a third-grade reader and workbook from the rubble. Suddenly, the moral is more complicated.
"The Corner," in essence, is the book-length version of such moments. Told from the point of view of the drug addicts and ordinary poor folk who populate West Baltimore, it explodes stereotypes of the ghetto poor and dispels some of the myths that even many of its residents hold dear. Tyreeka, 14 years old, gets pregnant not to obtain a government handout but in a desperate bid to keep a straying boyfriend. DeAndre, a young drug dealer, doesn't find fast-food work demeaning; it's part of a workaday world he scarcely comprehends. When he lands a job at Wendy's, he's so proud that he parades his new uniform in front of his mother and girlfriend. On the eve of quitting heroin, and the neighborhood, an addict named Mike waits to kill a dealer who's dissed him; the dealer doesn't show. Chance, as much as resolve, assures Mike's escape. Ella Fitzgerald, a saintly woman who runs the local community center, struggles to retain the double vision required of all corner residents: "DeAndre and R. C. and Tae are not drug dealers; they are her children . . . their possibilities still before them. And Smitty and Gale aren't beleaguered addicts; they're neighbors. And Ricky Cunningham," who volunteers at the center, "wasn't creeping past the high-rises, where he went to cop vials . . . he was a bystander caught up in someone else's evil."
The book's real protagonist, however, is the corner itself -- a menacing, malign presence that rules the neighborhood with ruthless logic. All its laws, the authors contend, derive from two axioms: "get the blast," or high, and "never say never." It is a code that allows for "a fiend's theft of the television set from the recreation center, of chalices from the corner churches, of the rent from his mother's bedroom." Addiction's toll on the neighborhood is often startlingly concrete. The United Iron and Metal Works, a local company, essentially underwrites the dismantling of the neighborhood by paying cash, no questions asked, for scrap metal -- copper piping, aluminum roofing, rain spouts, steel boilerplates, refrigerators, even cars -- most of it pried or stolen from the surrounding blocks. And like an abusive spouse, the corner isolates its victims. Several residents express their belief that if they stray even a few blocks from the corner, they will be lynched by the Klan. Few, however, have much direct interaction with whites; their fear is at least in part a product of their extraordinary remove from mainstream American life.
Although the drug trade drives the community's economy, most of the people who live here, of course, are not addicts. And at the heart of the book is three generations of the McCullough family: William and Roberta, a working-class couple, married some 50 years, who have lived near the corner all their lives; their 15 children, many of whom have escaped to middle-class suburban lives, and one of them in particular, Gary, a heroin addict who lives in the neighborhood's abandoned row houses; and DeAndre, Gary's son, a once promising student who, at 15, is a penny ante drug dealer and all but a junior-high dropout. By every conservative or liberal light, Gary should have lived the American dream. Raised in a loving family, he held two union jobs, managed a lucrative investment portfolio, owned a Mercedes and his own home. But "the corner," the authors write, "best serves the hard core." Gary slips, almost inexorably, into heroin addiction. (He dies of an overdose in 1996.) Still, his humanity remains intact: he reads Thoreau, takes time out to see "Schindler's List," which he finds deeply affecting, and even secures occasional employment -- working so hard at the local crab house that he's regarded as the "John Henry" of crabs. But it was Gary, the authors observe, who taught his family "to fear their neighborhood the way it ought to be feared." Many people assume that we understand the ghetto's problems, if not always the solutions to them, when the opposite is as often true. The McCullough children who escape do so, in large part, through well-worn paths: the public schools, community colleges, the civil service, affirmative action, the Army. The reasons for Gary's fall, however, remain stubbornly elusive.
Despite the obvious virtues of "The Corner," it remains, finally, a deeply frustrating work. The authors have a fine ear for dialogue, but the book is much too long, mired in detail and filled with policy analysis delivered in a cursing street patois that seems wrongheaded where it's not embarrassing. Still, Simon and Burns display an almost religious regard for individual human lives; it is a respect backed up not by cheap sentiment or easy moralizing but by the dangerous, backbreaking labor of intrepid reporting. They do not always condone their subjects' choices; sympathy is not the same as support. But they prove, as Auden once wrote, "that the first criterion of success in any human activity, the necessary preliminary, whether to scientific discovery or to artistic vision, is intensity of attention or, less pompously, love."

A review on Nov. 23 about "The Corner: A Year in the Life of an Inner-City Neighborhood," by David Simon and Edward Burns, misstated the name of the woman who runs a community center in the Baltimore neighborhood where the authors did their research. She is Ella Thompson.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 2; Editorial Desk
