HEADLINE: Trade Deficits Won't Ruin Us

BYLINE: By Laura D'Andrea Tyson; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a professor of economics and business at the University of California at Berkeley, was chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council in the first Clinton Administration.

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
There is widespread agreement that the American economy has been performing far better than expected in the last year. Growth has been stronger than predicted, inflation has been weaker, and the unemployment rate has hit lows that most economists doubted they would ever see again. Moreover, popular measures of the economy's performance -- for example, the growth of gross domestic product and changes in the consumer price index -- almost certainly understate just how well the economy has done.
But one popular and politically charged economic indicator is getting worse: the nation's trade imbalance. The September trade deficit in goods and service jumped to $11.1 billion, its highest reading since January. Based on results so far, the 1997 deficit will reach an all-time high, and China is poised to emerge as our No. 1 trade headache. 
 This growing trade imbalance has become a rallying cry for a diverse collection of opponents of globalization, a group drawn from the labor, environmental, human rights and religious organizations. And concern over the trade deficit has produced a disturbing paradox: even as our economy enjoys its soundest expansion in 30 years, political support for trade liberalization has ebbed to a dangerous low, as reflected in Congress's recent failure to pass "fast track" negotiating authority for the President. This trend threatens our leadership of the global economic system.
Before we embark on a self-defeating path of isolationism in a vain attempt to reduce the imbalance, we should at least recognize its many flaws as a gauge of economic health.
First, the absolute size of the trade deficit measured in dollars is irrelevant. A preferable measure is the size of the deficit compared with the overall size of the economy.
Measured in dollars, the 1997 trade deficit promises to be the largest in the nation's history, but that is also true for all of the other aggregate measures of the economy -- gross domestic product, consumption, profits, investment and labor incomes. The American economy is simply getting bigger over time -- isn't that supposed to be good news? -- and relative to the size of the economy, the trade deficit has actually declined sharply from its 1987 peak. In 1997, it stands at just less than 1 percent of gross domestic product, hardly a sign of economic duress, whether the barometer is our own economic history or that of other trading nations.
Second, in a world in which modern technologies are breaking down national borders, the trade deficit, which purports to tally exchanges between independent nation states, is an increasingly archaic concept. What is the significance of the United States trade deficit when nearly 40 percent of American imports represent intra-company transactions by American multinational corporations?
If the health of the American economy is tied to the health of its multinational producers -- if, in fact, "they are us" to a significant extent, as their large shares of the nation's capital stock, exports, sales and employment suggest -- then their imports should not be interpreted as a sign of our weakness.
The globalization of production has also blurred the meaning of our trade deficits with individual trading partners. Sure, our trade deficit with China has skyrocketed in recent years, but this trend has been largely offset by a decrease in our trade deficits with Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan. We're continuing to import labor-intensive products like toys, shoes and apparel from Asia, but the same multinational companies that once produced in the Asian tiger nations have moved their factories to China in search of lower labor costs.
If we blocked imports of such goods from China to reduce our bilateral trade imbalance there, production would not move back to the United States. The companies involved would seek low-cost locations elsewhere in the world.
And, lest we be tempted to do something foolish to contain our trade deficit with China, we should also recognize that our official numbers overstate the actual amount by as much as 25 percent because we can't -- or don't -- adequately distinguish between our trade with Hong Kong and our trade with China that is routed through Hong Kong.
Third, the composition of trade matters to the nation's prosperity. Our living standards depend on our ability to compete in high-wage, high-productivity industries, and the trade deficit masks our strengthening position in them.
The trade gap may be substantially larger today than it was during the 1980's, but so are our net exports of high-technology and capital goods. We may be importing more of our tomatoes from Mexico and our toys from China, at the expense of low-wage jobs, but we are also exporting more automobiles and jet aircraft, to the benefit of high-wage jobs.
Finally -- and most important -- there is no simple link between a nation's net trade position and its overall economic health. During the last four years, the United States has run a trade deficit of about 1.4 percent of its domestic product, while Japan has run a trade surplus of about 2.8 percent of its domestic product. The United States has been enjoying its strongest expansion in 30 years, while Japan has been suffering from the lingering effects of its deepest recession since the end of World War II.
Economic strength in the United States has been reflected in both the enhanced competitiveness of American exports and stronger import demand, while economic stagnation in Japan has had the opposite effects. There is no debate about which country has done better -- it is the one with the growing trade deficit.
Next year, our trade deficit with Japan and the rest of Asia will balloon -- not because of American economic weakness but because of painful slowdowns and currency devaluations in Asia triggered by recent convulsions in financial markets. That will mean slower growth for American exports and an increase in our imports as prices of Asian products fall. That is why it is in the interest of the United States to support International Monetary Fund programs to get the Asian economies back on track.
All this does not mean that there are no real trade challenges confronting the United States. Ninety-five percent of the world's consumers live outside our borders, many of them in countries with government and business practices that impede American companies from competing for their sales. The playing field of the global marketplace is not level -- access to the American market is far more open than access to almost any other market in the world.
Our major trade challenge is to break down barriers to international trade, and that requires tough, often prolonged negotiations. Unfortunately, the ability of the United States to conduct such negotiations has been curtailed by Congress's failure to grant fast-track authority to President Clinton.
As Emily Dickinson noted more than 100 years ago, sometimes belief without evidence is dangerous: "Faith is a fine invention for gentlemen who see, but microscopes are prudent in an emergency." We must interpret the trade deficit with the help of a powerful analytic microscope, or we will undermine our economy's health by misguided isolationism.

HEADLINE: A Wedding Of Theater And Social Issues

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Anna Deavere Smith, the playwright and performer who invented her own form of theater and has used it to explore matters like race and class, will head a new summer institute at Harvard University devoted to finding ways in which the arts might enhance the public discussion of social issues.
The institute, to be announced by Harvard today and to be financed initially by a $1.5 million Ford Foundation grant, is intended to serve as a kind of laboratory where professional artists in theater, dance, film and other fields will come together for six weeks each summer to develop new work. 
 Organized with the help of Henry Louis Gates Jr., the scholar and critic, the institute will also bring in academics, journalists and community leaders, not only to serve as sources of information and ideas but also to help investigate ways of engaging the interest of a broad and diverse audience. As many as four "master artists," with 40 "collaborating artists," are expected to spend their days working independently, then to meet over dinner for seminars and workshops with professors, civic leaders and others.
The institute is likely to resemble a hybrid between an artists' colony and a think tank, with some of the attributes of places like the MacDowell Colony in New Hampshire or the Eugene O'Neill Center in Connecticut. But its mission will be to encourage artists and work that might take the lead in initiating public discussion.
"In my own performances, I was always grateful to get a standing ovation," said Ms. Smith. "But what if instead they jumped to their feet and said, 'What can we do?' That's the beginning of a different kind of democracy. And that's what I would like the goal of this institute to be."
The undertaking comes at a time when many people believe that economic and political forces have conspired to trivialize or marginalize the arts, and that theater, in particular, no longer plays the role it once did in bringing people together to confront problems.
Ms. Smith said she hoped to increase the contact between artists and others, to make "the tower less ivory" and to create an atmosphere in which audiences approach art with the same readiness with which people approach a public discussion, feeling they have something to say.
"There has been a lot of talk about this kind of work," said Robert J. Orchard, managing director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., which will help administer the institute. "Can artists change society? What is the relationship of the artist to ideas? What are the responsibilities of institutions in connecting to different communities?
"All these are very important questions and a lot of good thinking and a reasonable amount of talk has gone into it. But this interests me, because we're going to be able to try it."
The idea for the institute arose out of a series of conversations initiated since 1992 by Ms. Smith, 47, who is also a professor at Stanford University. She has been trying, she said, "to use the ambiance and techniques of the theater to inspire discussion about the events of our time."
In her 1991 one-woman show, "Fires in the Mirror," she played 27 people she had interviewed about the racial violence between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, that year. In "Twilight: Los Angeles 1992," her 1994 production, she took a similar approach to the Los Angeles riots. Her current production, "House Arrest," investigating the American national identity as it has been embodied in the Presidency, opened on Thursday at the Arena Stage in Washington.
Ms. Smith's conversations over the last few years included officers of the Ford Foundation, which had underwritten the videotaping of "Fires in the Mirror" for public television; it had become interested in the idea of encouraging other artists to undertake similar work.
Last spring, while Ms. Smith was its first artist in residence, the foundation solicited proposals from institutions to set up an institute. They were looking for a forum where artists could work at using the arts to explore questions like identity, community and the relations among social groups. Harvard seemed to offer an excellent theater laboratory through its ties with the American Repertory Theater, links to the world of public policy through the John F. Kennedy School of Government "and an academic setting with a deep commitment to issues of race and gender," said Alison Bernstein, a vice president of the foundation.
Harvard also made the case that the Boston area would make a suitable setting, since it is large enough to have a complex array of urban communities and issues but small enough that any work developed at the institute and given public exposure might resonate deeply.
The three-year grant will be administered jointly by the theater, which operates out of the Harvard-owned Loeb Drama Center and offers theater courses, and by Harvard's W. E. B. DuBois Institute for Afro-American Research, of which Dr. Gates is the director. Ms. Smith called him "a perfect partner, because he's a master at creating conversations."
The financing plan for the new Institute on the Arts and Civic Dialogue will also include another $1 million that the theater and the institute intend to raise. The institute will begin accepting applications next month for the summer's projects, and plans to focus on theater, dance, music, film, video and fine arts.
Robert Brustein, the artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, described Ms. Smith as nonideological. "She doesn't impose her conclusions on the audience," he said. "That's what I think makes for great drama. What was it that Chekhov said? It's not my job to solve the problems, it's my job to present them correctly."

SECTION: Section D; Page 11; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Talking Stage

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Trying to reshape a dry monthly Government report on wholesale prices into an interesting radio news piece, David Brancaccio took a production crew into the gritty streets of Los Angeles.
With the roar of traffic as a backdrop, Mr. Brancaccio went no farther than a parking lot outside a windowless studio. He called out, as if to a passers-by, "Any sign of inflation over there?" 
 "No. Not a trace," a crew member answered.
"What about over there? Any sign of inflation?" Mr. Brancaccio repeated.
"Nope. Not here."
Undaunted, he tried again. "What about over there? Any inflation?" "Umm, maybe . . . Well, no," another answered.
Listeners have come to expect such snippets -- salted with dashes of creativity, mockery and detachment -- from "Marketplace," a half-hour business magazine that is one of public radio's fastest-growing programs. Now an independent production of the University of Southern California, the program was started by Public Radio International, the No. 2 distributor of public radio programs.
"Marketplace" is now as much a programming cornerstone to many of the nation's 1,200 public radio stations as the much better-known drive-time shows, "Morning Edition" and "All Things Considered," the flagship broadcasts of National Public Radio, the largest distributor of public radio programs.
The programming troika was singled out as the most responsible for bringing in listeners, donors and corporate underwriters to public radio in a recent study, which helps explain why the two programming rivals began merger talks last month. A decision is pending.
Fresh, innovative programs from Public Radio International -- like "Marketplace," Ira Glass's "This American Life" and the BBC co-production "The World" -- have sharpened the distinctions between the two competitors in recent years.
"We aren't locked into a couple of big news programs, which have sucked up a lot of resources," said Stephen Salyer, Public Radio International's president. "We worry that our audience will gradually gray if we don't push the boundaries."
Public Radio International, or PRI, began as American Public Radio in 1981 and was known as the "prairie network" for its first offering, Garrison Keillor's "A Prairie Home Companion." Its founding members were five public radio stations, led by Minnesota Public Radio, with ambitions to distribute their local shows nationally. Renamed in 1994, the distributor has grown with help from the federally financed Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
Public radio has doubled its audience over the last decade by successfully exploiting niches in news, foreign affairs and culture largely abandoned by commercial stations. It is a coveted audience, affluent and educated. At the same time but on the opposite end of the radio dial, commercial radio stations were consolidating into national broadcasting companies as ownership rules have been relaxed.
Public stations, too, have come under pressure to consolidate. They were threatened by a proposed cutoff in Federal money for public broadcasting by Congress in 1994. About 3 percent of National Public Radio's budget is from Federal funds; PRI's is 4 percent.
With that scare as a backdrop, the two rivals began considering a merger as a means to solve looming threats to their business. Besides financial constraints, technology is expected to affect radio listening as the Internet allows radio-on-demand, Mr. Salyer said. "The real competition may not be between NPR and PRI, but others," he said.
Delano Lewis, president of NPR, agreed. "It's where audio fits in a competitive world," he said. "I've got to figure out where I fit." He noted that NPR was discussing a possible deal to provide information for America Online Inc.
A merger would require a two-thirds majority vote of NPR's 600 member stations and approval by PRI's 10-member board. The potential benefits are still being explored and any vote is a long way off, Mr. Lewis said.
Robert Unmacht -- publisher of the M Street Journal, a broadcasting trade publication -- said that most stations would rather have the two programming distributors competing because it gives them more choice and generates price pressure.
Skeptics say a merger is unlikely because of the potential culture clash between PRI's entrepreneurism and NPR's centralization.
PRI has an $18.5 million budget and has 46 employees. Its 591 members pay fees for 400 hours of programming weekly, most of it created by local stations. The distributor pays the producer a licensing fee, based on the number of stations that carry the show, and solicits corporate underwriters, public radio's equivalent of advertising. Stations pay for programs based on the size of their market.
By comparison, NPR operates on a $63 million budget, has 580 employees and has 635 members. Its two self-produced trademark shows consume 40 percent of NPR's budget.
NPR's news programs attract 27 percent of public radio's listening audience, compared with PRI's 10 percent for all of its programming, said David Giovannoni, an audience researcher in Derwood, Md.; local programming accounts for the rest of the audiences. "Marketplace," carried by 215 stations and heard by three million people a week, draws 1 percent of the public radio audience but 4 percent of corporate underwriting money.
That gives "Marketplace" the highest underwriting income in public radio, based on cents per listener hour, he said.
In a commercial talk radio, on average six minutes of each half-hour are sold to advertisers. By comparison, "Marketplace" inserts the credits of its corporate sponsors, which support the show's production, within its 28.5 minutes of content, leaving 90 seconds for local sponsors. The show's content is so appealing to businesses that some stations, like KPBS-FM in San Diego, run the program three times a day. "The revenue we bring in at 3 and 6 more than covers the cost of the program. The 7:30 broadcast is free," said Bruce Bauer, development director of the station.
The $4 million "Marketplace" budget is one-third underwritten by corporate sponsors like the General Electric Company and the A. G. Edwards brokerage firm, said James B. Russell, the general manager of USC Radio/Marketplace Productions and the first executive producer of "All Things Considered." The rest is from station payments, foundations and in-kind services, he said.
"We like the audience," said James R. Harman, G.E.'s corporate advertising manager. "This subject attracts corporate decision-makers."
Mr. Brancaccio, the show's 36-year-old host, said "Marketplace" appealed to a younger audience by avoiding what he described as the "earnestness" of NPR and offering his own brand of cheeky storytelling and explanatory journalism.
The show's crew also produces short morning and hourly news updates. Texture comes from 11 bureaus and commentaries from traditional sources, like Robert B. Reich, the former Labor Secretary, and the less traditional, like welfare mothers.
Mr. Russell says "Marketplace" owes its success to being far from New York, the nation's traditional business center. That plan initially was scorned as "Business News from the Hot Tub." Now, Mr. Russell is proud of the sobriquet, while striving to give the program wit and substance. "In L.A., you're free to think a little bit differently," he said.
Mr. Brancaccio agreed. "The goal just isn't to make an audience of three million into four," he said. "It's to reflect ideas that aren't commercially driven."

Clinton Expects Asia To Overcome Crisis

 "I think this is a time for confidence in the future of Asia and confidence in the future of our relationship with them," Mr. Clinton said. "We have a few little glitches in the road here; we're working through them." Page A6.
 
Speculators See Bid for Hambrecht
Investors have stepped up their betting that Hambrecht & Quist, the leading investment bank for high-technology companies, will be taken over -- and sooner rather than later. The firm's shares soared 36 percent on heavy trading volume at the end of last week. Speculation has swirled around Hambrecht since its two leading competitors were taken over last summer. Market Place. D2.
 
Getting Ready to Rock the Internet
Signaling an intention to extend its blue-chip brand name into cyberspace, Wenner Media, the parent company of Rolling Stone magazine and other publications, plans to announce today that it will take an equity stake in JamTV, an Internet start-up, to create a music site on the World Wide Web. D4.

Public radio has doubled its audience in the last decade thanks in part to fresh, innovative shows like "Marketplace," which focuses on business. D11.

Modem Makers Have Poor Year
The modem industry introduced a technology in January that promised to double the speed of access to the Internet. But rival modem makers produced two incompatible formats. And, speaking of speed: As they say in Detroit, mileage may vary. The resulting consumer confusion and disappointment, analysts say, blunted modem sales this year. D4.

Congress has adjourned, but Capitol Hill's corridors on the World Wide Web are still humming with activity, as more lawmakers are posting sites to keep in touch. Taking In the Sites. D8.

Hate groups use World Wide Web sites to spread messages that would be illegal in some European countries, but there is little consensus on what should be done. D11.
 
A Brace of Thanksgiving Patents
Most turkeys consumed now are commercially produced. Several recent patents offer new ways to go about raising and slaughtering the birds. Patents. D2.

HEADLINE: Clinton Expresses Optimism on Asia's Economic Future as Pacific Rim Meeting Opens

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton used a gathering of Pacific Rim leaders here to reassure the world today that the current financial turmoil in Asia is temporary and that leaders were acting aggressively to stem it.
The President also said that the United States would exercise its economic muscle to promote sound economic policies in the region and to pry open global markets for a range of goods and services. 
 Mr. Clinton, appearing at a news conference with Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada, said that despite the sharp strains being suffered by a number of Asian countries, the overall economic future of the region remained promising.
"I think this is a time for confidence in the future of Asia and confidence in the future of our relationship with them," Mr. Clinton said. "We have a few little glitches in the road here; we're working through them."
Those "glitches" include South Korea's call last week for a huge loan from the International Monetary Fund to stem a spiraling financial crisis, as well as earlier bailouts for Thailand and Indonesia. Currencies in the region have plummeted and markets around the world have gyrated in recent weeks as investors worried that the Asian contagion might spread.
As if to signal that he felt that the Asian financial problems could be contained without a large-scale economic meltdown, Mr. Clinton spent the afternoon today playing golf with Mr. Chretien and Goh Chok Tong, the Prime Minister of Singapore.
In what is likely to be the most concrete outcome of the three-day economic conference of Pacific Rim nations, the President also hailed new, American-backed market-opening initiatives as evidence that Asian nations remain willing to work with the United States to liberalize trade.
Mr. Clinton passed up a chance to use the trade proposals -- potentially covering $1.5 trillion in trade in items from toys to medical devices -- to renew his call for new negotiating authority known as "fast track."
His aides said that Mr. Clinton cannot hope to achieve the tariff reductions outlined here unless Congress grants the President the new trade-negotiating authority that it withheld from him earlier this month. Fast-track authority would allow the President to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could approve or reject, but not amend.
But these aides said the potential deals outlined here would show recalcitrant Democrats in the House of Representatives how much the United States has to gain from pushing other nations to drop trade barriers.
The trade initiative is "the best possible argument to the United States Congress as to why we have to stay engaged," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman.
Trade ministers from the 18 members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or Apec, agreed late on Saturday to work to phase out tariffs on nine categories of products and services within two years, and to persuade the European Union and other major trading partners to go along as well.
The largest categories, from an American perspective, are chemicals, which accounted for $61.8 billion in exports from the United States last year; energy-related goods and services, which had exports of $51.6 billion; and medical equipment, which accounted for $20 billion in exports.
The ministers also agreed to work in coming years to reduce tariffs on other types of goods and services, although they did not immediately set a timetable for action. The categories include rubber, food, fertilizers, cars and civil aircraft.
American officials had been concerned that Asian nations would be unwilling to take steps to open their markets and expose their troubled economies to more competition.
But officials said that at a meeting of trade officials on Friday, representatives of Thailand made a strong plea to other Asian countries to agree to more free trade as a way of reassuring investors that they were committed to economic reform. That plea, they said, helped bring along nations that might otherwise have been reluctant to commit themselves to further trade deals.
Still, it remains unclear whether either the United States or the other nations here will be able to follow through and reach final agreements. In nearly all of the biggest product categories discussed here, the Administration would need fast-track authority to complete a deal, and despite the optimism expressed here by Administration officials, there is no assurance that the White House will have the votes it needs in Congress.
Moreover, some nations, including Japan, said they would not go along with the tariff reductions in all categories. And any further economic problems in the region could lead governments to postpone or reconsider their trade commitments.
In a matter unrelated to the conference's agenda, Mr. Chretien today again lobbied Mr. Clinton to join a global treaty banning anti-personnel land mines. Canada has been a leader in calling for the abolition of the weapons but the United States has resisted, saying it needs mines to protect its troops along the border between North and South Korea.
Mr. Clinton noted that the United States was rapidly destroying obsolete mines and those intended solely to kill people, rather than to slow the advance of tanks and artillery.
However, he said, "My first responsibility, since I may have to send our troops into conflict situations on behalf of a lot of the nations that have signed on to this treaty, is to make sure that if I do that I can protect them. Now, that is my position."
Mr. Chretien vowed goodnaturedly to "keep the pressure, gentle pressure, on the President."
Mr. Clinton said that while global warming is not on the list of formal Apec topics, he would take the occasion to offer reassurance to developing nations that the industrial world would not seek to cripple their growth by imposing harsh limits on emissions of greenhouse gases.

HEADLINE: Jorge Mas Canosa, 58, Dies; Exile Who Led Movement Against Castro

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Jorge Mas Canosa, who came to the United States as a penniless refugee from the dictatorship of Fidel Castro and built the Cuban-American National Foundation into one of Washington's most effective lobbying groups, died here this afternoon at home. He was 58.
Mr. Mas died of lung cancer, officials of the foundation said at a news conference this evening. But they also mentioned pleurisy and renal failure as causes of death and said he had also been suffering from Paget's disease, which causes the bones to degenerate. 
 From the moment he arrived in Miami in 1960, Mr. Mas dedicated himself to seeking the overthrow of Mr. Castro, first as a conspirator in various armed plots and then, for the last two decades, in the halls of Congress. His organization became a familiar presence on Capitol Hill and over the years earned a reputation as single-minded in purpose and generous in its donations to officeholders willing to endorse its objectives.
For more than a decade, three American Presidents have sought his advice on Cuban affairs to such an extent that many critics of Mr. Mas considered him the principal architect of an American policy they regarded as excessively rigid. Every significant piece of legislation on Cuba since 1980 has borne his imprint, from the establishment of Radio and TV Marti to last year's Helms-Burton Act tightening the economic embargo of Cuba.
At a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner in Miami in 1992, President George Bush declared, "I salute Jorge Mas." He called Mr. Mas the living embodiment of the success of Cuban immigrants in the United States. By then, Mr. Mas had already become a millionaire many times over in the communications and construction businesses.
To advance his cause, Mr. Mas also traveled extensively around the world, trying to form alliances with anyone he thought useful in the struggle against Mr. Castro. He was an early patron of Boris Yeltsin, energetically supported the Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi and encouraged Latin American leaders like Carlos Menem of Argentina to speak out against Mr. Castro.
But his many detractors in the United States and abroad saw in Mr. Mas the same dictatorial streak, relish for power and intolerance of opposing views that characterized Mr. Castro's rule. Over the airwaves of Spanish-language radio stations in Miami and in letters to the editor and public debates, Mr. Mas repeatedly questioned the patriotism of those who disagreed with him and threatened, in some cases, to ruin their lives or careers.
His death leaves a power vacuum among Cuban exile groups in Miami and will surely be greeted with relief, if not outright glee, in Havana, where the state-controlled news media for years have regularly reviled him as the main leader of "the counterrevolutionary Miami mafia." Mr. Mas had neither named nor groomed a successor and held the many fractious currents of the exile world together largely through force of personality and tenacity.
Foundation officials today named Alberto Hernandez, a physician who is the organization's vice chairman, as Mr. Mas's temporary successor. They said a permanent replacement would be elected at their group's congress next July.
Jorge Mas Canosa was born in Santiago, Cuba, on Sept. 21, 1939, the third of six children of a veterinarian in the Cuban Army. In some respects, his upbringing was much like that of his future enemy, Fidel Castro, who was 13 years older: Both had stern fathers, both were initially educated at private schools in Cuba's second-largest city, and both would later be remembered by their former classmates as fiery orators and aggressive, natural-born leaders.
During Mr. Castro's guerrilla struggle against the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista in the mid-1950's, Mr. Mas was sent by his father to the United States to study at a college in North Carolina. He returned home in January 1959, just days after Mr. Castro seized power, plunged into student politics, soon got in trouble with the new authorities and in mid-1960 returned to the United States, this time for good.
He quickly joined the exile force being trained by the Central Intelligence Agency for the Bay of Pigs invasion but ended up being put aboard a vessel that was kept offshore during that April 1961 debacle. A brief stint in the United States Army followed, ending with Mr. Mas leaving after it became clear the Kennedy Administration had no further plans to invade Cuba.
Back in Miami, Mr. Mas held a succession of blue-collar jobs, working as a milkman, stevedore and shoe salesman while devoting his free time to the anti-Castro movement. According to his associates of that time, he helped raise money, obtain weapons and scout possible sites in the Caribbean and Central America from which Cuba could be attacked or invaded.
By 1971, Mr. Mas had, with the aid of a $50,000 loan and recommendations from fellow exiles, acquired a small company, Iglesias y Torres, that did work for the telephone company in Puerto Rico. He renamed the business Church & Tower and within a year had won contracts to lay cable and install telephone poles for Southern Bell in Florida.
Over the years, Church & Tower became the foundation of a telecommunications empire that transformed Mr. Mas into one of the wealthiest Hispanic businessmen in the United States, with a net worth of more than $100 million at the time of his death. The family business, now called Mastec, today has interests in the United States and in telephone companies and other ventures throughout Latin America and in Spain.
But even as he was building his fortune, Mr. Mas remained active in exile politics in Miami. He abandoned his advocacy of armed struggle, arguing that ill-organized invasions of Cuba and acts of violence in the United States damaged the cause more than they helped, and he urged exiles to shift their attention to Washington and focus their efforts on using American foreign policy to cripple Mr. Castro.
After Ronald Reagan was elected in 1980, Mr. Mas became an American citizen and, at the suggestion of the new President's staff, founded the Cuban-American National Foundation. The organization, which today has 50,000 members, soon made its influence felt in Washington, funneling generous campaign donations to Republicans and Democrats alike and pushing for one bill after another to intensify the diplomatic and economic isolation of Cuba.
One of Mr. Mas's early triumphs was the establishment of Radio Marti, an American Government station intended to provide an alternative source of news for Cuba's 11 million people. By the end of the 1980's, that service had expanded into television, and Mr. Mas had been named chairman of the advisory board of the Office of Cuba Broadcasting, which oversees both stations.
Mr. Mas's critics, as well as several former Radio and TV Marti employees who had clashed with him, maintained he used the broadcasts to advance what they described as his ambitions to succeed Mr. Castro as president of Cuba. But each year Congress brushed off those criticisms, and to date has spent more than $250 million on programming for the stations.
In 1992, Mr. Mas was instrumental in passing legislation that tightened the economic embargo against Cuba in all areas except telephone communications. That triumph was followed four years later by the Helms-Burton Act, which embroiled the Clinton Administration in a complicated dispute with some of its closest allies and trading partners by allowing Cuban-Americans to sue foreign companies investing in or using expropriated properties in Cuba.
All the while, Mr. Mas's influence in Miami and Dade County politics was also growing. He and other leaders of the foundation gave generously to candidates for municipal and county office.
Mr. Mas also became known for personal feuds and lawsuits that were numerous and colorful. In one celebrated instance, he challenged Joe Carollo, who just last week lost his re-election bid as Mayor of Miami, to a duel, saying, "Your bullying has ended because you have encountered a man with a capital M."
Given a choice of guns or swords, Mr. Carollo defused the situation by suggesting water pistols be used. But he continued to criticize Mr. Mas and the Foundation, once calling them "a little clique of millionaires who have made a very profitable business of combating Communism."
In another instance, Mr. Mas lost a libel suit brought by an estranged younger brother, who testified that Church & Tower had won several of its contracts by dispensing bribes. But perhaps his longest-running dispute was with The Miami Herald, which he accused of harboring Cuban spies on its reporting staff and of encouraging "hate, disinformation and reckless disregard" of the Cuban exile community.
That feud reached a peak in 1992 when Mr. Mas and his supporters paid for advertisements on city buses that proclaimed, "I don't believe The Miami Herald" and organized a boycott of the newspaper that lasted for several months. At the peak of the dispute, some of the newspaper's vending machines were filled with excrement, and death threats were made to some of its employees, actions that Mr. Mas disavowed.
The apogee of his influence probably came in the summer of 1994, when President Clinton invited Mr. Mas to the White House to discuss how to stem the flow of refugees then coming across the Florida Straits in rafts and adopted several of his recommendations. Mr. Mas continued his efforts into the Clinton Administration's second term, but the pace of his activities slowed as his health gradually worsened.
Mr. Mas is survived by his wife, Irma, and three sons, Jorge Jr., who has for several years run the family business, Juan Carlos, a lawyer, and Jose Ramon.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 678 words

HEADLINE: Cuban-Americans Promise to Carry On Leader's Efforts

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Jorge Mas Canosa, the Cuban-American businessman and political stalwart who died today, was mourned as an irreplaceable figure in the fight for the democratization of Cuba, but officials of his Cuban-American National Foundation vowed to double their efforts to accomplish his goals.
"For those concerned about the future of the Cuban-American National Foundation, don't be concerned," a teary-eyed Francisco J. Hernandez, the foundation's president, said at a news conference. "This institution counts on men and women who were close to Jorge Mas Canosa from the beginning and were nurtured by his thoughts and his bravery," he said. 
 But the death of Mr. Mas is a significant blow to the hard-line majority in the exile leadership, in no small part because it is a strong reminder that Fidel Castro is still in power in Cuba after 38 years, outliving many of his opponents.
Mr. Mas, in fact, was among the youngest in the old guard of conservative anti-Castro leaders, and certainly much younger than Mr. Castro, 71, and his brother Raul, 66, the revolutionary leader's anointed successor.
The death of Mr. Mas, who assembled a political and economic empire in exile, also leaves Cuba without a favorite target of blame for the island's difficulties. Most recently, the Government in Havana had blamed Mr. Mas's Cuban-American National Foundation for a string of bomb explosions in Havana's hotels and other tourist spots.
Foundation leaders said that Alberto Hernandez, the vice chairman and a member of the organization for 15 years, would take over the chairmanship until elections take place in July.
Allies in the Cuban exile cause, like Senator Robert Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, predicted a difficult transition but said that Mr. Mas had left a more united, organized and powerful exile community than when the foundation was formed in 1981, including like-minded Cuban-Americans as members of Congress.
"If Fidel Castro takes some comfort in the passing of Jorge Mas Canosa, he's very mistaken," Senator Torricelli said. "At some point the movement for Cuban freedom became larger than the man and is now irreversible."
In a statement released by the White House tonight, President Clinton said: "Jorge was a born leader and organizer whose tenacity, strength of conviction and passion I greatly admired. He galvanized his community, his adopted country and people around the world for the cause of freedom and democracy in Cuba."
Although Mr. Mas's son, Jorge Mas Jr., 34, has taken over the family's telecommunications business, it is less clear who will succeed him in the political arena. Polls have shown that the elder Mr. Mas's public approval rating, particularly among older Cuban-Americans, was unparalleled, as was the combination of his vast economic resources with political power.
Max Castro, a sociologist with the University of Miami's North-South Center and a critic of Mr. Mas, said, "He was able to create an organization that was the only Cuban-American organization to insert itself into the structure of American political power."
"I have to recognize that he was effective," he continued. "The problem was how that power was exercised, and in my view the policies he pursued were not effective in bringing democracy to Cuba and aggravated the suffering of the Cuban people."
Experts on Cuban-American affairs say that Cuban-American elected officials like Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican member of Congress from Miami, are likely to increase their roles as spokesmen. Political moderates, too, may find an opening to assume greater influence in advocating a more conciliatory stance toward Cuba.
One of these moderate leaders, Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, founder of the exile group Cambio Cubano, or Cuban Change, today called Mr. Mas "a dynamic leader and organizer of proven intelligence" that he would have liked to debate "in a politically civilized climate" he said Miami lacked. In a written statement, he called for Cubans to restore the tolerance "that would allow us to disagree without hate."

HEADLINE: The Mayor and the River

 BODY:
Historically, New York City has done a poor job of opening up its extensive waterfront to its citizens. So when an opportunity comes along to improve the city's marine environment, New York's political leaders are duty-bound to seize it.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is in danger of letting just such an opportunity slip away. It lies in a grand plan to rescue the tawdry Hudson River waterfront from 59th Street south to Battery Park from years of decay, and replace it with an inviting mix of walkways, open spaces, playing fields and enough commercial development to sustain the park in future years. 
 Gov. George Pataki, after some dithering, has endorsed the plan. His economic development czar, Charles Gargano, is on board. So are most environmental groups. But Mr. Giuliani has not taken a leadership role. His staff spends more time raising concerns about the plan than seeking solutions. His economic advisers are entertaining proposals for commercial development on land that was originally targeted for open space.
Part of the problem arises from the split ownership of the land. The city owns the northern end, between 35th and 59th Streets. The state controls the land south of 35th. Five years ago, the city and state pledged to contribute $100 million each, and later established an agency, the Hudson River Park Conservancy, to draw up a master plan, take title to both city and state property along the river and oversee the park's creation.
This agency is the main reason for the Mayor's foot-dragging. The conservancy is legally a subsidiary of Mr. Gargano's Empire State Development Corporation, and Mr. Giuliani -- who has long resented quasi-independent authorities that do not answer to City Hall -- simply does not want to turn over city land to a state agency he cannot control. The city and the state are equally represented on the conservancy board, an arrangement that gives Mr. Giuliani plenty of power. But he cannot get over the fact that the conservancy is technically Mr. Gargano's child.
There is an answer to this. A bill soon to be introduced in Albany would establish a truly independent agency with equal state and city membership to oversee the park's construction and operation. Mr. Pataki endorses this approach. Mr. Giuliani should too. If the city does not climb aboard this project, New Yorkers will wind up with half a park, or maybe no park at all.
That would be a a great loss. The alternative to the park is further decay and shapeless privatization. But if Mr. Giuliani can see his way clear to working with the Governor, he could be remembered as the Mayor who gave New York's most majestic river back to its people.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Backlash

BYLINE: By THOMAS FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
It is not yet clear how the Iraq crisis will end. But it's already clear what it has exposed -- the serious tensions just beneath the surface of the U.S.-Russia relationship. Last Friday night, I found myself in Moscow watching CNN report from the White House that some U.S. officials suspect that the Russians and Iraqis may have cooked up the whole Iraq crisis in order to help Baghdad escape from U.N. sanctions. Wow. That's a serious charge. We haven't heard that kind of conspiracy talk since Khrushchev was pounding his shoe at the U.N. But after meeting here with Russian officials and analysts I can report that such charges certainly reflect the prevailing mood of U.S.-Russian ties. The U.S.-Russia relationship has gone in the last seven years from a strategic partnership, to a pragmatic partnership, to a relationship of benign neglect, to a relationship heading for malign neglect. Is it time to break out the reruns of "Seven Days in May" and "From Russia With Love"?
Not yet, but several factors are combining to push Russo-American relations downhill. One is a global phenomenon: There is a growing backlash against America's overwhelming economic and military superiority. America's allies and enemies are increasingly united in resentment of the U.S. Do you know what Iran calls America today? Not "the Great Satan." Iran calls America "the Capital of Global Arrogance." Unfortunately, that's also what the French, the Malaysians, the Russians, the Chinese, the Japanese and the Germans call Washington behind its back. 
 Saddam Hussein is tapping into this undercurrent of resentment against the U.S. In the 1990 gulf war, Saddam played the Arab Robin Hood, stealing from the Arab rich, Kuwait, to give to the Arab poor. This time he's playing Luke Skywalker standing up to the American Evil Empire. Saddam's Foreign Minister regularly complains that the U.S. behaves as if it were "the last days of the Roman Empire." A Baghdad man in the street whom CNN interviewed just happened to refer to America as an "international Dracula that sucks the blood of people around the world." This sense that America wants to decide everything but pay for nothing resonates far and wide. Russian commentator Aleksei Pushkov said that "the attitude here now is that Russia should be a balancing force to correct situations where America gets infatuated with its own power."
It's not that France, Russia or Malaysia wants to confront America. They just want to irritate it -- even though they know they need America to deal with the world's bad guys, indeed because they need America. Every time Boris Yeltsin meets with the Chinese or Europeans he now warns about the dangers of "hegemonism." He doesn't mention the U.S. He doesn't need to.
At the same time, the termites have been eating away at the core U.S.-Russia relationship. Arnold Horelick, a Russia expert at the Carnegie Endowment, remarked that in America "Russia is viewed more and more as a problem and less and less as an opportunity" -- a problem because of its loose nukes, mafia crime and all-too-free market for arms buyers. The growing attitude in Washington is that Russia's elites are not entirely competent to manage their own affairs.
From the Russians' side, there is still resentment at the way NATO expansion is being shoved down their throats -- a brain-dead Clinton move that has put the most pro-American Russians on the defensive. And there is deep concern about America's growing economic and political influence in the oil-rich former Soviet republics on Russia's southern frontier. There is a feeling, says the Russian strategist Sergei Rogov, that "Russia is being eased out of areas of the globe where we have our vital interests."
Yes, there still are cushions. Mr. Yeltsin still believes in the U.S.-Russia relationship and still delivers in the crunch. And there is now a web of economic ties between Russia and America, which is the largest foreign investor in Russia. Still, if the relationship doesn't become more positive soon, it will become more negative, and as Russia recovers its strength, it will become more difficult.
Now is precisely the time when the U.S. should be taking advantage of Boris Yeltsin's continued leadership to set a new course in the relationship. It's not too late, but it will be soon, or, as Mr. Horelick put it: "Just letting the forces of inertia run free will lead us toward mutual alienation -- if not something much worse."

HEADLINE: U.S. Pushes Israel for 'Credible' Withdrawal Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton and his Administration are turning up the heat on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to produce substantial progress with the Palestinians in talks in December, senior American officials said today.
The officials, speaking at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum here, said Mr. Clinton's refusal to see Mr. Netanyahu in Washington last week, his welcome of former Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's recent meeting with Mr. Netanyahu in London were all designed to increase the pressure on the Israeli Government. 
 The move comes at a time when the crisis over Iraq has demonstrated weakened support for the United States in the Arab world.
The United States wants Israel to announce a "serious and credible" withdrawal of troops from the West Bank, originally scheduled for September under existing peace accords with the Palestinians.
The officials denied threatening Mr. Netanyahu, saying that the American relationship with him and the Israeli Government "does not involve the invocation of threats.
"Threat is not the way we do business with Netanyahu, as a rule," a senior official said carefully, implying that the usual rules may be broken, in time.
"It is clear that the President is increasingly frustrated and impatient," another senior official said.
Ms. Albright, said another senior official, "does not threaten Mr. Netanyahu."
But the official added, "She has made it clear to him that she will 'tell it like it is' on the Middle East, and she will continue to do so, and she has definitely made it clear to the Israelis that the past 11 months have not been productive, and that we need to do some serious work in December."
The officials denied an Israeli press report that Ms. Albright had warned Mr. Netanyahu in London that without rapid progress, she would announce an "American position" on what an Israeli troop withdrawal ought to be. They also denied Israeli press reports that she specified to Mr. Netanyahu a percentage of West Bank territory that the United States wanted to see turned over to the Palestinian Authority in this second of three withdrawals called for under the Oslo accords and last January's Hebron agreement. Mr. Netanyahu postponed the second withdrawal for security reasons after the last suicide bombings.
"We want to see rapid progress on the troop withdrawal and other issues," one official said. "As to an appropriate percentage, we've only made clear it has to be serious and credible." But the officials did not rule out publicizing an American position.
The first Israeli withdrawal, after Hebron, involved 2.7 percent of the occupied territories, a percentage that the Palestinians criticized as ridiculous and that some American officials also thought was too small. Mr. Netanyahu is said to be examining a second withdrawal of 3 to 5 percent, which the United States would not regard as "serious and credible."
Last Friday, in Washington, President Clinton warned Israelis and Palestinians that "the window of progress will become smaller with time" as he accepted a peace award at the White House from Leah Rabin, the widow of the the slain Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and from Mr. Rabin's peace partner and successor, Mr. Peres. Mr. Clinton warned of the growing frustration of "ordinary people, both Israelis and Palestinians."
The Israeli press today carried accounts that claim to describe Mr. Clinton's private conversations at the award ceremony luncheon expressing his own frustration with Mr. Netanyahu. According to Yediot Ahronot, Mr. Clinton said: "Netanyahu has made all sorts of promises to me and hasn't lived up to them," including a promise for a timeout on expanding Jewish settlements in the West Bank, "but it hasn't happened." Mr. Clinton is then reported to have asked: "So how can I believe him?"
A senior White House official denied today that Mr. Clinton uttered those words, and said, "That doesn't sound right." But it is also true, an official said, that the Iraqi crisis has pointed up to Mr. Clinton the erosion in Arab support for American positions, resulting from stagnant peace efforts and the perception that Mr. Clinton will not pressure Mr. Netanyahu to keep his promises.
In London on Nov. 14, at a joint news conference with Mr. Netanyahu, Ms. Albright made the link explicitly, saying, "I made clear that for the sake of the Middle East peace process and for our broader mutual interests in the region, it is time for us to move on the peace process."
With America's moderate Arab allies distancing themselves from Washington at a time of crisis in Iraq, she called for "a greater sense of urgency" on the part of Israelis and Palestinians.
A senior American official said today: "Although we recognize no justified link between Iraq and the peace process, the reality is that it does make it harder to sustain Arab support for our positions in other areas, including the need to confront Iraq on weapons of mass destruction."
The Israeli Ambassador to the United Nations, Dore Gold, interviewed by telephone from New York, rejected the link, saying, "The notion that there is a connection between the peace process and the ability to form an anti-Iraq coalition is baseless."
In October 1994, he said, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq "massed Iraqi armor in southern Iraq and not a single Arab coalition partner, with the exception of Kuwait, was willing to back American action. And this was at a time when the Oslo peace process was racing ahead and Israel was signing new agreements with Jordan."
But a senior American official disputed Mr. Gold's version of history, saying, "We deployed forces to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia during that crisis, which we didn't do now, and there is not the kind of Arab criticism of our actions then as there is now."
History aside, the disagreement points to the increasingly public nature of the relationship between Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Clinton, who has in general kept his criticism quiet or has tried to attribute it to both Palestinians and Israelis.
Other Israeli officials confirmed that Mr. Netanyahu is feeling more pressure now from Mr. Clinton.
They say that the Hebron accords in January -- both a public "note for the record" and a private side letter at that time to Mr. Netanyahu from Warren Christopher, who was then Secretary of State -- explicitly link further Israeli withdrawals from the West Bank to the Palestinian commitment to "combat systematically and effectively, terrorist organizations and infrastructure."

Top Aid Quits After Likud Revolt
JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 (Agence France-Presse) -- Prime Minister Netanyahu today accepted the resignation of his chief of staff, Avigdor Lieberman, who quit apparently in an effort to defuse a revolt by top members of the ruling Likud party.
Many analysts viewed the resignation as a significant concession by Mr. Netanyahu, who has in the past dealt with threats to his position by brazenly attacking his opponents. "I express great sorrow over this resignation of a good, trustworthy friend who stood by me for many years," Mr. Netanyahu said.
Several ministers had demanded Mr. Lieberman's dismissal after a Likud party meeting earlier this month when he was accused of waging a campaign to strengthen Mr. Netanyahu's position at the expense of potential rivals.

HEADLINE: Ex-Official Now Looks To Church For Solace

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Nov. 23

 BODY:
This morning, the former Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary walked to the front of her mother's Presbyterian church in nearby Newport News, which she described as "a groovy place," and came to God.
"I'm very old and I just joined church today," said Mrs. O'Leary, who is 60, her eyes filling with tears when she talked about it. "I hopped out of my seat and went down and thought, 'Maybe this is what the last two years has been about.' " 
 That is two years of scandals, most recently accusations that she solicited a $25,000 donation for her favorite charity, Africare, in exchange for an agreement to meet with some Chinese clients of Johnny Chung, the lobbyist and prolific political donor. Attorney General Janet Reno is expected to announce a decision as early as Monday on whether to appoint an independent prosecutor in the case.
Mrs. O'Leary is not, however, confessing and asking for forgiveness, because she feels she has done nothing wrong. "When I look at the phenomenon of guys born again in Washington -- what's the toe-sucker's name? -- yeah, Dick Morris, he followed the recipe," she said, referring to President Clinton's fallen political adviser. "He sinned and was saved, but I haven't. I don't regret a moment of it. I regret the pain it caused my mother. She asked me, 'Are you going to jail?' And she said, 'I thought it was over.' "
It is not quite over, with uncertain signals from the Justice Department about the likelihood of a special prosecutor in the case. All Mrs. O'Leary, now an energy consultant, will say about the accusations is: "I know I didn't -- No, I can't talk about it. My high-priced lawyer would kill me."
Stylish and striking, she is full of fun today, telling stories with great relish and a theatrical sense of timing. But she is a sad figure, too, a woman known in her field as easily the best prepared energy secretary in the brief, 18-year history of the department, who nonetheless wound up the butt of jokes.
She played a significant role in paving the way for a nuclear test ban, but got more attention for the controversy surrounding her $4.5 million in foreign trips. She was widely praised as the first energy secretary to acknowledge cold war radiation experiments using Americans as guinea pigs, but also got a public spanking from the White House after news that her department had spent $43,500 of money to figure out which reporters were writing favorable articles.
She stood up for whistle-blowers at nuclear plants, announcing a policy of "zero tolerance" for retaliation against them and personally taking the perceived troublemakers under her wing. But she stood out for excesses like taking an entourage of 76 to India and leasing a plane that had also been used by Madonna. She won the Cavallo Foundation's award for moral courage and ethical resistance, but lost the public relations war, and came off looking like someone who was in charge of making nuclear weapons but could not be trusted with a gold card.
Almost a year after leaving office, when asked if there was anything she would have done differently, Mrs. O'Leary answered, "It doesn't matter, does it?" Forthright and flamboyant, she favors hot pink over gray and talks like a refugee from Esalen, using expressions like, "I own that," for "I'm responsible." Conservative Washington winced, and many observers saw racism and sexism in the way she was treated.
"She's an African-American woman, and every African-American woman in the Clinton Administration got a lot of heat," said Tom Carpenter, a lawyer with the Government Accountability Project who represents workers at bomb plants and has criticized Mrs. O'Leary on safety and cleanup. "This Congress goes after anyone they see as an uppity woman. I looked pretty carefully at the travel brouhaha and thought it was a tempest in a teapot. Some trips were bloated and probably unwise, but as scandals go it just doesn't rate."
Former aides say she was routinely undercut by her own staff as she struggled to change the internal culture of a traditionally super-secret department and got only feeble support from the White House.
"Except for Clinton and Gore, the White House staff didn't like her," in part because she refused to hire some of those they had recommended, said Bob Hanfling, an old friend who served as her first chief of staff. "The Republicans on the Hill sensed she was vulnerable."
There were also times, even those close to her acknowledge, when Mrs. O'Leary seemed her own worst enemy. The results are on display on the "O'Leary World Tour" web page, posted by the Congressional Republicans who investigated her travel expenses. It features the "O'Leary World Tour Quiz," gives a list of the five-star hotels she patronized, from the Hotel Meurice in Paris to the Taj Mahal Hotel in Bombay, and a rundown of the staff she took along, under the heading, "How many staff does it take to make an entourage?"
One of her chief critics, Representative Joe L. Barton, a Texas Republican, sums up the rap against her this way: "She was good at the press conference but not good at the details. We never had reason to suspect she was personally corrupt, but it was more management ineptitude than anything."
Even her friends suggest there is at least some truth in the criticism that she is pretty handy with a checkbook.
"Africare isn't even her favorite charity,' Mr. Hanfling said. So what is? "Probably Saks Fifth Avenue," he said, and laughed. "Kidding, I'm kidding. But she is not averse to contributing to the economy."
She says that it is ridiculous (actually, she used a little spicier word than that) that she was blamed for the blunders of the junior staff who plan trips.
"A lot of my friends say I should have done a better job of schmoozing the Hill, and people say I should be less arrogant," Mrs. O'Leary said. "This behavior in a man would not be called arrogant. I've just been at this too long to be uncertain."
Mrs. O'Leary was born in Newport News, the daughter of two doctors, and was largely raised by her stepmother, a former teacher. Because Virginia schools were then still segregated, she was sent north to live with an aunt and graduated from the High School of Fine and Performing Arts in Newark. There she sang, did poetry readings, and knew Connie Francis, she said, bursting into a few bars of "Where the Boys Are." She went on to Fisk College in Nashville and soon married, "because I was so tall I just kept catching the bouquet."
She had a son, Carl, now a Washington lawyer, and when he was still a toddler, she was in the grocery store one day when she saw a clock on the wall, saw it was 2 P.M. and shrieked, "Ohmigod, it's time for young Dr. Malone!" She rushed home to her soap, then realized she badly needed another outlet and called Rutgers Law School, where she enrolled the next fall. She went on to become a prosecutor in Essex County, handling some organized crime cases. Much later, after a brief, second marriage to the news anchor Max Robinson, she met her third husband, Jack O'Leary, at the Department of Energy, where they both worked in the early 1980's.
When he died of cancer, she moved to Minnesota and worked as a utilities company executive until Mr. Clinton invited her back to Washington as his Energy Secretary. Quite soon after taking the job, she startled everyone by refusing to sign off on a decision to continue nuclear testing.
"I looked down the table at all these guys, these white guys, some of them in uniform, and said, 'What the hell is wrong with zero testing?' "
"I made many enemies in the process" of pushing for a test ban, she went on, "and I'm O.K. with that. I'm at peace now. I'm really O.K."

HEADLINE: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Poor Without Cars Find Trek to Work Is Now a Job" (front page, Nov. 18) calls attention to a critical problem. While the New York City region's poor rely heavily on mass transit to commute to work, the most rapid job growth is occurring in areas that are only accessible by automobile. In grappling for answers, we must not lose sight of our most powerful asset. Unlike other metropolitan areas, the region's extensive mass transit system gives most low-income residents access to many thriving downtowns in the area. 
 Enhancements to this network could bring thousands of additional jobs within reach of the poor at locations like Kennedy and Newark International Airports, the Roosevelt and Mitchell Fields retail complex in Nassau County and other suburban downtowns. Long-term, mass transit improvements are an essential component of strategies to create jobs in urban areas and accessible suburban centers.
 
CHRISTOPHER JONES
New York, Nov. 19, 1997
 
The writer is director, economic programs, Regional Plan Association.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%);

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 133 words

HEADLINE: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit;
Making Work Pay

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article on welfare reform in Oregon (front page, Nov. 20) points out that low unemployment, brisk job growth and decent entry-level wages are helping some Oregon welfare recipients make the transition to work. An important complement to these positive developments is Oregon's minimum-wage policy. Its minimum is now $5.50, 35 cents above the Federal level, and will rise to $6.50 by 1999. 
 Clearly, Oregonians have made the connection between a higher legislated wage floor and the goal of "making work pay" for low-wage workers. What's more, the state's strong labor market belies claims by minimum-wage opponents that increases lead to job losses.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
Washington, Nov. 20, 1997
 
The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Albany Cuts Effort to Urge Conservation

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 23

 BODY:
New York State, once a national leader in promoting energy conservation, has, with little public notice, cut its conservation effort to about one-fourth its former size, even though the program has been highly praised by environmentalists.
The conservation program, begun in the late 1980's, requires the seven regional power companies in the state to reimburse their customers for some of the cost of replacing light fixtures, electric motors and appliances with more energy-efficient models. Reducing the demand for electricity cuts down on air pollution by lowering the amount of fuel burned in power plants. 
 The amount the state has required the utilities to spend on the program has fallen to $73 million this year, from $280 million in 1993, and is set to drop more over the next few years. The utilities' expenses are ultimately borne by ratepayers, but the savings from conserving energy typically cover those costs in the long term.
The program's decline began toward the end of the Cuomo administration, which inaugurated the program, and has continued under Gov. George E. Pataki. It has coincided with the growth of similar programs in other states, so that New York, once a model that others followed, now ranks below the national average in energy efficiency spending, and far behind most other states in the Northeast.
The cuts have angered and perplexed conservation groups, which often view the Republican Governor as an ally. Democratic lawmakers say they see the administration's treatment of the program as a potential weak spot for the Republican Governor in a re-election campaign in 1998.
"This governor's record on energy efficiency has been a total failure," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
The Governor's office declined to discuss the matter, referring questions to the State Public Service Commission, the agency that governs utilities and sets the level of conservation spending. The commission's members are appointed by the Governor.
Rather than requiring energy efficiency spending, "The commission believes that the market should be allowed to develop innovative programs and cost-effective energy conservation measures," said David Flanagan, the commission's spokesman.
The commission is moving the state away from the traditional system giving utilities a monopoly on power distribution, and toward a competitive market in which customers can choose among competing electricity providers. When that happens, Mr. Flanagan said, some energy companies will try to attract customers by offering conservation services.
But there is not yet any electric competition in New York, and under the current plan, most consumers will not be able to choose their supplier until the year 2002. It is not clear how many customers would voluntarily pay more for their power to gain access to a conservation program.
Although the program is paid for by slightly higher bills for every electric user, consumer groups have not opposed it. The utilities generally have not been hostile to the program, either, as long as the state set high enough rates to guarantee their profits.
The only organized opposition to the efficiency program has come from a coalition of heavy industries, which has protested that high electric rates hinder economic development, and has urged the state to lower them by any means possible. Manufacturers use large amounts of power, and so stand to gain from even a small drop in the price of electricity. Also, they have generally not been able to take much advantage of the rebate program.
This year, the industrial coalition's lobbying helped defeat a bill on energy policy that would have increased the level of conservation spending. The bill passed the Democratic-controlled Assembly, but was stopped in the Republican-led Senate.
"This is an example of the schizophrenia on environmental matters in the Pataki administration," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat and chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee. "They're very good on some things, but when there's a corporate interest involved, they fold."
For power consumers in New York, whether home or business, 0.7 percent of the average monthly electric bill now goes toward the conservation program. In nearby states, the current average is 5.5 percent in Connecticut, 4 percent in Massachussets and 3.4 percent in Vermont, according to a recent study by the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.
The utilities and environmental groups estimate that the new equipment installed under the program saves more than 5 million megawatt/hours per year, or 3 percent of the electricity consumed statewide, about equivalent to the output of two medium-sized power plants. That translates to almost $500 million a year in savings on electric bills, far more than the amount spent on the rebates.
Reducing the demand for power is a cherished goal of environmentalists because power plants are a major source of air pollution and greenhouse gases. They produce two-thirds of the nation's sulfur dioxide emissions, one-third of the carbon dioxide and one-third of the nitrogen oxides.
At the peak of New York State's program, a power user, usually a business, that wanted to replace its fixtures with energy-efficient ones could apply to the local utility for a rebate that would, in many cases, cover the entire cost of the new equipment. Often, the customer would hire an energy consultant to determine what changes were needed, install the equipment and prove to the utility that the work had been done. The customer had to pay the consultant's fee and labor charges for installation, but often earned it back within a few years through lower electric bills.
"In a typical office building that's 20 to 30 years old, we could find cost-effective measures that would reduce energy usage 20 to 40 percent, and it's primarily because new, modern equipment is more efficient," said Dennis T. Wilson, president of Manhattan-based Enersave, the largest consultant on energy use in New York City.
Today, the utilities are obliged to pay only a fraction of equipment costs, 20 percent in Consolidated Edison's case. With the smaller rebate, it takes customers longer to recover their expenses, so the program is less attractive to them. Also, the pool of money for rebates has grown so small that applicants are often turned away.
"Our business has been cut almost in half, which gives you some idea of what's going on," Mr. Wilson said.
Most users of the program have been office-based businesses, whose energy use consists mostly of lighting and climate control, which can often be made more efficient at relatively little cost. The program has been available, on a more limited basis, to homeowners, as well, but they have used it less often. Residents rarely shop for new appliances if the old ones, no matter how inefficient, are still working, and the out-of-pocket cost for new equipment and installation is often more daunting to an average person than to a business.
For factories, the program has had less to offer than for office buildings. The rebate program applies only to common uses, like better lighting and electric motors, not the more complex, often highly specialized machinery that accounts for much of a factory's power use.
In moving toward competition, the commission is making some changes in the conservation program that environmentalists welcome: the effort will be run by the state, not the utilities, and reimbursements will be based on the amount of energy saved, not the amount of money spent.
But as part of the industry restructuring, the commission is continuing to cut the program. Con Edison's spending on conservation, already down to $48 million this year, from $125 million in 1993, will drop to $30 million a year during the five-year transition to competition, and similar cuts are in the works for the other regional power companies.
